DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles lagged behind other big cities in federal narcotics charges when Robert Bonner, now President Bush's choice to head the Drug Enforcement Administration, was U.S. attorney there, court records show. Although the city regularly was near the top in the nation in federal drug arrests, it ranked far lower in the percentage of federal defendants charged with drug offenses during Bonner's tenure. Throughout the period, the most common federal criminal charges in the nation were drug-related, but in Los Angeles the most common were fraud and embezzlement, according to a recent analysis of court records by a Syracuse University research group. The study shows that Bonner's office brought a smaller percentage of drug charges than the national average for U.S. attorneys. Furthermore, he lagged behind a number of colleagues in big cities that had fewer drug arrests to begin with. From the beginning of 1984 through the first half of 1987, 19 percent of federal criminal defendants in Los Angeles faced narcotics charges. Federal prosecutors nationwide charged 27 percent of their defendants with drug counts during those years, the researchers found in response to a request by The Associated Press last week. The percentage of defendants charged with fraud and embezzlement in Los Angeles in those years ranged from 20 to 29. Bonner, who is awaiting Senate action on his nomination, declined to be interviewed about his work in Los Angeles. He has been praised by drug agents for pursuing criminal charges in the 1985 kidnapping and murder in Mexico of DEA agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena. But by early this year, drug crime was so rampant in Los Angeles itself that the city was one of five areas designated by national drug policy chief William Bennett for extra federal aid. In 1986, the DEA's Los Angeles office ranked third in the nation in drug arrests with 452, behind only New York with 1,066 and Miami with 861, according to DEA spokesman Joe Keefe. By 1989, Bennett noted, DEA had 1,033 major drug investigations under way in Los Angeles, again behind only New York and Miami. Bonner, 48, was U.S. attorney in Los Angeles from early 1984 until mid-1989 when he became a U.S. district judge there. Bush nominated him for the DEA post May 11. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel praised his ``extraordinary experience'' in drug investigations. The information about Bonner's record as a prosecutor was contained in a broader study by the nonprofit Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at Syracuse, using records from the Federal Judicial Center, a branch of the U.S. courts. This research is among the first made public comparing the work of U.S. attorneys. The Justice Department also has similar information but rarely discloses it. The Syracuse study was completed and sent to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh last October, long before Bonner was picked for the drug post. The research originally covered 1980-1987. Last week, at the request of The Associated Press, co-authors David Burnham and Margaret Hanus DeFleur calculated the averages for the portion of those years in which Bonner was chief prosecutor. Last year, Bonner's former chief assistant prosecutor, Gary Fees, said that the office had a heavy caseload of military purchasing fraud and savings and loan fraud _ both efforts which he said had high priority from the Justice Department. Neither area, however, commanded the money, manpower or new legislation that Justice devoted to the fight against drugs. Asked about the study, Justice spokeswoman Deborah Burstion-Wade said, ``Mr. Bonner is well respected by his peers and did an outstanding job for the attorney general and the department. We're certain that he will make an excellent head for DEA once he is confirmed.'' She said she was not in a position to comment on the specific numbers. The study also looked at the percentage of federal defendants charged with drug counts in 10 other U.S. attorney offices. All 10 had higher percentages of drug defendants during the four years than Los Angeles, which had 19 percent. They were: Baltimore, 36 percent; Boston, 33 percent; Brooklyn, N.Y., 44 percent; Manhattan, N.Y., 43 percent; Chicago, 20 percent; Detroit, 34 percent; Hartford, Conn., 40 percent; Newark, N.J., 29 percent; Philadelphia, 33 percent; and San Francisco, 21 percent. Asked about the study last October, the Justice Department's Executive Office of U.S. Attorneys released its own data for 1988, showing that Los Angeles' percentage that year was 26. Justice's 1988 data showed four of the 10 areas ranked ahead of Los Angeles: Brooklyn with 52 percent; Manhattan, 48; Detroit, 39; and Baltimore, 37. Hartford, Chicago, Boston and Philadelphia had 25 percent; Newark, 23 percent; and San Francisco, 18 percent. Bonner, boosted by Thornburgh for a judgeship and now the DEA post, has pursued some policies reminiscent of Thornburgh's. Early on as a prosecutor, Bonner unsuccessfully tried to take control of the department's independent organized crime strike force in Los Angeles. Thornburgh lost a similar battle as U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh in the early 1970s. Last year, when Thornburgh renewed that reorganization effort as attorney general, his aides recruited Bonner to sing the praises of the idea to reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Pat Carroll as Falstaff: `A Divine Role'
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: People are laughing _ yes, laughing _ at the sight of a plump, 63-year-old grandmother being mocked night after night as ``this gross wat'ry pumpkin ... this whale ... a bag of flax, a puff'd man, old, cold, wither'd and of intolerable entrails.'' Don't feel sorry for Pat Carroll. She has only herself to blame for her humiliation, and she loves every minute of it. Miss Carroll, a veteran stage, screen and TV actress and comedian, is believed to be the first female performer ever to play Sir John Falstaff, the leering, sack-swilling old windbag in ``The Merry Wives of Windsor.'' Eight times a week at the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger, Miss Carroll spends 45 grueling minutes acquiring jowls, side whiskers, mustache, beetle brows and wispy gray thatch. Then she struggles into the baggiest britches this side of Barnum & Bailey. Miss Carroll began preparing for Falstaff, ironically, by losing 30 pounds on a liquid diet and opting for extra padding around her belly. ``I knew this would be a very strenuous role, and I suffer from far too much weight,'' she said, munching on a juicy red apple during an interview. She shuddered at the thought of climbing those stairs and chasing Mistress Ford around the stage all night. And she sympathized with the two lackeys who haul Falstaff away in a laundry basket to help him escape the wrath of a jealous husband. ``I simply did not want to be responsible for bad backs and hernias,'' Miss Carroll said. Although she has a naturally low voice, made hoarse by age, cigarettes and her roaring Irish laughter, Miss Carroll practiced voice and breathing exercises to achieve a deeper, more masculine tone. She took walking lessons from Kabuki theater director Tadashi Suzuki, who makes his actors practice in bare feet. ``My walk is a combination of bad feet, sore knees, 20 pounds of costume and thinking of Jackie Gleason,'' she said. ``Because Jackie, even at his heaviest, had a kind of lightness about him. He used his hands very delicately, like a surgeon, and his feet were always twinkling. I used him as my mental image of a male body that was protuberance-heavy but still able to dance.'' With the help of the Folger's male actors, Miss Carroll overcame her feminine impulse to greet them with motherly hugs and learned instead to express ``male camaraderie'' with pokes, punches and slaps on the fanny. She took the time for some furtive research on facial hair and what men do with it. ``At restaurants I would sit casually and look at gentlemen with mustaches or beards,'' she said. ``Some are twirlers, some are fluffers, some are strokers and some are pinchers. I have a suspicion they're worried about food, crumbs and such, sticking in that hair.'' Miss Carroll has been lusting after the Falstaff role since the early 1960s, when she saw her first ``Merry Wives'' at the Royal Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, England, but she had a long wait. She starred in Broadway shows and films, did TV comedy routines with Sid Caesar and Danny Thomas, appeared as celebrity guest on ``What's My Line?'' and ``Password'' quiz shows, and won cheers for her one-woman show as Gertrude Stein. Her last credit was the voice for the animated squid-witch Ursula in Disney's Oscar-winning ``The Little Mermaid.'' She finally made her Shakespeare debut at the Folger in 1986 as the nurse in ``Romeo and Juliet,'' which won her a Helen Hayes Award for best supporting actress. Michael Kahn, the Folger's artistic director, asked what she'd like to do next, and she made her pitch for Falstaff. Kahn laughed, but thought about it. Two years later, when the Folger called about casting for ``Merry Wives,'' she was dead serious. After seeing her in fake whiskers, he bought the idea. ``It was a divine role that I wanted to play,'' she said, ``and a brilliant artistic director gave me the rope to hang myself.'' Not to worry, Miss Carroll. The show, which runs at the Folger through July 1, opened with rave reviews and the audiences are howling. Suspended disbelief is epidemic. Miss Carroll's only lingering apprehension concerns her mustache, which must endure Falstaff's frequent quaffs from a tankard. ``I perspire so profusely, and I drink an awful lot of water onstage,'' she said. ``I have nightmares about losing half my mustache. I'd look like a very pudgy Hitler.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Appear Headed for Tighter FmHA Loan Rules
DOC.TEXT: Congress may be getting a little fed up with a 3-year-old law giving the Farmers Home Administration a free hand in forgiving some big debts, including about 100 of $1 million or more. Bills in both the House and Senate would clamp a lid on the amount of bad debt that FmHA could excuse and would tighten some other loopholes in the agency's farm lending program. The free hand was provided by Congress itself in the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987, which was aimed at streamlining and liberalizing debt-collection policies of FmHA, an Agriculture Department agency. By last Nov. 30, the most recent tabulation available, almost 16,000 delinquent farm loans totaling nearly $2.8 billion had been forgiven by FmHA under the 1987 law. Those include write-downs, write-offs and other settlements of old debts, some going back a decade or more. The forgiveness of all or part of the debt owed to FmHA was authorized by Congress on grounds that in many cases the assets currently held by borrowers are worth far less than the face value of the original loans. Land values, a mainstay for farm credit, plummeted in the 1980s, wiping out much of the previous net worth of borrowers and reducing loan collateral. In many cases, a FmHA borrower could not be expected to regain enough cash flow to repay the old loans. So a solution has been to write down the debt to the current value of the collateral. Another practice has been to let borrowers ``buy out'' their loans at current liquidation values. By whatever method, the FmHA as of Nov. 30 had written off nearly one-third of the $8.8 billion in overdue loans. Last week the Senate Agriculture Committee approved a 1990 farm bill provision aimed at FmHA credit policies, including a $350,000 lid on debt forgiveness. A similar measure in the House would impose a $250,000 limit on the FmHA practice. The administration wants the credit loopholes plugged, and the Agriculture Department says it favors a $250,000 lid on FmHA loan forgiveness. Roland R. Vautour, USDA undersecretary for small community and rural development, told Congress earlier this year that ``huge amounts are being forgiven because there is no dollar limit in the law.'' Vautour, who oversees FmHA operations, said the average of all loan write-downs was $172,857 and that the average write-off was $205,674 per loan. ``Most borrowers would be unaffected if the maximum amount that could be forgiven were set at $250,000,'' he said. According to FmHA figures as of Nov. 30, more than 4,600 loans were written down $796.5 million. As Vautour testified, that was an average reduction of $172,857 each. There were more than 5,000 loans completely written off for more than $1.03 billion, an average of $205,674 each. Also, more than 6,300 old loans totaling more than $933 million were stricken from FmHA books as uncollectible. The FmHA has its roots in the Great Depression of the 1930s and traditionally has been the government's farm lender of last resort. Only those who can't get credit elsewhere need apply. Even without the write-offs and other forgiveness features, the agency would be operating at a loss. Vautour said FmHA estimated the cost of debt restructuring under the 1987 law alone will total more than $8 billion. ``When you add interest subsidies, write-offs not attributable to the (1987 law), and other expenses, we are looking at overall losses in our farm programs of something more than $22 billion over the next several years,'' he testified. Some critics, including Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, maintain that FmHA has effectively departed from being a credit agency and has operated grant programs in recent years. When Yeutter announced the Bush administration's proposals for the 1990 farm bill on Feb. 6, he was asked about FmHA programs. ``We've gone a long way from its original purpose of being a source of credit of last resort for farmers, and you've got a whole variety of ways that have made it very nearly a grant program in many of its attributes,'' Yeutter said. ``The result of that is that it has cost the department and the American taxpayer a great deal of money.'' Yeutter said FmHA has had ``immense losses'' through the years, and ``it just seems to us that in a time of budget austerity ... we cannot afford to run that program in the same manner anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Giant Jumpers Fizzle at Frog Jubilee
LaserPhoto XFRG1
DOC.TEXT: Three giant African frogs touted as potential record-breakers were big flops at the Jumping Frog Jubilee, beat out by a puny domestic one-pounder named Help Mr. Wizard. ``I wasn't afraid of the African frogs,'' said Gregg Jaschek, who took home the $500 first prize Sunday. ``I saw them on TV. They weren't so hot.'' Some veterans of the annual Calaveras County competition had complained the giants from Cameroon had an unfair advantage, but organizers voted in March to let Seattle animal collector Andy Koffman bring on his burly outsiders. Three of Koffman's Goliaths made it to the finals, but he couldn't get a decent leap out of the three-pounders. They were too big to fit on the 9-inch starting pad and were disqualified, or slipped and slid their way to lackluster hops. A dripping Help Mr. Wizard soared 19 feet, 3 inches in three jumps to best 72 other finalists. ``I'll be back,'' declared Koffman, who had claimed his frogs could leap 30 feet in a single bound. The 62nd annual jubilee 150 miles east of San Francisco drew a capacity crowd of 8,000, thanks to the controversy over Koffman's frogs. The event was inspired by Mark Twain's short story ``The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County,'' about a frog that couldn't jump because its belly had been filled with lead shot. Jaschek, an auto parts clerk from Concord, said he captured Help Mr. Wizard in the San Joaquin Valley. Its win was just luck, he said. ``I've been trying for 19 years and if I knew the secret of winning I would have won long before this,'' he said, kissing his frog as friends poured champagne on him. Second place went to an 18-foot, 4-inch leap in three jumps by a frog named Cho Cho. Third place was won by Jumpin' Jack. Koffman brought 27 Goliaths to the frog jump. The big frogs can weigh up to 15 pounds and range up to three feet in length. His three finalists _ Johnny Carson, Jay Leno and Sue _ weighed in at about three pounds each. The average domestic frog weighs about a pound and is about eight inches long. Koffman was done in by a rule that frogs must have all four feet on the pad. The big frogs also leaped at an angle and made little stutter hops after landing. Under the rules, the distance jumped is the total of three successive hops. ``They just kind of slip out of my hands and it slows them down,'' Koffman said. ``I'm really disappointed.'' Before the meet, Koffman, who keeps the frogs in a 1,500-gallon tank in his basement, predicted they would easily shatter the record, held by one-pound Rosie the Ribiter, who jumped 21 feet, 5} inches in three leaps in 1985. In one qualifying event, Johnny Carson jumped 12 feet, 4} inches, enough to win the round. Sue won its round with a leap of 13 feet, 5 inches. Jay Leno finished fifth on its way to the finals. The big frogs are on California's dangerous animals list and needed exemptions to be brought into the state. Koffman had to promise to keep the sharp-toothed frogs away from domestic animals. ``I think Mark Twain is up there right now looking down and laughing,'' jubilee official Buck King said in March at the height of the controversy.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Slows His `Aerobic Golf' Style
DOC.TEXT: It was a sight never before seen by the press corps that follows President Bush _ the president was actually sitting down during a golf match. But there he was _ in the middle of the Doug Sanders celebrity pro-am golf tournament _ seated on the green, not just once, but on two different holes. Bush, who puts as much emphasis on golfing speed as he does on precision, was forced to cool his heels while the tournament leader, Lee Trevino, finished his much more contemplative play just ahead of Bush's foursome. It was definitely a change of pace for the president to play in a tournament instead of a wide-open course where everyone allows him to blast through. ``It's different, that's for sure,'' Bush said, chatting briefly with reporters while waiting for Trevino to finish the 13th hole at the Deerwood country club outside Houston. Known for his hyperkinetic energy and pace, Bush generally races through 18 holes without pausing for longer than it takes to wipe his brow. His record was under two hours at the Cape Arundel Golf Course last summer near his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. One aide has dubbed his playing style as ``aerobic golf.'' Sunday's 18 holes in sweltering heat and humidity took him 4{ hours. Bush was joined by his oldest son, Texan George W. Bush, who also is no slouch at fast play. But the president didn't seem to mind waiting, especially since it gave him a chance to savor the adulation of thousands of people lining the links and cheering him on. Bush, whose golfing tends to be a bit uneven, was ebullient when he hit a good shot, downcast when he flubbed one. At one point, he used his club to help fish one of his son's errant shots out of the water. At another point, he demonstrated how to pick up his golf cap from the ground with a club. When his son hit an exceptionally accurate drive, Bush exclaimed, ``That's my lad. That's my fine boy.'' He scrunched up his face and moaned, ``Oh, oh, oh, oh'' in disappointment when his tee-off on the same hole veered far to the side.

Bush is a familiar visitor to Houston's St. Martin's Episcopal Church near his sometime residence in the Houstonian apartment-hotel complex. His presence on Sunday was acknowledged by the Rev. Claude E. Payne. Payne did not mention the president by name, instead telling the congregation that the church was honored by yet another visit from ``a commuting parishioner who has been coming here for 30 years and who now resides in Washington D.C.'' Bush usually sits with his wife Barbara during church services. But he had different seatmates on Sunday since Mrs. Bush did not accompany him to Houston. The president sat between golf pro Doug Sanders, his partner from the previous day's tournament, and an old friend, Pete Roussel, once his congressional press secretary and now a public relations executive in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Wants to Get the House `Mail Monster' Under Control
DOC.TEXT: While Congress and the Bush administration hold urgent talks on deficit reduction, House members are deluging constituents with taxpayer-financed mail in an election year. The House has been getting its nose tweaked by the Senate over the stream of newsletters and town meeting notices that are an incumbent's best friend. ``It goes without saying that taxpayers will likely be outraged'' to learn the House may exceed its $40.7 million mail budget by $38 million, Sens. Harry Reid, D-Nev., and Don Nickles, R-Okla., wrote to a House committee chairman last month. Last week, the cost overrun was projected by lawmakers at $44 million. The Senate, meanwhile, ``is expected to have a $6 million surplus'' in its $23.7 million mail budget, the two senators wrote to Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill. Reid is chairman and Nickles the ranking Republican on the Appropriations subcommittee on the legislative branch. Annunzio is chairman of the House Administration Committee. Why the difference in mail costs? The Senate has imposed rules on itself to hold down the mail expense. The House agreed to some changes last year, but didn't go as far. Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., chairman of the House Appropriations legislative branch subcommittee, said he wouldn't support overall restrictions in mass mailings, but would listen to suggestions on setting limits for individual members. He accused the Senate of transferring money from other accounts into the mail account ``in an election year.'' Fazio's criticism only underscores the bitterness lingering from the Senate's insistence last year that the House curb its mail costs. The Senate requires each member to disclose his mail costs. Mailings are prohibited once a senator's money allotment is exhausted, although the Rules Committee can switch funds from another senator who failed to use his full amount. Senators are given allotments based on a state's population. During last year's battle over mail costs, the Senate persuaded the House to agree to separate accounts for each chamber. The number of House newsletter mailings was reduced from six to three. But the House still lacks individual disclosure and can keep on mailing after the budgeted money is exhausted. The House can pass a supplemental appropriation to reimburse the Postal Service or make that agency absorb the costs. Either way, the mail gets delivered. Fazio last week won tentative support from senators to let the House use $25 million in unspent funds to make up a portion of the postage deficit. Reid said he's encouraged by Fazio's willingness to discuss individual accounting and disclosure for House members. ``That's the key, a step in the right direction,'' Reid said. But he also expressed a willingness to do battle again, adding, ``We're going try to get the mail monster under control.'' The Postal Service said senators sent out 45.4 million pieces of mail at a cost of $6.9 million in the first half of fiscal 1990. Over a year the projections, based on historical trends, are 115.6 million pieces and $17.7 million in cost. The Postal Service show the House spent $32 million to send 212.5 million pieces of mail in the first half of fiscal 1990, which began Oct. 1. Projected over a full year, the figures would be 532.7 million pieces and $78.9 million in expenditures. Two prominent House Republicans, Minority Leader Bob Michel of Illinois and Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, have introduced bills aimed at further limiting the number of town meeting and newsletter mailings, establishing separate accounts for each House member and public disclosure. Both plan to try to add their proposals to the appropriation bill for running Congress. ``At the moment, there has been no sign'' of help from the majority House Democratic leadership, Frenzel said. ``The frank is a very powerful influence in elections. I don't think the Democrats are going to let loose of it without some great pressure being applied.'' Frenzel, who is retiring, said the mail cost could be a ``good political issue'' for Republicans, but quickly added, ``There are a number of Republicans who regard the franking perk as zealously as Democrats.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Personal Tragedy Shapes Debate on Two House Bills
DOC.TEXT: Politics, lobbying and public opinion polls drive Congress' agenda. But sometimes another motivation comes into play: personal tragedy. Such is the case with two House bills debated this month _ one on family leave policy and the other aimed at expanding the rights of the disabled. Republican Rep. Marge Roukema of New Jersey has spent a decade in the House racking up a pro-business voting record. But on the issue of whether the government should give employees the right to unpaid leave for family medical emergencies, she and the business lobby part ways. Roukema was the prime Republican sponsor of the bill which passed the House earlier this month. She scolded those, especially business groups, who went the other way. ``The organized business lobby in Washington is out of step with the real world and that includes conscientious, no-nonsense, bottom-line business people at the grass roots,'' she said. ``The lobbyists have overreacted in a way that no one can explain to me.'' For Mrs. Roukema, the need to take unpaid leave from work to care for a new child or a critically ill relative relates directly to her own suffering. ``These are not abstract problems,'' she told the House in an emotional speech. ``I know. I've been there.'' She recalled that when she started raising a family, her son was stricken with fatal leukemia. He ``needed home care, I was free to remain at home and give him the loving care he needed.'' But today, many households don't have the luxury of one spouse making enough money so the other can quit work. ``I continually asked myself during this process, `What would I have done if I not only had the tragedy and the trauma of caring for my child, but also had to worry about losing a job and a roof over my head?''' she said. Many years later, Mrs. Roukema found an answer in the parental leave bill. This week, the House expected to complete action on the Americans With Disabilities Act. One of the main forces in getting that legislation moving is no longer in the House, but he came back last week for the start of the debate. Former House Majority Whip Tony Coelho resigned from the House last year to avoid an inquiry into his personal finances. But his support for the bill has nothing to do with money. Coelho has epilepsy. ``If I were not epileptic, I probably wouldn't have the real passion in disabilities issues that I do,'' Coelho said. ``I know what it's like to be discriminated against.'' For most in Congress, ``You don't think about these folks because you aren't disabled,'' he said. ``They,'' he said, referring to the people in wheelchairs who sat outside the House chamber during the debate, ``They don't have a PAC (political action committee) and they don't understand the political process.'' When he left Congress last year, Coelho said he told Speaker Thomas Foley that he didn't intend to come back as a lobbyist as so many of his colleagues have. ``But I made one exception. For the rest of my life, I would lobby on disability legislation,'' he said. There was plenty of lobbying on both the parental leave bill and the disabilities act. But the stories behind the legislation added poignancy missing from debates on the budget or foreign aid. They also helped tip the scales toward passage. The Roukema and Coelho tragedies, not to mention others recalled in the debates, make it extraordinarily tough for lawmakers to make a dispassionate choice. Congress can be a very intimate place, and the peer pressure can be so enormous that voting ``no'' is not an acceptable option. Of course, much of what Congress does is based to some degree on personal experiences of the members, such as the former farmer who might get on the agriculture committee to write farm laws. Other lawmakers' experiences may be translated into legislation of a less magnanimous nature, such as a provision in a tax bill to help out the family business, or a government project for a developer friend back home.
Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Commanders Say They Won't Give Up Their Guns
DOC.TEXT: Contra commanders say they have stopped disarming and will not tell their troops to give up their guns unless the government offers more safety guarantees. ``Demobilized fighters are not getting the treatment they deserve,'' said Oscar Sovalbarro, the second-ranking Contra commander, in an interview with The Associated Press. Sovalbarro, known as ``Commander Ruben,'' said the demobilized Contras were being harassed by the Sandinistas and weren't getting enough food, medical care and assistance to establish themselves in civilian life. His statements Saturday followed a meeting with government disarmament coordinator Roberto Ferrey. According to a presidential communique, Ferrey told the Contra high command: ``The government remains steadfast in its commitment to give you all the guarantees and security measures you require.'' In the communique, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro called on the Nicaraguan people to support ``the demobilized and disarmed that have been integrated into civilian life . . . in order to contribute to the pacification of the country.'' The U.S.-backed Contras fought the leftist Sandinistas for nine years in a civil war that claimed 30,000 lives. When Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-supported administration took over from the Sandinistas after February elections, the rebels agreed to disarm by June 10. But so far, only 1,084 out of an estimated 11,000 fighters have put aside their weapons, according to the latest government figures. Sovalbarro blamed the delay on the Sandinistas, who he said were subverting Mrs. Chamorro's reconciliation efforts. ``The government is sympathetic. But it doesn't have any money, and the Sandinistas are disobeying orders,'' he said. He cited a six-day civil service strike last week, which virtually paralyzed the government, as an example. The public employees' union is controlled by the Sandinistas. The Sandinistas claim the Contras' stalling is a pretext for attracting U.S. aid. Sovalbarro spoke for the Contra high command gathered at El Almendro, a village 110 miles southeast of Managua in the center of one of five security zones where Contra fighters agreed to lay down their arms. High command leaders, from whom rebels take their orders, chose to hold forth in El Almendro because they feel it is safer than other security zones where they fear they might be surrounded by the military. El Almendro is set in a sparsely populated ranching area where support for the rebels is strong. The nearest Sandinista troops spotted by reporters were 25 miles up a dirt road to the north. Sovalbarro said that the June 10 disarmament deadline could still be met if there was ``an atmosphere of confidence.'' He said the Sandinistas would have to stop their ``war of insults'' against the Contras and would also have to stop ``trying to destabilize the government.'' He cited what he considered examples of Sandinista harassment _ two demobilized fighters beaten by Sandinista militants in Masaya, another fighter's body found along a road. He said one former fighter had returned to camp complaining of harassment. Ferrey had said Saturday that the Contras would continue disarming despite the high command's decision. But Sovalbarro said that simply meant individual Contras wouldn't be stopped if they wanted to leave. He said that had always been the case _ the Contras are volunteers and anyone can leave any time. ``But as leaders, we cannot tell our fighters to demobilize until there is a guarantee that they will be left in peace,'' Sovalbarro said. Fighters interviewed by the AP said they would not disband without orders. ``The Sandinistas are doing things that aren't good for us,'' said a rebel who called himself Bengala, ``The Bengal.'' He said he had been fighting for six years.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Smoke Called Proven Cause of Heart Disease in Non-Smokers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Benzo(a)pyrene is cq in 18th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Other people's smoke is a proven cause of heart disease in non-smokers, raising their risk of dying from the disease by up to 30 percent, a study says. In a presentation in Boston at the World Conference on Lung Health, Stanton Glantz of the University of California, San Francisco, said research is beginning to show exactly how cigarette smoke alters the heart, blood and arteries. He presented a study in which he reviewed others' research on the subject. In 1986, the Surgeon General concluded in his annual report on smoking and health that so-called passive smoking causes lung cancer in non-smokers. At that time, the evidence was insufficient to link passive smoking with heart disease, the report said. Newer studies have changed that, Glantz said Friday in a telephone interview. ``The evidence that passive smoking causes heart disease is stronger today than the evidence was in 1986 that passive smoking caused lung cancer,'' Glantz said. Glantz's report comes one week after the Environmental Protection Agency said it will soon declare environmental tobacco smoke a known carcinogen. The EPA concluded that passive smoking causes 3,000 deaths. Glantz said passive smoking also causes 32,000 heart disease deaths. ``The heart disease deaths combined with the cancer deaths make passive smoking the third leading cause of preventable death, behind smoking and alcohol,'' he said. Glantz is a researcher and statistician who conducts research in cardiology, has written two textbooks on biostatistics and serves on the California State Scientific Review Panel on toxic air contaminants. His collaborator in the study was Dr. William Parmley, a cardiologist, chief of the division of cardiology at University of California, San Francisco, and a past president of the American College of Cardiology. The Tobacco Institute, which represents cigarette makers, emphasized that the Surgeon General in 1986 had failed to find proof that passive smoking causes heart disease. ``There have been only three studies since then, and they continue to support the conclusions,'' Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the institute, said in a telephone interview Friday. But Glantz said there are 11 studies on passive smoking and heart disease deaths, and ``all but one the tobacco industry funded show an increased risk.'' The studies showed an increased risk of between 20 percent and 30 percent, he said. Furthermore, he said, ``there's evidence from several areas that passive smoking reduces the ability of the heart to obtain and profit from oxygen.'' Carbon monoxide in cigarette smoke binds with hemoglobin in the blood, reducing its capacity to carry oxygen, Glantz said. Smoke also reduces the ability of cells in the heart to covert oxygen to a chemical called adenosine triphosphate, or ATP, which provides energy to the heart, he said. ``What you end up with is: The blood doesn't carry oxygen well. The heart doesn't pump as well. And what oxygen gets to the heart isn't used as well,'' he said. One consequence of that _ which can be measured _ is that people exposed to second-hand smoke can't exercise as long, he said. That is true of both healthy non-smokers and non-smokers with heart disease, he said. Cancer-causing agents in the smoke, especially benzo(a)pyrene, have been found to injure artery linings, he said. Such injuries are one of the first steps in the development of life-threatening blood clots in the coronary arteries that nourish the heart, he said. Studies have also shown that blood platelets, which help blood clot, become ``stickier'' and more likely to clot in non-smokers exposed to cigarette smoke. In fact, non-smokers are much more sensitive to this effect than are smokers, he said. This ``stickiness'' can increase the risk of clotting in the coronary arteries, Glantz said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,765.05, down 248.67 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: State Ban on Small Life Insurance Policies Headed for Court
DOC.TEXT: A state ban on life insurance policies that regulators consider unfair to the elderly could be the start of a national trend if it withstands an industry challenge in court, officials say. The policies typically are advertised on television with the appeal: `You cannot be canceled. Your premium can never go up and your protection can never go down.'' The policies offer immediate protection and are intended for the elderly. But they require high premiums that can amount to more than the benefits at death. Washington Insurance Commissioner Dick Marquardt adopted a regulation last year that restricts the sale of such policies. Two insurance companies that specialize in the policies challenged the regulation in Superior Court and lost. They appealed, and the state Supreme Court is scheduled to take up the case May 24. ``We're a trailblazer with this regulation,'' Marquardt said. ``Other state regulators are inquiring. And the fact that we're in court points up the fact we're a leader in this type of regulation.'' Marquardt said he searched for years for a way to ban the policies. Since he cannot regulate life insurance policies or rates, he came up with a regulation against unfair competition or ``deceptive acts or practices.'' ``We have been concerned because many plans currently on the market literally trap the insured individual in a no-win situation,'' said David Rodgers, the state's chief deputy insurance commissioner. Rodgers said elderly holders of the policies would be better off putting the money in a bank. He gave the following example: A 77-year-old woman buys a 10-year policy at a monthly premium of $21.55. The death benefit starts at $500 and increases to $1,000 after 10 years. If the woman had simply banked the money at 5 percent interest, the return would have been better, Rodgers said. He said after the first year, premiums plus interest would have totaled $266. Had the woman died in the first year, her estate would have received $500, or $234 more than premiums, Rodgers said. After that, the estate would lose. Premiums and interest after the second year would have totaled $544, the benefit $540. At the end of 10 years, premiums plus interest would have totaled $3,340, the benefit $1,000. ``Unless the olicyholder dies within a small window of time, the premium will be more than the benefit,'' Rodgers said. ``Even if the policyholder dies within the window of time, the gain for the estate is often so small as to be meaningless even in a modest estate.'' The challenge has been mounted by Omega National Insurance Co., which has been doing business in Washington since 1979, and Pierce National Insurance Co. It has been doing business in the state since 1948. Most of the life insurance policies the companies handled in Washington were banned, their lawyers said in court papers. The regulation, they said, ``violates a fundamental precept of insurance, that risk classifications should be equitable.'' The companies said that forcing them to dump the policies would force younger, healthier policyholders to subsidize the elderly. They said Marquardt ``has attacked a perceived but unsubstantiated problem with a sledge hammer.''

DOC.HEAD: House Plans Clean Air Vote This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: House convenes noon EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: The House is aiming for a vote this week on clean air legislation, but first must decide whether to require automakers to manufacture non-gasoline cars for nine of the most polluted cities. House leaders have said they want a vote on the bill before Congress begins its Memorial Day recess on Friday. Floor debate was scheduled to begin today on the measure, which would be the first revision of federal air pollution laws in 13 years. The Senate approved clean air legislation in April after lengthy private discussions between Senate leaders and the White House. The Bush administration has had no such discussions in the House, where the Energy and Commerce Committee produced a bill by a 41-1 vote in April. Both versions would cost the economy about $21 billion a year when the new controls go fully into effect. The House bill, like the Senate version, calls for steep cuts in acid rain pollutants as well as unprecedented controls on urban smog, largely from automobiles, and curbs on toxic industrial emissions. ``We're pretty well where we're going to stay,'' Rep. Terry Bruce, D-Ill., said of most of the major components of the package, including provisions that will force coal-burning electric utilities to reduce their annual acid rain emissions by 10 million tons. Key congressmen and their staffs were holding private talks in hopes of working out agreements on some of the dozen or so amendments expected to be brought to the floor for votes, probably Wednesday and Thursday. The proposed amendments include one by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., that would require automakers to manufacture up to 1 million alternative-fuel cars for sale in nine of the most smog-troubled cities. A tentative agreement was reached on a proposal to require use of a cleaner fuel in dozens of cities to curb the urban smog problem. But no deal was expected on the Waxman amendment or on a proposal to broaden the phaseout of chemicals that damage the atmospheric ozone layer. Those issues are likely to be thrashed out on the House floor, sources said. Waxman's amendment calls for manufacturers to build up to 1 million alternative fuel vehicles to be sold in the nine cities. The automakers, who oppose the amendment, have a strong ally in Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee. The automakers argue that no one has shown that cars powered by such fuels as methanol, ethanol natural gas or electricity would be accepted by the public, especially if there was uncertainty about the fuel supply. ``The fate of alternative fuel vehicles hinges on consumer acceptance and consumers are flashing a yellow warning light,'' argues Thomas Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. Supporters of Waxman's amendment suggest that by late in the decade when such cars would have to be produced, the fuel availability issue will have been resolved. Industry also has lobbied vigorously against the amendment that would broaden the phaseout requirements on ozone-depleting chemicals, including some that are considered ``bridge'' substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC. Manufacturers already are committed to phasing out CFCs, but have argued they need the ``bridge'' substitutes.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania, Bjt ^Ethnic Hungarians and Romanians Put Aside Enmity on Election Day
DOC.TEXT: CLUJ-NAPOCA, Romania (AP) _ Ethnic Hungarians and Romanians put aside their traditional enmity for at least one day as they flocked to the polls throughout Transylvania, where bloody ethnic clashes erupted earlier this year. There had been fears that the volatile passions aroused by the campaign might lead to violence on Election Day. In March, six people died and some 300 were injured in clashes in the town of Tirgu Mures. But on Sunday, both ethnic Hungarians and Romanians relished the opportunity to cast votes in the country's first free elections in 53 years. ``We found the Romanians genuinely excited about the chance to vote freely,'' said Eric Koenig, a member of the Washington-based Human Rights Law Group and among about 500 foreign observers monitoring the election. ``In this area, we didn't see any evidence of an organized effort to tamper with or influence the voting process,'' said Koenig, after touring polling places in Cluj-Napoca and nearby villages Sunday. Sandor Balazs, president of the Cluj chapter of the Hungarian Democratic Union, a group representing Romania's 2-million-strong Hungarian minority, said members of the rival ethnic communities even shared horse-drawn carts to get to rural polling places. Under ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, ethnic Hungarians complained of discrimination, saying their language and cultural traditions were being suppressed. The Democratic Union says the Hungarians must continue to fight for their rights following the bloody December revolution that led to Ceausescu's execution. An exit poll taken by a West German polling firm showed the ethnic Hungarian party winning 6 percent of the votes nationwide for seats in the two-chamber parliament. In the Cluj region, the only major complaint was the same echoed elsewhere in the country _ the long lines of people waiting to vote, due to a heavy turnout and complicated voting procedures. ``I've been coming by all day, hoping the crowd diminished,'' complained Tibor Szekely, an 85-year-old ethnic Hungarian, as he viewed the long line stretching outside a downtown polling station in a school. In Leglia, a sleepy ethnic Hungarian village of 700 peasants about 20 miles northwest of Cluj, residents complained about having to travel to a nearby village to vote. But fears of a hostile reception by the Romanian residents of Aghires, one mile down the road, did not materialize. There was even a long line of voters outside the Romanian Embassy in the Hungarian capital of Budapest. At least 15,000 Romanian citizens, most of them ethnic Hungarians, fled to Hungary to escape the Ceausescu regime. Those who still retained their Romanian citizenship seemed eager to vote. The Hungarian news agency MTI said about 3,500 had voted at the embassy by early evening, and thousands more were waiting. Transylvania was ruled by Hungary for centuries before being ceded to Romania after World War I. Hungary annexed the province during World War II, but it was returned to Romania when the war ended.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Children Vote in First Free Elections
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Their father never allowed a free election during his brutal 24-year rule, but the jailed children of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu were not denied their chance to vote. Ceausescu's two sons and daughter were not handcuffed when they appeared at a Bucharest police station to cast their ballots in Sunday's elections, the first free vote in Romania in 53 years. The dictator's children are awaiting trial on charges of complicity in his rule. All three have been jailed since December and, if convicted, face sentences of up to life in prison. Nicu, 40, Ceausescu's youngest son and once his heir-apparent, voted first. He spent several minutes in the booth before emerging and dropping a large envelope in the ballot box. Nicu goes on trial next weekend on charges of complicity in genocide in the Transylvanian city of Sibiu, 155 miles northwest of Bucharest. He was regional Communist Party chief there until his arrest. Clad in jeans and a dark sweater, Nicu declined to speak to reporters at his first public appearance since being shown on television the night of Dec. 22, just after his capture. Ceausescu's oldest son, Valentin, 43, a nuclear physics engineer, spent comparatively little time in the booth. ``I'm treated like everyone else in prison,'' he said, smiling and looking relaxed in a jogging suit top and jeans. He had long hair, a beard and mustache. Ceausescu's only daughter, Zoia Elena, 38, a mathematician, looked nervous and came out of the booth after only 20 seconds. She refused to made a statement. Rompres said the young Ceausescus were allowed to vote ``as they were under investigation and still not sentenced and stripped of political and civil rights.'' Members of Ceausescu's ruling Politburo who face trial also were allowed to vote, the agency said. Ceausescu was toppled by a popular uprising Dec. 22. He and his wife, Elena, were tried in secret and convicted of causing the deaths of thousands while in power. They were executed by a firing squad on Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: For Young And Old, Vote Was First Chance To Choose
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Simon Feller, 86, was a young man when he last had a chance to vote in a free election in his country 53 years ago. Through four decades of Communist rule he harbored a secret wish. ``I always hoped to vote in a fair election,'' he said. He got his chance Sunday when Romania held free elections for president and the 506-seat parliament, just five months after a bloody revolution toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. For 21-year-old Julius Cristea, the election offered a chance to cast a ballot for a democratic Romania. ``I want Romania to become a democratic country and I'd like communism to be erased from the earth,'' said Cristea, an architecture student. For young and old alike, election memories were of the rubber-stamp affairs held every four years by Ceausescu, in which he claimed near unanimous support. Ion Moraru, 73, a retired auto mechanic, said he voted in past years because ``if you didn't, they put you out of your job.'' Sunday's election offered voters a choice from among 88 parties. ``I never thought I could live this long,'' said Stefan Ionescu, 75, a retired plumber. An exit poll showed the National Salvation Front, which has governed the country since the December revolution, and its leader, Interim President Ion Iliescu, headed for victory in the presidential and parliamentary races. Voters of all ages expressed hope that the election would usher in a new era of democracy in a country accustomed to authoritarian rule. ``I hope the election will bring liberty, democracy and the reduction of tension,'' Feller said. A 27-year-old engineering student who identified himself only as Sorin said, ``Freedom makes my heart free. I am very happy to give my vote in liberty.'' ``We are hoping for a new life in Romania, a new life with the rest of Europe, a life where we are the masters,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Yehuda Lisky Dead, Editor of Britain's Last Yiddish Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Yehuda Lisky, editor of the last Yiddish newspaper in Britain, is dead at 90, The Daily Telegraph reported today. The newspaper described Lisky as a champion of Yiddish culture who ``wrote Yiddish, spoke Yiddish, dreamed Yiddish and, as he once put it, drank Yiddish _ although in fact his favorite (drink) was Scotch.'' From his own resources in the 1950s, Lisky launched Dos Yiddishe Folk (The Jewish People). It was published first weekly, then biweekly, then monthly and finally whenever he had the money and energy to produce it. He launched the newspaper in collaboration with Avron Stencl, the poet of London's East End. Yiddish was the common language of East European Jewry. It largely disappeared following the Nazi persecution of World War II and the dying out of the older generation of survivors. Lisky was born in Oszene, Poland, and joined his brother Abraham Fuchs, an established Yiddish writer living in Vienna. He came to London in 1930 and worked on a Yiddish daily, Die Zeit. When it folded in 1950, Lisky started his own paper. He also taught Yiddish at summer and winter schools in Oxford. Lisky was short in stature, bespectacled and cheerful. He wore a black beret pulled low over his right ear and was well-known around the cafes and bookstores of east and central London. He lost the sight of one eye when he was attacked by a robber in his London home in his 90th year. The Daily Telegraph said Lisky's wife Sonia died in 1984 and they are survived by two sons. It did not give the date or cause of death.

DOC.HEAD: Two Inmates Shot to Death in Prison Melee
DOC.TEXT: Guards at a maximum-security prison shot and killed two inmates about to attack fellow prisoners with makeshift knives, authorities say. Three other inmates were reported injured, one seriously, in the melee Sunday night at the Stateville Correctional Center. The shootings came after a fight broke out among about 10 inmates from a prison gang, said Illinois Department of Corrections spokesman Nic Howell. ``My understanding is the staff shot the inmates as they were attempting to do harm to other inmates,'' Howell said. The cause of the fight, which authorities said was brought under control within 45 minutes, wasn't disclosed. Inmates were confined to their cells after the brawl. One inmate was reported in fair condition at Silver Cross Hospital with a gunshot wound to the leg. Another was listed in serious condition with at least one stab wound. An inmate received wounds on the hand and was being treated at the prison, a hospital spokesman said. Stateville is one of two maximum-security state prisons in Joliet. The prison was built in 1920 to house 1,506 prisoners but now holds about 2,100. Two inmates were stabbed to death in 1988 and 1989. A guard known for aggressive tactics in confiscating drugs and weapons was beaten to death last July after being put on a prison hit list signed ``The Executioner.''

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan's President Calls For Better Ties With China
DOC.TEXT: President Lee Teng-hui marked his inauguration by calling for an end to hostilities and improved relations with China's Communist government. Lee's remarks during Sunday's presidential inauguration ceremony marked the first time a Taiwan president publicly indicated a desire to move away from the 40-year-old policy of the ``three No's'' toward Beijing _ no official contact, no negotiations and no compromise. In Beijing, there was no mention of Lee's speech in any of the nationally circulated official dailies, and the government declined immediate comment. An official of the Taiwan Department in the State Council's Overseas Chinese Office, asked for reaction on Lee's speech, referred questions to the Foreign Ministry. The ministry, which usually says Taiwan is part of China and thus not a foreign affairs matter, had no immediate response. At his inauguration, Lee also promised amnesty for political prisoners. He pledged the restoration of civil rights to previously jailed political prisoners _ including the chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party _ allowing them to run for public office. Nine people imprisoned on sedition charges were released Sunday, including Hsu Hsin-liang, 49, who was jailed last year after returning from self-imposed exile in the United States. Taiwan's best-known political prisoner, Shih Ming-teh, was released early this morning. He had been jailed in 1979 on charges of instigating an anti-government riot in the southern port city of Kaohsiung. He had originally refused to allow his family to sign for his release because he maintains he is innocent, his sister said. Human rights groups claim Taiwan has roughly a dozen other political prisoners. Meanwhile, Lee's nomination of Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun, the nation's only four-star general, as premier continued to spark protests on Sunday. Hau's opponents believe his nomination is a step backward for democracy and could lead to a resurgence of military influence. About 10,000 people, including students and opposition party members, staged a noisy march through Taipei, smashing windows and throwing eggs at offices of the military and the ruling Nationalist Party. Lee heads the Nationalist Chinese government that has been based on the island of Taiwan ever since losing a civil war to Communist forces on the Chinese mainland in 1949. The Nationalists still claim to be the rightful government of all China, and Beijing regards Taiwan as a renegade province. Lee proposed establishing ``channels of communication'' and said the two countries should ``completely open up academic, cultural, economic, trade, scientific and technological exchange to lay a foundation of mutual respect, peace and prosperity.'' But Lee said before relations could be established, Beijing must renounce the use of force against Taiwan, end its policy of isolating Taiwan diplomatically, and promote democracy and a free economic system in China. While Beijing previously has indicated it would not meet conditions set by Lee, the speech clearly was designed to reflect Taipei's desire to gradually improve relations with its neighbor across the Taiwan Straits. Recently, civilian and business contacts have been growing between the two sides. Lee became the first native Taiwanese to lead the government in January 1988 when he moved up from the vice presidency to succeed President Chiang Ching-kuo, who died in office. Chiang was the eldest son of Chiang Kai-shek, the Nationalist leader who led the retreat to Taiwan four decades ago.

DOC.HEAD: Host Says Former Chinese Diplomat Visiting U.S. Won't Seek Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A high-ranking Chinese Communist Party official who left Hong Kong for Los Angeles has no plans to defect and merely wants some rest and relaxation, his host says. Master Hsing Yun, a Buddhist monk, held a news conference at Hsi Lai Temple in Hacienda Heights, 20 miles from Los Angeles, to dispel reports that Xu Jiatun defected. Xu, director of the Hong Kong branch of the Xinhua News Agency for nearly seven years, did not appear at the news conference. Hsing Yun would not disclose his whereabouts or say how long he planned to stay. ``Because we are friends, I do not have the right to ask why he came or for how long,'' the monk said through an interpreter. ``He said he did not come here to seek political asylum.'' ``He told me that after he rests for a while he's planning to make a broad survey and research on American society. He still wishes to go back to his country and will not ever seek political asylum.'' He has been in seclusion since arriving in California on May 1. The Buddhist master said he and Xu have taken several trips together, including a visit to the Grand Canyon. As bureau chief of the Beijing-controlled New China News Agency in Hong Kong, Xu was China's top representative to the British colony from 1983 until last year. His assignment was to prepare Hong Kong for its return to China in 1997. Xu reportedly fell out of favor with the government of Premier Li Peng after revealing his sympathy toward the pro-democracy movement that was crushed last June in Tiananmen Square. Xu, 74, was reported to have left without the approval of his government. But Hsing Yun said he believed Xu had permission to visit the United States and that he was carrying a visa good for up to six months. Public confidence in Hong Kong's future under Chinese rule was shaken by Xu's departure. Many of Hong Kong's 5.7 million residents have long been suspicious of China's plans for the territory after the British leave. On Thursday the Foreign Ministry in Beijing said Xu was merely ``touring and taking a rest in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Bodies Found in Atlantic City Apartment
DOC.TEXT: Two adults and three children were found dead in an apartment house where four people reportedly were overcome by carbon monoxide a day earlier. Authorities awaited autopsies today for the cause of death. Three police officers at the building on an related matter found the bodies in a first-floor apartment Sunday after smelling a strong odor and forcing their way in, police said. A woman and a boy, about 2{ years old, were in a bedroom; a man was in the living room; a 15-month-old girl was in the bathroom, and a 4-year-old boy was in another bedroom, said Capt. Joseph North. Their identities and relationships were not immediately available. WCBS-AM in New York reported that four people, including two children, were overcome by carbon monoxide fumes at the building on Saturday. They were treated at a hospital and released. North said he was unable to confirm the report.

DOC.HEAD: Three Die in Bar Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Three men sprayed a Harlem bar with gunfire, killing three patrons, and left behind photos of themselves posing with their guns, police said. Two Polaroid snapshots were found Sunday on the floor of the International Bar, said Capt. William Roe. In the pictures, three men are displaying a machine pistol, a rifle and an automatic pistol. Some patrons recognized the gunmen in the photos or knew them by nicknames, Roe said. Witnesses said the three had posed for a street photographer in the bar early Sunday and were headed for the door when they wheeled and fired 15 shots into the crowd, the New York Post reported today. About 40 to 50 people were in the bar. Police said they had no motive for the shootings. David Solferino, 22, was shot several times, leading police to believe he may have been the target. Also killed were Randi Thomas, 26, who was shot once in the chest and died at the scene, and Leon Dean, 22, who died at a hospital. Two of the injured were listed in stable condition. A third was treated for a facial wound and released. The bar's owner, Leonard Williams, said there had been no fights or arguments shortly before the shootings. He said several men near the dance floor opened fire and yelled, ```Everyone get down! Get down on the floor!'' He said that within seconds, the men had fled and many patrons had run out in panic. He said he did not recognize the men. ``If it was robbery, then they changed their minds,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Demands End to Protests
DOC.TEXT: Government officials called today for a halt to to the violent protests that have rocked this southern provincial city for the past three days. Also today, radical student leaders demanded that police be held responsible for the death of a student who suffered fatal head injuries Saturday after jumping from a train in an effort to join the protesters. The students said 21-year-old Shin Jang-ho would be buried as a martyr and patriot Wednesday after funeral services at Kwangju's Chonnam University. About 100 militant students armed with metal pipes guarded the hospital morgue where Shin's body was kept. Shin was among thousands of students who tried to avoid police roadblocks in an effort to reach Kwangju for protest rallies marking the 10th anniversary of the country's bloodiest civilian uprising. Several thousand riot police who have been deployed in the vicinity of the provincial government building since protests erupted Friday stayed mostly out of sight today, apparently to avoid antagonizing the radicals. In the past, the deaths of protesters have triggered massive demonstrations. Kwangju Mayor Choi In-kee issued a statement saying the protests against the government of President Roh Tae-woo and the presence of U.S. troops in Korea had been instigated by outsiders. ``Violence will no longer be tolerated,'' the statement said. Other government officials also demanded an end to the protests. Radical student leader Lee Ki-hon told a news conference today that the ruling Democratic Liberal Party was ``a violent group.'' He demanded that police officials be held accountable for Shin's death and said those responsible should resign. The student protesters say that if the police roadblocks had not been in place, Shin would not have had to jump from the train. The District Prosecutor's Office in Kwangju said today that testimony from train workers and other witnesses indicated Shin died of injuries suffered when he jumped from the train. The prosecutor said an autopsy would be performed to confirm the finding. On Sunday, violence erupted for a third straight day when some 10,000 protesters shouting ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' battled riot police in downtown streets. Protesters tore up sidewalks for projectiles to hurl at police and built bonfires at a dozen intersections to light firebombs. Police fired 40 warning shots from automatic rifles to stop about 50 protesters who tried to stage a firebomb attack on a police station. Seoul's Dong-a Ilbo newspaper said 84 police officers and more than 200 protesters were injured. The newspaper said 6,342 people had been arrested nationwide since May 18, most of them in Kwangju, about 150 miles south of Seoul. Of those arrested, it said 15 were formally charged with instigating unrest, 35 sent before a summary court judge, and 130 others remained under investigation. The rest were released with warnings, it said. The protesters are demanding the resignation of Roh, a former army general who was a key leader of the martial law government that crushed the 1980 Kwanju pro-democracy uprising. They claim the January merger of the ruling party with two opposition groups is a scheme by Roh to prolong his power. Kwangju citizens claim U.S. military officials condoned the military crackdown on the 1980 uprising, which claimed some 200 lives and left more than 1,700 injured.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Crews Begin Spreading Fertilizer to Clean Alaska Shores
DOC.TEXT: Exxon has begun applying fertilizer to the shoreline to speed the breakdown of oil from the Exxon Valdez spill. The company got the go-ahead from the state to use the chemicals after a debate over whether they would cause even more harm to the environment. ``Our key objective is to achieve the appropriate level of cleanup with the least amount of stress on the environment,'' said Bob Mastracchio, Exxon's technical manager for the cleanup. This year's cleanup got under way May 1 with crews removing tar by hand. Exxon expects to complete its work by mid-August under a cleanup plan approved by the government's cleanup coordinator, said Exxon spokesman Joe Tucker. The Exxon Valdez ran aground on a reef on March 24, 1989, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound. After the spill, thousands of cleanup workers and hundreds of boats worked for weeks to clean hundreds of miles of shoreline. Thousands of birds, mammals and other wildlife were killed in the nation's worst oil spill. Late Sunday, workers began spreading nitrogen and phosphorous fertilizer in liquid and granular form. The chemicals promote the growth of bacteria that eat oil. Three boats and 29 people were deployed to coat about 175 square yards, Tucker said. Only three three or four workers were actually applying the fertilizer. Most of the rest were federal, state or company officials observing the work. To protect birds and other wildlife from the potentially harmful chemicals, crews put out brightly-colored helium balloons and roped off the treated areas with flags. The cleansing action of the tides will reduce the risk after the first 24 hours, Exxon said. The company plans to use the fertilizer on about 400 sites. Last year, 74 miles of shoreline were treated. A multi-agency team will monitor the sites for six weeks to help judge the effectiveness of the technique, bioremediation, and decide whether second applications of the fertilizer will be made during the summer, Exxon said. State officials and some environmental groups have expressed fears that the chemicals might further pollute the water or harm wildlife. After weeks of debate, the state finally agreed with Exxon and the Coast Guard that the technique should be used despite the risks.

DOC.HEAD: Storms From Texas to North Carolina, Rain in Northeast and West
DOC.TEXT: Rain drenched much of the Northeast today, and thunderstorms cut a swath through the South. Today's forecast called for showers in the Pacific Northwest. A band of thunderstorms was expected to stretch from central Texas through North Carolina. Rain fell early today from Washington, D.C., to Portland, Maine, and west to Cleveland. Forecasters said parts of Indiana and Illinois also could expect rain. The National Weather Service issued severe thunderstorm warnings overnight for parts of Oklahoma and Arkansas. On Sunday, thunderstorms rattled through parts of Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana. In Alabama, trees downed by high winds damaged homes in Lamar and Walker counties, and near Tuscumbia. Storm winds also downed power lines and damaged cars around Birmingham. Winds gusted to 58 mph at Argo. In Georgia, storms felled trees and power lines near Alpharetta, Cumming and Gainesville. Winds also downed trees at Westminster, S.C. In Mississippi, hail pounded Clarksdale, Grenada Lake and Greenwood, and winds gusted to 65 mph in Jackson and downed trees and power lines in Warren County. Storms in central Louisiana produced dime-size hail at Alexandria. In Missouri, a tornado tore through two trailer parks on the edge of Rogersville, 12 miles east of Springfield, injuring up to 10 people. In southeastern Wyoming, storms spawned a tornado at Cheyenne. The high temperature for the nation was 109 degrees at Laredo, Texas.
