DOC.HEAD: Jubilant Mills College Graduates Bring Balloons to Commencement
DOC.TEXT: Jubilant seniors at Mills College brought yellow balloons to graduation to celebrate their successful fight to keep undergraduate men out of the women's school. Rain delayed the ceremonies for several hours Sunday but didn't dampen the enthusiasm of the 428 graduating seniors. The liberal arts school announced May 3 it would admit men as undergraduates to boost enrollment and revenue. Students boycotted class, demonstrated and took over the campus for two weeks, and the trustees dropped the idea Friday. Mills College has 777 students, including men in graduate programs. Administrators wanted to boost enrollment to 1,000. The school's alumnae came up with financial pledges that should help Mills preserve a $70 million endowment. They also promised to help recruit more students. On Sunday, 178 women received bachelor's degrees. An additional 250 men and women were awarded graduate degrees. Because of the shutdown, diplomas won't actually be delivered for several weeks, pending verification of student records. During commencement, students held colorful umbrellas and yellow balloons as ``a memento and a symbol of unity,'' said Shirley Weishaar, associate director of the school's career center, which distributed the items. Mills is one of three all-women colleges in California and one of 94 colleges in the nation with all-female undergraduate classes.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather in at Least Five Cities for AIDS Remembrance Vigils
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people in at least five cities from San Francisco to the nation's capital marched or lit candles to remember those stricken with AIDS. Barbara Bush took part by putting lighted candles in 10 White House windows. About 20,000 people marched with candles Sunday to San Francisco's City Hall for a solemn reading of the names of recent AIDS victims. As gospel music played through speakers, the crowd shouted, ``We will not forget!'' after each name. Similar activities were held in New York, Washington, Salt Lake City and Seattle in an annual observance organized by the Mobilization Against AIDS, based in San Francisco. ``It helps to remember,'' said Harvey Maurer, an AIDS activist at the San Francisco ceremony. He was diagnosed with the disease 1{ years ago. ``From an intellectual point of view I still can have hope that we'll see a cure. But I also know that I keep losing people.'' Mrs. Bush participated by placing a candle in each of 10 White House windows facing Pennsylvania Avenue, said spokeswoman Anna Peres. The candles were in the second-floor, residential portion of the White House, she said. ``I think this is encouraging that the lights are in the White House windows tonight. It's a wonderful symbolic gesture of support,'' said Andy Ilves, spokesman for the Mobilization Against AIDS. The Washington group Lifelink estimated 2,000 people lit candles and walked around the reflecting pool in front of the Lincoln Memorial. In New York, about 25,000 people walked 6.2 miles and raised nearly $4 million for the fight against AIDS, organizers said. ``We are here because we care, because we love life, because we love each other,'' playwright-actor Harvey Fierstein said. The walk benefited the Gay Men's Health Crisis, an AIDS service organization in New York. Mayor David Dinkins addressed walkers at Lincoln Center, reiterating his call for an end to prejudice. ``As we work together to conquer the health crisis of AIDS we must also work to promote unity, to denounce discrimination and division,'' he said. Several groups in Seattle also observed the vigil, first organized in 1983 to draw attention to the toll AIDS was taking on homosexuals. About 250 people gathered for a candlelight ceremony in Salt Lake City to remember 186 Utah residents killed by the disease and 272 others diagnosed with it. ``You can either be living with AIDS or dying with AIDS,'' said Carolyn Spriggs, whose son has the disease. ``We are raising him as a child with AIDS who is living.'' The largest and loudest contingent in San Francisco came from the largely gay Castro District, where as many as 10,000 joined the pilgrimage to City Hall, many dressed in black, most holding hands or linked arm and arm, and some in drag. ``This is the 1,000 points of light that Bush hasn't looked at,'' said Robert George, a member of the Interfaith AIDS Coalition. ``We need more funding to help the AIDS programs which are just strapped and overburdened.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Reed Returns Home to Uncertain Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf pvs, `I couldn't ...' to ADD that interview took place over the phone from Washington.
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Frank Reed once traveled to exotic places around the globe. Now he heads home nearly broke, facing the likelihood of living with his wife and child in his mother's small apartment. Held captive 42 months in the Middle East, Reed returns to this Boston suburb, this weekend or early next week, from a Maryland hospital. To friends and relatives, Reed, 57, was an almost larger-than-life figure, an adventurer who studied at Harvard and trekked to the North Pole, the jungles of Brazil and the Australian outback before accepting a post at Beirut's International College in 1977. ``He was a fellow who would take risks,'' said Reed's brother, Edward. ``He stayed in Beirut even though he knew it was dangerous.'' In 1986, Reed was seized from his car by gunmen and held by Moslem extremists for the next 3{ years. When he was released last month, a pale, gaunt Reed told of being beaten when he tried to escape and of being chained and blindfolded for months at a time. Reed's family and friends are preparing, as best they can, for his return home. Reed has no job, little money and no home of his own. ``A lot of pieces need to be put together,'' said Bob Langston, his son-in-law. ``Medical care, housing, these all need to be dealt with. A lot depends on his health.'' Reed is still weak, and relatives say he has memory lapses, apparently caused by beatings to the head. ``He remembers the past very well but had troubles with things that happened the other day,'' said his mother, Leota Sprague, 91. His wife, Fahima, holds a job at an insurance firm. She and her 9-year-old son, Tarek, have lived with Reed's mother in her two-bedroom apartment for almost a year. Reed had money invested in his school in Beirut, Sprague said. But that was lost when the school was bombed out. ``I was blessed, I had a job to come back to,'' said Jeremy Levin, former Cable News Network bureau chief in Beirut who was held by kidnappers for 13 months before gaining freedom in 1985. ``But the recovery will be slower for him. He has no job, so the Reeds may have a problem. It could be a terrible burden on him.'' Former hostages and psychiatric experts said Reed may also have to overcome psychological hurdles to readjust to an ordinary life, after having lived under extraordinary circumstances. Freed hostages also find they are sudden celebrities sought by reporters and talk show hosts. ``I couldn't get back into the normal swing of things at first,'' Levin said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``We all did a lot of public speaking, and that put off the time of getting into a normal routine.'' Once the spotlight turns elsewhere, former hostages are left to deal with the everyday world. ``When you're a hostage, you give up thinking about the future because you have no future, you could be killed tomorrow,'' said Brian Schulman, a psychiatrist in Bethesda, Md., who has counseled Vietnam veterans and concentration camp victims. ``Then you're released, and suddenly you have to think about mundane things like getting a job.'' ``All people know about Frank Reed is that he's been a hostage,'' Schulman said. ``But hostages eventually become old news, and that's when they have to re-establish their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes into Home; Pilot Killed
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine plane missed a foggy runway at Cuyahoga County Airport and crashed into a house, killing the pilot, police said. Ken Kemper escaped out a window of the home and was not hurt Sunday night. The crash destroyed his living room, said Fire Chief William J. Heckler. The plane went down less than a half-mile from the airport, hitting a tree, a pole, the ground and then the house, said Robert Shea, manager of the airport east of Cleveland. The pilot's identity was not immediately released. Officials said he was from Menton and was returning from South Carolina. Kemper said he had just gone into a back bedroom when he heard a crash and saw a ball of flame. ``I thought the plane came right down my driveway,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Exiles Stage High-Seas Democracy Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Cuban exiles sailed across the choppy Florida Straits for a high-seas democracy rally at the edge of Cuba's waters, where they threw wreaths and bottles carrying messages overboard. Cuban patrol boats looked on but took no action against the flotilla that left Sunday from Key West. Backers of the expedition said it was a demonstration against Cuba's communist government and a celebration of the anniversary of Cuba's independence from Spain. ``It was a very emotional moment for all the Cubans who participated in this,'' said Julio Rebull of Miami. Some smaller boats among the 34 that started out turned back because of 8-foot waves. The boats rendezvoused about 20 miles off Cuba's northern coast, then sailed parallel to the coast for six miles before heading back to Key West. For seven minutes, a Roman Catholic priest read prayers over the radio to a Cuban radio monitor at a Havana lighthouse, Rebull said. The operator acknowledged the message but made no further response. The current on the straits carried the flowers and bottles north, away from Cuba. Coast Guard cutters monitored the flotilla by radar but provided no escort. Coast Guard officials earlier warned the exiles to lodge verbal protests but to go along peacefully if they were intercepted by Cuban forces. At least one boat carrying a TV news crew from Miami had to turn back in the middle of the windswept Gulf Stream because of seasickness.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Rips Through Trailer Parks; At Least 11 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with one more injured, five businesses hit, damage estimate, details. Pick up last graf, `In Rogersville ...'
DOC.TEXT: A tornado tore through two trailer parks on the edge of town, injuring at least 11 people, including two children in critical condition, authorities said. A 3-year-old boy and his 6-month-old brother were found in the rubble of a trailer home and were taken to St. John's Regional Medical Center in nearby Springfield, said Rogersville Police Chief Mike Crider. Several residents were cut by broken glass when the tornado hit Sunday night, he said. The National Weather Service said nine people were treated at hospitals in Springfield, 12 miles miles west of Rogersville, and released. About a half dozen mobile homes were reported damaged or destroyed at one trailer park and nine at another. Authorities had to contain leaks from the propane lines and tanks that served homes in one of the parks. ``I had just laid down and suddenly there was no warning or anything, just a loud boom,'' Donna Manning said. ``A tree went through my 14-year-old son's bedroom window and a limb went into the hallway.'' She said her son was not in the bedroom when the storm hit. Crider said damage would exceed $2 million. Five businesses were destroyed or heavily damaged, including a camper shell manufacturer, a tanker truck repair service and an auction barn, he said. In Rogersville and elsewhere in southwestern Missouri, the violent weather also brought golf ball-size hail. Winds up to 90 mph blew out windows and downed power lines and tree limbs.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Flocking to Site of Oil Spill
With PM-Alaskan Spill
DOC.TEXT: Stan Stephens has run charter boats out of this port town for 20 years, but this is the first season Bligh Reef rated a mention on his tourist brochure. A growing number of tourists want a look at the site of the nation's largest oil spill, even though only a buoy marks the spot where the Exxon Valdez rammed the reef. ``We're including that in our new schedule to make sure we swing by it because it has become part of the history of the sound,'' Stephens said. ``Everyone last year asked. We had thousands of oil questions.'' Inquiries from prospective tourists for the summer were up 30 percent over winter, the Valdez Convention and Visitors Bureau said. Marilyn Mitchell of the Valdez Chamber of Commerce chalks up some of the interest to ``morbid curiosity.'' ``I think it's human nature,'' she said. ``People want to see where things happen. There's been a lot of interest in people wanting to come and just see where the ship went off the reef.'' It's too soon to know how many people actually will visit, but bookings at some motels, bed and breakfasts and charter companies are going strong, said the visitors bureau director, Gary Kranenberg. Indications are that this year's tourist visits may not only rebound to 1988 levels of about 100,000, the highest on record, but could surpass that number by up to 15 percent. About a dozen travel writers normally come to Valdez before the tourist season. This year 150 dropped in, Kranenberg said. Most visitors come to Valdez for sightseeing and fishing. The spill, which occurred in March 1989, simply made more people aware of the town's scenic beauty, tourism officials say. Still, this year's tourists want to know where the oil was. ``We didn't get down to exactly where the spill happened, but we're all curious about it,'' said Wilbur Langley, 55, of Lecanto, Fla., who took a charter tour of the sound last week with his wife and other tourists. ``We were interested and asking the captain about it. He explained everything to us.'' Even if tourists get to the reef, it is under water with a single buoy for a marker. The sound's oil-tainted shores are even less accessible and some will be bustling with Exxon cleanup crews this summer. ``A lot of people are disappointed there's nothing to see,'' said Howard Clifford, spokesman for Seattle-based Princess Tours, which runs cruise ships into Prince William Sound. Charter plane and helicopter services also get requests to take tourists to see remnants of the spill. ``I tell them it's at least a one-hour round trip at about $548 an hour,'' said Walt Woodrow, manager of ERA Helicopters. ``Not many of them want to do it after they hear that.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Gold was..' with 1 graf to CORRECT that gold was higher. Pick up 3rd pvs, `The dollar...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed in European trading this morning, supported by indications that U.S. interest rates will not be reduced again soon. Gold was higher. The dollar closed at 153.25 yen, up 0.35 yen from last Friday's close. In four trading days, the dollar has gained 1.95 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.35 yen. ``There was no major market-affecting news other than slowdown of the lowering of U.S. interest rates,'' said a dealer with Daiichi Kangyo Bank in Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But I don't expect the dollar's upswing to continue much further.'' Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: _1.6580 West German marks, up from 1.6478 _1.4165 Swiss francs, up from 1.4045 _5.5890 French francs, up from 5.5555 _1.8605 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8550 _1219.50 Italian lire, up from 1212.00 _$1.1765 Canadian, down from $1.1782 The British pound was quoted at $1.6930 from $1.6910 late Friday. Within the European Monetary System the lira was trading steadily after Italy's discount rate was cut by one point to 12.5 percent. Italy lowered its discount rate Saturday, citing the need to restore stability to the EMS after the lira had strengthened significantly against the other European currencies this year. The lira's rise against the French franc had been a particular source of tension, and the Bank of Italy intervened heavily last week to support the franc. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $373.40 a troy ounce this morning, up from $369.75 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold was quoted at $373.40 an ounce, up from $370.60 bid late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped 22 cents an ounce from Saturday's level to close Monday at $374.08. Silver bullion traded at $5.14 a troy ounce, up from $5.06 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Petunia the Burro Wins Beauty Contest, Again
DOC.TEXT: A toothy beauty named Petunia captivated judges for the third time in five years to become the most beautiful burro in Texas. Petunia ``has a fine set of teeth,'' said Henry Wolff Jr., a newspaper columnist who founded an annual beauty contest for the pack animals under the auspices of the Better Burro Bureau. The judges picked Petunia in 1986, last year and again Sunday. Burros were brought to Texas by Spanish settlers in the early 1700s. Dictionaries point out that burros and donkeys are asses, but Wolff, who works for The Victoria Advocate, said he makes it a point to avoid using that word in reference to the competition he began in 1983. ``We do say, `This is the place where people can come and show their blank-blank-blank if they've got one.' That's the fun of it,'' he said. Entrants are dressed up in costumes. Nearly 4,000 people attended the contest at The Texas Zoo. One contender this year did not help her cause when she walked down the runway. ``Let's just say she wet down the stage,'' Wolff said. ``I think she had been saving up for the contest.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Coast Guardsmen Helped Cocaine Smugglers in Florida
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guardsmen in the Florida Keys have been jailed for helping cocaine smugglers, a Coast Guard spokesman said. But the alleged corruption outlined in the report aired Sunday on NBC's ``Expose'' program actually was detected and dealt with two years ago, according to Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Karonis, spokesman for the Coast Guard's Miami-based southeastern district. NBC cited unidentified federal authorities and Tom Cash, chief of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office in Miami, as saying the guardsmen disabled patrol boats and sold drug agents' codes to smugglers. Raids by federal authorities on smugglers' homes turned up records of secret radio frequencies, patrol schedules and codes used in radio transmissions for every law enforcement agency in the Florida Keys, NBC reported. Federal authorities investigating the relationship between smugglers and U.S. Coast Guardsmen have named the case ``Operation Tempest.'' NBC reported that at least 15 guardsmen assigned to the Islamorada station worked either for or with the smugglers they were assigned to catch. Four guardsmen stationed at Islamorada, all crew members of a high-speed boat used to intercept smugglers, are in jail for taking cocaine from the smugglers, NBC reported. ``The Coast Guard people involved were brought to justice and are in jail right now. The system works and they're paying for it,'' Karonis said after the broadcast. The NBC report did not say when the alleged corruption occurred. Karonis, contacted late Sunday by the Associated Press, said the Coast Guard detected the alleged conspiracy _ and stopped it _ back in 1988. Art Sola, the commander of the crew that stole cocaine from smugglers for themselves, was convicted on drug charges handed down in July 1988 by federal prosecutors in North Carolina, Karonis said. Karonis said other guardsmen were indicted a short time later. They were convicted in separate trials later that year, he said. He added that that few newspapers reported the case at the time. Sola told NBC he and his fellow guardsmen decided one afternoon to steal a kilogram of cocaine from a shipment they found floating in the Atlantic Ocean 15 miles offshore. The cocaine, according to the report, was worth as much as $16,000 _ about the same as the guardsmen's annual salary at the time. ``It's easy. It's very easy. It's a lifestyle down there. Everybody knows somebody who's involved in drugs or smuggling. It's very easy to get hooked on,'' Sola said in a jailhouse interview. NBC reported that another guardsman, identified on ``Expose'' as Bobby Gosnell, also got caught up in drug smuggling. Gosnell, NBC reported, bought a $500,000 home with an airstrip after leaving the Coast Guard. But Gosnell wound up murdered, shot in the chest in a dispute over whether he should cooperate with the federal investigation, NBC said. Karonis, contacted at home late Sunday, said he had no further details on the case, but he expressed confidence that little corruption remains at the Islamorada office today. ``Every agency has bad apples, but we're confident the vast majority of Coast Guard people are honest and do their job every day,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Disaster Team Arrives as Lava Claims Another House
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano destroyed yet another house and posed an immediate threat to several more, and a federal disaster relief team arrived to help the victims of the seven-year eruption. One house was 100 feet in front of the seven-mile-long river of molten rock, Craig Hindle, a Hawaii County civil defense spokesman, said late Sunday. The house and six others were expected to be destroyed in 24 hours by the flow that was filling up low spots and then oozing forward, Hindle said. Earlier Sunday, the eruption that began Jan. 3, 1983, claimed its 143rd house. Just 30 homes remain in Kalapana; 67 have been destroyed since April 4. Before traveling to Hawaii Island, members of the federal disaster relief team met with local officials in Honolulu. President Bush issued a disaster declaration Friday for this region of Hawaii Island. Some victims eligible for disaster relief had their homes destroyed seven years ago, while other homeowners have been unable to collect insurance because, although rendered useless by surrounding lava flows, the houses are still standing.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Invites Syria's Assad to Attend Arab Summit
DOC.TEXT: A top Iraqi official met today with Syrian President Hafez Assad to deliver an invitation to an Arab League summit. It was the first time a senior Iraqi official has visited Syria since the feuding Arab countries broke diplomatic relations in 1979. Assad and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein are bitter enemies. Iraqi Justice Minister Akram Abdul-Qader arrived today aboard a special Iraqi Airways jet carrying an invitation to the May 28 summit from Saddam. Abdul-Qader later met with Assad and Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, according to Assad's presidential spokesman, Gibrane Kouriem. There was no immediate word on Assad's response to the invitation. So far, Assad has resisted appeals from Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and other Arab leaders to attend the summit in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, in the interest of Arab unity. Saddam has called the summit to discuss Arab concerns about the expected influx of tens of thousands of Soviet Jewish emigrants to Israel as well as a perceived ``Israeli and imperialist threat'' to Iraq. Saddam is seeking to rally support after Britain and the United States accused Iraq of trying to smuggle nuclear bomb triggers. Iraq denied it is developing nuclear weapons but threatened to use chemical weapons against Israel if attacked. The Iraqis are also seeking to rally support after Iraq-bound shipments said to contain parts for a ``super gun'' capable of hitting Israel were seized in Britain, Greece, Turkey and Italy. In a related development, Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat arrived in Baghdad today to meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, who invited him to the summit. The PLO announced Friday that Arafat had sent a letter to Damascus urging Syria to reverse its stand boycotting the meeting. Mediation efforts earlier this month by Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt all failed. Assad has remained adamant that neither he nor other Syrian officials will attend. Assad has insisted that the location and agenda of the summit must first be discussed at an emergency meeting of foreign ministers of the 22-member Arab League in Tunisia. But Iraq has said the summit will go ahead as planned in Baghdad, preceded by a foreign ministers meeting on May 22 in the Iraqi capital to set the agenda. Syria and Iraq are ruled by rival wings of the Baath Arab Socialist Party. Their feud deepened during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war when Syria supported the Iranians, while most Arab countries sided with Iraq. Saddam, in turn, has supported Christian factions in Lebanon that are opposed to Syria, thwarting Assad's efforts to end the 15-year-old Lebanese civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Tutu Appearance Disrupted By JDL
DOC.TEXT: Radical Jewish activists jeered Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu outside a church after he delivered a sermon there, prompting the church's officials to cancel an outdoor reception that was to follow. ``Why do you hate Jews?'' members of the militant Jewish Defense League shouted Sunday at the Nobel laureate. ``Tell him to lay off Israel,'' said JDL spokesman Irv Rubin, apparently referring to Tutu's support of a Palestinian state. The Rev. George Regas, rector of All Saints Episcopal Church, said Tutu was not angered by the protesters. ``Please let them say what they want to say, because in my country they are not allowed to do that,'' Regas quoted Tutu as saying. Before the confrontation, Tutu had delivered an hourlong sermon to an overflow crowd. Worshipers began lining up about 7 a.m. to hear the 9 a.m. service. Up to 2,000 people were turned away and watched outside on TV sets. The outspoken church leader touched on various subjects, including world hunger and South Africa, and referred to those gathered as ``God's collaborators'' and said they could change the world and bring an end to injustice and oppression. Tutu is on a fund-raising and speaking tour of Southern California. On Saturday, he visited Disneyland with his wife, two daughters and 3-year-old grandson. ``I think this was a tremendous inspiration from God to have this kind of place for people to come and unwind and discover how human we are when we are childlike,'' he said in praise of the theme park.

DOC.HEAD: Agents Seize $25 Million in Erroneous Drug Bust
DOC.TEXT: Federal and local narcotics agents mistakenly seized $25 million during what they believed was one of the Dallas area's largest ever drug-tainted cash shipments, the Dallas Times Herald reported today. Agents converged on an American Airlines jetliner arriving at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport Wednesday after an anonymous tip led them to the baggage compartment where they found eight canvas bags filled with $25 million. But the agents later learned that the transfer of cash was legitimate. A commercial New York bank, which authorities declined to name, was transporting currency from the San Antonio branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said Phil Jordan, special agent in charge of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office in Dallas. The money was loaded at the San Antonio airport; after its arrival at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport, it was to be transferred by armed, private security guards to a New York-bound jet, West said. Apparently, the courier accompanying the shipment told someone at the San Antonio airport he was transferring a large amount of cash. That person called local authorities, who then alerted airport officials. ``Money is transferred in cargo holds all the time,'' said Robert Boykin of the Federal Reserve in Dallas. ``There's nothing unusual about that.'' But DEA officials said they disagree with Boykin and plan to continue investigating the transfer. ``We have never seen it before. It was a strange thing to all of us,'' said Danny West, a DEA agent in Fort Worth. ``It was unusual that they would put that kind of money into the belly of an airplane.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Preaches Peace in Face of Heightening Racial Tensions
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins preached racial conciliation after a week of heightening citywide strife, then led a memorial parade for Martin Luther King Jr. through midtown Manhattan. ``Tensions are threatening to plunge New York into a cycle of fear and frustration that could tear us apart,'' Dinkins said Sunday at the Salem United Methodist Church in Harlem. He urged the city to begin healing recent wounds before the scheduled visit next month of South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. ``When Mandela arrives, I hope he will find a city at peace, not a city tearing itself apart,'' Dinkins told worshipers. In the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, marchers for racial harmony met pickets chanting for the boycott of two Korean-owned grocery stores Sunday as a large police riot squad looked on. No confrontation occurred, said police who outnumbered opposing advocates by 3-to-2. The store boycotts and the severe beating of a Vietnamese man by a young black man combined with two jury verdicts in the Brooklyn racial mob-killing case of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins to inflame racial tensions. Blacks were angered on Friday when a jury acquitted the accused mob leader, 19-year-old Keith Mondello, of murder and manslaughter charges. He was convicted on lesser charges. A day earlier, another jury convicted Joseph Fama, also 19, of second-degree murder in the Aug. 23 shooting. At the church in a burned-out Harlem neighborhood, Dinkins knelt alone before the altar and buried his face in his hands. Then he stepped to the pulpit. ``We all come from somewhere else. We came here to escape prejudice. All of our people share an ancestry of oppression,'' he said. Dinkins praised Erasmus Hall High School students who last week defied the store boycott and shopped at one of the Korean groceries. The boycott was triggered by accusations that a black woman was attacked in a store in January by Korean-American employees who suspected her of shoplifting. Some in the church crowd punctuated the mayor's words with outbursts of affirmation and an elderly woman repeated, ``Bless you! Bless you!'' Later, Dinkins led a mostly black throng of marchers in the Martin Luther King Jr. memorial parade up Fifth Avenue. ``This year's parade is more important than any other,'' Cardinal John O'Connor said as he greeted the crowd on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. ``King would have been very saddened, but he would have told all of us to calm down.'' Silk-costumed Korean schoolchildren joined black students atop the ``Gorgeous Mosaic'' float _ a rotating globe with ethnic flags whose name is Dinkins' favorite term for New York's ethnic diversity. A weekend poll revealed that 75 percent of New York residents believe race relations have worsened. The Daily News-Eyewitness News Poll of 670 people, 213 of whom are black, found both races agreed that racial tensions are building. Three percent said relations were better and 20 percent said they were the same. The 75-percent figure was up greatly from August 1985, when a similar poll found 20 percent felt race relations were worse, 30 percent said they were better, and 43 percent said they were the same. The poll had a margin for error of plus or minus 4.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Three More Palestinians Killed In Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with new violence; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers fatally shot three Palestinians and wounded 94 others today in violent protests over the massacre of seven Palestinians by an Israeli gunman. The suspect, Ami Popper, appeared in court today with his feet shackled and under heavy guard. Magistrate David Muallem extended Popper's detention for 15 days and ordered him to undergo a psychiatric evaluation. Police said the suspect was suicidal after breaking up with his girlfriend. Black flags flew from cars and rooftops in the West Bank and graffiti called for armed struggle against Israeli rule of the occupied territories. Seven Palestinians were shot and killed by Israeli soldiers and more than 700 were wounded in rioting after Sunday's massacre in the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Letzion. The Palestinians were killed as a group of Arab laborers from Gaza waited at the Roses junction. Witnesses said Popper ordered 50 workers to sit in a line, then opened fire with an assault rifle, killing seven and wounding 11. Sunday's rioting was the worst bloodshed in the 29-month-old uprising since April 15, 1988, when 17 Palestinians died in riots after PLO military leader Khalil Wazir was slain in Tunis, reportedly by Israeli commandos. In recent months, the level of violence had declined. Today's dead brought to 705 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians since the uprising against Israeli rule began in December 1987. Another 216 have been slain by fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators. Forty-three Israelis also have been killed. The unrest persisted today in the occupied lands and spilled over into Arab areas of Israel. The army poured in hundreds of reinforcements and clamped a curfew on about 1.1 million Palestiniams in the occupied Gaza Strip and much of the West Bank. U.S. State Department officials called on Israel's army to use restraint and prevent further bloodshed. The most intense violence occurred in the Gaza Strip where the massacre victims lived. Stone-throwing protests broke out in at least 10 neighborhoods and refugee camps in defiance of the curfew. In Gaza City's Sabra quarter, troops shot in the head a 17-year-old girl, Manal Suleiman Mohammed al-Dairy, who died on the operating table at Shifa Hospital, Arab reports said. Safia Suleiman Jarhoon, 55, died in Nasser Hospital after being struck in the chest by a bullet during a clash in the Khan Yunis refugee camp, the reports said. In Rafah, Arab reporters said 22-year-old Imad Ahmad al-Atamneh, was fatally wounded in the neck during clashes in the Shabura refugee camp. An additional 94 Palestinians suffered wounds from either live ammunition or plastic bullets, the reports said. The army confirmed there was unrest in Gaza and that several people were wounded but said it was checking other reports. In the northern Israeli city of Nazareth, Israeli Arabs staged a sympathy strike, and violence also broke out there. Arab witnesses said 10 youths were wounded by police gunfire and six were arrested. A half-dozen firebombs were thrown at police and four officers were injured by stones and bottles. A pall of black smoke hung over the city, roads were blocked with garbage carts and burning tires and Israeli cars were stoned. A crew of the British television agency Visnews came under gunfire from Israeli police during the unrest, according to an agency employee. No injuries resulted. Israel radio said outlawed PLO flags fluttered from electricity poles in other Israeli-Arab towns. It said Swastikas were painted on walls in Haifa and stones blocked the streets in the town of Kfar Kassem. In the Jabaliya refugee camp, where the intefadeh _ or uprising _ began nearly 2{ years ago, roads were covered with stones and columns of black smoke could be seen from burning tires. Youths hurled stones at a convoy of four army vehicles that brought a press pool into Gaza for the first time since rioting began on Sunday. In Amman, Jordan, police said a Palestinian gunman shot and wounded 10 people including nine French tourists aboard a tourist bus today. Police said the man also had a dagger and some people might have been stabbed. The man said he was taking revenge for the Palestinian slayings in Israel, according to police. And in Nicosia, Cyprus, an Arab caller contacted a Western news agency and claimed responsibility for the slaying of an Israeli restaurant owner Sunday night. He also said it was in revenge for Sunday's massacre. Slogans spray-painted on walls in Bethlehem said, ``yes to armed struggle'' and followed the lead of Palestinian leaders in blaming Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government for creating a climate of anti-Arab violence. Maj. Gen. Natan Vilnai, commander of troops in Gaza, said he was concerned there would be more revenge attacks. ``I believe the other side is going to do its utmost to give new life to the uprising,'' he said. ``There is no doubt we have a grave problem here with the growing number of people who have a personal account to settle with us.''

DOC.HEAD: Increase Of Tuberculosis Due to AIDS Virus Poses New Health Threat
DOC.TEXT: Tuberculosis is alarming health officials again because it's posing new health threats with its connection to the AIDS virus. A 35 percent increase in tuberculosis in 1989 in Newark, N.J., has caught the attention of health officials, who had been previously recording with satisfaction a slow, steady decrease in TB cases over the last few decades. They attribute the 5 percent national increase in TB cases in 1989 to the ravages of the AIDS virus, which destroys the body's immune system and leaves victims open to TB infection, Dr. Philip C. Hopewell of San Francisco General Hospital said Sunday. Hopewell and other health officials discussed the link between AIDS and TB during the a four-day World Conference on Lung Health in Boston, which ends Wednesday. About 4 percent of Americans identified as having the AIDS virus also have been diagnosed as being infected with tuberculosis, said Dr. Dixie E. Snider Jr., director of the division of tuberculosis control at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. The American Lung Association estimates that 20,000 Americans a year develop TB. In parts of Africa, where AIDS is already a health risk, tuberculosis has become epidemic, said Dr. Annik Rouillon, executive director of the International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease in Paris. ``The combination of the two is really catastrophic,'' she said. Snider stressed that tuberculosis, unlike AIDS, is a curable disease and called for TB screenings at drug rehabilitation programs, prisons or other places where AIDS tests are being administered. Snider also said doctors should administer TB tests to all persons testing positive for the HIV virus since TB may not be readily diagnosed in AIDS patients. ``It's important we get control of the situation,'' he said. In Wyoming, the Centers for Disease Control recorded no new cases of TB in 1989, demonstrating that it is a condition that can be controlled and cured, according to Dr. Lee B. Reichman, director of the pulmonary division of the University of Medicine and Dentistry in New Jersey. ``I have never heard of a rise of the magnitude seen in New Jersey or, on the other hand, the hope generated by no cases in one state,'' Reichman said. Moreover, unlike AIDS, TB is a highly contagious disease that can be spread by airborne particles coughed up by a person with untreated, clinically active pulmonary TB. Untreated, tuberculosis kills about 50 percent of its victims within two years, according to the Centers for Disease Control. Snider said sustained contact is necessary for TB transmission, and would not pose new problems for AIDS victims already fighting discrimination in jobs and housing. However, he noted that there had been an increase in positive TB tests among AIDS health workers. Tuberculosis is caused by a bacterium that commonly affects the lungs but can attack almost any organ. For the last three decades, it has been preventable and curable through multiple drug therapy, Snider said. Snider said 10 million to 15 million Americans have been infected with the tuberculosis germ, but only a small percentage of them develop the disease because their immune system was strong enough to prevent the disease from developing. If, however, a person's immune system is impaired by poor nutrition or weakened by the HIV virus, people can develop active TB. ``TB is long known as an opportunistic organism,'' Hopewell said. The doctors said U.S. minority groups have become increasing susceptible to TB. Snider said there has been a 150 percent increased in cases of TB among young blacks in New York City. Tuberculosis can be effectively treated, even in AIDS patients, underscoring efforts to screen persons for the disease, the doctor said. Reichman noted that most American have forgotten about the problems of TB; from 1981 to 1984, TB cases declined an average of 6 percent per year according to the Centers for disease control. But, he said, ``TB is back with a vengeance.'' While associated with poverty and crowded living conditions, TB through history has ravaged both the poor and the famous. TB victims include Henry David Thoreau, Washington Irving, Franz Kafka, Ring Lardner, Somerset Maugham and Vivien Leigh. An estimated 3 million persons a year die worldwide from TB, according to the American Lung Association.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Denies He Protected Aide During Leak Investigation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to remove redundant full reference to Ayer
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has denied that he tried to cover up when a top aide showed deception on a lie detector test while the Justice Department was investigating news leaks. Thornburgh said Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer, the agency's departing No. 2 official, was ``sadly misinformed'' in criticizing how the case was handled. Ayer, who has resigned effective Friday, has charged that Thornburgh mishandled the Justice Department's investigation in an attempt to protect Robert S. ``Robin'' Ross, a longtime Thornburgh aide. ``The attorney general was participating in an effort to prevent appropriate disclosure and evaluation through established procedures of the activities that earlier this week resulted in Robin Ross' abrupt removal from office,'' Ayer was quoted as saying in Sunday's Los Angeles Times. Sources speaking on condition of anonymity have told The Associated Press that Ross and another veteran Thornburgh aide, David Runkel, showed deception on polygraph tests. The tests were given as part of the department's attempt to find who leaked information to reporters about an investigation into alleged financial irregularities involving Rep. William Gray, D-Pa. Thornburgh, appearing Sunday on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program, replied, ``Absolutely not'' when asked if he tried to conceal Ross's performance on the lie detector test. ``We conducted an investigation into leaks. There was no evidence that tied any person on my staff to the unauthorized disclosure of that information,'' Thornburgh said. The attorney general also said that failing a polygraph test ``isn't evidence of wrongdoing _ not in our courts of law.'' Thornburgh said he was saddened that Ayer ``feels that he has to lash out against his former colleagues, but there is no basis in fact for that kind of story.'' The Justice Department has had a series of high-level personnel changes since Ayer announced May 11 that he was leaving. Ross resigned three days later as Thornburgh's executive assistant to head a new international division. He said he plans to leave the department in two or three months. Runkel was reassigned from serving as spokesman, taking on the new title of director of communications. In the Los Angeles Times interview, Ayer criticized the way Thornburgh dealt with the Gray case. Thornburgh had ordered the investigation into the leaks _ which Democrats charged were politically motivated _ last spring while Gray was running for the House majority whip post. Ayer said Thornburgh tried to keep the results of the leak investigation out of the hands of the department's internal watchdog agency, the Office of Professional Responsibility. Unsuccessful in that attempt, Thornburgh then refused to follow the unit's recommendation for further investigation, Ayer told the newspaper. Ayer did not return a telephone call Sunday seeking comment. Thornburgh reported to Congress in September that the criminal investigation of the Gray leak failed to identify the source of the story. The attorney general told Congress the head of OPR had concurred with the conclusion to drop the investigation. But Ayer said the internal watchdog agency had never seen the report. When Ayer and two other top officials suggested to Thornburgh on Jan. 30 that he remove himself from the case and turn it over to the watchdog agency, the attorney general ``rejected our advice out of hand,'' Ayer said. Ultimately the case went to OPR, after prodding by Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. After the OPR review was finished, Thornburgh turned the issue over to Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, who concurred with the attorney general's decision not to discipline any department officials.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Mutant Turtles Exist Offscreen, Too Sick to Fight Crime
DOC.TEXT: Teen-age mutant turtles exist offscreen, but they are too sick to fight crime or eat pizza. The unhappy green sea turtles suffer from an Elephant Manlike disease called fibropapilloma that causes tumors internally and on their eyes, mouths, necks, flippers, jaws and tails. ``Some tumors get larger than a softball and often reoccur,'' said Dr. Elliot Jacobson, a professor of wildlife medicine at the University of Florida. ``They make the turtle grotesque. Teen-age mutant green turtles are for real.'' Afflicted turtles have been found off the Florida Keys, in the Indian River Lagoon on Florida's east coast, the Caribbean and near the Hawaiian Islands. In the Keys, the plague is so widespread that experts say 50 percent of the endangered green sea turtles are sick or dying from fibropapilloma, which causes them to become blind or drown. ``It's an epidemic among green sea turtles comparable to AIDS in humans,'' said Jacobson, who is heading a yearlong research project. Fibropapilloma was first identified by marine biologists in 1938. Its cause is unknown, but the strongest theory blames a virus possibly aggravated by water pollution, Jacobson said recently. Scientists are unsure how many green turtles are left in the world, but they are considered an endangered species. They feed on seagrass and marine plants. Between 1983 and 1989, 134 green sea turtles were found dead, Jacobson said. Seventy had fibropapilloma. Hardest hit were turtles in the teen-age stages of life. ``It's hard to find a turtle that is healthy and free of growths,'' said Tina Brown, a conservationist and Keys charter boat captain. She and Richard Moretti recruited Jacobson to study the disease at the Hidden Harbor Marine Environmental Project center, Moretti's state-licensed marine sanctuary on Key Vaca, where Marathon is located. Six healthy turtles on loan to the Cleveland and the Toledo zoos were returned to Florida this month to participate in the study. Five others from Clearwater, found to be free of fibropapilloma but suffering handicaps, round out a study group. The 11 turtles are being housed in an 800-gallon fiberglass tank, where they will be infected and exposed to the disease in hopes of finding its agent and ultimately the key to a serum. Before fibropapilloma, the most serious threat to the species was its popularity as the main ingredient in soup. In the 1950s, a federal law was passed prohibiting the sale or import of green sea turtles. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are cartoon creations depicting pet turtles transformed into pizza-eating, martial arts-loving crime fighters. They were recently introduced in live-action form to the movies, where they vaulted to box office success.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Examine Troubled Heart-Liver Transplant Patient
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Jones' condition today. Picks up 5th graf pvs: ``Remember I'm ...'
DOC.TEXT: Doctors have begun tests on Stormie Jones to determine whether the 12-year-old is rejecting her second transplanted liver. The world's longest surviving heart-liver transplant patient returned to Pittsburgh on Sunday from her home in White Settlement, Texas, after routine tests revealed high liver enzyme levels _ a sign of possible organ rejection. ``They wanted to get it under control before it got to be a big problem,'' said her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell, who traveled to Pittsburgh with Stormie. ``Her numbers had been real good up until the last couple of weeks.'' Stormie was listed in fair condition today at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. She walked into the hospital and met briefly with reporters at the behest of staff members who wanted to assure the public she was not critically ill. ``Remember I'm getting paid for this,'' she joked. ``And this is just for five minutes.'' Stormie said she felt fine and was not experiencing any symptoms. Her evaluation is expected to take several days. In the meantime, doctors plan to give Stormie an experimental anti-rejection drug intravenously, hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo said. Stormie usually takes the drug, FK-506, orally and at a lower dose. At age 6, Stormie received a new heart and liver at Children's in 1984 to control a congenital condition that left her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. Before the operation, Stormie had suffered two heart attacks and had undergone two triple coronary bypass operations. Stormie received another liver Feb. 20 after doctors discovered hepatitis had damaged her donor liver. Her heart was unaffected.

DOC.HEAD: New Studio Park Opens for Sneak Previews
DOC.TEXT: Universal Studios Florida opens its doors to the public today for three weeks of ``sneak previews'' of a Hollywood-style attraction expected to draw up to 6 million visitors in its first year. Guests will pay slightly more than half-price and take in about half of the major rides and shows that will be functioning at the 444-acre Orlando complex. The $600 million attraction will officially open June 7. Universal, owned by California-based MCA Inc. and Rank Organisation PLC of London, is going up against stiff competition. The Disney-MGM Studios theme park, which opened a year ago just a few miles down the highway, is based on a similar concept. It reported about 8 million clicks of its turnstiles during that period. Universal, which relied heavily on filmmaker Steven Spielberg's advice and creativity, will spend $110 million in marketing the Florida park before the year is out, officials said. Not to be outdone, Disney has stepped up its own marketing campaign for its three Florida attractions: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center and the 135-acre Disney-MGM Studios. Entertainment analysts say the company is spending at least $50 million this year on advertising. Disney officials underestimated the appeal of their studio park, and Disney Co. Chairman Michael Eisner earlier this year announced a 10-year expansion plan that would double its size. In the head-to-head competition with Disney, Universal executives emphasize the new park's larger size, the greater number of rides and shows and what they consider more sophisticated technology. ``Across the board, we're going to deliver a more impressive entertainment experience,'' MCA Vice President Jay Stein said in a recent interview. Universal's major lure is Hollywood's great movies. ``See the Stars. Ride the Movies,'' is its theme. Top shows are based on King Kong, E.T. the Extraterrestrial, Jaws the killer shark, the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and other spectaculars. ``We've made the movie experience something that fans can see, feel, touch and smell,'' said Spielberg. After its grand opening, the theme park segment of the complex will feature 15 major rides and shows and a ``back lot'' tour with 50 locations, including Hollywood Boulevard, a New England village, the San Francisco Wharf and New York street sets. ``Sneak Preview'' tickets are $15.95 for adults and $12.95 for children. After June 7, when all rides and shows are operating, tickets will be almost twice that much.

DOC.HEAD: Actor on Nickelodeon, Theater
DOC.TEXT: Dale Engle, an actor whose long career included roles on Broadway and, most recently, on the Nickelodeon Cable Network, has died of colon cancer. He was 68. Engle died Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was known to many as Smitty on the children's show ``Pinwheel'' on Nickelodeon. But Engle, who lived in Manhattan, had appeared in more than 200 plays since 1942, including a Broadway production of ``The Student Prince'' and national companies of ``Inherit the Wind'' and ``The Best Man.'' A World War II veteran, he also appeared on many live television programs beginning in the 1950s. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Sheehan, and his son, Todd Engle, both actors of Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: National Salvation Front Headed For Victory In Free Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with more returns, comments; CORRECTS exit poll numbers; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist, appeared headed for a landslide victory today after Romania's first free elections in 53 years, but opponents complained of fraud. The first official returns showed Iliescu with an overwhelming lead in the presidential race. His National Salvation Front appeared to be headed for victory in the parliamentary elections, which would allow him to govern without forming a coalition with the opposition. With more than 2 million ballots counted from Sunday's election, Iliescu won 89 percent to 8 percent for the National Liberal Party's candidate, Radu Campeanu, and 3 percent for Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party. A West German exit poll of 14,539 voters showed Iliescu winning 83 percent of the votes nationwide. Campeanu was second with 11 percent, and Ratiu had 6 percent. The chief U.S. observer of the elections said Romania had taken ``a very giant step toward democracy,'' but that allegations of fraud must be assessed before the United States determines whether the election was free. Gov. Garrey E. Carruthers of New Mexico urged the government to establish a freer press and set up an independent panel or allow the courts to investigate allegations of campaign and voting irregularities. But others among the 500 foreign observers said that although there were some irregularities, they were not significant enough to alter the outcome. The two opposition candidates alleged numerous instances of election fraud. Ratiu said Carruthers' assessment of the election would mislead the American people and President Bush. ``There was no semblance of democracy about it,'' Ratiu said. The Front took power during the bloody December revolution in which Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted and executed after 24 years of rule. One of the main opposition charges against Iliescu and the Front was their refusal to relinquish control over radio, television and newsprint. The opposition argued that control of the airwaves gave the Front an unfair advantage in the campaign. The Central Electoral Bureau estimated that at least 85 percent of Romania's 16.8 million eligible voters cast ballots for president and 506 representatives to the two-chamber Parliament. The Front won a projected 66 percent of vote for seats in parliament, said the exit poll, conducted by the West German polling group INFAS at the invitation of the Romanian government. In second place was the National Liberal Party with about 10 percent of the votes, the poll said. The party representing the country's 2 million Hungarian minority had 6 percent, the Ecological Movement had 5 percent and the Peasant Party had 3.5 to 4 percent, according to the poll. No margin of error was given. The projected victory for the front would break a string of victories by centrist and conservative political parties in free elections held elsewhere in Eastern Europe following the ouster of old Communist regimes. Communist reformers were overwhelmingly defeated in elections earlier this year in East Germany and Hungary. Iliescu, a 60-year-old former Communist Party secretary who fell out of favor with Ceausescu, praised citizens for their high turnout and calm behavior, the state news agency Rompress reported. Iliescu appeared to have capitalized on his standing as interim president. He also gained popular credibility by opposing Ceausescu in 1971 and then suffering demotion. The Front, a loose grouping of former Communists, workers and technocrats, advocated a more gradual pace of introducing free market reforms, while the main opposition parties called for a swift dismantling of the Communist system. Ratiu and Campeanu, both exiles who returned from long years abroad only after the revolution, were vulnerable to charges that they were not in Romania during the harshest Ceausescu years. Voters had 88 parties to choose from, and slow-moving lines of 200 or more people snaked outside polling places. The original closing time of 11 p.m. was extended when it became clear the voting was much slower than expected. Still, voters relished the chance to cast ballots in their first free election since 1937. In Timisoara, the cradle of the December revolution Vancea Aurel, 78, a retired civil engineer, was elated as he waited to cast his ballot for the National Liberal Party. ``Until December, I was convinced that neither I nor my children would ever take part in free elections,'' said Aurel, who voted in the 1937 elections. Up to 3,000 anti-Communist demonstrators gathered in Bucharest's University Square, where a round-the-clock protest has gone on for weeks to demand the ouster of Iliescu and other former Communists from the government. ``We hoped (Iliescu) would have a greater opposition,'' said Dan Trandafirescu, a 33-year-old engineer. Opposition parties have called Iliescu a ``neo-Communist'' who would merely continue the old system under a new name. Iliescu says he wants to lead the country toward social democracy. Although the pre-election campaign occasionally turned violent, no major incidents were reported Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Affectionate Turner, Fonda Steal Show at CNN Birthday Bash
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner and Jane Fonda stole the show at the anniversary party for Cable News Network, the Turner brainchild that turns 10 on June 1. The Turner Broadcasting chairman and the actress-aerobics empress drew crowds wherever they turned during the celebration Sunday night at CNN Center, headquarters for Turner's media empire. But the attention didn't keep them from being openly affectionate. While a highlight tape of CNN's first 10 years was shown on a giant monitor, Ms. Fonda wrapped her arms around Turner's waist and rested her chin on his shoulder and he caressed her hand. ``I have to kind of pinch myself to realize it's gone by so quickly,'' Turner said in brief remarks about CNN's first decade. ``The next 10 won't be quite as exciting as the first 10, but stay tuned.'' The party, which drew about 3,000 guests, was timed to coincide with the opening of the National Cable Television Association's annual convention, next door at the Georgia World Congress Center. Among other celebrities attending were Maureen Reagan, talk show host Larry King, CNN anchorman Bernard Shaw and U.S. Rep. Edward Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House telecommunications subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Money Given Mormon Missionaries Not Deductible
DOC.TEXT: Monies given directly to Mormon missionaries by the church's members are not deductible donations under federal tax law, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today. The court said Congress did not intend to make such direct contributions tax-deductible. Ruling against an Idaho couple who were denied the tax deductions for subsidizing their two sons' missionary service, the justices resolved conflicting federal appeals court rulings that allowed such tax deductions in six states and banned them in nine states. Writing for the court, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said that under federal tax law ``a taxpayer may claim a deduction for a charitable contribution only if the contribution is made to or for the use of a qualified organization.'' Giving money directly to a church missionary is ``not a contribution to or for the use of the church'' under federal tax law, O'Connor said. She said such contributions could qualify as tax-deductible if held in ``a legally enforceable trust for the qualified organization or in a similar legal arrangement.'' The decision is a defeat for Harold and Enid Davis of Idaho Falls. They had been represented before the high court by Rex Lee, former U.S. solicitor general and now president of Brigham Young University. The couple spent about $7,600 subsidizing their son Benjamin's missionary work in New York City in 1980-81, and about $1,500 for their son Cecil's missionary work in New Zealand in 1981. Money was deposited into each son's bank account, and the subsidies for neither son exceeded amounts set by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The Davises made the deduction claims belatedly, unsuccessfully seeking refunds of $1,779.71 and $2,613.10, respectively, for the two years. The Bush administration, although contending that lower court rulings against the Davises should be upheld, had urged the justices to review the case. Government lawyers noted that 36,000 Mormon missionaries currently are serving the church. The case is Davis vs. U.S., 89-98.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Lawyer Named to High Navy Post
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon announced today the appointment of Ben Rose, a lawyer in Lima, Ohio, and former leader of the Republican minority in the Ohio House of Representatives, as principal deputy assistant secretary of the Navy for installations and the environment. Rose was a member of the Ohio House from 1973 to 1986, becoming the ranking minority member of the Finance@Appropriations Committee and then minority leader. He returned to law practice after an unsuccessful campaign for state auditor in 1986. Rose was a Navy officer 1961 to 1966, serving on an Atlantic fleet destroyer and later in Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes in Estonia, But Not Widespread
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with strikes in Estonia, but not widespread, quotes; CORRECTS spelling of Estonian government spokesman's name to Kopytyn sted Koptyn; pickup 7th graf pvs, `The pro-Moscow...'
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Moscow forces in Estonia stopped work today at several factories to protest the republic's independence drive, but the strikes were not widespread, spokesmen said. ``There are no obvious strikes going on currently in Tallinn,'' Estonian government spokesman Juhan Hindov said from the capital. But Artur Kopytyn, a spokesman for the Russian Strike Committee in Tallinn, said 15 large plants were fully on strike, and limited work stoppages were reported at dozens of others. Journalist Tarmu Tammerk disputed those figures, however. He said that at an electrical and technological facility Kopytyn said was on strike the employees voted to continue working. ``These plants are not vital for everyday life,'' said Tammerk, editor of the weekly Estonian Independent. ``They are not integrated into the Estonian economy. They could be on strike every day with no effect.'' The work stoppage made no visible impact on Tallinn, he said. Hindov said pressure for the strikes was coming from pro-Moscow administrators at the factories and from the Russian Strike Committee, ``but people do not want to strike.'' Sixty-five percent of the republic's 1.8 million population is Estonian. Russians comprise 28 percent, with Ukrainians and Byelorussians making up the rest. In the breakaway republic of Lithuania, lawmakers who rejected Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call to suspend their March 11 declaration of independence met in committees today to consider a counteroffer, a spokesman for the legislature said. The pro-Moscow forces in Estonia and Latvia have stepped up their activities in the week since Gorbachev branded the secession campaigns in those republics unconstitutional. On Sunday in the Latvian capital of Riga, 1,193 pro-Moscow delegates representing cities and rural areas gathered to form the Committee for the Defense of the Constitution and the Rights of Citizens of the U.S.S.R., the Tass news agency reported. The group _ mostly Russians and other ethnic minorities in the republic _ said the Latvian parliament did not have the legal authority to declare independence earlier this month, Tass said. It also criticized leaders of the pro-independence People's Front as not living up to their words concerning the equality of all people. Russians and other minorities in all three Baltic republics complain that they are discriminated against as a result of the independence movements. ``We have been brought together by our common concern about the fate of Soviet power in Latvia,'' said Alfred Rubiks, first secretary of the Communist Party in the republic. He said the pro-Moscow Communist Party would ``step up its activity'' in the coming days. According to Tass, the committee's aims include ensuring the operation of the Soviet constitution and the laws of the U.S.S.R. and Latvia, to ensure social and legal protection of residents, and to consolidate social and political forces ``recognizing the people's socialist choice and intending to renew socialism and the Soviet federation.'' Gorbachev imposed an economic embargo on Lithuania following its declaration of independence, and on May 14 he decreed that Latvia's and Estonia's steps toward independence violated the constitution. He has not taken any punitive actions against those two republics. Last Tuesday, pro-Moscow forces in Latvia and Estonia tried to enter the parliament buildings of both republics, but they were turned back by police and pro-independence crowds. Gorbachev's embargo on Lithuania, in effect for more than a month, has cut off all supplies of oil to the republic and nearly all supplies of natural gas, and has reduced supplies of other key raw materials. Thousands of people have been laid off as a result. Over the weekend, Lithuanian lawmakers agreed to reject Gorbachev's demand that they suspend their declaration of independence because it would mean accepting Soviet control over Lithuania, said legislator Zigmas Vaisvilas. Parliament ordered a committee to work out other compromise proposals to offer Moscow, he said. Lawmakers were following the advice of Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, who met with Gorbachev Thursday night in Moscow. The Soviet president's meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene ended a two-month refusal to talk with the Lithuanians, and came after the republic offered to suspend laws implementing independence in exchange for negotiations. In meeting Mrs. Prunskiene, Gorbachev may have been influenced by the fact that she planned to meet the following day with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker was in Moscow setting the agenda for the superpower summit at the end of May. ``It's very clear Gorbachev wanted to show President Bush before the summit that he has started negotiations, and he is not demanding the same things as in the beginning,'' Vailvilas said.

DOC.HEAD: Township Tense Following Clashes That Leave Seven Dead
DOC.TEXT: Scores of police armed with semiautomatic weapons and shotguns patrolled the township of Thabong today after police fired on black protesters, killing seven and injuring about 40. Groups of black protesters angry over the deaths Sunday and Monday roamed the township outside Welkom in Orange Free State armed with knives, axes and rocks, witnesses said. They said protesters used burned-out vehicles, trees and burning tires to set up barricades across some streets, and at least one police vehicle was set ablaze, according to the witnesses. Welkom, a gold mining center, has been the scene of repeated clashes between whites and blacks. Two whites were killed last week in a clash with blacks. ``It's very tense. Buildings have been burned out and it's not safe to move,'' said one journalist, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Army troops called in to help police Sunday night were not in sight Monday, witnesses said. Police said Monday that officers opened fire on a protest by blacks returning from a rally. Four people were killed and about 40 people hurt, they said. The superintendent of Welkom hospital, Dr. Flip Nel, said three more people died Monday. A police spokesman said on condition of anonymity that police were forced to fire because the blacks had attacked police and buildings and were trying to march to the white town of Welkom. A white man was stabbed and beaten by blacks Sunday night when he arrived in Welkom on a bus used mostly by blacks, the independent South African Press Association reported. Police said Monday that three people had been killed in separate incidents in other parts of the country in the previous 24 hours. The dead included a black man killed in Natal Province when police opened fire on protesters who stoned a police vehicle, police said. In Welkom, right-wing whites have formed ``white defense groups'' and carry out armed patrols in the town. Blacks have retaliated with a boycott of white shops and businesses that has harmed the local economy. The government has made repeated efforts to try to ease the rising racial tension in the town. Whites are angry and fearful about government plans to end white-minority rule and share power with blacks. Top government officials held talks in Welkom last week to try to ease the situation. Police and army reinforcements have been rushed to the town to help maintain order, but clashes have continued. White and black leaders trying to end apartheid fear violent confrontations could derail political negotiations. The government and black groups have appealed to people to avoid violence.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Gunman Shoots, Wounds Tourists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CLARIFY that 2 of wounded were stabbed; pickup 4th pvs, `Police immediately...'
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian armed with a pistol and a dagger boarded a tour bus near a downtown tourist site today and attacked its occupants, wounding nine French tourists and a Jordanian, officials said. Amman police chief Fadel Ali said one of the French victims was seriously wounded and the rest only slightly. However, French Ambassador Dennis Bouchard said two of the French tourists were in critical condition. He cited reports from embassy officials at Amman hospitals. Two of the wounded were stabbed, and the rest were shot, officials said. Police immediately arrested the Palestinian and identified him as Ahmad Badwan, 28, a Palestinian from the Gaza Strip who carries a temporary Jordanian passport and lives in Amman. A witness, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he heard in a police report that Badwan reported he acted to avenge the killing of seven Palestinians by an Israeli near Tel Aviv on Sunday. Police did not immediately confirm the witness' report . The incident occurred near the Roman amphitheater in downtown Amman, a popular tourist site. The man boarded the bus with 30 tourists aboard near the Roman amphitheater in downtown Amman and ``threatened to shoot if anybody moved,'' a police official said. ``The tourists were scared and many started shouting, which pushed the gunman to fire in all directions from a 7mm pistol,'' the official said. An Interior Ministry spokesman said Badwan fired until he ran out of ammunition, then continued his attack with a dagger before surrendering to police. Hundreds of bystanders crowded around the tourist bus after the incident, which took place on a downtown street close to the amphitheater. Ali said French President Francois Mitterrand called Bashir Hospital to inquire about the condition of the injured. He said King Hussein and Crown Prince Hassan rushed to the hospital to see the victims. Fakri Hussein, manager of the Royal Tours Agency which handled the French group, said the tourists arrived in Jordan Friday for a weeklong visit.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Law Requiring Payments to Help Crime Victims
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld a law requiring people convicted of federal crimes to pay money into a fund to help crime victims. The court unanimously rejected arguments that the law is unconstitutional because it originated in the Senate, and not in the House of Representatives. The Constitution states that all revenue-raising bills ``shall originate in the House of Representatives.'' But the court, relying on an 1897 decision, today said the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is not a revenue-raising measure. The law is aimed at generating money to offset the costs of helping crime victims by imposing ``special assessments'' against convicted criminals. Justice Thurgood Marshall invoked the 1897 decision in stating: ``A statute that creates a particular governmental program and that raises revenue to suppport that program, as opposed to a statute that raises revenue to support government generally, is not `a bill for raising revenue' within the meaning of the (Constitution's) origination clause.'' The case stemmed from a $50 assessment against a man named German Munoz-Flores, who was convicted of helping an illegal alien evade inspection by immigration officials in San Diego County, Calif., five years ago. Munoz-Flores was placed on probation for two years. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the assessment, agreeing with arguments that the law was a revenue-raising measure enacted improperly by Congress. Today's decision reversed the 9th Circuit court's ruling. The ruling is a victory for the Bush administration even though the justices rejected its argument that the case presented a ``political question'' federal courts should avoid. ``The government may be right that a judicial finding that Congress has passed an unconstitutional law might in some sense be said to entail a lack of respect for Congress' judgment,'' Marshall said. ``But disrespect, in the sense the government uses the term, cannot be sufficient to create a political question,'' he said. ``If it were, every judicial resolution of a constitutional challenge to a congressional enactment would be impermissible.'' The case is U.S. vs. Munoz-Flores, 88-1932.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises `Close Consultation' With Moscow on Conventional Forces
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 6 grafs after 4th graf pvs, bgng, The president ... to UPDATE with Bush's speech; picks up 5th graf, He flew...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is vowing to keep pushing for agreement with Moscow on a treaty to reduce conventional forces in Europe, while hailing dramatic progress in other arms talks. ``In the arms control area, there's been some progress. There still remain some other problems,'' Bush said after breakthroughs were announced over the weekend in negotiations to limit chemical weapons and long-range nuclear missiles. Bush said that, despite the current impasse on cutting troops and tanks in Europe, he still hopes that a 35-nation treaty setting reduced conventional force levels throughout Europe can be signed by year's end. The president today was completing a four-day speaking tour with Republican fund-raising appearances in Portland and in Los Angeles. At today's Republican fund-raiser for Oregon Attorney General David Frohnmayer, called for a balancing economic concerns with environmental priorities. His remarks did not appear likely to win praise from environmentalists, who have been battling timber interests here over the status of the Spotted Owl. His administration must decide by June 23 whether to designate the owl as an endangered species. To do so would close off vast tracts of Oregon forest to lumbering activities. ``Common sense tells us to find a needed balance,'' Bush said. ``I reject those who would ignore the economic consequences of the Spotted Owl decision.'' ``The jobs of many thousands of Oregonians and whole communities are at stake,'' he said. About 150 to 200 people demonstrated outside the hotel where Bush spoke, burning American flags and newspapers and setting off smoke bombs. Several were arrested. He flew to Portland on Sunday afternoon to speak at a ceremony dedicating a planned memorial to slain police officers. Speaking with reporters on Air Force One, Bush said he was pleased with the outcome of Secretary of State James A. Baker III's four-day negotiating session in Moscow. Baker brought home an agreement to end chemical weapons production and reported major progress on a long-sought treaty to limit strategic nuclear weapons. Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev are expected to act on both measures at their May 31-June 3 summit in Washington. ``I'm satisfied with the progress made in Moscow that we'll have a good summit,'' Bush said. However, he tempered his remarks by noting a lack of progress on an agreement to reduce troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. ``We've got to get that done,'' Bush said of the conventional force reduction treaty. ``Until it's totally finished we've got to stay in close consultation'' with the Soviets. ``This is important not only to us but to all of Europe,'' he said. Bush had predicted a year ago that the agreement would take six months to a year to complete. The stalemate raised the likelihood that an agreement would not be ready to be signed, even in a preliminary form, at the upcoming superpower summit. Asked if a conventional arms limitation treaty is still possible this year, Bush said, ``Oh sure, sure.'' The Soviets apparently are reluctant to scale back their forces in Central Europe to 195,000 unless the German army is sharply reduced as well. Impending prospects of a reunified Germany apparently are increasing Soviet resistance to the troop cutback. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft told reporters earlier that the Soviets ``are now stonewalling'' on a conventional arms treaty. Bush said he had talked to Baker on Sunday and that the secretary of state was ``generally upbeat'' although he added, ``Obviously there are some things we still have to work out.'' The president said other U.S.-Soviet differences were sure to be aired at the summit _ including long-festering disputes over Cuba and Afghanistan. Bush also cited differences over German unification. ``Nobody thought it would be easy. So we're just plugging away on a wide array of agenda items,'' he said. Bush declined to clarify conflicting reports about what Baker told Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene while in Moscow. U.S. officials with Baker denied statements by some sources that he had urged the Lithuanians to suspend their declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. Bush used his speech at the Portland Police Memorial ceremony on Sunday to accuse the Democratic-led Congress of watering down his proposed anti-crime package. The legislation is scheduled for debate in the Senate this week. ``For the past year, it's gathered dust in the House and spawned weak imitations in the Senate,'' Bush said. ``This country deserves better.'' His bill calls for expanded use of the death penalty and relaxed rules on what police can do in gathering evidence. The Senate version includes a proposed ban on the manufacture of semi-automatic assault rifles, which the administration opposes. Bush also joined the debate over the northern spotted owl, saying the jobs of timber-related workers must be considered before forests are cordoned off to protect the owl. ``There's a lot of people who's livelihood is threatened out here. ... We've got to be concerned about the human equation as well as the environmental equation,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: States May Impose Requirements on Liquor Sold at Military Bases
DOC.TEXT: States may impose labeling and reporting requirements on liquor sold at U.S. military bases within their borders, the Supreme Court ruled today.
