The court said North Dakota's regulation of liquor sold at two military bases there does not violate a clause of the Constitution which generally gives federal policy priority over state regulations. North Dakota requires that all liquor sold in the state be distributed through a state-controlled system. The state said out-of-state liquor distributors must put a label on each bottle sold at the Grand Forks and Minot Air Force Bases stating that the liquor is for consumption only at the military installations. The state also said suppliers must report monthly on how much liquor they shipped into the state. The high court upheld the labeling regulation by a 5-4 vote and the reporting rule, 9-0. Justice John Paul Stevens, in the court's main opinion, said both regulations are valid under the 21st Amendment to the Constitution which repealed Prohibition and gave states sweeping power over liquor distribution. Stevens said the rules serve the state's legitimate interest in preventing diversion of liquor from military bases into the civilian market. He was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Sandra Day O'Connor. Justice Antonin Scalia voted to uphold both regulations, but for different reasons he expressed in a separate concurring opinion. Voting to uphold North Dakota's reporting regulation but strike down the labeling requirement were Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and Anthony M. Kennedy. Federal officials challenged North Dakota's liquor regulation system on grounds it violates a federal policy aimed at assuring liquor sold at clubs and stores on military bases would be purchaed by the government at the lowest possible price. Profits from the military base sales are used to pay for recreational activities. Federal officials said it could cost the government $200,000 to $250,000 more each year if they are forced to abide by North Dakota's rules. They said the regulations will force them to purchase more liquor from North Dakota distributors at higher prices. Today's ruling overturns a 1988 decision by the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The National Beer Wholesalers' Association supported North Dakota's appeal, saying the state has good reason to be concerned about diversion of liquor from military bases. The case is North Dakota vs. U.S., 88-926.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Charged with Killing Administrator, Setting School on Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with investigators quotes as saying victim walked in on suspect as he was trying to blow up school, further quotes, details; editing to trim and conform. No pickup. ^By TERESA M. WALKER
DOC.TEXT: A science teacher was preparing to blow up the school when the assistant principal discovered him, so he shot the administrator to death, according to a published report today. Teacher Donald Givens is charged with fatally shooting Assistant Principal Ron Wallace, then setting fire to the school, authorities said. Givens was being held without bond today at the county jail. The Nashville Banner, quoting unidentified investigators, reported today that Givens was planning to set off an explosion at Hickman County High School when Wallace walked in on him Sunday morning. At the time, Givens was turning on propane gas spigots in the school science department where candles were burning, investigators told the Banner. Superintendent Wayne Qualls said several student complaints had been lodged against Givens, 50, and the teacher may have feared he was about to lose his tenured job. Tennessee Bureau of Investigation agent Tom Brown declined to comment on what Givens was doing at the school except to say ``he was engaged in an activity that he didn't want public.'' ``He panicked and reacted without thinking and set the fire to cover it up,'' Brown said. Wallace had gone to the school Sunday morning to put the finishing touches on the school's auditorium for the afternoon baccalaureate service, Principal Rick Brewer said. Wallace was shot twice, and the body was discovered in the hall outside the biology laboratory at the burning building, said police Officer Howard Choate. Candles were used to set fire to the science wing, and fires were also set in two libraries, Choate said. He said the natural gas in the biology lab had been turned on, but firefighters shut it off before it ignited. Firefighters put out the blazes 20 minutes after the 9 a.m. call. Damage, estimated at $150,000, was confined to books and materials. Before his arrest Sunday, Givens had come to the school and acted like one of the bereaved faculty, sitting at a desk and drinking coffee, Fire Chief Kenneth Thompson said. He would not say what led authorities to Givens. Wallace also was athletic director at the school in this town of 2,800 people 40 miles southwest of Nashville. His daughter, April is the class president for this year's graduating seniors at the 850-student school. Classes were canceled today. ``It's a devastating and shocking situation,'' said English teacher Linda Richardson. ``It's really frightening. This is something that you just don't expect to happen. This community is really close knit.'' Wallace had been named assistant principal last fall and was set to complete his certification for principal in July, Ms. Richardson said.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses: Police Fire on Mourners, Killing 30
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with official comment; pickup 4th graf pvs, `For five...'
DOC.TEXT: Security forces fired today on a crowd of 100,000 Moslems carrying the body of a slain Kashmir religious leader, and at least 30 people were killed and 200 injured, witnesses and doctors said. State government officials in Srinagar could not be reached for comment, but an official source in New Delhi gave a different version of the shooting. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said militants opened fire on paramilitary troops ``and in the cross-fire approximately 20 people were killed and 40 were wounded.'' Witnesses and doctors in Srinagar said 30 bodies and at least 200 people with bullet wounds were brought to Soura hospital. Many of the injured said 40 more bodies still lay on the streets in the Srinagar neighborhood where the firing occurred. The city was under curfew and further details were not available immediately. For five months soldiers and other security forces have been deployed in Srinagar, the capital of Kashmir, in a bid to control a violent campaign by Islamic militants who want the predominantly Moslem state to secede from mostly Hindu India. The situation has renew50 N.Y. Merc spot per troy oz. Fri. n.q.-not quoted, n.a.-not available

DOC.HEAD: Government Landlord Left Out of the Money
DOC.TEXT: Two championship caliber golf courses in Scottsdale, Ariz., produce revenues for the city, local business and the professional golf tour _ leaving only the landowner without a dime. The landlord is the federal government. The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation had the option of investing money to help turn a desert into golf courses _ and cutting itself in on subsequent revenues. The bureau chose not to invest, instead simply leasing the land free to the city. Scottsdale then built the courses and hired a subsidiary of the profit-making PGA Tour to run them. The city gets a percentage of the course fees and sales. The PGA makes a profit. The U.S. government, which has the land as a flood control project, gets nothing. The deal doesn't look like a hole in one to Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., whose House Government Operations environment subcommittee is investigating the arrangement and plans to hold a hearing this summer. ``It begs the question of whether they had any common sense and whether they had any vision,'' Synar said of the federal lease negotiators. ``If people in the private sector did these kind of deals, they'd be fired.'' Bureau of Reclamation officials said their purpose was to turn the area into a public recreation project and avoid maintenance costs. ``If we had to do it again, we would look at the revenue issue a lot more in depth,'' said Bob Michaels, a bureau recreational resource specialist in Phoenix who helped negotiate the lease. City officials had a similar purpose in avoiding maintenance costs, but still arranged to benefit from course revenues. And their vision didn't stop with the golf courses. Scottsdale allowed a resort, the Princess, to be built next door on non-federal land. The city's room tax on the resort brings in additional revenue. The Princess also generates business for the courses _ 17 percent of the tee times are reserved for its guests. Of the two courses, the Stadium Course is site of the Phoenix Open each January, and everyday players pay $75 in fees to use the facility during the peak winter season. The adjoining Desert Course charges $16 in the winter to allow use by players of average financial means. The courses are on 180 acres within the Paradise Valley Flood Detention Basin of the Central Arizona Project, a canal that brings Colorado River water to about 60 communities. The property is a vital holding basin to protect the canal in case of a flood. Bureau of Reclamation officials note that they made the land available for recreation, avoided $300,000 in annual maintenance costs and still preserved the acreage for flood protection. The bureau gave Scottsdale, which adjoins Phoenix, a free 50-year lease in June 1985. Carder Hunt, assistant to Scottsdale's city manager, said the city spent $18 million _ $13 million from bond issues _ to develop the courses, which opened in 1987. The Bureau of Reclamation is allowed to invest up to 50 percent of the cost of adapting water project land for recreational use. The bureau can then cut itself into any revenue arrangement from the recreation facility. ``At that time, the issue of revenue generating capacity never came up to the degree it does today,'' said Michaels, the bureau's lease negotiator. ``We didn't know the resort would come in, and that the Phoenix Open would come in there. At the time, we knew the thing could probably carry itself, but we didn't go into an economic analysis,'' he said. ``I guess we didn't go quite far enough. We didn't examine the issue of large revenues.'' Judy Weiss, special projects manager in Scottsdale's Community Services Department, said city officials made it clear during negotiations that it needed a package deal that would include two high-caliber golf courses and a resort. Reclamation Bureau spokesman Bob Walsh in Phoenix said the agency saves its investments for projects that ``draw from a diverse and large geographical area.'' The golf courses, he said, ``will get some out-of-state traffic, but by and large it will be from the local community.'' But Bill Reid, the general manager of the courses, estimated half of the more than 130,000 golfers at the facilities each year are from out of town. Hunt said the Phoenix Open drew 350,000 spectators in January, pumping an estimated $13 million into the Phoenix-Scottsdale economy. Scottsdale expects that combined revenues it receives from the courses and the resort will exceed the city's annual bond debt beginning in 1992. The city's cut of sales and fees at the courses generated $485,000 in 1989. Scottsdale only retained $100,000, however. The rest went to the Tournament Players Club, under a temporary arrangement to repay the club for money loaned during construction.

DOC.HEAD: British Told Rest of Europe Sees Them as Slobs
DOC.TEXT: A magazine Monday berated the British for their dress and manners, saying European neighbors regard them as the slobs of the continent. ``We go out without combing our hair, wear the same shoes two days running and throw rubbish out of our car windows,'' complained ``She,'' a monthly women's magazine. It said other Europeans consider British men ill-mannered and chided British women for dressing badly and shouting at their children in public. If the British want to join the ``nouveau European'' elite, the magazine said, their manners, attitudes, habits and appearance all need ``a complete overhaul.'' Tips offered by the magazine include never leaving home unless groomed immaculately, remembering to wish everyone good morning, afternoon or evening, and walking with ``dignity and grace.'' Other guidelines: spending more on personal appearance, displaying family loyalty, drinking more mineral water and never eating junk food in the street.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 130 Dead or Missing After Passenger Ship Sinks
DOC.TEXT: A passenger ship sank off Indonesia, and more than 130 people were dead or missing, the official Antara news agency reported Monday. The agency said 56 bodies had been recovered from the sea since the ship, the Macoli, went down Sunday night in heavy seas off East Kalimantan, about 1,000 miles northeast of Jakarta. The search for victims or survivors was continuing, it said. The ship, with a capacity of 110, was carrying at least 133 people from Nunukan to Tarakan, both in East Kalimantan province, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Aftershocks Recorded in Quake Area, Still No Injury Reports
DOC.TEXT: Seismographs recorded strong aftershocks to a major earthquake that shook a refugee-filled area of Sudan, but there were no reports Monday of significant damage or injuries. The aftershocks in southern Sudan followed Sunday morning's quake, which measured 7.5 on the Richter scale. A quake of that magnitude is capable of causing widespread destruction. The earthquake zone is about 700 miles south of Khartoum, Sudan's capital, an area of sprawling wetlands and trackless jungle. The shock was felt in towns controlled by the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army and in government-held areas. Juba, the south's largest urban area, is 60 miles southwest of the epicenter. It is full of people displaced by the war and living mainly off supplies from international relief agencies. Damage was said to be negligible in government-controlled Juba, a collection of low-slung British colonial style mortar buildings and refugee shanties. Because of refugees, its population is roughly double the normal 125,000. Relief workers reported no damage from rebel areas, mostly rural settlements with few substantial buildings. Egyptian geologist Rashad M. Kebeasy said two of the aftershocks measured about 5 on the Richter scale. Kebeasy, president of Egypt's National Research Institute of Astronomy and Geophysics, said Sunday's quake would have probably been a disaster in a populated area. ``I'm sure that if somebody went into the jungle, he would find big faults, cracks in the earth,'' said Kebeasy, an expert on northeastern Africa's earthquake patterns. ``But this area is very unpopulated. There's nothing there to bring down.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gets Pay Increase, Tass Says
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's popularity may not be soaring at home, but the official Tass news agency said Monday he is in line for a hefty pay raise. Tass said the Soviet legislature had set Gorbachev's monthly pay at 4,000 rubles _ $6,480 _ more than twice what he is currently reported to be earning. The news agency also said lawmakers decided to make presidential perks part of the public record, replacing traditional ``secret instructions'' regarding their leaders' compensation. They formalized the fact that Gorbachev is entitled to the use of specially equipped cars, planes and helicopters and to official residences in the capital and the Crimea, a Black Sea resort area. A magazine editor last year disclosed that the Soviet leader's monthly salary was 1,500 rubles _ $2,430 _ about seven times the pay of a typical Soviet worker. After taxes, his new monthly income will be 2,300 rubles, or $3,726, Tass said. The news agency did not report details of any debate on Gorbachev's salary and benefits. The pay raise comes at a time of increasing public discontent over Gorbachev's domestic policies, particularly economic reforms that have left store shelves bare and millions of Soviets with insufficient housing.

DOC.HEAD: Blast Near Israeli Airlines Office Injures Three Turks
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Monday near the office of the Israeli airline El Al, slightly injuring three people and shattering some windows, the Anatolia news agency reported. There was no claim of responsibility for the blast, which occurred during the afternoon in the central district of Taksim. Three post office technicians working a few yards away were slightly hurt by flying glass, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Population Grows 12 Percent in One Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of inmates in state and federal prisons grew a record 12 percent last year to 703,687 prisoners, according to a Justice Department study. The inmate population increased 76,099 last year from a 1988 prison population of 627,588 held in state and federal facilities, said the study by the Bureau of Justice Statistics released Sunday. The nation's prison population has more than doubled in the last decade, from 373,866 inmates in 1980 to 703,687 last year, said the study. The increase in the number of prisoners outstripped the number of new cells being built by state and federal prison systems, the study said. The study estimated that the capacity of the nation's prisons increased by 40,000 to 60,000 beds last year and prisons were overcrowded by 10 percent to 29 percent. Overcrowding in facilities operated by 19 states and the District of Colombia forced authorities to house 18,236 prisoners in local jails or other facilities, the study said. Only three states _ Kansas, North Dakota and Alaska _ reported decreases in prison populations last year. The biggest proportional increase occurred in Rhode Island, where the number of inmates jumped 30.1 percent, followed by Colorado, with a 26.9 percent increase. South Dakota had the third highest percentage increase _ 25.2 percent _ and Utah ranked fourth with a 21.3 percent jump.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Erupts, Releasing Hazardous Materials at Medical School Facility
DOC.TEXT: A laboratory run by Nobel Prize-winning scientists at a medical school was damaged when a fire broke out, releasing hazardous material and forcing an evacuation from the building. Dallas fire Chief Mike Zak said 12 firefighters and eight people who were building employees or security officials were taken to Parkland Memorial Hospital for observation but were later released. Investigators today were trying to determine how Sunday night's fire started in one of several labs run by Michael S. Brown and Joseph L. Goldstein at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center. Initial reports that radioactive substances had been released at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center turned out to be wrong, Zak saud. Such materials are used at the lab. College spokeswoman spokeswoman Tommy Bosler said about a cup of hydrazine burned, but that the floor has been reopened. The hydrazine posed no threat, she said. Hydrazine, a flammable, corrosive material, is poisonous and may be fatal if inhaled, swallowed or absorbed through the skin. The compound burns the eyes and skin on contact and its vapors may cause flash fires and explode. The fire began in a ventilator hood, used to store chemicals that could be hazardous if spilled or inhaled, Ms. Bosler said. ``The official results aren't in but the general consensus is there was an electrical short in this ventilator hood,'' Ms. Bosler said. Brown and Goldstein won the 1985 Nobel Prize in medicine for discoveries related to cholesterol metabolism and cholesterol-related diseases. The two-alarm blaze on the building's fifth floor forced the evacuation of several people, Zak said. Authorities also diverted traffic around the medical center.

DOC.HEAD: Police Try To Seize Body of Dead Student Activist
DOC.TEXT: Police firing tear gas stormed a hospital ground Monday to try to seize the body of a dead student activist but fled after students fought back with metal pipes and rocks, students and witnesses said. About 100 combat-clad riot police charged into an outdoor area at Chonnam University Hospital. About 500 students armed with firebombs and metal pipes were guarding the body of 21-year-old activist Shin Jang-ho, which was inside the hospital morgue. The student suffered fatal head injuries Saturday when he jumped from a train to try to avoid police checkpoints. Students blamed police for the death. Students had set up a funeral altar with burning incense in the courtyard, which they said was not disturbed in the clash. There were no reports of arrests or injuries. About 1,000 riot police remained at entrances to the hospital, checking identities of those who entered. More police watched from across a major road outside the hospital's main entrance. There was no official explanation for the police action. In the past, police have tried to seize bodies of dead activists to return them to their families and to deprive radicals of a symbol to continue anti-government protests. Government officials in Kwangju called Monday for a halt to violent protests that have rocked this southern provincial city for three days. Radicals vowed more demonstrations. Radical student leaders called for a huge street rally Tuesday ``to oppose the U.S., which manipulated from behind the Kwangju massacre.'' Thousands of radical students and dissidents gathered in Kwangju last week for Friday's 10th anniversary of the Kwangju civil uprising against the government. They have staged violent anti-government and anti-U.S. protests for three days. Protesters claim U.S. military officials condoned the military crackdown on the 1980 uprising, in which officials say 200 people died. Dissidents say the death toll was much higher. The United States has denied any role in the Kwangju action. On Sunday, more than 200 students and citizens and 84 police were injured in a six-hour rampage in downtown Kwangju after police blocked 10,000 protesters trying to march to the provincial government headquarters. Radical student leader Lee Ki-hon told a news conference Monday the police should be held accountable for the death Saturday of Shin. Radicals said Shin would be buried as a martyr Wednesday after funeral services at Chonnam University. In the past, the deaths of protesters have triggered huge demonstrations. Kwangju Mayor Choi In-kee said the protests against the government of President Roh Tae-woo and the presence of U.S. troops in Korea had been instigated by outsiders. ``Violence will no longer be tolerated,'' he said in a statement. Other officials also urged an end to the demonstrations. In the central city of Taegu, about 80 students shouting anti-government slogans attacked a police substation with firebombs and rocks, the national news agency Yonhap reported. Yonhap said the students had left a rally at Kyunbuk National University commemorating the Kwangju anniversary.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Meets With West German Official
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney met Monday with a West German official before leaving for a NATO meeting in Brussels. The Pentagon said the brief meeting between Cheney and Walter Wallmann, minister president of the West German state of Hesse, was a courtesy visit. Wallmann's office said the session was the beginning of a round of meetings dealing with possible reductions in U.S. military strength in Germany. Wallmann's position as minister president of Hesse is similar to that of governor of an American state. Hesse includes a number of U.S. military installations, including V Corps headquarters at Frankfurt and large concentrations at the famous Fulda Gap leading into East Germany. Wallmann planned to discuss the social effects of possible U.S. troop withdrawal, what happens to German civilians working for the U.S. military and the future of Wiesbaden-Erbenheim Army airfield, his office said. The United States wants more combat helicopters and other Army aircraft stationed at the field, but is meeting opposition from local residents complaining of aircraft noise. Frankfurt officials have suggested turning Erbenheim into a civilian expansion of Rhein-Main Airport, which is shared by civilian airliners and the U.S. military. Cheney was leaving Monday for a two-day meeting of the NATO Defense Planning Committee in Brussels, Belgium. Wallmann also was to meet with National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. On Tuesday, aides said, he is scheduled to meet with Lawrence S. Eagleburger, deputy secretary of state.

DOC.HEAD: One in Four Iowans Own Bib Overalls
DOC.TEXT: About one in every four Iowans owns a pair of bib overalls, which apparently are a hot fashion item among some younger people. Honest. This news comes from the wacky folks at the Iowa Poll, who previously have revealed how many Iowans own lawn ornaments (24 percent), believe there is life on other planets (43 percent) and believe that it's not the heat, it's the humidity (87 percent). The latest finding, published in The Des Moines Register on Sunday, is that 28 percent of adult Iowans own a pair of bib overalls. Furthermore, the denim outfits are favored about equally by young women, male Baby Boomers and farmers. Forty percent of the women aged 18 to 24 own a pair, but only 20 percent of the men in that age group. That figure increases to 39 percent for men 25-44, the survey found. Forty-one percent of the state's male farmers wear bib overalls and 45 percent of the male blue-collar workers own a pair, according to the poll. Bib overalls have been around since 1895, and originally were worn mostly by men. And that remains true among older Iowans. The poll found that 37 percent of the Iowa men 65 and older have bib overalls, but only 11 percent of the women in that group. Although popular among young Iowans, bibs aren't about to push Izod and Ralph Lauren off department store clothing racks. The poll shows bibs remain more popular in rural areas and small towns than in large cities. And they are least popular with white-collar workers and college graduates. The poll's figures were based on interviews with 811 Iowans selected at random. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Four People Hurt in Blasts Believed in Protest of Roh Visit
DOC.TEXT: A series of blasts occurred outside an Osaka apartment house used by government employees Monday, injuring four people, and police blamed extremists opposed to the visit of South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. The three explosions broke windows in the apartment building and in nearby homes, according to police in Osaka, 255 miles west of Tokyo. One of the injured was a firefighter, who officials said was in serious condition. The other injuries, to apartment dwellers or area residents, were minor, they said. The South Korean president arrives in Japan on Thursday. Radical groups, including the leftist Chukaku-ha, or Middle Core Faction, say Roh's visit is a step toward re-establishing the Japanese empire as it existed before and during World War II. Japan ruled Korea as a colony from 1910 to 1945. Roh has been under pressure in South Korea to cancel the three-day visit unless there are more agreements involving the treatment of the estimated 677,000 Korean nationals living in Japan. Last month, Japanese and South Korean government officials reached agreement on the legal status of third-generation Koreans in Japan, many of them descendants of Koreans brought by force to Japan as workers before and during World War II. Under the new guidelines, Koreans of the third and succeeding generations may live in Japan permanently and no longer have to submit to fingerprinting by authorities.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Man Barricaded in Church with Wounded Hostage
DOC.TEXT: A gunman shot two people this morning and took one of his victims hostage in a church, police said. The man shot the people about 8:45 a.m., said Julie Wolinksi, a police spokeswoman in Melbourne Beach. He then barricaded himself inside the Episcopal church, Saint Sebastian-By-The-Sea. No one else was believed to be inside the church, she said. But reporters at the scene heard a man and a woman screaming, leading them to believe two people were being held hostage. The gunman's identity was not immediately known, officials said. The other shooting victim was taken to the Holmes Regional Medical Center, Ms. Wolinski said. The victim, Diane Conarroe, was in surgery with two gunshot wounds to the abdomen, said hospital spokeswoman Valerie Davis. The 43-year-old woman was expected to be in surgery for most of the afternoon, Davis said. Police surrounded the church as a hostage negotiator from the Brevard County Sheriff's Office tried to talk the gunman into releasing the hostage and surrendering, she said. Homes and schools were being evacuated in this town of 2,600 people, 25 miles south of Cape Canaveral, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Cuts Prices, Farmers Rally Against Western Competition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE West German opposition saying it opposes proposed merger treaty; pickup 8th graf pvs, `The East...'
DOC.TEXT: East German shops slashed prices on everything from televisions to sportswear today in a move to compete with a flood of Western products. The government announced the price cuts just six weeks before East Germany is to implement a free market and merge its economy with West Germany, a major step toward uniting the nations. Parliament met in East Berlin to debate a proposed treaty that would merge the economies and social institutions of the German states by July 2. Hundreds of farmers driving tractors and trucks left nearby Potsdam for a protest during the legislative session. East German farmers want protection from West European food imports, which are better packaged and often cheaper than East German goods because of European Economic Community subsidies. In the West German capital of Bonn, the main opposition party rejected the economic merger proposal at it now stands and demanded better terms for East Germany. The position of the Social Democrats could mean trouble for the treaty since the party has control of the West German parliament's upper house. Party leader Hans-Jochen Vogel said the treaty falls short of helping create ``modern and qualified jobs'' for East Germans and guarding against the collapse of East German businesses. The treaty was signed Friday by the East German and West German governments but still must be approved by the nations' parliaments. The Social Democrats control the West German Bundesrat, and they could delay approval if their demands are not met. Vogel said his party's actions will depend on ``answers to our demands.'' In East Berlin, lines of consumers formed outside clothing, furniture and electronic stores as dramatically reduced prices went into effect. The East German Commerce and Tourism Ministry said the price cuts would average about 60 percent on a variety of consumer goods, according to a report by the government news agency ADN. Television prices dropped from about $1,818 to about $780. The moves were aimed at competing with the huge influx of Western products flooding into East Germany. Even though economic union is not scheduled until July 2, the date which Western businesses can legally begin operating independently in the country, many foreign firms already have begun ``joint ventures'' with East German interests. The joint ventures often amount to little more than using an East German storefront or hotel room. Herman Pflaum, head of the East German government commission on joint ventures, said 1,145 were in effect in East Germany by late April, 90 percent of them involving West German firms. Western food products also are increasingly appearing on East German store shelves. East Germans began buying Western goods in November, when the former Communist government was forced to open the borders in the face of a massive revolt. The effect has been a steady increase in joblessness and worker unrest. Shoe industry workers have staged frequent strikes to protest what they say is the loss of their market to Western competitors. That industry last week was the first to announce drastic price cuts to compete. Although Eastern goods, especially food, often are cheaper than Western-made goods, quality is often much poorer. Many of East Germany's state factories and enterprises are expected to shut down when they are forced to compete in a free market. Hundreds of thousands of workers are expected to lose their jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Make Mush of Arkansas Resort City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf with 3 grafs to UPDATE with status of Indiana towns lacking water. Picks up 11th graf pvs: `Elsewhere, farmers . ..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LR1
DOC.TEXT: Flash flood worries receded today in Hot Springs, Ark., one day after a 6-foot wall of water caved in shop windows, carried off bridges and swept up cars and people. Residents had to be rescued from their roofs after their homes were swamped by nearly 13 inches of rain in the 24 hours ending Sunday morning. Several people rescued from cars were taken to hospitals with minor injuries. ``A wall of water just came in and everything was just floating around,'' said Bill Goodwin, who owns a souvenir store in the resort city. ``Even the fixtures _ they just turned over and floated.'' Goodwin said he watched a floating compact car crash through a window. Jerry Chambliss, who runs an art gallery, said a woman was washed out of a bathhouse and down a street but grabbed a sign at the end of the block. ``We couldn't get to her and we told her to hang on,'' he said. ``She was hollering and screaming. Then this guy came by in a front-end loader and just scooped her up.'' A 90-year-old landmark iron bridge in Malvern on the Ouachita River was washed away. Eight other bridges in the Hot Springs area were washed out. ``It was like the Colorado rapids,'' Chambliss said. ``I expected a raft to come by. There were these big waves. I've never seen anything so frightening in my 42 years.'' The National Weather Service issued severe thunderstorm warnings overnight for parts of Oklahoma and Arkansas, including Hot Springs, but flash flood warnings were not posted. Early today, southeastern Oklahoma was blasted with 50 mph winds and hail stones nearly as big as golf balls, but flood levels in two affected rivers were expected to begin dropping by afternoon, officials said. In Indiana, residents in Petersburg and Boonville suffered the irony of having no fresh water despite the storms because raging torrents broke water mains. Today, only about 60 homes in the Boonville water system remained without water, but Petersburg residents faced a water crisis that could last 10 days, officials said. Meanwhile, local authorities in southern Indiana were preparing for inspections this week by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which will determine whether home and business owners are eligible for low-interest federal loans. Elsewhere, farmers in central Louisiana who erected levees to hold back the bloated Red River were warned to expect even higher water next month. In the southeastern Texas town of Coldspring, Wayne Pady and his wife, Debbie, turned their hilltop home into a shelter, feeding and housing about 20 people forced to flee high water from Lake Livingston. ``I had just purchased a house on top of a hill, so we just had everyone down there come up here,'' Pady said. The 39-year-old is disabled by back problems from a 1985 car accident, and his only income is Social Security. ``Everybody helps one another down here,'' said Charlie Bell Wright, 60, whose husband and daughter were staying with the Padys. ``They try to share what they've got. You don't find many people like this in other places.'' Flooding in the region along the Arkansas, Trinity and Red rivers has caused hundreds of millions of dollars in losses and killed 13 people in the past three weeks in Texas, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Louisiana. Floods eased in Missouri, Kansas, Illinois and Indiana. At least two people died in Illinois and authorities searched for a woman missing in flooding near Jefferson City, Mo., since Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Killings Alleged at Zaire University
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 students demonstrated outside Zaire's embassy Monday and then marched to the Zambian Foreign Ministry to protest alleged slayings of university students by security forces in Zaire. The placard-waving protesters were escorted by heavily armed riot police. They brought traffic to a halt, but there were no reports of violence or arrests. The students demanded the ouster of Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko and urged Zambia to impose trade sanctions on its northern neighbor. At the Foreign Ministry, they were addressed biefly by Foreign Minister Luke Mwananshiku. He said the government had not received confirmation of violence in the southern Zaire town of Lubumbashi. The demonstrators say an unspecified number of students were killed by state guardsmen Friday at the university in Lubumbashi. Reports of the alleged killings came from travelers reaching Zambia's central Copperbelt province, about 60 miles from the Lubumbashi university, students said. There has been no independent confirmation of the reports. However, the government-owned Times of Zambia said over the weekend that up to 150 students may have died in clashes with guardsmen during a week of protests at the Lubumbashi campus. The newspaper quoted a Lubumbashi medical student who fled to the Copperbelt town of Ndola as saying guardsmen stormed the campus early Friday. The student did not give details of the students' grievances. Mobuto promised to end two decades of authoritarian one-party rule in Zaire recently after widespread protests. Newly legalized opposition groups, however, have accused the pro-Western government of violently suppressing their activities. Mobutu's U.S.-backed government has also been accused of large-scale corruption.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: When actor Robby Benson and his wife, actress-singer Karla DeVito, left Hollywood two years ago, their friends thought they were crazy. But Benson and DeVito, who now lead a quiet life at the campus of the University of South Carolina, may have the last laugh. With no agents, no managers, not much money and little fanfare, Benson has produced a romantic comedy, ``Modern Love.'' It's playing in selected cities in the Southeast and will be more broadly distributed this summer. Even if the $1.5 million film is not a box-office smash, Benson said he and DeVito already are a success. ``We've already won because of the way Karla and I feel about each other and what we accomplished,'' he said in the May 28 issue of People magazine. Benson landed at the university after he struck a deal to teach film making if he could make a film at the school. He wrote the screenplay and produced and directed the movie, which stars himself, DeVito and their 6-year-old daughter, Lyric. Benson also enlisted pal Burt Reynolds, who acted for scale wages of $398 a day. ``The problem with Robby is he's almost too good to be true,'' Reynolds said. ``He had a great career and then made some films that didn't work, and he got blamed. That's Hollywood, it eats people alive.''

It's probably no surprise, but Ted Turner and Jane Fonda were the hottest item at the anniversary party for Turner's Cable News Network, which turns 10 on June 1. The couple turned heads throughout the celebration Sunday night at CNN Center, headquarters for Turner Broadcasting. But the spotlight didn't keep them from being openly affectionate. While a highlight tape of CNN's first 10 years was shown on a giant monitor, Ms. Fonda wrapped her arms around Turner's waist and rested her chin on his shoulder and he caressed her hand. ``I have to kind of pinch myself to realize it's gone by so quickly,'' Turner said in brief remarks about CNN's first decade. ``The next 10 won't be quite as exciting as the first 10, but stay tuned.'' The party, which drew about 3,000 guests, was timed to coincide with the opening of the National Cable Television Association's annual convention, next door at the Georgia World Congress Center. Among other celebrities attending were Maureen Reagan, talk show host Larry King, CNN anchorman Bernard Shaw and U.S. Rep. Edward Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House telecommunications subcommittee. Earlier in the day, Turner was the commencement speaker at Tougaloo College near Jackson, Miss., where he advised graduates to ``Aim high. Aim real high.''

Judith Durham, the original golden voice of the 1960s folk-rock group The Seekers, was in satisfactory condition Monday after surgery for injuries sustained in a car crash. A spokesman for Melbourne's Royal Prince Alfred Hospital said the 47-year-old singer was resting comfortably after lengthy surgery for compound fractures of the left leg and right wrist. Durham was injured Sunday night when the car in which she was traveling collided head-on with another vehicle northwest of Melbourne. A woman passenger in the other car was killed. The accident occurred the day after Durham and her husband, pianist Ron Edgeworth, had performed before a packed house at the National Theater. Durham left The Seekers in the late '60s to pursue a solo career. Her voice had given the group its characteristic sound on songs such as ``Georgy Girl'' and ``I Will Never Find Another You.'' The Seekers recently reformed and Durham's place was taken by Australian singer Julie Anthony.

Tevin Campbell says he doesn't feel like a superstar. But the 13-year-old still has plenty of time to acquire the feeling. Music critics liken his soulful voice to that of a young Michael Jackson, and Tevin has been swarmed by the media since he sang on Quincy Jones' ``Back on the Block'' album. Tevin's fan club has also started to grow because of recent layouts in teen magazines and television performances on programs such as ``The Arsenio Hall Show.'' ``People come up and ask me for my autograph, but I don't feel like a superstar,'' Tevin told the Dallas Times Herald during a recent interview at his suburban Dallas home. ``I guess it hasn't caught up with me yet.'' His ballad ``Tomorrow'' has been climbing the charts since it was released last month as a single from Jones' album. But Tevi still acts like a typical teen-ager _ wearing torn blue jeans, shopping at the mall and teasing his siblings. ``The first time I heard it (on the radio), I didn't believe it was me,'' he said. ``Now it's getting kind of regular to me.''

Former tennis star Arthur Ashe told 2,200 graduates of the State University College that dealing with a culturally diverse world would be their greatest challenge. ``You'll have to learn how to get along with the rest of the world,'' said Ashe, a former Wimbledon and U.S. Open champion and author of a book about black athletes. ``Cultural diversity is something you'll have to deal with, whether you like it or not,'' he said at Sunday's commencement. ``There are now several clusters of power in the world, and there are no longer advantages to being an American. ``Cultural diversity is like a marriage: you have to work at it.''

DOC.HEAD: Acne Medicine Promising Treatment for Throat Cancer
DOC.TEXT: The widely used acne drug Accutane appears to signficantly block the growth of new tumors in people being treated for smoking-related cancer of the mouth and throat, according to a study released Monday. Although doctors can often initially remove all signs of this cancer with surgery and radiation, patients face a high risk of recurring tumors elsewhere in their throat and lungs. The new research suggests that Accutane, an artificial form of vitamin A, can prevent the development of these second tumors, perhaps by halting the progression of smoking-related injury to the body. ``This is a very promising lead,'' said Dr. Waun K. Hong. ``It has the potential to prevent second cancers.'' Hong, now a physician at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, began the study in 1983 while at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Boston. He presented his results at the annual meeting of the American Society Clinical Oncology. ``I think this stuff is great,'' said Dr. Bruce Cheson of the National Cancer Institute. ``If we can do this (prevent second cancers), it will be a major service.'' Cancers of the head, neck, esophagus and lungs account for almost one-third of the 510,000 cancer deaths expected in the United States this year. In his study, Hong gave Accutane to 49 patients in whom doctors had removed all outward signs of cancer. Another 51 people took dummy placebos. During three years of follow up, two of the Accutane patients, or 4 percent, developed second cancers, compared with 12 patients, or 24 percent, in the comparison group. Both of the Accutane patients had a single recurring tumor, while four of the 12 placebo patients had multiple second cancers. Patients took high doses of Accutane, and this turned out to be a drawback, because many suffered unpleasant side effects. These included dry skin, chapped lips and eye inflammation. The problems were so severe that 14 of the patients did not finished the year-long course of treatment. ``Some people said, `Doc, I just can't take it. My face is so red that people think I'm drinking,''' Hong said. Because of the side effects, Hong said he does not recommend the drug for routine use in these cancer patients. He said new studies will be necessary to see if lower doses will cause fewer problems yet still prevent recurring cancers. Accutane, known technically as 13-cis retinoic acid, can also cause birth defects if taken during pregnancy. Dr. Roger Foster of the University of Vermont said that despite the drawbacks, ``the interesting thing is that there has been a demonstration of a preventative agent.'' Dr. Edith Mitchell of the University of Missouri in Columbia added, ``It's a big deal, but we need to find the minimal dose that patients can tolerate.'' Hong also cautioned that although the drug appears to prevent the development of second tumors, it does not stop the cancer from coming back in the site where it was initially treated. The study was too small to determine whether it helped patients live longer. Hong theorized that it works by suppressing pre-cancerous abnormalities in the body's air passageways. He said this approach also raises the possibility that drugs may someday be able to prevent a first cancer in people who are at high risk because of a lifetime of exposure to tobacco smoke. But even if this can be done, it should not be an excuse to keep smoking. ``It would be very dangerous for smokers to think they can take a pill instead of giving up smoking,'' he said. Hong said he hopes to study less toxic forms of vitamin A, which may be more tolerable for long-term use.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
ABC's Fall Schedule Renews ``Twin Peaks,'' Despite Ratings Drop
DOC.TEXT: ABC unveiled its fall schedule today and renewed David Lynch's surreal, quirky ``Twin Peaks,'' even though the series has slid sharply in the ratings and had its lowest Nielsens to date on Thursday. NBC planned to announce its fall schedule later today. While renewing one of the season's most written-about new series, ABC dropped six other midseason replacements, including ``Elvis'' and Oprah Winfrey's ``Brewster Place.'' All had low ratings. The other casualties: ``Capital News,'' ``The Marshall Chronicles,'' `H.E.L.P.'' and ``Sunset Beat.'' ABC renewed ``China Beach,'' ``Life Goes On,'' ``thirtysomething,'' ``Roseanne'' and ABC News' ``PrimeTime Live'' and ``20-20'' series. But the cancellations included ``Anything But Love'' and Saturday's ``ABC Mystery Movie'' quartet that had new versions of yesteryear's ``Kojak'' and ``Columbo.'' ABC put six new series on its fall roster. Three are sitcoms _ ``Baby Talk,'' based on the hit movie ``Look Who's Talking''; ``Going Places,'' about four young adults in Los Angeles working on their first TV show _ a ``candid videos'' series; and ``Married People,'' about three generations of married couples sharing the same building. Capitalizing on its top-rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC also will have ``America's Funniest ... Part II.'' The two one-hour shows are Steven Bochco's ``Cop Rock,'' a blend of music and police drama, and ``Gabriel's Fire,'' starring James Earl Jones as a former convict-turned-private investigator. Whether ABC would renew ``Twin Peaks,'' a continuing saga of sex, murder and jelly doughnuts set in a small logging town in the Pacific Northwest, had caused some suspense _ but not as much as who killed Laura Palmer. She's the high school homecoming queen, whose body was found at the start of the show's premiere. Although ABC won't give critics an advance look at the season's eighth and final episode this month, the segment is expected to resolve her murder. The series has been shown on Thursdays, but the final episode was moved to Wednesday to add its numbers to those ABC will get for the May ratings ``sweeps,'' which end Wednesday night. The sweeps period helps determine advertising rates for local stations. Preceded by heavy publicity and generally favorable reviews, the two-hour premiere of ``Twin Peaks'' on April 8 got the highest ratings of any two-hour movie aired last season, according to ABC. It averaged a 21.7 rating and a 33 percent share of the audience in its time period. But the show steadily lost viewers during the next six episodes that ABC aired opposite NBC's top-rated ``Cheers.'' ABC officials weren't immediately available to discuss why they renewed the show. But industry observers said the network likely would pick up the series because it is attracting a female audience desirable to advertisers and it eventually might get a larger general audience. Although Wednesday's episode could get high ratings because of the murder mystery involved, last Thursday's show had a viewing audience 51 percent smaller than for the premiere; the show gave ``Twin Peaks'' its lowest ratings to date _ a 10.6 rating and a 17 percent audience share. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Urban Educators Tackle Goals
DOC.TEXT: Urban educators concerned that their students will be overlooked in a national effort to improve education formed a task force Monday aimed specifically at problems facing big city schools. ``Over the last five years, numerous reports have been written about the condition of urban education in this country,'' said Joseph Fernandez, chancellor of New York City schools. ``While many of these reports contain excellent recommendations, it is critical that the practitioners, those impacted most by the recommendations, become involved in discussions of our national education agenda,'' Fernandez said. Holmes Braddock, president-elect of the Council of the Great City Schools, said the task force would develop its plan within three years. Urban schools, he said, have heavy concentrations of minorities or non-English speaking children as well as low-achievers and low-income students. Other problems include crumbling facilities and inadequate teaching materials. Fernandez will head the group, which will analyze goals that include increasing expectations for all urban school students and adequately staffing urban schools with qualified teachers ``who are culturally and racially sensitive and who reflect the racial characteristics of their students.'' The task force also will review ways to restructure education in urban areas, and discuss controversial ideas such as eliminating grading and testing from kindergarten through third grade, lengthening school days, team teaching and increased federal financial commitment. Fernandez said the task force would seek ``bottom up'' approaches as opposed to the ``top down'' scenario offered by the nation's governors. A final report on the urban goals will be completed by Jan. 15, 1991. The national education goals, approved by President Bush and the governors in February, are targeted for 2000. Those goals say all children will start school ready to learn, high school graduation rates will increase to at least 90 percent, American students will be first in the world in mathematics and science, students will leave grades four, eight and 12 competent in basic subjects, every American adult will be literate and every school free of violence and drugs. The Council of the Great City Schools is a coalition of 45 of the nation's largest urban school districts.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Refuses to Let Anti-Abortion Group Block Access to Clinics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 18, Bolstered the, to fix typo in ``bolstered.'' ^By RICHARD CARELLI
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today allowed a permanent ban on demonstrations by an anti-abortion group that blocked access to abortion clinics in New York. It was th second legal setback in two weeks for Operation Rescue. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal judge's order that forbids Operation Rescue members from blocking women trying to enter New York area abortion clinics. Operation Rescue members are under similar injunctions in other cities. Today's action came a week after the high court, by a 5-4 vote, left intact a similar ban on Operation Rescue blockades at abortion clinics in Atlanta. But today's action is a bigger setback for Operation Rescue. The court's order in the Atlanta case was preliminary in nature. The dispute had reached the justices as a request for emergency help before Georgia courts had finished studying the controversy. The four justices who voted to allow demonstrations in Atlanta said free-speech restrictions should not have been imposed before Georgia courts had a chance to rule definitively. Today, the high court rejected a formal appeal by Operation Rescue after lower courts ruled definitively against the group in the New York case. And, in contrast to the Atlanta case, there were no dissenting votes today. Randall Terry, founder of Operation Rescue, said in a statement about the ruling: ``No court can prohibit us from rescuing babies. These judges have joined the heritage of Nazi judges who sanctioned the murder of the innocent. The day of judgment will hold terrifying consequences for them.'' In other action, the court: _ Upheld a law requiring people convicted of federal crimes to pay money into a fund to help crime victims. The court unanimously rejected arguments that the law is unconstitutional because it originated in the Senate, and not in the House of Representatives. _ Rejected an appeal by a company accused of illegal bias for refusing to hire as a truck driver a Navajo Indian who used peyote in religious ceremonies. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the company engaged in illegal discrimination even though it offered to hire the man after he complained to New Mexico officials. _ Ruled unanimously that defendants can be required to make restitution only for specific crimes of which they are convicted, not related alleged offenses. The justices said a former post office worker in Texas is not required to pay a bank $90,431 he allegedly stole through credit card fraud. _ Bolstered the federal government's power to control water used by hydroelectric dams. Voting 9-0, the court struck down California regulations aimed at assuring survival of trout in the American River and Rock Creek, a small tributary of the river. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing for the court, said the Federal Power Act preempts California's stream-flow regulations. _ Ruled unanimously that monies given directly to Mormon missionaries by the church's members are not deductible donations under federal tax law. The court said Congress did not intend to make such direct contributions tax-deductible. In the abortion case, the National Organization for Women and other abortion rights advocates sued Operation Rescue and Terry in a New York state court in 1988. The suit, seeking an end to the group's blockades, alleged violations of several state laws and one federal law, the Ku Klux Klan Act. Operation Rescue's lawyers had the case transferred to federal court, where U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward in early 1989 permanently enjoined the abortion clinic demonstrations. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last Sept. 20 upheld Ward's injunction, and became the nation's first federal appeals court to rule that Operation Rescue's tactics violate women's civil rights and are not a type of protected free speech. The group's members ``were trespassers without right, constitutional or otherwise,'' the appeals court said. ``There is no constitutional privilege to assault or harass an individual or to invade another's personal space.'' Among other things, the appeals court said the Operation Rescue demonstrators had violated the Ku Klux Klan Act's ban on conspiracies which violate the rights of a ``class of persons.'' Acknowledging that the Civil War era law was aimed primarily at protecting newly freed slaves, the appeals court said the law ``is necessarily tied to evolving notions of equality and citizenship.'' ``As conspiracies directed against women are inherently invidious and repugnant to the notion of equality for all citizens, they are therefore encompassed under the act,'' the 2nd Circuit court ruled. Rejecting Operation Rescue's free-speech arguments, the appeals court said, ``Blocking access to public and private buildings has never been upheld as a proper method of communication in an orderly society.'' The appeals court upheld a $50,000 contempt-of-court fine issued against Operation Rescue and Terry. But it ordered that the fine be paid to the U.S. Treasury, not to the abortion rights advocates who filed the lawsuit. In the appeal acted on today, Operation Rescue lawyers contended, among other things, that women who seek abortions are not among those protected by the federal civil rights law. The case is Terry vs. New York State NOW, 89-1408.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
ABORTION
The court allowed a permanent ban on demonstrations by an anti-abortion group that blocked access to abortion clinics in New York. It was the second legal setback in two weeks for Operation Rescue. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal judge's order that forbids Operation Rescue members from blocking women trying to enter New York area abortion clinics. Operation Rescue members are under similar injunctions in other cities. Today's action came a week after the high court, by a 5-4 vote, left intact a similar ban on Operation Rescue blockades at abortion clinics in Atlanta. The case is Terry vs. New York State NOW, 89-1408.
CRIME VICTIMS FUND
The court upheld a law requiring people convicted of federal crimes to pay money into a fund to help crime vicims. The justices unanimously rejected arguments that the law is unconstitutional because it originated in the Senate, and not in the House of Representatives. The case is U.S. vs. Munoz-Flores, 88-1932.
PEYOTE
The court rejected an appeal by a company accused of illegal bias for refusing to hire as a truck driver a Navajo Indian who used peyote in religious ceremonies. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the company engaged in illegal discrimination even though it offered to hire the man after he complained to New Mexico officials. The case is U.S. vs. Munoz-Flores, 88-1932.
CRIME RESTITUTION
The court ruled unanimously that defendants can be required to make restitution only for specific crimes of which they are convicted, not related alleged offenses. The justices said a former post office worker in Texas is not required to pay a bank $90,431 he allegedly stole through credit card fraud. The case is Hughey vs. U.S., 89-5691.
HYDROELECTRIC DAMS
The court bolstered the federal government's power to control water used by hydroelectric dams. Voting 9-0, the court struck down California regulations aimed at assuring survival of trout in the American River and Rock Creek, a small tributary of the river. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing for the court, said the Federal Power Act preempts California's stream-flow regulations. The case is California vs. FERC, 89-333.
MORMONS
The court ruled unanimously that monies given directly to Mormon missionaries by the church's members are not deductible donations under federal tax law. The court said Congress did not intend to make such direct contributions tax-deductible. The case is Davis vs. U.S., 89-98.
LIQUOR LABELING
The court ruled states may impose labeling and reporting requirements on liquor sold at U.S. military bases within their borders, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court said North Dakota's regulation of liquor sold at two military bases there does not violate a clause of the Constitution which generally gives federal policy priority over state regulations. The case is North Dakota vs. U.S., 88-926.

DOC.HEAD: Court Goes Along with Ban on Blocking Abortion Clinics
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court refused Monday to let an anti-abortion group block the entrances to abortion clinics in New York. It was the second high court setback in two weeks for Operation Rescue. The justices' action was praised by abortion-rights advocates and denounced by Operation Rescue founder Randall Terry. The court left intact an order in which a federal judge permanently banned the group's members from interfering with women entering New York-area abortion clinics. Operation Rescue members are under similar injunctions in other cities. ``It's a tremendous victory,'' said Bill Baird, who runs two Long Island clinics where demonstrations have occurred repeatedly. ``I'd like to see the courts go further and assign federal marshals to escort women in, just as they escorted blacks into buildings in the 1960s,'' he said. Terry, in a statement released from Operation Rescue's office in Binghamton, N.Y., said, ``No court can prohibit us from rescuing babies. These judges have joined the heritage of Nazi judges who sanctioned the murders of the innocent.'' The justices took Monday's action _ not a formal ruling but a denial of Operation Rescue's appeal _ without comment and without any recorded dissenting vote. Just last week, the court voted 5-4 to leave intact a similar ban on Operation Rescue blockades at abortion clinics in Atlanta. But Monday's action was a bigger setback for Operation Rescue. The court's order in the Atlanta case was preliminary in nature. The dispute had reached the justices as a request for emergency help before Georgia courts had finished studying the controversy. The four justices who voted to allow demonstrations in Atlanta said free-speech restrictions should not have been imposed before the state courts had a chance to rule definitively. The high court Monday rejected a formal appeal by Operation Rescue after lower courts ruled definitively against the group in the New York case. The National Organization for Women and other abortion-rights advocates sued Operation Rescue and Terry in a New York state court in 1988. ``It's a humdinger ... couldn't be better,'' said NOW President Molly Yard. ``They were breaking the law,'' she said, adding that her organization is ready to seek court injunctions anywhere Operation Rescue members try to bar access to clinics. The suit, seeking an end to the group's blockades, alleged violations of several state laws and one federal law, the Ku Klux Klan Act. Operation Rescue's lawyers had the case transferred to federal court, where U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward in early 1989 permanently enjoined the demonstrators. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last Sept. 20 upheld Ward's injunction and became the nation's first federal appeals court to rule that Operation Rescue's tactics violate women's civil rights and are not a type of protected free speech. The appeals court said the Operation Rescue demonstrators had violated the Ku Klux Klan Act's ban on conspiracies that violate the rights of a ``class of persons.'' Acknowledging that the Civil War-era law was aimed primarily at protecting newly freed slaves, the appeals court said the law ``is necessarily tied to evolving notions of equality and citizenship.'' ``As conspiracies directed against women are inherently invidious and repugnant to the notion of equality for all citizens, they are therefore encompassed under the act,'' the 2nd Circuit court ruled. In other matters Monday, the Supreme Court: _Ruled unanimously in a case from Idaho that Mormons who contribute money directly to the church's missionaries may not deduct those donations from their federal taxes. _Enhanced the federal government's power to control water used by hydroelectric dams, unanimously striking down California's regulations to protect trout in the American River and its tributaries. _Upheld a law requiring people convicted of federal crimes to pay money into a fund to help crime victims. The court rejected arguments in a case from California that the law is unconstitutional because it originated in the Senate, not the House.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Cooling System Refilled
DOC.TEXT: NASA technicians began refilling Columbia's cooling system Monday, one of the final steps in a long series of repairs that grounded the shuttle. The space agency is working toward a May 30 liftoff, two weeks later than planned because a bad cooling valve had to be replaced. Columbia will carry seven astronauts and an on-board observatory. A new valve was installed last week after coolant was drained from the shuttle, and the system tested favorably over the weekend, said Lisa Malone, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It was the first time the work had been performed at the launch pad. ``Everything's been going real well,'' she said. The process of replenishing the system with 29 gallons of the refrigerant Freon was expected to be completed early Tuesday, followed by sampling and other tests. An official launch date will be confirmed by mission managers on Thursday. If May 30 stands, NASA estimates it will cost the agency $250,000 to $500,000 in holiday weekend pay, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham.

DOC.HEAD: Army to Introduce New Sand Bullet
With AM-Jordan-Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The army plans to introduce a bullet made of compressed sand as a new riot deterrent in the occupied territories, a military spokeswoman said Monday. The sand bullet, expected to be introduced in a few months, is designed to be fired during close-range confrontations, she said. ``The aim is to reduce the force of impact. The bullet is not meant to cause serious injuries, but to deter,'' the spokeswoman said. Israeli soldiers will continue to use plastic bullets, rubber-coated metal pellets and live ammunition in their battle against the 29-month Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. More than 700 Palestinians have died of Israeli gunfire in the rebellion, and an additional 216 have been killed by other Arabs as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators. Forty-three Israelis also have been slain. In July 1988, the army introduced plastic bullets to break up Palestinian demonstrations with a minimum of fatalities. Such bullets are not supposed to be lethal if fired from a range of 70 yards. However, at least 128 Palestinians had been killed by plastic bullets as of March 2, 1990, according to army figures. Neither the army nor Israeli human rights groups could provide figures on fatalities resulting from the rubber bullets. However, several Palestinians have been killed by the rubber bullets, including the so-called ``improved'' round rubber bullets with an enlarged metal core.

DOC.HEAD: Lynch's `Wild At Heart' Wins Best Film Award
DOC.TEXT: ``Wild At Heart,'' a bloody, sexually explicit black comedy by American director David Lynch, won the Golden Palm award tonight as the best film at 43rd annual Cannes Film Festival. Krystyna Janda of Poland won the best actress award for her portrayal of a dissident who undergoes torture in ``The Interrogation,'' and Gerard Depardieu, already France's dominant film actor, won the best actor award his title role in ``Cyrano de Bergerac.'' The best director award was given to Pavel Lunghin of the Soviet Union for his first film, ``Taxi Blues,'' a look at the seamy side of glasnost. Another Soviet director, Gleb Panfilov, was honored for best artistic contribution for ``The Mother,'' the story of a Russian woman's anguish as her son becomes radicalized by the family's harsh life under Czarist rule and is tried for subversion. Lynch's ``Wild at Heart'' competed with 18 other films for the Golden Palm. His works include the films ``Eraserhead'' and ``Blue Velvet'' and the current television series ``Twin Peaks.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Finds Salvadoran Promotions Despite Links to Abuses
DOC.TEXT: Military officers in El Salvador have risen to power despite having commanded units linked to human rights abuses, according to a report issued Monday on the eve of a congressional battle over cutting U.S. military aid. The congressional study said 14 of the country's 15 senior military commanders have commanded units that are documented to have killed civilians, tortured prisoners, carried out kidnappings or covered up such abuses. ``The promotion to senior positions of so many officers whose troops committed repeated abuses of human rights, and the absence of prosecutions of even junior officers for these abuses, suggest that at a basic level there is little accountability,'' concluded the report by the Arms Control and Foreign Policy Caucus. The report, underscoring the already tarnished reputation of the Salvadoran military, was issued the day before a partisan House floor battle over U.S. military aid to El Salvador. The aid totals $85 million this year and the Bush administration wants the same level for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. But some Democrats claim they will narrowly win a vote to slash the military aid in half this year and next, and to impose conditions to pressure the government and leftist rebels to reach a negotiated peace.moved.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
AIDS Activists Demonstrate at NIH, More Than 80 Arested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new to update with latest numbers; picks up 5th graf pvs, Mark Harrington.
DOC.TEXT: More than 80 AIDS activists were arrested at the National Institutes of Health today during a demonstration calling for more AIDS research by government scientists. Nearly a thousand protesters draped red streamers through the trees outside a number of NIH buildings to symbolize the red tape of the bureaucracy that they say is slowing down work to find a cure for AIDS. The demonstrators moved from building to building, chanting slogans and erecting cardboard head stones on the lawns of some of the buildings. Bob Shriver, a spokesman for the National Institutes of Health, said about 60 people were arrested on trespassing charges at the main Bethesda campus. He estimated the crowd at about 900. At the Rockville office of the director of AIDS Research for the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, 21 demonstrators were arrested on loitering charges, Montgomery County police said. Police said the demonstrators had the option of paying a $50 fine or requesting a court date. All those arrested were freed, authorities said. Mark Harrington of the New York-based AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power, ACT UP, said the activists want NIH to put more emphasis on drugs that fight the opportunistic infections that kill AIDS patients, whose immune systems are weakened by the disease. He said they also want more research into new anti-viral drugs that work differently from AZT. AZT is currently the only approved anti-viral drug that fights the AIDS virus directly. The demonstrators say government researchers have focused too much of their work on AZT and have failed to start studies on other anti-viral drugs. Since AZT was approved, researchers have been studying its effectiveness on people in different stages of the disease. ``We're just trying to get them to change the rules,'' Harrington said. For years AIDS activists had directed their criticism at the Food and Drug Administration, saying health officials there were too slow in approving new drugs to fight the disease and the infections it causes. But activists have shifted their focus to NIH, saying the FDA ``can't approve drugs that aren't there.'' ``Now we're mad because approaches that are promising aren't being pursued,'' Harrington said. The protesters also complained that government-sponsored studies have enrolled very few women, blacks, Hispanics and drug users. One group of women in the demonstration held up a banner that said, ``Women are invisible at NIH.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Sending Experts Here This Week in Pre-Summit Push for Accord
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is sending arms experts here later in the week to resume pre-summit negotiations to cut long-range nuclear weapons, and they will find the Bush administration in a mood to strike a deal. The negotiators will take up a half-dozen issues that were not resolved by Secretary of State James A. Baker III last week in Moscow. The aim is to settle as many as they can before Gorbachev arrives May 30 for summit talks with President Bush. The U.S. strategy is to look for a tradeoff, accepting the position taken by the Soviets on some issues in exchange for their agreeing to the U.S. stand on others, a senior U.S. official said Monday. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The Bush administration is not tipping its hand about its priorities before the talks begin, Wednesday or Thursday at the State Department. But one of the main U.S. objectives is to keep the Soviets from improving their powerful SS-18 nuclear missiles. As part of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, the Soviets already have agreed to reduce their arsenal of 308 of these land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles by 50 percent _ to 154. The Bush administration would like to halt improvements in the missiles that will remain, but is reluctant to accept curbs on its own arsenal of deadly multi-warhead ballistic missiles carried aboard nuclear submarines. Other unsettled issues include how many land-based mobile missiles would be allowed, whether the Soviet Backfire bomber should be regulated and how to verify compliance with a START treaty. Another tough issue _ restricting nuclear-tipped cruise missiles _ was resolved during the four days of talks Baker held in Moscow. That breakthrough involved a tradeoff. Baker accepted the range limitations proposed by the Soviets on cruise missiles carried aboard airplanes while the Soviets agreed to exclude the new U.S. Tacit Rainbow air-to-surface missile from any restraints. Also, the Soviets gave in to the U.S. demand that there be no inspection of cruise missiles carried aboard submarines. Baker's trip also produced what he called a ``trailblazing'' U.S.-Soviet agreement to end the production of chemical weapons. But with the summit only 10 days away, the two sides are concentrating on trying to reach agreement on as many strategic weapons reductions as they can include in a declaration to be initialed by Bush and Gorbachev. The Soviet delegation will be headed by Aleksander Bessmertnykh, a close adviser to Gorbachev. He is due to present his credentials to Bush next Monday as the new Soviet ambassador. Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew will head the U.S. team. Meanwhile, U.S. and Soviet negotiators are continuing to work on the treaty in Geneva. The proposed text runs 400 to 500 pages. Even if all key issues are settled it will take several months, at least, to complete it. Work in Vienna on another treaty to cut U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, artillery, airplanes and helicopters in Europe has slowed down. Baker was unable to perk up the negotiations during his meetings in Moscow with Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. The Soviets are reluctant to pull 600,000 soldiers out of Central Europe until they are assured the German army also will be sharply reduced. Even so, the Bush administration intends to go as far as it can in completing the START treaty. Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said Monday the administration would not delay completing one accord while the other lagged. ``START can be a very important agreement,'' he said. The treaty would cut U.S. and Soviet strategic nuclear weapons by 30 percent to 35 percent, overall.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Injured When Bomb Explodes in Crowded Bazaar
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden under a parked car exploded in a crowded marketplace Monday, seriously injuring eight people, police said. The bomb blew up outside a hotel in the Shoba Bazaar, the city's busiest shopping area, police said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blast, which badly damaged the hotel lobby and the adjacent office of Gulf Air and destroyed three vehicles. Hundreds of bombs have exploded in recent years in the Northwest Frontier Province and its capital, Peshawar. Agents of the Soviet-backed government in neighboring Afghanistan are routinely blamed. Pakistan is the base of U.S.-supported guerrillas fighting to overthrow Afghanistan's communist-style government. The blast occurred a day after government officials said two Afghan warplanes intruded into Pakistani air space and bombed the border area of Waziristan. The officials said the jets dropped two bombs on unpopulated mountainous areas.

DOC.HEAD: David Wood Dead, Former Political Editor of The Times
DOC.TEXT: David Wood, a journalist who reported life at the top of British politics with deep knowledge and insight for The Times of London, has died at 75, his former newspaper reported Monday. Wood died Friday, according to the newspaper. The cause of death was not disclosed. His best-remembered exclusive was his disclosure on June 1, 1959, that Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd had been told by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan that ``enough was enough'' and he would be transferred to another Cabinet post in several months' time. The report created an international sensation because Lloyd was then in Geneva attending a pre-summit conference of the prime ministers of the so-called Big Four nations _ British, French, Soviet and U.S. - and his position was undermined. Lloyd was a controversial figure because he had been foreign secretary during the Anglo-French secret collusion with Israel and invasion of Egypt over the Suez crisis in 1956. Macmillan and government information officers denied Wood's report on Lloyd, but it was Macmillan himself who had given Wood the information. Lloyd was made chancellor of the exchequer the following year. Later, when top officials of the Conservative Party were discussing who would succeed Macmillan, Wood reported accurately what was going on and ranking Tories tried to have him thrown out of his job. They were rebuffed by the late Sir William Haley, who is remembered as one of the great editors of the 205-year-old newspaper. Wood, a laborer's son, became a reporter in his hometown of Grantham when he was 14. He was a fast shorthand writer and in reporting the town council he got to know Alderman Alfred Roberts, whose daughter Margaret is today Prime Minister Thatcher. In World War II, Wood served in tanks in North Africa and was an intelligence officer in France and Germany. He joined The Times in 1948 and was its political editor for more than 20 years. His Monday morning articles on the background of politics were essential reading for all legislators and notable for the fine quality of writing and their political insight, The Times obituary said. Wood retired in 1979. He is survived by a son and a daughter.
