DOC.HEAD: Eagleburger: Latin America Will Be Top Foreign Policy Priority
DOC.TEXT: Latin America will gain ``a place of first importance'' in U.S. foreign policy as the Cold War ebbs, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger said Monday. Eagleburger's statement, delivered before an audience of corporate executives, was clearly intended to reassure Latin American leaders worried that their region will get scant attention in the growing U.S. fascination with the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. The focus of U.S. policy will ``increasingly and inevitably be drawn to our own hemisphere'' as relations with the Soviet Union improve and democracy becomes rooted in the former Soviet bloc, Eagleburger said. ``We may well be at the edge of removing from the U.S. foreign policy agenda the tremendous concern with East-West relations that has, of necessity, dominated the agenda for the last 45 years,'' he said. ``The world is clearly changing,'' Eagleburger said, adding that the changes ``will clearly redound to the benefit of Latin America.'' Eagleburger said it was natural for the United States to expend considerable energy in Europe because ``the prospect of ending the Cold War is of overriding stategic importance.'' But, he said, long-term responsibility for aiding the nations of Eastern Europe in their struggle to install democratic institutions and revive prosperity will be borne by their West European neighbors. Success in ending the East-West struggle and fostering stability and prosperity in Europe will open a new chapter in U.S. foreign policy, he said. ``The ending of the Cold War should bring with it a demilitarization of foreign policy'' and a new set of economic and political challenges, especially in Latin America, Eagleburger said. As a result of improvements in East-West relations, ``Latin America is going to occupy a place of first importance in U.S. foreign policy,'' he said. U.S. trade with Latin America ``will be seen as a vital national interest,'' in part to promote democracy, prosperity and stability and in part out of sheer self-interest, he said. ``But it is an interest that will be increasingly threatened if the region remains mired in debt and unable to buy our products,'' Eagleburger said. It is clear, he said, the United States and Latin America will have to move to open up trade, to boost U.S. investment and the flow of technology and to help solve Latin America's crushing debt problems. ``Statist and protectionist policies must be fully rolled back,'' he said. ``If the door is not opened wide enough, investment will go elsewhere.'' Eagleburger also predicted the United States will take a ``a much more open attitude toward free-trade agreements,'' but acknowleged that negotiating them country by country will be time consuming and difficult.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Lights Candles for AIDS Victims
DOC.TEXT: Ten candles burned in the upstairs windows at the White House, a signal of Barbara Bush's support for an international AIDS memorial. The candles were placed in the windows of the residence overlooking Lafayette Park on Sunday night, as 2,000 people rallied by candlelight at the Lincoln Memorial a mile away to remember victims of AIDS. The gathering was part of the seventh annual International AIDS Candlelight Memorial in which people around the world held vigils for those who have died or are afflicted with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The crowd that lined both sides of the Reflecting Pool Sunday evening cheered when it was announced that Mrs. Bush had placed candles in the White House windows. ``She was asked to participate. That was her participation,'' Anna Perez, Mrs. Bush's press secretary, told reporters Monday. Mrs. Bush made no mention of it Monday during brief remarks following a White House luncheon for Senate and Cabinet wives. A dance troupe of handicapped youths called the New Visions Dance Theater performed in the East Room. Mrs. Bush herself left afterward for New York and Kennebunkport, Maine, where she planned to spend the week at the Bushes' oceanfront home. President Bush will join her there Friday for the Memorial Day weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Receipts Spur Record Budget Surplus in April
DOC.TEXT: A surge in income tax payments helped the government set a record $42.52 billion budget surplus in April, one month after a record monthly deficit, the Treasury Department reported Monday. April's receipts reduced the deficit so far for the fiscal year that started last Oct. 1 to $108.34 billion, down from $150.85 billion in March but still 23.3 percent more than the deficit at this time last year. And the deficit still was more than the $100 billion target set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law with five more months remaining in fiscal 1990. The March deficit had been $53.34 billion, topping the previous record of $39.4 billion in May 1986. The Bush administration budget last January estimated the 1990 deficit to be $123.8 billion, although officials admit it will be revised upward because of the unexpected costs of the savings and loan bailout, increased interest rates and a less-than-expected revenue. The Congressional Budget Office in March projected the deficit to be $159 billion. Revenues last month were up 8.3 percent from April 1989 to $139.624 billion, while spending rose 9.9 percent to $97.107 billion. The biggest previous monthly surplus was the $40.57 billion of April 1989. Individual income tax receipts totaled $74.38 billion last month, up from $68.53 billion in April 1989. Corporate income taxes payments, however, fell from $14.69 billion in April 1989 to $13.38 billion last month. Louis Crandall, chief economist for R.H. Wrightson & Associates in New York, said the unexpectedly large income tax receipts were due to payments that usually are posted in May being entered in April's books. ``It's setting us up for a very steep May deficit,'' he said. Revenues for the first seven months of fiscal 1990 totaled $597.92 billion, up 4.9 percent from the same period of fiscal 1989. Spending totaled $706.26 billion, a 7.4 percent advance over the first seven months of the last fiscal year. The biggest spending categories, as usual, were the military, Social Security and other programs for the Department of Health and Human Services, and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $21.39 billion for the month and $166.86 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $286.79 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $18.87 billion for the month and $138.24 billion for the year so far. They are projected to total $244.59 billion for the year. Other HHS programs including Medicare and Medicaid totaled $16.81 billion during April and $109.46 billion thus far. They are projected to total $191.17 billion in fiscal 1990. Interest on the national debt amounted to $16.57 billion for the month and $145.84 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $254.85 billion for the entire year.

DOC.HEAD: Court Bolsters Federal Power to Control Water Use in California Case
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 5-6: ``California's appeal,'' with one graf to CORRECT that all other 49 states, sted 43, supported California
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today bolstered the federal government's power to control water used by hydroelectric dams. Voting 9-0, the court struck down California regulations aimed at assuring survival of trout in the American River and Rock Creek, a small tributary of the river. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing for the court, said the Federal Power Act preempts California's stream-flow regulations. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) ``has indicated that the California requirements interfere with its comprehensive planning authority and we agree that allowing California to impose the challenged requirements would be contrary to congressional intent,'' O'Connor said. California's appeal was supported by all 49 other states, who said a victory for the federal government threatened state control over water resources. Leading environmental groups, including American Rivers, the National Audubon Society and the Sierra Club, had said a victory for the federal government would shield ill-conceived hydroelectric development from state regulation. FERC in 1983 licensed construction of a hydroelectric power project on Rock Creek near Placerville, Calif. The owner of the dam, Rock Creek Limited Partnership, planned to generate electric power to be sold to the Pacific Gas & Electric Co. for use by the utility's customers. The California Water Resources Control Board sought to limit the flow of water over the dam by requiring that enough water would continue to flow in Rock Creek to assure suvival of the trout population. The federal agency in 1987 said it has exclusive control over how much water should flow over the dam. Today's ruling upheld a decision last year by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The justices relied heavily on a 1944 high court ruling that gave states control over water distribution only for limited purposes _ for irrigation and city water supplies. O'Connor said, ``There has been no sufficient intervening change in the law or indication that (the 1944 ruling) has proved unworkable or has fostered confusion and inconsistency in the law that warrants our departure from established precedent.'' The case is California vs. FERC, 89-333.

DOC.HEAD: NBC and ABC Unveil Fall Lines; `Twin Peaks' Renewed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NBC schedule around 6 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: ``Twin Peaks'' will be back next fall along with ``China Beach'' but there will be no more ``Elvis'' sightings, ABC said Monday. The new schedule, unveiled shortly before the scheduled release of NBC's fall roster, contains six new series, including Steven Bocho's hourlong ``Cop Rock,'' a mix of cops and musical production numbers. ``Elvis'' wasn't the only midseason ABC show to get the ax. ``Brewster Place,'' starring talk show star Oprah Winfrey, was canceled, too. Also out: ``Capital News,'' ``The Marshall Chronicles,'' `H.E.L.P.'' and ``Sunset Beat.'' All had low ratings. But so did ``Twin Peaks,'' directed by David Lynch of ``Blue Velvet'' fame and one of this season's most written about new series. A dark saga of sex, murder and jelly doughnuts, it had top ratings of 21.7 for its April 8 premiere, but has steadily lost viewers, despite even a favorable New York Times editorial. This Wednesday's season-closing episode likely will have high ratings because it is to resolve the murder of a key character, a high school beauty named Laura Palmer. The mystery even has touched off sales of T-shirts marked ``I Killed Laura Palmer'' in California, an ABC spokesman said. But last Thursday's show gave the series its lowest Nielsens to date _ a 10.6 rating and a 17 percent audience share. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Still, ABC spokesman Tom Mackin said the network expects the ratings will improve next season when the series follows the renewed ``China Beach'' in the latter's new time slot on Saturday nights. Other ABC renewals include the high-rated ``Roseanne,'' and ``thirtysomething,'' ``Life Goes On,'' and ABC News' ``PrimeTime Live'' and ``20-20'' series. Three of the five other new series on ABC's roster are sitcoms _ ``Baby Talk,'' based on the hit movie ``Look Who's Talking''; ``Going Places,'' about four young adults in Los Angeles working on their first TV show _ a ``candid videos'' series; and ``Married People,'' about three generations of married couples sharing the same brownstone in New York. Capitalizing on its top-rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC also will have ``America's Funniest ... Part II.'' James Earl Jones, whose ``Paris'' police series on CBS flopped a decade ago, will try again in a new hourlong ABC series, ``Gabriel's Fire,'' playing a former convict working as a private investigator for a defense attorney. The release of CBS' schedule is uncertain. It may come out later this week, or early next week, a spokesman said. Fox Broadcasting says it will give out its schedule on May 29.

DOC.HEAD: Hezbollah Leader Says Attack Must be Settled with U.S.
With AM-Jordan-Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader who aided in the recent release of an American hostage said the shooting deaths of seven Palestinians in Israel meant the time had come to settle scores with the United States. Hussein Musawi, leader of a pro-Syrian wing of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, said the level of violence in the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip should escalate. He also warned that more attacks on Palestinians could be expected as Israel tries to find room for hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants. On Sunday, an Israeli shot and killed seven Palestinians day laborers in the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Letzion. Violent protests broke out in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank in response. ``The real retaliation to this massacre is in escalating the suicide attacks in the occupied territories and outside them, and a serious settlement of accounts with the Americans,'' he said. Musawi, speaking from his Baalbek headquarters, did not specify how the Americans were involved or what actions would be taken. He did not mention the 16 Western hostages. Musawi urged extremist kidnappers holding American hostages to release a captive last month as goodwill gesture. After the April 22 freeing of Robert Polhill, he said the kidnappers expected reciprocity from the United States. Musawi was against the release of Frank Herbert Reed on April 30 after the U.S. House of Representatives passed a non-binding resolution recognizing Jerusalem as the united capital of Israel. Jerusalem is the third-holiest site in Islam and the eastern portion was occupied by Israel during the 1967 Israel war. The 16 Westerners held include six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. Longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Elsewhere in Lebanon, black flags and Palestinian banners waved across Palestinian refugee camps to protest the violence in Israel. Angry Palestinians took to the streets of the camps in separate demonstrations. Shops, schools and businesses in the camps closed Monday in protest. In west Beirut's devastated Bourj el-Barajneh camp, children carrying stones in their fists and Palestinian guerrillas armed with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic rifles, led the demonstrators. ``The people of the West Bank and Galilee will not knuckle under,'' chanted the protestors, estimated at about 2,500. A similar demonstration occured in south Lebanon's largest camp of Ein el-Hilweh, the Palestine Liberation Organization's main military base. Thousands of people roamed the shantytown chanting anti-Israeli slogans and calling for armed struggle.

DOC.BYLINE: Mosbacher Calls U.S. Business Too Slow in Eastern Europe ^By CARL HARTMAN
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said Thursday that U.S. business has been too slow to take advantage of opportunities in an Eastern European nations moving away from communism. Mosbacher recalled that Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was national security adviser to former President Carter, was surprised at the slow pace of investment compared to the moves into Spain and Portugal when dictatorships ended in those countries. ``I second Dr. Brzezinski's statement,'' Mosbacher said. ``Spain and Portugal have come a long way in 20 years _ and so have American businesses who went into those countries early. ``In 1990 U.S. business is on the doorstep of another historic opportunity, and we have a truly unique advantage. Our nation has long been a symbol of hope in eastern Europe, not only as leader of the free world for the last 45 years, but in centuries past.'' Mosbacher appeared at a seminar on business relations between the United States, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union that included Stanislav V. Assekritov, deputy chairman of the Soviet State Commission for Economic Reform. The commerce secretary told Assekritov he believed in Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform efforts, but he declined to answer a question from Assekritov about prospects for a trade agreement. ``I think we better leave (that) to our respective presidents and to the hopes the Soviet Union will very soon pass their emigration bill,'' he said. The United States has made a trade agreement contingent on a new Soviet law to allow free emigration. The Supreme Soviet may take the legislation up at the end of the month. The Soviets had hoped to sign the trade pact at the May 30-June 3 superpower summit, but the crackdown in Lithuania may jeopardize that schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Former Diplomat Says He Gave Indonesian Officials Names of Communists
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. diplomat said Monday that he gave Indonesian military authorities the names of high-ranking communists who were subsequently killed in a 1965 purge that terrorized the country. Robert J. Martens, who was a political officer at the U.S. Embassy in Jakarta, said he gleaned the names of thousands of Partai Kommunis Indonesia, or PKI, activists from the media. The same reports were available to Indonesian authorities but Martens said the officials were disorganized and didn't appear to have the names. PKI, with 3.5 million members and as many as 18 million people affiliated with it, was the largest communist party in the world and was active in every level of government and the military. Martens, now an adviser to the State Department, said the PKI was in danger of taking control of Indonesia at a time when communists were flexing their muscle throughout Asia. The purge of the PKI at the end of 1965 coincided with the start of U.S. activity against the communists in Vietnam. Among the names he provided were all the members of the PKI's central committee, Martens said in an interview. ``I thought it was the right thing to do,'' he said. ``I have no regrets.'' Martens said he gave names of activists in the cities and within the party apparatus, and not in the provinces. Martens said he and other U.S. officials were aware that Indonesia's military leader, Gen. Suharto, was rounding up PKI cadres and was determined to annihilate the party. Martens said he dealt with Suharto loyalists, who were opposed to then-President Sukarno and his support for the left wing. Sukarno opposed the crackdown, but he had lost power to such an extent that he effectively relinquished his post to Suharto in 1966. Suharto has beens president since 1968. Martens said he made the decision to provide the names, thinking it was standard practice to share information with host governments and that ``it wasn't a big deal.'' He said he hadn't consulted with his superiors and only told them about it several years later. The former deputy chief of the CIA station in Jakarta, Joseph Lazarsky, and Martens' boss, Edward Masters, said CIA employees contributed to the PKI lists, according to a report published Monday by States News Service, a small Washington-based news service. States News Service reported that U.S. officials used Martens' list to check off the names of PKI members who were killed. It said a 1968 CIA report estimated the number of those killed at 250,000. CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield denied that the agency was involved in the preparation or distribution of a list used to track down PKI members. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said PKI leaders were well known to Indonesian authorities. ``It's highly unlikely that we could have provided any information which was not known to the Indonesian government of the time,'' Boucher said. ``And, of course, we would not have provided names of people for the purposes'' of having them killed. Martens said the government had not put together any names because it was ``petrified'' by the assassination of six anti-communist generals. The military blamed the killings on the PKI and launched the purge that virtually destroyed the party.

DOC.HEAD: Catalytic Converters to be Replaced
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is recalling some 1987-model Jeep Cherokee, Comanche and Wagoneer models to replace catalytic converters that overheat and break down, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday. The recalled vehicles are those built before Oct. 16, 1986 and equipped with the 2.5-liter fuel-injected engine. Vehicles sold in California, which has different pollution standards than the other states, are included in the recall. The agency said an insulation layer between the inner and outer layers of the converter assembly traps too much heat, damaging the ceramic catalyst support inside and destroying the effectiveness of the converter. The problem was discovered in routine EPA tests that showed the Jeep models exceeding federal emission standards for all pollutants, EPA said. The agency said 11,056 Jeep models were produced with the defective catalysts. An unknown number of owners have replaced the converters under warranty, and they will not receive recall notices. The converter sits in the exhaust pipe to turn pollutants into harmless substances.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Mulls Compromise Offer; Latvia, Estonian Leaders to Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A strike by pro-Moscow forces in Estonia failed to win widespread support Monday when many workers ignored a call to walk off the job in protest of the republic's independence drive. In Lithuania, lawmakers put together a new offer aimed at breaking the republic's deadlock with Moscow. Also Monday, the presidents of Estonia and Latvia arrived in Moscow for talks with Kremlin officials, reports said. The three Baltic republics _ Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia _ were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union 50 years ago, and all are in varying stages of efforts to break free of Moscow's control. The contents of the proposal drafted by Lithuanian lawmakers _ which must be voted on by the Lithuanian legislature as a whole _ were not revealed, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. But Tass quoted Lithuania's prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, as saying it touched on the issue of whether to back off on Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. Gorbachev has demanded lawmakers suspend the declaration; they have so far refused to comply, but have offered to consider rescinding measures aimed at implementing the declaration. Lithuania is feeling the squeeze from the cutoff of oil, natural gas and other raw materials imposed by Moscow more than a month ago. Lithuanian parliamentary spokesman Rita Dapkus said Monday that total industrial, construction and transportation layoffs topped 12,100, not counting taxi and bus drivers idled by the resulting shortage of gasoline. In the agricultural sector, the embargo has forced the shutdown of 712 enterprises, or 60 percent of the republic's total, Ms. Dapkus said. On May 14, Gorbachev decreed that steps toward independence by Latvia and Estonia violated the constitution, but he has not taken any punitive actions against those two republics. The presidents of Estonia and Latvia arrived in Moscow on Monday for talks with Kremlin officials, the Estonian News Service reported. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel and Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov planned to meet Tuesday with members of Gorbachev's advisory body on the nation's republics and nationalities, the news service said. Ruutel told a news conference a private meeting with Gorbachev was possible. Tuesday's talks would be the second session in less than a week between Kremlin officials and Baltic leaders. Mrs. Prunskiene met with Gorbachev on Thursday. In Estonia, there were conflicting reports on the success of the anti-independence forces' strike call, but most accounts suggested the walkouts were far from crippling. Artur Kopytyn of the anti-independence Russian Strike Committee claimed there were strikes Monday at 18 enterprises. But Estonian Radio, together with Estonian journalist Tarmu Tammerk, said stoppages hit no more than six or seven enterprises whose work was not vital to everyday life in the republic. ``The city is calm, the workday is over and there were no incidents,'' Tammerk said by telephone from Tallinn, the republic's capital. ``The strike seems to be a failure for today.'' Government spokesman Juhan Hindov said pressure for the strikes was coming from pro-Moscow administrators at the factories and from the Russian Strike Committee, ``but people do not want to strike.'' Estonia's prime minister, Edgar Savisaar, told Estonian radio no more than 10 businesses were on strike and that five or six others would join Tuesday. ``We're too poor to strike,'' one burly, unidentified worker told the evening Soviet television newscast ``Vremya,'' which noted there was little support of the call to walk off the job. Kopytyn, in a telephone interview, said he could not say how many workers participated in Monday's strikes. But he said they would continue Tuesday and support would be ``bigger and bigger and bigger.'' He acknowledged, however, that bus drivers and other transport employees did not take part in the job action. ``The agitators ... made all they could to call people to the strike,'' said Mati Magi, director of the Tallinn Bus Enterprises. ``But our Russian drivers would not join the action.'' Sixty-five percent of the republic's 1.8 million population is Estonian. Russians make up 28 percent, with Ukrainians and Byelorussians making up the rest. Russians and other minorities in all three Baltic republics complain that they are discriminated against as a result of the independence movements.

DOC.HEAD: Report Outlines Effects of Much Larger Wheat Crop
DOC.TEXT: A dramatic increase in wheat production this year will help rebuild U.S. stockpiles and probably will mean stiffer regional competition for some export markets, an Agriculture Department report said Monday. Total wheat output has been projected at more than 2.69 billion bushels, a rise of more than 650 million bushels from the weather-reduced 1989 harvest. It would be the biggest year-to-year increase on record, besides resulting in the nation's third-largest wheat harvest, the report said. Winter wheat alone is forecast at 2.09 billion bushels, up 44 percent from 1989. As a result of the larger crop, lean stockpiles are expected to increase by June 1, 1991, to about 765 million bushels from an estimated 442 million bushels this June 1. Wheat prices received by farmers in 1990-91 are forecast at $2.90 to $3.30 per bushel, down from an average of $3.71 in 1989-90 and $3.72 in the 1988-89 marketing year. ``The 1990-91 price relationships and competition across classes (kinds) of wheat may change dramatically from 1989-90,'' the report said. ``Supplies of hard red winter wheat will be up sharply, resulting in more competition with hard red spring for the hard wheat market.'' Hard red winter wheat is concentrated in Kansas and other parts of the central and southern Great Plains, while hard red spring wheat is mostly in northern areas. White wheat is grown mainly in the Pacific Northwest and soft red winter is raised in the eastern third of the country. ``Larger crops and reduced imports are expected in South Asia,'' the report said. ``This will mean that the larger U.S. white wheat crop will have to compete with soft red winter for export markets such as Egypt that take both classes of wheat.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sees ``Important Beginning'' With Romanian Elections
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Monday said Romania's first free elections since 1937 represent ``an important beginning'' but that the new government will have to improve the democratic process. Richard Boucher, the State Department's deputy spokesman, said election observers sent to Romania by the Bush administration reported voting was ``free, peaceful and enthusiastic,'' and that turn out was heavy with long lines at the polls. ``We note that problems with voting and other election day irregularities appear to have been minimal, although opposition political party leaders have complained of breaches of election law procedures,'' Boucher said. ``We see this as an important beginning for Romania,'' he said. But he said the election campaign itself was flawed by candidates' lack of access to the news media and the intimidation of opposition candidates, he said. ``Further improving the process of democracy will be a key task of whatever government emerges in Romania,'' Boucher said. Boucher said there were no conclusions about possible U.S. economic aid to Romania because ``our assessment of the elections is only now beginning.'' The first official returns in Romania showed interim President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist, with an overwhelming lead in the presidential race. His National Salvation Front appeared to be headed for victory in the parliamentary elections, which would allow him to govern without forming a coalition with the opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Le Pen Hometown Says No To Right-Wing Gathering
DOC.TEXT: TRINITE-SUR-MER, France (AP) _ The hometown of extreme right-wing leader Jean-Marie Le Pen refused Monday to let him bring in a gathering of like-minded politicians from around Europe. A majority of Trinite-Sur-Mer's 15 municipal legislators voted to reject the request by the town's most famous son to allow a meeting of extreme-right European leaders next month. His birthplace, a coastal resort of 56,000 people on the Atlantic coast, joined Vichy, Aurillac, Angouleme, Lorient and Poitiers in turning away the chief of the anti-immigrant National Front party. Councilors cited public objections to renting a public hall to Le Pen, who frequently makes anti-Semitic remarks, following a series of desecrations at Jewish cemeteries around France. The council also objected to the likely presence of Franz Schoenhuber, a former Waffen SS soldier who heads West Germany's far-right Republican Party. ``We have had enough of seeing our town associated with the image of Le Pen,'' three assistant mayors declared in a joint statement last week. ``We prefer the image of the sailing capital of Brittany.'' About 400 citizens signed a petition asking the council to turn down the National Front's request to use the public meeting hall during the meeting planned June 5-8. In Paris, the City Council held a moment of silence Monday in honor of the dead whose graves were found defiled May 10 in the southern town of Carpentras. The desecration of the 34 graves and mutilation of a corpse touched off a wave of vandalism in France, but also prompted public demonstrations against a perceived rise in anti-Semitism.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Triumph Leaves Bitter Taste For Timisoara Opposition
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As early returns indicated a landslide for the interim government, bitter disappointment set in Monday among opposition activists in the town where the December revolution began. The National Salvation Front ``did not make the revolution _ they came to power because of it, and now they have finally stolen it from the people of Timisoara,'' said Gheorghe Serban, of the Timisoara Society, a civic group formed during the uprising. A West German exit poll of 14,539 voters indicated interim president Ion Iliescu of the Front would win 83 percent of the votes nationwide. National Liberal Party candidate, Radu Campeanu, was second with 11 percent, and Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party had 6 percent. Early returns appeared to confirm the sweep of the Front, a party with several former Communists, including Iliescu. But with 20 percent of the vote counted in Timisoara, Iliescu had 77 percent and the Front's share of the parliamentary vote was 54 percent, less than the nationwide average. The results reflected Timisoara's proximity to the West, rather than the Soviet Union, and its ethnic blend of Romanians, Hungarians and Serbs. It was an ethnic Hungarian pastor, now Bishop Laszlo Toekes, whose threatened deportation prompted the protests that became Timisoara's, and then the nation's, revolt against longtime Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Also born in the city was the so-called Timisoara Declaration, a document drawn up by activists and later adopted by Bucharest demonstrators who wanted all former Communists out of Romanian politics. The civic groups spawned by the revolution campaigned for Radu Campeanu, head of the centrist National Liberal Party. He was the younger and less aristocratic of the two former exiles who challenged Iliescu. Campeanu appeared headed for about 17 percent of the vote in Timisoara, reflecting some success in the campaign. Nonetheless, Timisoara's opposition was bitter. They felt cheated out of recognition they felt was their due. Serban said Iliescu mounted a propaganda campaign to convince Romanians that only 93 people died in the Timisoara uprising, ``when we all know that 20 times as many gave their lives for our freedom.'' Final casualty figures for the revolution have never been released, but observers have said hundreds and perhaps thousands died in the fighting. A sense of shock was tangible in the Liberals' Timisoara headquarters Monday. Volunteers shuffled among heaps of campaign literature and returning electoral officials brought further news of the party's defeat. Some of the opposition alleged fraud in the vote in their attempt to explain what was apparently a stunning loss. ``We don't know what, but something is not right in all this,'' said party spokesman Marius Lapugean. He alleged ``numerous irregularities,'' including inadequate voter registration lists and a lack of ballot boxes. More impartial observers attributed Iliescu's apparent triumph even in Timisoara in part to what they termed the vehemence of the anti-Front campaign waged by the Liberals and Peasants. ``The opposition in the city went completely overboard with their mud-slinging campaign against Iliescu,'' said Srboljub Miskovic, editor of the local magazine. ``Unsubstantiated insults'' only provoked the public to rally in defense of the party that steered the country to its first multiparty elections in decades. ``They did themselves a disservice because the National Liberal Party's political platform was essentially acceptable and Campeanu is personally well liked and respected,'' Miskovic said.

DOC.HEAD: Protestors Calling for More AIDS Research Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 81 AIDS activists who were demonstrating at the National Institutes of Health on Monday for more government research on the disease. About 1,000 protestors chanted and shouted as they moved from building to building on the NIH campus, draping red streamers through the trees to symbolize the bureaucratic red tape they say is slowing research. On the lawns in front of several buildings, they erected cardboard headstones symbolizing the many lives lost to AIDS. ``We're just trying to get them to change the rules,'' said Mark Harrington of the New York-based Aids Coalition to Unleash Power, ACT UP, which organized the demonstration. Harrington said the activists want NIH to put more emphasis on testing drugs that fight the opportunistic infections and cancers that kill most AIDS patients, whose immune systems are weakened. They also want more research into anti-viral drugs that work differently from AZT, currently the only approved drug that fights the AIDS virus directly. The demonstrators say government researchers have focused too much on AZT and its effectiveness in people with varying stages of AIDS infection. The result, the activists say, is that studies on other anti-viral drugs have not begun. In a statement to the media during the demonstration, NIH officials rejected the criticism. The National Institute of Allergies and Infectious Diseases, which does most of the government's AIDS research, ``has conducted or is preparing to conduct clinical trials of virtually all promising anti-AIDS drugs and immune-enhancing agents,'' said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the institute. William Raub, acting director of NIH, said that largely due to the institutes' word, ``effective therapies are now slowing the disease, prolonging lives and making a significant difference in the quality of life of people with AIDS.'' About 60 people were arrested on trespassing charges at the main Bethesda campus, said Bob Schreiber, an NIH spokesman. At the nearby Rockville office of the director of AIDS Research for the NIAID, 21 demonstrators were arrested on loitering charges, Montgomery County police said. Police said the demonstrators had the option of paying a $50 fine or requesting a court date. All those arrested were freed, authorities said. For years, AIDS activists focused their criticism on the Food and Drug Administration, saying the agency moved too slowly in approving new drugs to fight the disease. But they are shifting their focus to the researchers at NIH. ``Initially there was a bottleneck'' at the FDA, said Robert Garcia of ACT UP. ``But as the epidemic has grown, we have had to focus on what people are dying from, and those are the opportunistic infections.'' Harrington said the FDA ``can't approve drugs that aren't there.'' ``Now we're mad because approaches that are promising aren't being pursued,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: State, Federal Prosecutors Meet on Bensonhurst Case
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Attorney's office is considering a possible civil-rights prosecution of the young white man acquitted of murder in the Bensonhurst racial case, authorities said. The case of Keith Mondello, who was tried on state charges in the death of a black teen-ager, is being reviewed, said Mary Jo White, chief assistant U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York. She declined to disclose the nature of discussions between her office and Brooklyn prosecutors. ``We're showing them everything we have,'' said a Brooklyn prosecutor who spoke on condition on anonymity. Mondello, accused of leading the white mob that killed the youth Aug. 23, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter on Friday, but was convicted of riot and other lesser charges. Another defendant, Joseph Fama, was convicted Thursday of murder and other charges. Meanwhile, the trial judge in the case ordered murder defendant John Vento to be ready for trial in three weeks, rejecting a plea by the defense lawyer for a delay. Vento and four other alleged members of the gang of whites await trial on murder charges; another man is charged with assault. Vento, 21, is charged with two counts of second-degree murder, first-degree riot, first-degree assault and other crimes in the slaying of Yusuf Hawkins. Prosecutors allege that Vento was part of a mob of young whites who surrounded and shot Hawkins after he and three friends went to the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood shopping for a used car. Vento's lawyer, Gerald J. DiChiara, argued he needed additional time to study more than 700 police reports given to him last week and to prepare his client's defense. After the attack, Vento agreed to cooperate with the district attorney's office in exchange for immunity from prosecution. He was indicted in March after backing out of the deal, and is being held without bail.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Teacher Fellowship Grants To Spread To 10 Cities
DOC.TEXT: A five-year-old program granting Peace Corps volunteers scholarships to earn master's degrees in education while teaching in urban schools will spread to 10 cities next fall, it was announced Monday. Paul Coverdell, director of the Peace Corps, made the announcement at Teachers College of Columbia University, which has run the program for the past five years. Similar programs will start next fall in Los Angeles, Miami, Philadelphia, Houston, San Antonio, San Diego and Atlanta, Coverdell said. Two other cities will be named later. Under the plan, returning Peace Corps volunteers work in city schools while studying for their master's degrees at a local university. Eighty-five Peace Corps volunteers have taken part in the program at Teachers College during its five-year history, and 35 more are scheduled to begin studies next fall. Volunteers in Los Angeles will be able to study at the University of Southern California. In Miami, they will work toward degrees at Florida International University. Planning is still underway in the other cities. In New York, scholarships cover from one-third to three-fourths of tuition depending on the field of study. The highest amounts go to those majoring in math and science, while those studying special education, bilingual education or English as a second language usually get smaller awards. The New York City program operated on grants totaling $150,000 from the New York City Board of Education, Xerox Foundation, Chase Manhattan Bank, Hebrew Technical Institute and several anonymous benefactors.

DOC.HEAD: New Mexico Lawyer to Head National Indian Museum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Robert McC. Adams in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A member of the Cheyenne-Araphoe tribes has been named founding director of the National Museum of the American Indian, the Smithsonian Institution said Monday. W. Richard West Jr., an Albuquerque, N.M., lawyer, was chosen by a search committee that began work in January, Smithsonian Secretary Robert McC. Adams said at a news conference. The museum will be built in the last remaining space on the Washington Mall, between the National Air and Space Museum and the U.S. Capitol. Ground is expected to be broken in 1994. ``My highest aspiration for the National Museum of the American Indian is that it will re-analyze, redirect and, in many cases, reformulate entirely the concepts and presentations of the past concerning Indian culture,'' West said. West, a partner in the Indian-owned law firm of Gover, Steton, Williams & West, has worked with the Native American Council of Regents of the Institute of American Indian Arts. He is the son of Indian artist Walter Richard West Sr. West, 47, said he would resign from the law firm. His appointment is effective June 1 at a yearly salary of $115,000.

DOC.HEAD: University Will Require African-American History Course
DOC.TEXT: Students at Florida A&M University, the only predominantly black university in the state's nine-school system, will be required to take a course in African-American history starting next spring. The three-hour, one-semester course will be taken by freshmen and sophomores, Eva Wanton, dean of general studies, said Monday. FAMU faculty and students have for several years supported such a history requirement, and it was adopted this year during an overall review of the core curriculum, Wanton said. The Faculty Senate gave its approval May 8. Many black educators say humanities have long been taught in a vacuum, and that a lack of knowledge about black contributions breeds a lack of respect. FAMU professors concede that one course won't ensure a pluralistic education, but say it's a first step. The university plans to hire additional faculty to help teach the course. Eventually, Wanton said, FAMU professors hope to write a new American history textbook in which black contributions would be reported, and ``Hispanics and Native Americans would get their due.'' Last spring, the last term for which figures were available, FAMU's student body included 6,424 blacks, 751 whites, 110 Hispanics, one American Indian, 53 Asian or Pacific students, and 130 non-resident immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Ministers Urge Western Europe Nations to Pay More for Defense
DOC.TEXT: West European countries must prepare to pay more in common defense costs as the United States moves to substantially reduce its military presence in Europe, defense ministers said Monday. ``It is increasingly incumbent upon us, as Europeans, to assume a greater responsibility for our defense,'' the ministers said in a statement at the end of day-long talks at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The United States' plans for a diminished role in Europe means ``we have to be prepared to take a major responsibility,'' said Gerhard Stoltenberg, the West German defense minister. The United States has increasingly called for the prosperous nations of Western Europe to pay more of the West's defense costs. Members of the U.S. Congress have complained that Europeans are not sharing a fair portion of the defense burden. West European officials are now talking about footing more of the collective security bill because of the possibility of an arms control accord between the United States and the Soviet Union. Stoltenberg told reporters West Europeans must realize that the United States will gain the ``major part of reductions'' in troops and arms in a conventional arms agreement with the Soviet Union. Negotiators for NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact are in Vienna, bargaining over reductions in tanks, troops, artillery and other conventional forces in Europe. Western officials want to reach an accord in the fall. An agreement could lead to the United States and the Soviet Union reducing troop size in central Europe to 195,000 on each side. The United States would maintain an additional 30,000 in Britain and southern Europe. To meet the new levels, Moscow would have to pare 370,000 soldiers. The United States would have to trim 60,000 in central Europe and 20,000 outside the region. The European officials, known as the Eurogroup, met a day before a regularly scheduled meeting of NATO defense ministers. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will attend the meeting at the alliance headquarters in Brussels. In a final statement, the Eurogroup ministers said NATO must ``adapt to the changing security environment,'' prompted by the political upheavals in Eastern Europe. The ministers said the potential military threat from the Warsaw Pact has been significantly reduced. It would decline further, they said, with the reductions in soldiers and weapons expected under a conventional arms treaty. But they cautioned that even after an arms accord, the Kremlin ``will retain substantial and modern nuclear and conventional forces.'' They said NATO remains vital for the security of Western Europe. They also welcomed the prospect of a united Germany and said membership in NATO of the merged nation would further stabilize Europe. West Germany is a member of NATO, and East Germany belongs to the Warsaw Pact. Moscow has opposed Western demands for the joined nation to be part of NATO. A dozen West European countries were represented at Monday's talks. Iceland, which has no armed forces, attended as an observer. France, which does not belong to NATO's joint military structure, did not participate.

DOC.HEAD: Last Days of School Year Filled with Shock Instead of Joy
DOC.TEXT: What should be the happy, hectic last days before summer at Hickman County High School instead are filled with shock and sorrow. Students' lives have been turned upside down by the killing of a assistant principal, allegedly at the hands of a science teacher trying to blow up the school. ``We should be crying tears of joy at graduation. We'll be crying, but there will be no joy,'' senior Carol Wilson said Monday. ``We're all really upset,'' said another senior, Jeanine Harlowe. The science teacher, Donald Givens, 50, was ordered held without bond Monday at his arraignment on charges of first-degree murder in the shooting death of Ron Wallace, 41. Givens, described by school officials as troubled and fearful of not being rehired in the fall, also was charged with aggravated arson for allegedly setting fire to the school while someone was inside. Investigators allege that Givens shot Wallace after the assistant principal surprised him as he prepared to blow up the school Sunday morning. Several of the 850 students at the rural school had complained about Givens, but not about anything serious, said school district Superintendent Wayne Qualls. The complaints ``were that he couldn't get along with the kids. But not any real serious problems,'' Qualls said. Harlowe said Givens was ``very weird. But I would never have believed he would do something like this.'' Anthony Pharris, a recent graduate, also described Givens as ``weird. He'd be teaching a class and he'd just get lost.'' Givens, who has taught in Hickman County for 16 years, may have feared he was about to lose his tenured job, Qualls said. But while the teacher ``probably supposed things were stacked against him,'' none of the student complaints had been brought before the school board, Qualls said. The superintendent said Givens had personal problems, including having to care for an invalid brother who was paralyzed in an automobile accident. He also was responsible for taking care of the family farm and his elderly parents, Qualls said. School officials decided Monday to proceed with the graduation ceremony as scheduled on Friday, and set a rehearsal for Tuesday. ``We all agreed that's what Ron would want, for us to go ahead and proceed in some form,'' said Principal Rick Brewer. The rest of the school year _ three days of final exams this week _ was canceled. Teachers decided to give students grades of 100 for any unfinished work and average final grades from there. Wallace was shot in the head and chest with a .38-caliber revolver. His body was discovered in the hall outside the science department after firefighters responded to a fire call. Wallace had gone to the school, 40 miles southwest of Nashville, Sunday morning to prepare a conference room for afternoon baccalaureate services. Apparently, investigators said, he walked in on Givens as the teacher was turning on propane gas taps in the science department, where candles were burning. Givens was accused of setting, after the shooting, three separate fires that caused approximately $150,000 in damage to the school library, science department and auditorium, police said. Before he was arrested Sunday, Givens was at the school with other teachers, surveying the damage to their classrooms. In addition to his assistant principal duties, Wallace was girls' softball coach and had previously coached girls' basketball. His daughter, April, is one of 187 seniors scheduled to graduate Friday. Some of her fellow students said the exercises should be canceled out of respect. ``It would be too hard on April, sitting there thinking about her daddy,'' said Wilson.

DOC.HEAD: Biden Returns Bush Fire on Crime Package
DOC.TEXT: Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph Biden on Monday denied President Bush's accusations of congressional foot-dragging on major crime legislation, saying the administration should stop playing politics on the bill. ``If the administration wants to make this issue partisan, then we will,'' Biden said as the Senate opened debate on a wide-ranging package dealing with capital punishment and related issues. Biden, D-Del., said he was disturbed about recent statements made by Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle charging that Congress has given short-shrift to a crime package the president submitted a year ago. ``We have heard ... a lot of rhetoric suggesting that the president's crime bill has been languishing in the Senate since last May and I think it's time to set the record straight,'' Biden said. The Democratic and Republican leadership, with the concurrence of the White House, agreed that the crime bill should be discussed now, Biden said. Some elements of the Bush package already have been passed, including the 1988 bill allowing the death penalty for murders committed by drug kingpins, Biden said. Bush, in a Sunday speech to a law enforcement audience in Portland, Ore., accused Congress of spawning ``weak imitations'' of his proposals to attack crime after allowing them to languish for a year. ``We must reject those who soft-pedal the need to be hard on crime,'' Bush said. He accused lawmakers of sitting on key anti-crime proposals, but acknowledged that Congress agreed to his request for more federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors and prisons. Biden said in the Senate floor speech that Congress not only passed key elements of the original Bush package, but that lawmakers ``strengthened it, made it stronger.'' On the difficult remaining issues such as capital punishment and the length of time prisoners have for filing federal appeals, he said, the administration seems to have no interest in negotiating. ``The time to play politics on this kind of issue is over,'' Biden said. ``If they don't want to talk, well, so be it. That's their prerogative,'' he said. ``They are not interested in compromise, at least it seems to me, and I hope it's not because they see more political gain in conflict over ... cooperation.'' Many of the Senate's Republicans are supporting a rival crime bill introduced by Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina because of its tougher death penalty provisions. Thurmond, the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, told the Senate on Monday that he was concerned about an amendment to the Democratic bill, introduced by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., which would invalidate use of capital punishment in states where it is applied disproportionately to blacks. Thurmond said no evidence had been produced to show that blacks or other minorities are discriminated against in the application of the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Generals Executed for Coup Plot
DOC.TEXT: Twelve generals have been executed for leading an attempted coup against Ethiopian President Mengistu Haile Mariam, Ethiopia's state radio reported Monday. The report said the men were sentenced to death Saturday after being found guilty of trying to overthrow the government. ``The final verdict passed by the Supreme Court has been carried out,'' said the broadcast monitored in Nairobi, Kenya. It did not say whether the men admitted the charges at the trial, which was held in secret. It also did not say when or how the men were killed. Soldiers found guilty of treason in Ethiopia normally face firing squads. Addis Ababa Radio said a rear admiral also convicted was sentenced to 15 years in jail and a major general was given 10 years in prison. War-weary generals discouraged by a succession of battlefield defeats against rebels in northern Ethiopia tried to overthrow the government last May, while Mengistu was on a trip to East Germany to request arms. It is not known how many soldiers died in the fighting around Addis Ababa, the capital. Those killed included Defense Minister Maj.-Gen. Haile Giorgis Habte Mariam, who remained loyal to Mengistu and was shot by mutinous forces. Heavy fighting also occurred in Eritrea, where some soldiers supported the coup attempt. Many military leaders wanted Mengistu to negotiate with the rebels. Since the coup attempt, he has begun talks, but they are stalled. The rebels, like Mengistu, are Marxist-Leninists. Rebels in Eritrea province want independence, while those in Tigre want autonomy. Mengistu has ruled this Horn of Africa nation, strategically located at the mouth of the Red Sea, since 1974 when he and a group of young army officers ousted Emperor Haile Selassie.

DOC.HEAD: New Evidence Casts Doubt on IRA Bomb Factory Convictions
DOC.TEXT: New evidence casts doubt on the convictions of seven people accused of running an Irish Republican Army bomb factory in the 1970s, the legal counsel for a judicial inquiry said Monday. Tests that found traces of nitroglycerine on the hands of the seven defendants were insufficient to sustain their convictions, said David Clarke, in an opening statement to a judicial inquiry. The inquiry, conducted by Sir John May, has no power to reverse the convictions. It may be a year before the inquiry makes its recommendations to the government. British courts in the past 12 months have reversed the convictions of four people accused of IRA bombings and three others convicted of plotting to assassinate a British government official. Earlier this year, Home Secretary David Waddington ordered a review of the convictions of six men for IRA bombings in Birmingham that killed 21 people in 1974. That review has not been completed. No explosives were found in the possession of the seven defendants currently under review, but they were convicted of possessing explosives. Their convictions were based on tests and on statements made by two men convicted of killing seven people in pub bombings in Guildford and Woolwich in 1974. Those men and two others convicted of the pub bombings were freed last year after prosecutors admitted that police lied about statements made by the defendants. Following their release, May, a former Appeal Court judge, was appointed to conduct an inquiry into the Guildford and Woolwich case, and the related conviction in 1976 of four members of the Maguire family, two relatives and a friend. The test used in the case, known as thin-layer chromatography, or TLC, is a reliable test for nitroglycerine, Clarke said. ``In a nutshell, the results of the TLC tests, viewed now with the benefit of hindsight, did not of themselves prove that there had been in the house ... a bulk or quantity of explosive, which had been handled by all the defendants,'' Clarke said. ``But they do suggest that there had been at least a secondary source, that is to say a person who had been in contact with a primary source. That person need not have been one of the defendants.'' Clarke said one of the defendants may have handled a glass or towel previously touched by someone who had handled nitroglycerine. Convicted in the case were Patrick Maguire, his wife Anne, and sons Vincent and Patrick; Guiseppe Conlon, husband of Patrick Maguire's sister; Sean John Smyth, Mrs. Maguire's brother; and family friend Patrick Joseph O'Neill. Conlon, whose son Gerard was convicted in the Guildford case, died in prison; the others have completed their sentences. Police began investigating the Maguires after statements by Paul Hill and later by Gerard Conlon identifying Anne Maguire as a bomb maker. Hill and Conlon have said their statements were obtained under duress. Clarke said it was impossible to regard any of the Maguire convictions as ``safe,'' the standard used by the Court of Appeal in reversing the Guildford convictions.

DOC.HEAD: Former AP Correspondent Spencer Moosa Dead at Age 85
DOC.TEXT: Veteran Associated Press foreign correspondent Spencer Moosa, one of the few journalists to have had easy access to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, has died, his family said Monday. He was 85. Born in Shanghai, Moosa was a correspondent in China and Taiwan for 29 years, until his retirement in 1968. His daughter, Irene, said he was rushed to a hospital Friday and died several hours later. Doctors attributed his death Friday to heart and lung disease. A noted raconteur, Moosa worked for the British news agency Reuters before joining The AP, traveling with Nationalist Chinese forces to Canton, Nanking, Chengdu and Chungking. His friends in the Nationalist Chinese hierarchy included Chiang Kai-shek, allowing him rare access to the Nationalist leader. In 1949, when Chiang and his retinue fled Chengdu to Taiwan to escape the victorious Communist army, Moosa was on one of the last planes reserved for Nationalist leaders leaving the Chinese mainland. Earlier that year, Moosa had been taken into custody by Communist troops in Beijing and accused of ``false reporting,'' although he accurately described a negotiated agreement for joint Nationalist-Communist administration of Beijing as a ``surrender'' document. He and another journalist were vilified by the Communists as ``the claws and fangs of American imperialism,'' and students threatened to lynch them until an unknown high-ranking official intervened. In Taiwan, Moosa was the AP's chief correspondent until his retirement, when he joined the Taiwan Tourism Bureau. In addition to his daughter Irene, Moosa is survived by another daughter, Maya, and son, Alexander. Funeral services are scheduled Friday in Taipei.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Officials: U.N. Presence Needed To Safeguard Palestinians
With AM-Jordan-Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PLO officials urged Monday that U.N. troops be sent to the Israeli-occupied territories to protect residents, and one official vowed the organization ``will not be silent'' following the murders of seven Palestinians. Abdallah Frangi, representative for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Bonn, released a statement Monday calling for U.N. troops in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Frangi also warned of retaliation for the slaying Sunday of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli civilian. ``The whole world should know _ we will not be silent. We will reply. We have the power to reply.'' Farouk Kaddoumi, foreign affairs chief of the PLO, said the international community has a responsibility to protect Palestinians in the occupied lands by using U.N. observers. ``Statements and verbal commitments are no longer sufficient. The moment has come for concrete acts,'' said Kaddoumi. He spoke while passing through Rome airport en route to the Arab summit in Baghdad, scheduled for May 28. Frangi appealed to the European Economic Community to support the proposals for U.N. deployment. He charged that silence by the United States and the EEC had made Israeli officials ``feel encouraged'' in their current policies. At least one EEC member, Italy, denounced Israel's handling of the Palestinian protests that erupted after Sunday's slayings. The Foreign Ministry released a statement Monday saying the recent unrest confirms that the situation in the occupied territories is ``untenable.'' It urged Israel to ``welcome the offer for a peace dialogue growing from the moderate turn in the Palestinian movement.'' Frangi said he fears Israel's continued presence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip will spark a ``war of annihilation'' in the Middle East during the next few years. ``I am more convinced today that in the near future we will not be able to experience peace,'' said Frangi. ``And I would dare say that in the coming years there will be a war of annihilation, and those to be held responsible will be Israeli politicians,'' he said. Frangi said the PLO will wait for a decision on how to react to the recent violence after the summit of Arab states.

DOC.HEAD: 41 Killed, 300 Wounded as Troops Fire on Funeral Procession
DOC.TEXT: Security forces in Kashmir on Monday opened fire on a crowd of 100,000 mourners carrying the body of a slain Moslem leader, killing at least 41 people and wounding 300, officials said. Earlier Monday an official source in New Delhi, speaking on condition of anonymity, gave a different account of the shooting. He said militants opened fire on paramilitary troops ``and in the cross-fire approximately 20 people were killed and 40 were wounded.'' Witnesses and doctors in Srinagar said 30 bodies and at least 300 people with bullet wounds were brought to Soura hospital. Official sources in Srinagar, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 41 were killed in the firing. Witnesses said about 40 bodies were still on the streets of the Hawal neighborhood of Srinagar where the shooting took place. The city was under curfew and the reports could not be confirmed immediately. Prior to Monday's killings, nearly 400 people had been killed in Kashmir in clashes between security forces and Moslem militants. The militants want the predominantly Moslem state to secede from mostly Hindu India. A high-ranking U.S. government delegation arrived in New Delhi late Sunday to talk with Indian leaders about the Kashmir crisis that has inflamed tensions between India and Pakistan. Deputy National Security Adviser Robert Gates and John Kelly, the assistant U.S. Secretary for Near East and South Asian affairs, arrived from Pakistan where they met with senior officials. Gates and Kelly met Indian Prime Minister V.P. Singh and urged India and Pakistan to settle the issue with dialogue. On Monday, Srinagar, the capital of Kashmir, was under curfew following the assassination of Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, Kashmir's top Islamic religious leader. But tens of thousands of mourners defied the curfew and streamed to Soura hospital where they took Farooq's body and began marching in a procession to his office, 6 miles away. Witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said members of the paramiltary Central Reserve Police Force opened fire without warning on the procession at about the 5-mile point. They said Farooq's coffin was hit with bullets and the body fell out. Some of the mourners put the body, with fresh bullet wounds, back into the coffin and ran with it into the narrow alleys to his office. Foarooq's aides said a funeral date has not been set. Farooq, 45, was shot and fatally wounded in his office early Monday by three unidentified gunmen, said his chief aide Mohammad Maqbool. He said the youths were dressed in Western clothes and appeared to be Kashmiris. Farooq suffered 15 bullet wounds to the head and body and later died in Soura hospital, a doctor said. Before dying, Farooq blamed his assassination on the Hindu fundamentalist group, Shiv Sena, or Shiva's Army, named for the Hindu god of destruction, Farooq's private secretary Mohammad Yaqub said. State government officials blamed the killing on Kashmiri militants but several militant groups denied responsibility in phone calls to local reporters and repeated announcements over loudspeakers in mosques that the ``freedom fighters'' had no hand in the slaying. Farooq had long urged a political settlement of the Kashmir dispute but saw his importance in the troubled valley eclipsed by Moslem militants. He denounced the Indian military deployment in the region and joined the call for independence after the Jan. 20 crackdown. The violence in Kashmir has led to a deterioration of relations between India and Pakistan. India accuses Pakistan of arming and training the Moslem militants. Pakistan denies the charge and accuses India of violating human rights in a bid to quash what it says is a fight for self-determination. The dispute began in 1947 when British colonial India gained independence and was divided along religious lines into Pakistan and India. Kashmir's Hindu ruler chose to merge his state with India despite its Moslem majority. Pakistan objected to the move and the dispute has led to two wars with India.

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Bacteria Treatment for Bladder Cancer
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday approved use of a live but weakened bacteria to treat a type of bladder cancer. The product, Bacillus Calmette Guerin Live, or BCG Live, was approved to treat bladder cancer referred to as ``carcinoma in situ.'' This type constitutes 20 to 30 percent of the 45,000 cases of bladder cancer detected in the United States each year, the FDA said. The treatment calls for the bacteria to be administered directly to the bladder through a catheter to attack the cancer cells on the lining of the organ. The inflammation that results eliminates many of the cancer cells. Studies sponsored by the National Cancer Institute found that 74 percent of patients with carcinoma in situ of the bladder responded to BCG treatment. Of those, the median time for recurrence of the cancer was four years, the FDA said. The most common side effects of the treatment are flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills and nausea and bladder discomfort. However, the FDA-approved labeling also warns physicians to watch for spread of the BCG organism throughout the body. This, the FDA said, has been associated with two deaths. Treatment with BCG is given once a week for six weeks and then monthly for six to 12 months. The product is made by Connaught Laboratories Ltd. of Willowdale, Ontario, Canada. It will be marketed under the trade name Theracys.

DOC.HEAD: Stuffed Animals Recalled Because of Choking Hazard
DOC.TEXT: A California company is voluntarily recalling six models of stuffed animals imported from China because their eyes can detach, posing a potentially fatal choking hazard, the government said Monday. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said there have been no known deaths or injuries caused by the toys, all of which contain music boxes and are distributed by the San Francisco Music Box Co. The six toys have eyes with washers on the back and the company discovered defective washers that allow the eyes to become detached, posing the choking hazard, the CSPC said. The CSPC, in a statement, said the six toys have wind-up keys protruding from their backs and a small white tag sewed to the side or bottom that reads: ``The San Francisco Music Box Company, Emeryville, Ca., Reg. No. PA-2642 (RC) All New Materials Made In China.'' Approximately 2,866 of the stuffed animals were distributed nationwide from December 1988 through June 1989, the CSPC said. Consumers should return the animals to the retail outlet from which they were purchased for a full refund. Additional questions can be directed to the company by calling the toll free number, 1-800-227-2190. The names of the animals, their model numbers and the song played by the music box are: _White Jointed Bear, 55-0046, ``You Are My Sunshine.'' _Beige Jointed Bear, 55-0061, ``Don't Let Me Go.'' _Beige Small Jointed Bear, 55-0038, ``It's A Small World.'' _Pink Bear, 55-0079, ``A Baby's Lullabye.'' _Pink Monkey, 55-0095, ``Zip-a-dee-doo-daa.'' _Beige Articulated Santa Bear, 55-0368.

DOC.HEAD: Observers Clash Over Whether Romanian Election Free or Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Ion Iliescu captured 87 percent of the 6.7 million votes counted so far, but foreign observers clashed Monday over whether Romania's first multiparty election in 53 years was free of fraud. The main opposition parties charged results of Sunday's balloting were rigged, called Romania's first attempt at democratic voting a failure, and said they would contest the elections in court. Ion Ratiu, the National Peasants' Party's presidential candidate, said he would take legal action to have the election declared ``null and void.'' He vowed to fight ``against the renewal of Communism in Romania,'' which he said Iliescu represents. Iliescu, 60, came to power in the December revolution against Nicolae Ceausescu and was the heavy pre-election favorite. He drew huge campaign crowds, especially in the countryside where he was seen as the man who saved Romania from the Communist dictator. The campaign occasionally turned violent, but no major incidents were reported Sunday. First official results published by the state news agency Rompres suggested an overwhelming win for Iliescu. Most official results were not expected until Wednesday because of the heavy turnout, estimated at more than 85 percent of the 16 million eligible voters, and the complicated ballot, which contained more than 30 pages. The dispute among the 500 foreign observers who fanned out across the country to watch the voting centered on whether a series of irregularities added up to acceptable or unacceptable election violations. Gov. Garrey E. Carruthers, R-N.M., the official U.S. government observer, called the poll ``a good election'' and ``a very giant step toward democracy.'' Austrian parliamentarian Andreas Khol, general secretary of the European Democratic Union, disagreed, saying: ``These were a big step toward free and democratic elections, but they were not free and not democratic elections.'' Carruthers asked the Romanian government to set up mechanism to investigate allegations of fraud and irregularities during the campaign and voting. Prime Minister Petre Roman, a prominent member of Iliescu's governing National Salvation Front, said later the Central Electoral Bureau had set up a commission to investigate alleged improprieties. ``Already some fraud was discovered,'' he told The Associated Press, citing as an example what he said were 25 ballots pre-stamped for the National Liberals' candidate, Radu Campeanu. Rompres said that with 6.7 million votes counted, Iliescu had 87 percent; Campeanu 10 percent, and Ratiu, 3 percent. Its vote report also had the Front winning nearly two-thirds of the seats in Parliament so far. A onetime Communist official who opposed Ceausescu in 1971, Iliescu gained sympathy for being demoted and was far better known and popular than either Campeanu or Ratiu, who spent decades in exile. Iliescu won wide support from peasants by permitting them to own large plots of land. Industrial workers, about 40 percent of Romania's labor force, liked his pledges to move slowly in transforming Romania's state-controlled economy to a capitalist free market. His apparent triumph and the strong showing for the Front suggested that anti-Communist demonstrators who blocked a main square in Bucharest for a 30th day Monday and protesters in other cities enjoyed little broad popular support. Iliescu and the Front look like becoming the first ex-Communists in Eastern Europe to triumph in the region's current series of multiparty elections. Initial Rompres results for the two-chamber Parliament gave the Front about 65 percent; Liberals, 7 percent; Peasants, 3 percent; and ecologists 3 percent. The Hungarian Democratic Union, representing Romania's 2 million Hungarian minority, had about 7 to 8 percent. The other votes went to tiny parties. Ratiu, who attended Carruthers' news conference, said the governor's upbeat assessment would completely mislead Americans and President Bush. Calling the election a fraud, Ratiu said, ``There was no semblance of democracy about it.'' ``We will contest the election if this is the sort of result that we get,'' he said, pledging to demand new elections. The various observer groups reported instances of ballots pre-stamped for Iliescu, Front members accompanying elderly voters into the booth, non-registered voters casting ballots, and individuals voting several times. Many observer complaints focused on the campaign rather than the voting itself. Several alleged that the Front, which dominated the interim government, unfairly controlled the election apparatus and the electronic media. Carruthers and other observers urged the West and the new Romanian government to work to create a free press as a guarantee of future democracy. ``The process was flawed. But the very fact that an election has taken place is itself a remarkable achievement,'' said a 60-member delegation sponsored by the U.S. Republican and Democratic parties. ``One could not say there was organized fraud,'' said Andre Billardon, vice president of the French National Assembly and a member of its observer group. The United States has said future U.S-Romanian relations, and U.S. trade concessions important to Romania's shattered economy, are conditional on whether the elections were ``fully free and fair.''

DOC.HEAD: House Takes Up Clean Air Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House began debate Monday over the first strengthening of clean air laws in 13 years, while closed-door negotiations appeared unlikely to head off a floor fight over a tougher smog-control proposal. The House was expected to vote on a series of about a half-dozen amendments to the bill later in the week, with a final vote on the legislation expected by Thursday. The Senate already has approved a clean air bill. The legislation before the House won overwhelming approval from the Energy and Commerce Committee in April. Its major provisions _ including major cuts in acid rain pollutants, reduction in smog causing auto emissions and controls on toxic industrial releases _ are unlikely to be changed dramatically during floor action. The legislation's cost to the economy because of new pollution-control requirements has been put at about $21 billion a year when all its provisions go into effect. As floor debate began on the bill, key congressmen and staff aides worked to reach compromise agreements on about a half-dozen amendments, with an aim toward avoiding as many contentuous floor battles as possible. But parties to the discussions said a floor fight has become almost unavoidable on a proposed amendment by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., that calls for the annual production of 1 million non-gasoline powered automobiles for sale in the nine U.S. cities with the highest air pollution. The cities are Los Angeles, San Diego, Houston, Chicago, Milwaukee, Baltimore, New York, Philadelphia and Hartford, Conn. The measure would make the bill's smog-controlling auto emission requiring significantly tougher than the Senate version, which has no production requirement. The auto industry has launched an all-out campaign to block the proposal, arguing that it would require manufacturers to rush such cars into production without clear evidence there would be a market for them. Waxman, speaking on the House floor, characterized his proposal as nothing more than what President Bush had sought nearly a year ago when he included as part of his clean air proposal a requirement for alternative-fuel vehicles. But the White House backed away from imposing a production requirement after intense lobbying from the auto industry. The Senate defeated efforts to impose a similar requirement as did Waxman's own Energy and Commerce subcommittee. Both environmentalists and auto industry lobbyists predicted a close vote on the amendment when it comes to the House floor. In opening remarks in the floor debate, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the Energy and Commerce Committee chairman who has long been protective of the auto industry's interests, suggested that most controversies on the clean air legislation ``have been largely eliminated.'' Dingell characterized the remaining issues of disagreement, as being ``not environmental in character, but rather differences of views'' among congressmen. Meanwhile, compromise agreements were reported Monday to have been worked out on several amendments, assuring their swift approval when brought to the floor. These included: _A requirement to sell in the nine cities with the worst smog problem a cleaner gasoline blend that has a specific oxygen content, allowing it to burn cleaner. The oil industry vigorously opposed the measure, calling it tilted toward the use of ethenol, which comes from grain. _Require the Environmental Protection Agency within two years to develop regulations on regional haze near major federal parks and wilderness areas. Environmentalists have claimed the EPA has been slow in curbing air pollution in such areas. _Streamline some provisions of the permitting and enforcement section of the bill to ease the paperwork burden to some businesses. Other amendments likely to be taken up on the House floor include a provision broading the required phaseout of a variety of atmospheric ozone-damaging chemicals in addition to chloroflurocarbons, or CFCs, and an amendment that would impose federal air pollution requirements on offshore oil-drilling platforms.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Tries to Sweep to Victory With Broom as Her Symbol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to CORRECT grammer graf 5 `With Regina's' and ADDS her age. Picks up 6th, `They operate...'
DOC.TEXT: One thing distinguishes Regina Liska from the 11 other candidates for president in the May 27 elections. She's a witch. She also is the only candidate making some alarming predictions. The 58-year-old woman says a nuclear accident in Brazil will kill many people, and a U.S. city will be wiped out. Known as Regina 11, she also is the only candidate married to an American. Her husband is Danny Liska, of Niobrara, Neb., a motorcycle enthusiast who cruised into town and married her in 1968. With Regina's broom, her official symbol, and Liska's motorcycle, the pair have ridden to fame. They operate out of a huge, three-story building where there are some rather strange goings-on.
