In one huge room recently, a dozen people holding hands in a circle swayed and moaned while an elderly man sat in a chair. No one would say what it was all about. There is a book store, a shop offering metaphysical paraphernalia and a shop where disciples' yellow, graduation type gowns are made on sewing machines. Each night, scores of people, sometimes as many as 300, gather around a large wooden platform to hear Regina 11. She makes predictions and talks about spirits, curing people, abstaining from liquor and cigarettes and voting for her next Sunday. This is the second time she has run for president. The first time, in 1986, she received 74,000 votes. She had 860,000 but was cheated of victory by fraud, she said in an interview at her headquarters. Predictions for the coming year? _An earthquake will destroy vast parts of northern Mexico and southern California. _A city in the United States will be wiped out by an illness that will be caused by an ashlike material falling from the sky. Ash from a volcano? Radioactive dust from a nuclear bomb? She does not know. _An earthquake in Nicaragua will kill thousands. _Nuclear weapons will explode in Brazil. There will be a plague across the land. An earthquake and fires will devastate a Brazilian city, perhaps Rio de Janeiro. _An earthquake in China will kill 4 million people. Regina 11 says she has had the power to cure and to see the future since she was four years old. Her body floated in her room then, and a face appeared in a vision. A voice said she would ``know the world'' through the number 11. Hence, she calls herself Regina 11. She says she has already predicted to her disciples several major tragedies and assassinations in Colombia. She said the visions started seven years ago. She has had no visions on whether she will win Sunday's election. Regina 11 had enough votes from the last election to warrant the government treating her as a serious contender this time. She, like the other candidates, has received free television and radio time. Her campaign has only one theme: peace without weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in the Middle East
With AM-Jordan-Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at developments Monday involving the Middle East.

ISRAEL _ Riots break out across the occupied territories in response to Sunday's slayings in Israel of seven Palestinians by an Israeli civilian. Soldiers shoot and killed three Palestinians and wound as many as 112. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens says the government bears no responsibility for Sunday's murders. But Arab leaders blame the attack on the hard-line policies of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

AMMAN, Jordan _ A Palestinian armed with a pistol and dagger boards a tour bus and opens fire, then begins stabbing passengers when he runs out of bullets. Nine French tourists and a Jordanian are injured. Police speculate the 28-year-old man was bent on avenging the deaths of the seven Palestinian laborers killed in Israel on Sunday. Thousands of demonstrators chanting anti-U.S. slogans and waving the Koran march toward the U.S. Embassy, hurling rocks and police who try to keep them away.

LEBANON _ Hussein Musawi, a Shiite Moslem leader who aided in the recent release of an American hostage from Lebanon, says the slayings Sunday meant the time has come to settle scores with the United States. He makes no mention of the 16 Western hostages in Lebanon.

WASHINGTON _ State Department spokesman Richard Boucher criticizes the Israeli army for its handling of riots that broke out Sunday after the Palestinian murders, saying the United States is ``disturbed by the number of casualties inflicted by the Israeli army.'' Seven Palestinians were killed in the rioting.

BONN, West Germany _ Abdallah Frangi, representative for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Bonn, releases a statement calling for U.N. troops in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to protect residents there. Frangi also warns of retaliation for the slayings Sunday, saying, ``The whole world should know _ we will not be silent. We will reply. We have the power to reply.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Cites Kentucky Mine Operator for 121 Safety Violations
DOC.TEXT: The operator of a Kentucky mine where 10 workers died in an explosion last year was cited Monday for 121 alleged violations of federal safety laws. The Labor Department's Mine Safety and Health Administration said 42 violations against Pyro Mining Co. involved ``reckless disregard'' of safety, the highest degree of negligence in the agency's penalty system. The number and nature of the violations show ``a lack of concern about safety on the part of the operator as well as poor safety management,'' said William Tattersall, assistant secretary of labor for mine safety and health. James Greenlee, executive vice president of Costain Coal, Inc., which owns Pyro, said the company was reviewing the alleged violations to determine whether it will request a conference with federal investigators to give them more information about safety procedures. Companies are allowed to provide additional information before the agency proposes fines for alleged safety violations. Eventually, Pyro Mining could face civil penalties of up to $10,000 for each violation. An agency report earlier this month said 10 specific violations contributed to the Sept. 13 explosion in Wheatcroft, Ky. Most of the violations identified Monday had nothing to do with the cause of the blast, but ``we still consider them serious,'' Tattersall said. The agency report released May 8 said an investigation showed that Pyro Mining managers knew explosive methane gas was accumulating in the mine four days before the explosion, but they did not maintain adequate records that would have alerted the others. That report alleged that managers failed to make required checks for the deadly gas in the hours before the explosion, failed to keep enough clean air in the mine to clear out methane and made a series of changes in air pathways that caused a methane buildup the day of the disaster. Federal investigators were unable to determine exactly what triggered the explosion. Monday's announcement said investigators looking for possible ignition sources found 65 electrical violations in cables and circuits. One electrical cable had 36 splices, all of which had been improperly made, Tattersall said. Investigators also found 41 violations concerning ventilation and pre-shift safety examinations. Another 15 citations involved miscellaneous safety violatings, including blasting caps haphazardly left in the work area.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for `Balance' Between Environmental, Economic Concerns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs new material after 10th graf pvs, Earlier this
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday the federal government ought to strike a ``needed balance'' between environmental priorities and economic concerns. Addressing a controversial proposal to protect the northern spotted owl, the president told a Republican fund-raising breakfast that he rejects environmentalists who ``ignore the economic consequences'' of protecting such fragile species. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is to decide June 23 whether to add the owl to the endangered species list. Such a decision would require federal agencies to protect the owl's habitat, the Northwest's old-growth forests. Earlier this month, the U.S. Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management said such a decision would cut timber harvests from federal lands nearly in half over the next five years, producing a net loss of about 13,000 jobs in Oregon, Washington and northern California. Bush said that he is concerned ``about preserving and protecting our environment'' but that he rejects ``those who would ignore the economic consequences of the spotted owl decision. The jobs of many thousands of Oregonians and whole communities are at stake.' He told the breakfast, held to raise money for GOP gubernatorial candidate Dave Frohnmayer, ``Common sense tells us to find a needed balance.'' ``It's going to take a lot of work to protect this great planet and its wildlife without throwing hard-working citizens out of a job,'' the president said, telling his audience he disagrees with those ``who do not recognize their obligation to protect our delicate ecosystem.'' Referring to other contentious environmental issues, Bush said, ``I want Congress to pass a bill that will sharply cut acid rain, smog and toxic pollutants. But Congress has got to respect another kind of delicate ecology _ that of jobs and opportunity.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, asked after Bush's speech if the administration was considering proposing changes in the Endangered Species Act, said, ``There has been no consideration of it.'' Earlier this month, however, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said the law was ``just too tough'' and added, ``We've got to change it.'' Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., said Bush has agreed to schedule a White House meeting with a group of Oregon residents to discuss a long-term solution to the Northwest's timber-supply problem. ``This meeting will give Oregonians living in rural communities the chance to tell their side of the story,'' Smith said. ``Their jobs and way of life are on the line, and yet all we've been hearing about is how we need to protect the spotted owl.'' National Wildlife Federation President Jay D. Hair said, meanwhile, that ``if President Bush is truly committed to protecting both Oregon jobs and the environment, he should recognize that the problems of an ailing timber industry predate concerns over owls or ancient forests. Resorting to scapegoating the owl for political gain does nothing to achieve balance.'' Bush also said he wants Congress to move on his proposals to block drug smugglers, fund more border agents and give them more enforcement authority, as well as the power to order suspected drug-smuggling planes to land. ``To those who ask if our measures are too harsh, I say that the threat to many Americans, especially those living in the inner-city, is too great,'' he said. About 150 to 200 people demonstrated outside the hotel where Bush spoke, burning American flags and newspapers and setting off smoke bombs. Police arrested 27. The demonstrators appeared to be mostly of college age and represent many groups, including peace activists, pro-choice demonstrators, environmentalists and gay rights advocates. Frohnmayer is seeking to replace Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt, who is retiring. From Portland, Bush travelled to Los Angeles and sat in on a meeting of anti-drug activists in a private home in the Oakwood district of Venice. He praised the community for banding together to drive out drug dealers, who had once overrun the neighborhood. ``Working with police, they decided to reclaim their streets, to reclaim their children, to reclaim their future. And they are succeeding,'' Bush told a gathering outside the house. The president delivered a plaque to community leaders naming the Oakwood Community Beautification Committee as a daily ``point of light.'' Bush issues the award every day to individuals or organizations that exemplify his ``thousand points of light'' theme of volunteerism.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Lawmakers Urges P&G to Reconsider Boston Ad
DOC.TEXT: Four members of the Massachusetts congressional delegation urged Procter & Gamble on Monday to resume advertising on two TV stations that aired spots critical of P&G's purchase of coffee from El Salvador. A letter signed by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy and Reps. Edward Markey, Joseph P. Kennedy II and Joseph Moakley, all Democrats, said P&G's decision to pull ads from a station in Boston and another in Worcester, Mass., set a dangerous precedent. The company, the nation's largest advertiser of packaged products, pulled ads in response to a 30-second commercial that called for a boycott of Folgers Coffee. The commercials were produced by Neighbor to Neighbor, a political advocacy group that favors a boycott of Folgers as a way of influencing U.S. foreign policy toward El Salvador. A portion of the coffee that goes into Folgers comes from El Salvador. ``We are alarmed that your company's decision to suspend advertising on the two stations, simply for disagreeing with the content of another paid advertisement broadcast over those stations, is an extremely harmful precedent,'' the legislators wrote. ``Our concern is that television stations might fall victim to intimidation from a large advertiser out of fear of economic retribution for airing paid commercials from smaller advertisers,'' the letter said. ``Such economic intimidation comes very close to an effective corporate censorship over advertising content.'' The letter was addressed to Edwin L. Artzt, chief exectutive officer of Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble. A spokeswoman for Procter & Gamble did not immediately return a phone call seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: South and North Yemen Expected to Merge on Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: North Yemen's pro-Western parliament on Monday approved a plan by President Ali Abdullah Saleh to merge Tuesday with socialist South Yemen, official radio reports in North Yemen said. The reports said the 159-member Shura Council, or parliament, had ``agreed with a sweeping majority'' to merge the two Yemens, which are among the world's least developed states. San`a, the North Yemeni capital, is to serve as capital of the newly named Yemen Republic. South Yemen's parliament, the Supreme People's Council, also held a special session to approve the unification of the two Red Sea nations. A united Yemen would be the second such union between two Arab states in this century. In the 1950s, Egypt and Syria joined as the United Arab Republic, but the merger collapsed after three years because of internal squabbling. The new state would bind together 11 million people _ nine million from the north and two million from the south. South Yemen was the Arab world's only avowedly Marxist state after it gained independence from Britain in 1971. But Yemen began to reform as democratic changes swept through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The two Yemens are poor and undeveloped; labor unrest in South Yemen has been aggravated in recent months as Western goods were transported from North Yemen to the south. Strikes mushroomed in most government offices and factories in South Yemen. The merger bid has been outwardly promoted by oil-rich nations on the Arabian Peninsula such as Saudi Arabia, which is eager to snuff out Soviet influence. Scores of Cuban and East German military experts are said to have left Aden, the capital of South Yemen in recent months. A friendship pact entitles the Soviets to maintain as many as 18,000 troops in the port city, but the extent of their deployment is unknown. The merger was originally planned for Nov. 30, but it was moved up to May 26. In recent days there had been pressure to speed up the schedule even more so the two Yemens can attend an emergency Arab summit on May 28 in Baghdad, Iraq, as one state. Shortly after the start of the session of South Yemen's 111-member Supreme People's Council, television announced that Foreign Minister Abdul-Aziz al-Dali had suggested Tuesday as the merger date. North Yemen's president then said he, too, expected a merger at noon Tuesday, when the new flag of the Yemen Republic would be raised. The flag is similar to the black, white and red one of North Yemen, but without the stars. North Yemen's lawmakers were to travel to Aden for a joint parliamentary session to proclaim the merger. A draft agreement on unification was agreed to by leaders of both nations on April 22 in the city of Taiz, halfway between Aden and North Yemen's capital of San`a. A planned transition period of 2{ years coincides with the remainder of the five-year terms for both legislatures. North Yemen's president is expected to be elected as head of a five-member presidential council.

DOC.HEAD: American David Lynch Wins Top Film Award at Cannes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to CORRECT graf 3 `Krystyna Janda' with description of her role in movie, film an underground favorite with Solidarity. Picks up 4th pvs, `The best...'
DOC.TEXT: ``Wild At Heart,'' a bloody, sexually explicit black comedy by American director David Lynch, won the Golden Palm award Monday night as the best film at the 43rd Cannes Film Festival. The host country's favorite, French box-office idol Gerard Depardieu, was honored as best actor for his title role in ``Cyrano de Bergerac,'' a lavish costume drama. Krystyna Janda of Poland won the best actress award for her portrayal of an innocent, apolitical woman who accidentally is sucked into the Kafkaesque prison system because a man she knew was a suspect in ``The Interrogation,'' by Polish director Ryszard Bugajski. The 1980 movie by Bugajski was banned from Polish theaters until the pro-democratic reforms last year. The film was a favorite with the Solidarity underground on videotape. The best director award went to Pavel Lunghin of the Soviet Union for his first film, ``Taxi Blues,'' a look at the seamy side of glasnost. Another Soviet director, Gleb Panfilov, was honored for best artistic contribution for ``The Mother,'' the story of a woman's anguish as her son becomes radicalized by the family's harsh life under czarist rule and is tried for subversion. Lynch, 43, became the second American in a row to win the Golden Palm, following Steven Soderbergh, the 1989 winner for ``sex, lies and videotape.'' ``I've been trying to get to the Cannes Film Festival for 20 years,'' Lynch told a celebrity-filled audience. ``It's a dream come true.'' Known for the bizarre nature of such films as ``Eraserhead'' and ``Blue Velvet,'' Lynch introduced himself in his movie's program at Cannes as ``an Eagle Scout from Missoula, Mont.'' His other work includes the current American television series ``Twin Peaks.'' ``Wild At Heart'' portrays a love affair between Sailor Ripley, who commits manslaughter in self-defense, and Lula Pace Fortune. The film becomes a chase, as the young couple _ played by Nicholas Cage and Laura Dern _ is pursued through the deep South and Texas by a variety of antagonists. There is close-up gore, explicit love scenes and frequent flashes of humorous fantasy. Janda, 38, has worked with several of Poland's top directors but until Monday was little-known abroad. In ``The Interrogation,'' she is constantly on screen, moving audiences with a harrowing portrayal of a victim of repression. Depardieu, 41, is a veteran of 60 films and has received unanimous raves from French critics for his portrayal of Cyrano, the long-nosed, lovelorn cavalier of Edmond Rostand's famous play. The Jury's Grand Prize, traditionally a sort of runner-up award, went to two films from other continents _ ``Sting of Death'' by Kohei Oguri of Japan and ``Tilai'' by Idrissa Ouedraogo of Burkina Faso. The First Jury Prize went to ``Hidden Agenda,'' a controversial film by Briton Ken Loach depicting British government attempts to cover up human rights abuses by security forces in Northern Ireland. The Grand Prize for technical achievement was awarded to Pierre Lhomme, director of photography for ``Cyrano de Bergerac.'' Several films not in the running for the Golden Palm were honored by the 10-member jury. These included ``Don't Move, Die or Come Back to Life,'' by first-time Soviet director Vitali Kanevski, and ``The Lunch Date,'' by American Adam Davidson, selected as best short film.

DOC.HEAD: Stepped-Up Warnings Called For
With AM-Cancer Accutane
DOC.TEXT: Panels of medical experts on Monday recommended stronger efforts to ensure that the acne drug Accutane is not taken during pregnancy because it can cause birth defects. But the two Food and Drug Administration advisory committees rejected the advice of some within the agency who want Accutane withheld from all women to eliminate any risk of birth defects from the drug. The manufacturer, Hoffman-LaRoche, said it was pleased with the recommendations, which it said were close to additional warnings it announced earlier in the day. Accutane, which has been on the market since 1982, is the best treatment for severe recalcitrant cystic acne, a disfiguring and debilitating form of acne. But a woman who takes the drug during pregnancy has a 1-in-4 chance of having a baby with serious birth defects. The committee actions came as other physicians were reporting that Accutane can significantly block the growth of new tumors in people being treated for smoking-related cancer of the mouth and throat. In September 1988, Roche Dermatologics, a division of Hoffman-LaRoche, began a pregnancy prevention program aimed at emphasizing and educating physicians about the importance of avoiding pregancy during treatment. Roche officials say 86 cases of birth defects have been reported to the company as being associated with Accutane since the drug was first marketed. But David Graham, an FDA medical epidemiologist, said that number represents only about 10 percent of the number that actually occur. He estimated that since 1982, nearly 1,000 babies have been born with birth defects because their mothers were using Accutane. Graham also estimated that about 90 percent of the women using Accutane do not have the severe form of acne for which the drug is indicated. Accutane was prescribed last year for about 65,000 women of child-bearing age. But the estimated annual incidence of severe recalcitrant cystic acne in this group of women is less than 4,000, Graham said. The overprescribing exposes tens of thousands of women to the possibility of a malformed child if they become pregnant while being treated, he said. It also increases the likelihood of abortion, he said. Citing a Michigan Medicaid study, he said women using Accutane had twice as many abortions as women not using the drug. He said Roche's pregnancy prevention program ``has failed to achieve its objective.'' ``The only way to eliminate exposure is to eliminate use of this (drug) by women,'' he said. Robert Armstrong, director of medical affairs for Roche Dermatologics, said Graham's estimates were based on shaky assumptions. He also said that no one is sure how many women have the severe acne. But he said he was sure the number of congenital malformations that result from Accutane are not as large as Graham believes. ``If there were that many out there, they would be noticed and reported,'' Armstrong said. The FDA's advisory committees on dermatologic drugs and fertility and maternal health drugs recommended by general consensus that the company emphasize in its program the importance of a pregnancy test before a patient starts using Accutane. The panels also recommended a program for patients to return any unused Accutane at the end of treatment and that forms to record patient consent, now available in English and Spanish, be available in more languages. Additionally, the panels said physicians should be encouraged to refer Accutane patients for contraception counseling. Roche announced earlier in the day it was supplementing its pregnancy prevention program to stress the importance of the first pregnancy test, which Roche will offer to pay for _ and which must show no pregnancy before therapy can begin. Other new measures include stepped-up advertising aimed at physicians, possible development of a special prescription pad to reinforce the warnings, provision of an illustration of a deformed infant in the package literature and development of a method to return unused Accutane.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Wounds 10 on Jordan Tour Bus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with bus attack, protest march on U.S. Embassy, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian with a dagger and pistol boarded a bus carrying French tourists Monday and shot or stabbed 10 people, wounding at least one critically, police said. They said he acted to avenge a massacre in Israel. On Monday night, police fought thousands of demonstrators marching toward the U.S. Embassy to vent their fury over Sunday's killings of seven Palestinian laborers in Israel and subsequent violence on the West Bank and Gaza strip. Several police were injured, at least two demonstrators arrested and dozens of shop windows shattered, but no serious casualties were reported. The slayings set off protests in Jordan's Palestinian refugee camps. Jordanian authorities said nine tourists and a Jordanian tour photographer were wounded Monday in the bus rampage by Ahmad Badwan, 28, a Palestinian from the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip who carried a temporary Jordanian passport and lived in Amman. ``The motive behind the Amman shooting incident was to avenge the killing of Palestinian laborers in a Tel Aviv suburb Sunday,'' a police spokesman said but refused to elaborate. Israeli police said the Israeli who shot seven Palestinians to death and wounded others was deranged. The shootings led to violent demonstrations in Israel's occupied territories in which more deaths and injuries occurred. On Monday morning, the Palestinian gunman got on the bus with 30 tourists aboard while it was parked near a popular tourist attract, the Roman amphitheater in downtown Amman. He ``threatened to shoot if anybody moved,'' said a police official, who cannot be named under standing regulations. ``The tourists were scared and many started shouting, which pushed the gunman to fire in all directions from a 7mm pistol,'' he said. An Interior Ministry announcement said the man fired until he ran out of ammunition, then stabbed two tourists with a dagger before surrendering to police. Police arrested the attacker amid pandemonium. Pedestrians and shopkeepers fled in panic when the gunshots rang out. Five tourists were treated at Bashir Hospital and released. Five other victims were transferred to Hussein Medical Center for further treatment. The hospital said 55-year-old Andre Pierro of Paris was in critical condition with gunshot wounds in his left arm and right thigh and a stab wound in the stomach. French Ambassador Denis Bauchard said Christian Legendre, 62, of Paris, was shot in the left side of the chest and also was in critical condition. Jordanian Marwan Al-Baba, 30, was shot in both palms. He was a photographer for the Jordanian agency that handled the tourist group. French President Francois Mitterrand called the hospital to inquire about the victims, Jordanian officials said. King Hussein and Crown Prince Hassan visited the wounded. Jordanian police said they were tightening security for foreign tourists. They said police cars would escort the estimated three dozen tour buses visiting Jordanian sites. Hussein said in a TV address he was surprised that the attack ``took place in our hospitable nation. ... It is probably related to a feeling of anger ... toward Israel and its crimes, especially for what happened yesterday.'' But he said the violence in Israel was ``not an enough excuse at all for what happened in Amman today.'' The demonstration was brewing in the streets as the king spoke. The protesters appeared a mix of Moslem fundamentalists and Palestinian nationalists. Some waved the the Koran, Islam's holy book, and shouted, ``Allahu akhbar!'' (God is great). Others waved black or Palestinian flags and yelled ``The U.S. is the head of the snake!'' _ referring to Israel. They hurled rocks at police on the roads leading toward the embassy, wounding several. Police used tear gas and billy clubs trying in vain to divert the demonstrators from the mixed residential and business area around the embassy. The police and army deployed a huge force to seal off the street outside the U.S. Embassy, where 30 riot police linked arms at each of 10 roadblocks. Frustrated demonstrators broke shop windows and traffic lights and rolled garbage cans into the street. At least 20,000 Palestinian residents of the Baqaa Refugee Camp, 17 miles northwest of Amman, demonstrated on Monday to protest the killings in Israel. They rolled burning tires onto the Amman-to-Damascus highway, closing it for more than four hours. Police fired tear gas inside the camp when the demonstrators started to march toward Amman. Roughly half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families who fled or were forced from their homeland during the 1948 and the 1967 Arab-Israeli wars.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls Throughout South, Also Northeast Corner and Pacific Coast
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains, gusty winds and hail buffeted the South on Monday, and thunderstorm watches were posted for most of the Gulf states. Morning thunderstorms continued to drift to the south and east. By afternoon storms extended from central Louisiana across Mississippi, central and western Alabama, and parts of Tennessee, Kentucky, Indiana, Illionis and Missouri, and along the Georgia and South Carolina coasts. Severe thunderstorm watches were issued for parts of central and southern Mississippi, eastern Louisiana, southern and central Alabama and central and southern Georgia. Hail up to an inch in diameter fell at Montgomery, Ala., and Brookhaven, Louisville and Philadelphia, Miss. Gusty winds caused minor damage in Sheffield, Ala., and a half-dozen Mississippi towns. Rain wasn't limited to the Southeast. Northwestern New York, most of New England, Maryland and Delaware, and the northern half of the Pacific Coast also had thunderstorms. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 1.35 inches at Columbus, Miss., and .86 inch at Monroe, La. Flood warnings were issued along the White River from Edwardsport to Hazleton, Ind., and along the Wabash River from Mount Carmel, Ill., to New Harmony, Ind. The Mississippi River was flooding from Cairo, Ill., to Caruthersville, Mo., and was expected to reach flood stage at New Madrid on Tuesday. Elsewhere, temperatures were unseasonably cool in the Rockies, dropping into the 20s and 30s in some places overnight. Late season snow and sleet fell in the Vermont mountains. Up to 3 inches of snow fell overnight near Anchorage, Alaska. The morning low for the nation was 23 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 38 degrees at Worcester, Mass., to 96 at both Kingsville and Sanderson, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Aylwin Vows Justice in Rights Cases in State of Nation Address
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin said Monday in his first state of the nation address that he will seek ``truth and justice'' in investigating human rights abuses under the past military regime. ``We know that many cruel and painful things have occurred, leaving as a result not only suffering but also anger among many of our compatriots,'' he said. ``Ignoring those events would mean worsening that suffering and allowing that anger to turn into irrational expressions of hatred and violence,'' the 71-year-old president added. Aylwin spoke before a joint session of the two-chamber congress in this port city 75 miles northwest of Santiago. The nation's top military and civilian leaders attended the address. But Aylwin's predecessor, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, was absent from the assembly. Pinochet ruled for 16{ years until March 11 and was condemned by international organizations for widespread rights abuses. Aylwin's two-hour speech restored a tradition in Chile in which the president delivers his annual state of the nation address before Congress. During Pincohet's rule, congress was suspended and the annual address was delivered before military commanders, government officials and supporters. The 74-year-old general remains commander of the 60,000-man army. He has made clear his deep opposition to Aylwin's efforts to investigate rights violations. Pinochet personally conveyed to Aylwin his concern over the president's establishment in April of the Commission for Truth and Reconciliation, which is gathering information on rights cases. The commission's work is expected to result in a number of rights trials, many involving military officers. Aylwin insisted Monday that the commission not ``bring the armed forces to trial.'' The panel, he said, will not only investigate abuses committed by security officials of the Pinochet regime, but also terrorist attacks in which soldiers were the victims. After taking power in a 1973 coup, Pinochet launched a harsh crackdown on the supporters of the ousted leftist government. Thousands were arrested and many were tortured or killed. Tens of thousands were forced into exile. Aylwin said in his speech that he wants a ``reconciliation among civilians and military,'' but he admitted this would be difficult. ``For decades, the members of the armed forces had good reason to feel segregated,'' Aylwin said. ``And for the last 16{ years, a large portion of our population had good reasons to feel mistreated and humiliated.'' Aylwin said his government will also try to preserve and strengthen the newly restored democracy, maintain economic development, promote social justice and respect human rights.

DOC.HEAD: Final Campaigning Before U.S. Senate Primary
DOC.TEXT: Veteran Congressman Larry Craig shook hands with workers at shift changes Monday, confident of victory in the GOP primary race to replace U.S. Sen. James McClure. ``I think it will be a good win, a strong win,'' said Craig, who is favored to beat Attorney General Jim Jones in the primary Tuesday. McClure, a Republican who served three terms, will retire at the end of his current term. Jones, who raised just one-tenth of the $400,000 Craig gathered to bankroll his campaign, also was in Boise Monday, but focused on his official duties after his populist, shoestring campaign ran its course. Beside voting, his only election-day plans were to take his 12-year-old daughter to lunch. ``At this point, the die is pretty much cast, and we'll see how things come out,'' said Jones, who hoped for a relatively light turnout that would indicate a failure of Craig's campaign to energize voters. State election officials expected 30 percent to 35 percent of registered voters to vote after a generally lackluster campaign for one of only three U.S. Senate races this year without an incumbent involved. Boise businessman Ron Twilegar, the former state Senate Democratic leader, met with strategists on the eve of his anticipated primary victory over political newcomer David Steed, an Idaho Falls businessman. Twilegar admitted he faced an uphill battle in the fall for a seat that has traditionally gone to the GOP. All three Republicans fighting for the right to block Democrat Gov. Cecil Andrus' heavily favored bid for an unprecedented fourth term this fall put in a final day of campaigning. Polls indicated GOP voters remained largely undecided. State Sen. Rachel Gilbert of Boise, the chairman of the tax-writing committee, pressed her claim to the front-runner's spot, and former state Senate Majority Leader Roger Fairchild of Fruitland admitted a low turnout would hand Ms. Gilbert the nomination. Boise stockbroker Milton Erhart pinned his hopes on being the only candidate in the field with a pro-choice abortion stand, and he also needed a relatively high turnout to draw voters beyond the traditional conservatives who generally dominate Idaho GOP primaries.

DOC.HEAD: Observers Disagree Whether Romanian Election Free or Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to RECAST; INSERTS 5 grafs after 14th graf `Already some' to UPDATE with State Department reaction. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `Rompres said...' Edits thereafter to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBUC6
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Ion Iliescu captured 87 percent of the 6.7 million votes counted so far, but foreign observers disagreed Monday whether Romania's first multiparty election in 53 years was free of fraud. The main opposition parties charged results of Sunday's balloting were rigged, called Romania's first attempt at democratic voting a failure, and said they would contest the elections in court. Ion Ratiu, the National Peasants' Party's presidential candidate, said he would take legal action to have the election declared ``null and void.'' He vowed to fight ``against the renewal of Communism in Romania,'' which he said Iliescu represents. Iliescu, 60, came to power in the December revolution against Nicolae Ceausescu and was the heavy pre-election favorite. He drew huge campaign crowds, especially in the countryside where he was seen as the man who saved Romania from the Communist dictator. The campaign occasionally turned violent, but no major incidents were reported Sunday. First official results published by the state news agency Rompres suggested an overwhelming win for Iliescu. Most official results were not expected until Wednesday because of the heavy turnout, estimated at more than 85 percent of the 16 million eligible voters, and the complicated ballot, which contained more than 30 pages. The dispute among the 500 foreign observers who fanned out across the country to watch the voting centered on whether a series of irregularities added up to acceptable or unacceptable election violations. Gov. Garrey E. Carruthers, R-N.M., the official U.S. government observer, called the poll ``a good election'' and ``a very giant step toward democracy.'' Austrian parliamentarian Andreas Khol, general secretary of the European Democratic Union, disagreed, saying: ``These were a big step toward free and democratic elections, but they were not free and not democratic elections.'' Carruthers asked the Romanian government to set up mechanism to investigate allegations of fraud and irregularities during the campaign and voting. Prime Minister Petre Roman, a prominent member of Iliescu's governing National Salvation Front, said later the Central Electoral Bureau had set up a commission to investigate alleged improprieties. ``Already some fraud was discovered,'' he told The Associated Press, citing as an example what he said were 25 ballots pre-stamped for the National Liberals' candidate, Radu Campeanu. In Washington, State Department Deputy Spokesman Richard Boucher said voter fraud was minimal and hailed the elections as ``an important beginning for Romania. ``We note that problems with voting and other election day irregularities appear to have been minimal, although opposition political party leaders have complained of breaches of election law procedures,'' Boucher said. But he said the election campaign was flawed by candidates' lack of access to the news media and the intimidation of opposition candidates. He said there were no conclusions about possible U.S. economic aid to Romania because ``our assessment of the elections is only now beginning.'' The United States has said future relations and U.S. trade concessions, important to Romania's shattered economy, are conditional on whether the elections were ``fully free and fair.'' Rompres said that with 6.7 million votes counted, Iliescu had 87 percent; Campeanu 10 percent, and Ratiu, 3 percent. Its vote report also had the Front winning nearly two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. A onetime Communist official who opposed Ceausescu in 1971, Iliescu gained sympathy for being demoted and was far better known and popular than either Campeanu or Ratiu, who spent decades in exile. Iliescu won wide support from peasants by permitting them to own large plots of land. Industrial workers, about 40 percent of Romania's labor force, liked his pledges to move slowly in transforming Romania's state-controlled economy to a capitalist free market. Iliescu and the Front will likely be the first ex-Communists in Eastern Europe to triumph in the region's current series of multiparty elections. Initial Rompres results for the two-chamber Parliament gave the Front about 65 percent; Liberals, 7 percent; Peasants, 3 percent; and ecologists 3 percent. The Hungarian Democratic Union, representing Romania's 2 million Hungarian minority, had about 7 to 8 percent. The other votes went to tiny parties. Ratiu, who attended Carruthers' news conference, said the governor's upbeat assessment would completely mislead Americans and President Bush. Calling the election a fraud, Ratiu said, ``There was no semblance of democracy about it.'' ``We will contest the election if this is the sort of result that we get,'' he said, pledging to demand new elections. The various observer groups reported instances of ballots pre-stamped for Iliescu, Front members accompanying elderly voters into the booth, non-registered voters casting ballots, and individuals voting several times. Many observer complaints focused on the campaign rather than the voting itself. Several alleged that the Front, which dominated the interim government, unfairly controlled the election apparatus and the electronic media. Carruthers and other observers urged the West and the new Romanian government to work to create a free press as a guarantee of future democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Floodwaters Retreat, Hot Springs Spruces up for Tourists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to UPDATE with partial damage estimate.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR1
DOC.TEXT: The flash flood that turned this resort town's main drag into a river receded as fast as it arrived, but a new problem emerged from the muck Monday: The weekend flood caused a drought of the thermal spring water that gave the town its name and its tourist industry. The 13 inches of rain that fell in 24 hours knocked out the pumps at the end of Bathhouse Row that supply 140-degree underground water to the spas. It will take at least a week to fix them, said Roger Giddings, superintendent of Hot Springs National Park, which runs the pumps. ``It's the lifeblood of Hot Springs,'' Giddings said of the water that has has attracted the infirm, the health-conscious and the athletic to this city of 36,000 for nearly a century. Elsewhere, waterlogged communities in Louisiana and Texas were emerging from under floodwaters that have raged through several states for days. Downtown Hot Springs, which lies in a steep valley, was flooded when rain overwhelmed drainage systems. Nobody was injured, and a preliminary, partial estimate by the city manager's office put damage at $5.3 million to businesses and public works. That doesn't include damage to more than 100 private homes. Business leaders were more concerned about a loss of business than the temporary loss of water, which is pumped from the area's 23 springs to seven bathhouses and three hotels. At least 90 percent of the downtown business is linked to tourism, and the city isn't ready to concede that kind of money to a flood, especially with Memorial Day looming. On Monday, store owners replaced shattered windows and swept away the mud. An advertising blitz was planned to let potential tourists know the town is waiting with open arms. ``Our town and state have been shown to a national television audience as being swept by torrents of raging rainfall,'' said Bob Wheeler, a member of the city board of directors. ``True, here in Hot Springs we had a bad Saturday night, but that is over and we will be ready for summer vacationers by this weekend.'' Elsewhere on Central Avenue, Don Wilson of the Salvation Army handed out ham and cheese sandwiches from a beat-up food truck. Don Heath, owner of Craft and Fair, watched as several workers hauled his carpet out to the street and hosed off the sediment. ``I don't want to win any awards, but we were the hardest hit,'' said Imy Marcus, owner of the Toy Chest downtown. He said about $30,000 worth of stuffed animals and dolls _ about 40 percent of his inventory _ were swept away by the two flash floods that hit Saturday and Sunday. His store will be open by next week, Marcus said. Far worse was the plight of the owners of about 136 homes destroyed by the flood. Flooding along Lake Catherine, about 20 miles from downtown, appeared to be the worst. Phil Phillips, whose house sits about 20 feet from the lake, picked through his soggy furnishings. ``This fiddle was made in 1814,'' he told a reporter. ``Can't tell you how much it's worth.'' His wife, Edith, said the water rose to the rooftop but dropped to puddle-level within a few hours Sunday morning. ``It came so quick and did so much,'' she said. In Louisiana, the Red River that runs through the Red River Parish northeast of Alexandria began inching back toward its banks. Flood covered at least 140 square miles of farmland and drove more than 300 people from their homes in the past week. Most were able to return by Monday, officials said. ``We're in better shape now than we've been in a long time,'' said Chief Warren Perkins of the Red River Sheriff's Office. ``We're just worried about more rain. ... I suspect a lot of people will leave the sand bags in place for a while.'' In southeast Texas, the Trinity River's rise in Liberty County appeared to slow Monday. The Trinity hit a record of 29.51 feet in Liberty on Monday, and the National Weather Service said it was expected to crest at 29.6 feet Thursday, 5.6 feet above flood stage. It could be weeks before the Trinity is back in its banks, officials said. An estimated 4,600 homes have been affected by flooding in a seven-county area, although Red Cross spokesman Bill Barron said he didn't know whether that many homes actually had been flooded.

DOC.HEAD: Police Strike Threatening Ivory Coast Leader's Grip on Power
DOC.TEXT: Police went on strike Monday, firing shots into the air and shooting out the tires of cars and buses, further threatening this embattled government's grip on power. State radio said Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny met with a delegation of police and promised to review their demands, and by late afternoon police appeared to have returned to their regular duties. The radio gave no further information. Houphouet-Boigny has met with various striking groups in recent weeks, including the military, and each time promised to improve their conditions. Although France recently stepped up aid to this former colony, it was not clear how Houphouet-Boigny would be able to fulfill his promises. The government has been unable to pay its foreign debt, and has had difficulty meeting government payrolls. The police strike came as no surprise after last week's army mutiny. Soldiers took over the national broadcast center twice and on May 16 seized the Abidjan airport for nine hours. They left after being promised their demands for better pay and working conditions would be met. Many of the mutinous soldiers were conscripts who said despite difficult conditions they wanted to remain in the military because they believed they had no hope of finding other jobs. France, a strong supporter of Houphouet-Boigny, refused his request to intervene and dislodge the soldiers from the airport. But it did send a top paramilitary police official to Abidjan to advise the president. Two days after the airport seizure, the government announced it had met the soldiers' demands. Several other groups, including bus drivers, have launched strikes, and have also won their demands. The economic difficulties are the result of a sharp fall in prices for the country's main exports, cocoa and coffee. The wave of protests began after the president, under pressure from foreign creditors, tried to impose austerity measures in March. The protests forced the closing of schools for the rest of the year and the withdrawal of the austerity measures. Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest serving president, also was forced to ease severe restrictions against opposition parties. Houphouet's Democratic Party has ruled the country as a de facto one-party state since independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Standards for Medical Laboratories Proposed
DOC.TEXT: More than 300,000 medical laboratories, including those in physicians' offices, would have to meet federal standards, under regulations proposed Monday. The regulations written by the Department of Health and Human Services are aimed at assuring the quality and accuracy of medical tests, said HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan. ``Under our plan, every laboratory, regardless of its location, must be federally certified as meeting quality standards,'' he said. ``Labs must prove they can perform their tests correctly.'' Under the proposal, laboratory tests would be divided into three categories. Tests that are complex and pose a high risk if done incorrectly, such as Pap smears to test for cervical cancer, and simpler tests with some risk, like cholesterol screening, would be subject to federal standards. Twenty-eight tests that HHS describes as simple with low-risk, such as dipstick urinalysis, would be waived from regulation. Labs that fail to comply with federal requirements for quality control, personnel qualifications and proficiency testing could have their certification revoked, suspended or limited or suffer other civil penalties. The regulation would implement a law passed by Congress in 1988 after reports about inaccuracies in Pap smear tests.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Announces Full Recognition of Israel
DOC.TEXT: Greece has granted full diplomatic recognition to Israel for the first time since the Jewish state was founded in 1948, Premier Constantine Mitsotakis said Monday. He told a Cabinet meeting Greece has also upgraded ties with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Greece is the last member of the 12-nation European Community to grant Israel full recognition. But Mitsotakis said that de jure recognition ``does not recognize the annexation nor the occupation by Israel of Arab territories seized in 1967.'' Greece has often expressed its opposition to Israel's continued occupation of the West Bank and its policy toward the Palestinians. Mitsotakis made a campaign pledge to recognize Israel prior to the April 8 general election. He said Greek ties with the PLO would resemble those now existing between France and the PLO. France recognizes the missions of Quebec and the PLO in Paris as general delegations and their representatives as delegate general. It traditionally recognizes countries and not governments or movements. The PLO's status as a general delegation is the only of its kind in France. It is less than a full state and does not imply diplomatic recognition. The PLO maintains a diplomatic mission in Athens and its ranking member is accorded the title of head of mission. Israel's diplomatic representative will now have full ambassadorial recognition. A Foreign Ministry announcement said that ``in agreement with the maintenance of friendly relations between states, the Greek government and the government of Israel have decided to upgrade the status of their relative diplomatic representations to the status of embassies.'' The announcement said representatives of both governments met Monday in Brussels and announced their new diplomatic status in a joint statement.

DOC.HEAD: Wolf Study Sent to Congress; McClure To Call for Wolf Transplants
DOC.TEXT: A new study on how wolves might act in Yellowstone National Park was sent to Congress on Monday, but one senator won't wait for that report to be dissected before legislating the predator's return. As summaries of the study were shipped to Capitol Hill, word came from Sen. James McClure's office that the Idaho Republican would call this week for wolves to be transplanted to Yellowstone as well as the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness in central Idaho. In Yellowstone, meanwhile, Superintendent Bob Barbee hailed the 586-page study compiled by the National Park Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service as the most thorough document yet on wolves. U.S. Rep. Ron Marlenee, however, called it ``poppycock.'' ``They established where they wanted to get to, and then did their study and made their evaluations so they could arrive at that point,'' the Montana Republican said. The study, put together with information from wolf experts from throughout the world and researchers from three universities, predicts little impact on wildlife or livestock near Yellowstone if wolves are returned. However, it speculates that some wolves would leave Yellowstone's boundaries and have to be controlled by one means or another to protect livestock interests. While some critics of the recovery plan fear wolves would decimate Yellowstone's big game herds, the study said the available prey base was at least five times greater than that which 100 wolves _ the ideal recovery population _ would be expected to reduce or even limit. The study said at least 30 wolves would have to be released initially to assure the program's success. It also suggested that wolves returned to Yellowstone be considered a ``nonessential experimental population'' so biologists would have freer rein in controlling them than if they were covered by the full Endangered Species Act. It also calls for more studies on the predator, and the Park Service has budgeted $175,000 for that work this fiscal year. Bryce Dustman, press secretary for Sen. Conrad Burns, a Montana Republican who is opposed to the wolf program, said he wasn't surprised by the report's claim that wolves would have little effect on wildlife or livestock. He said ``it jumped out at him'' that the two leading proponents of wolf restoration in Yellowstone _ the Park Service and Fish and Wildlife Service _ wrote a study saying the wolf wouldn't have a detrimental affect on livestock or big game.

DOC.HEAD: Stormie Not Rejecting Liver, May Return Home Soon
DOC.TEXT: Doctors on Monday increased Stormie Jones' doses of an experimental drug and were hopeful the world's longest surviving heart-liver transplant recipient will not reject her second donor liver. ``We're not alarmed,'' said Dr. Robert D. Gordon of Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Gordon operated on Stormie's first transplant on Feb. 14, 1984. ``This is a mild rejection episode. It is not a serious crisis event. We don't think this liver is in jeopardy or that she's looking at another transplant. She just needed an adjustment in her medication,'' he said. The 12-year-old girl returned to Pittsburgh Sunday after routine tests revealed she had high liver enzyme levels _ a sign of possible organ rejection from the Feb. 20 transplant of the second donor liver. Gordon said doctors found Stormie wasn't receiving adequate doses of FK-506, an experimental anti-rejection medication approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use only at two University of Pittsburgh hospitals. Stormie will receive higher doses of FK-506 intravenously until she is discharged and later will take the drug orally. Doctors said they hoped she could return to home to the Dallas suburb of White Settlement, Texas, within a few days. That's good news for Stormie, who has been eagerly awaiting a party for her 13th birthday on May 31, said her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell. ``Thirteen is a very special time in someone's life. So she's looking forward to that,'' she said. ``She's excited. She's running around all over the place.'' National attention has been focused on Stormie since she received the historic 1984 heart-liver transplant to control a congenital condition that left her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. She returned to Pittsburgh in November 1989 after hepatitis damaged her first donor liver. Up until that time, she had been taking cyclosporine, an anti-rejection medication that lowers the body's ability to fight infection.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Takes Hostage in Church; Kills Self
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to CORRECT spelling to Conarroe sted Connaroe, UPDATE with condition of deacon; pick up 11th graf pvs, `A few minutes...' INSERTS one graf after 15th pvs, `I knew...,' to ADD that Pearson from Toronto.
DOC.TEXT: A heavily armed man who was upset at renovations to a church wounded two people and barricaded himself inside the church with a hostage for seven hours Monday before killing himself. Officers fired tear gas and stormed St. Sebastian-By-The Sea Episcopal Church at 3:15 p.m. to find the body of the man, identified by police as Douglas Pearson, 47. Pearson was a member of a church building committee and church members said he had been upset about renovations at the church, including a plan to add trim to the church's new copper steeple, said committee member Ted Ferris. Joan Heller, a spokeswoman for the Brevard County Sheriff's Department, said the gunman apparently shot himself. The hostage, Deacon George Smodell, crawled out as police stormed the church, Heller said. Smodell was in stable condition at Holmes Regional Medical Center with a gunshot wound to the leg, a hospital spokeswoman said. The gunman also went to the red brick church Saturday night, armed and upset, Heller said. Police were called, and confiscated two assault rifles and a pistol then. On Monday, he had a .357-caliber Magnum and .45-caliber pistol, authorities said. The attacks began about 8:40 a.m. when Pearson's wife called police to say: ``He's all upset. He has guns.'' A short time later, in Melbourne Beach, a 43-year-old woman was shot twice in the abdomen at point-blank range in her home with a .45-caliber pistol, Heller said. The woman, Diane Conarroe, was the wife of a church official, said Ted Ferris, a member of the church building committee. Pearson went to the home looking for John Conarroe, but shot his wife instead when she answered the door, Ferris said. Mrs. Conarroe was in critical condition at Holmes Regional Medical Center, said Debbie Helton, a hospital spokeswoman. A few minutes later, the gunman walked into an office, shot the deacon, and then ordered painter David Oraboni and a secretary to leave. ``He walked right by me,'' Oraboni said. ``I said `Good morning' to him and he said `Good morning.' Not more than 10 seconds later he pulled out a gun and started shooting. At first I didn't think it was real.'' While barricaded in the church, the gunman ignored repeated calls from police negotiators using the telephone and a bullhorn, said J.D. Wilmer, a sheriff's inspector who was one of the negotiators. Building committee member Ferris said Pearson had been upset for about a week about restoration work on the 25-year-old church, including a plan to add trim to the copper steeple. He talked to Pearson by telephone about 7:30 a.m. ``I knew he had some grudges against some people in the church,'' Ferris said. ``He said on the phone `this was (his) last hurrah.' '' Ferris added that he thought Pearson meant the last church remodeling project. Ferris said Pearson, who moved to Florida from Toronto about three years ago, worked in construction and design. Melbourne Beach is on the east coast of central Florida. The church is just across the Intracoastal Waterway from Palm Bay, where on April 24, 1987, a gunman killed six people and wounded 10 in two shopping centers. He then held a supermarket employee hostage for five hours before being captured by police officers. William Cruse, a former librarian, was convicted of the killings and sentenced to death in July 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Defused at School of Colombian President's Grandchild
DOC.TEXT: Bodyguards for one of President Virgilio Barco's grandchildren extinguished the burning fuse of a dynamite bomb set Monday in front of the child's school in Bogota, a diplomatic source and a teacher said. In the cocaine capital of Medellin, meanwhile, two men on a motorcycle killed federal Sen. Federico Estrada and his chauffeur in their car Monday. Estrada was a former member of the Supreme Court and former ambassador to Italy. The bomb was in front of the Helvetia school, a spokesman for the Swiss Embassy told The Associated Press on condition he not be identified for security reasons. The private school is known as Bogota's Swiss school. Many upper-class families send their children there. The dynamite was in two large burlap bags on a sidewalk in front of the school in northern Bogota, Ascal Stoffer, a teacher at the school, told The AP. No one claimed responsibility, but drug traffickers have killed scores of people with bombs in Colombia the last nine months. ``We were saved because bodyguards of the grandchild of the president were able to put out the fuse in time,'' Stoffer said in a telephone interview. He said bodyguards spotted the burning fuse while bringing the child to school. Barco has two grandchildren, both girls, attending the school in this city of 6 million people. The dynamite bomb was 1{ miles from where a car bomb exploded Sunday night, wounding 16 people. Barco's senior Cabinet minister, Horacio Serpa, called that bombing an obvious attempt by drug traffickers to scare people away from the polls in next Sunday's presidential elections. In reply to a question, he said he did not know if the bomb at the school was an attempt to kill one or both of the president's grandchildren. Serpa met with the reporters at the presidential palace after meeting with Barco. As minister of government, Serpa is in charge of security in Colombia. Five car bombs exploded in Bogota, Cali and Cartagena in the previous eight days, killing 28 people and wounding more than 300. Barco ordered security forces to destroy drug traffickers last Aug. 18 after presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan was assassinated by traffickers. Traffickers have set off dozens of bombs since then, including one that killed all 107 passengers aboard a domestic airliner. Police also blame traffickers for the slaying of two more presidential candidates. National Police headquarters in Medellin said police had no leads on who shot Estrada and his driver. Drug traffickers kidnapped Estrada a month ago and released him unharmed two days later with no ransom paid. Neither police nor senator said why he was kidnapped. In the previous 12 days in Medellin, 25 police have been killed and 25 wounded. The police blame all the deaths on drug traffickers, who have offered about $4,000 for each policeman killed there.

DOC.HEAD: Death Knell for Nightly Bell Ringing, Judge Rules
DOC.TEXT: Tranquility won over tradition Monday as a judge ordered that the Hatfield town bell be silenced at night, ruling in favor of a couple of newcomers who said the cherished custom kept them awake. The ruling was greeted with relief by the couple and with dismay by townsfolk who had argued that the hourly chiming was a treasured part of the New England character of their 320-year-old farming community. ``I think it's lousy,'' Selectman Chairman George Zgrodnick Jr. said after Hampshire Superior Court Judge John F. Murphy ordered that the 92-year-old bell be turned off after 9 p.m. and before 7 a.m. ``A certain part of the heritage of the town has been disrupted and I think that's very important, Selectman Thomas Hurley said. W. Michael Ryan, who represented newcomers Richard and Pamela Carnall, said the ruling, effective immediately, actually harks back to an old tradition of ringing the bell at curfew. ``We've ended a 20th-century tradition and revived a colonial-federalist era tradition,'' Ryan said. The Carnalls were unavailable for comment Monday, but Ryan said he had spoken to them. ``They're pretty private people. They have not enjoyed being in the public spotlight over this but they just felt that it was necessary to endure the publicity in order to obtain a relief,'' he said. Zgrodnick said the ruling would mean turning off the bell all the time, at least for now, because the town doesn't have the funds for an automatic timer. Earlier, the Carnalls had offered to pay for such a device, but Ryan said the offer has been withdrawn. The selectmen said it was too soon to tell if townsfolk would authorize money for an appeal, but that it would be discussed. The Carnalls moved from nearby Northampton in August 1988 and bought a 19th-century house on Main Street across from the First Congregational Church. The bell, housed in the church that once doubled as town hall, was broken at the time. But six months later it was fixed and is hourly resonant chiming resumed. The couple complained they and their young daughter couldn't sleep. After selectmen refused to stop the chiming, the Carnalls filed a civil suit against the town. Jurors ruled May 14 that the bell was a nuisance, but decided that only Mrs. Carnall was injured by its ringing and that neither plaintiff was entitled to damages. Based on the ruling, the Carnalls asked Murphy to grant an injunction that the bell be silenced after 9 p.m. and before 7 a.m. Town Counsel William O'Neil had argued that the injunction shouldn't be granted because the jury's verdict was mixed. But the judge agreed with the jurors that the ringing was a nuisance.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Rebuffs Iraqi Invitation to Arab League Summit
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad on Monday snubbed an Iraqi invitation to attend an Arab League summit and reiterated it should be preceded by preparations in a meeting of foreign ministers, an official said. But Assad made a conciliatory gesture toward Baghdad and said he would stand by Iraq in the event of an Israeli attack. Earlier Monday, Iraqi Justice Minister Akram Abdul-Qader arrived here carrying an invitation to the May 28 summit in Baghdad from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Abdul-Qader left for home after his meeting with Assad _ the first visit by an Iraqi official to Syria since the two countries broke diplomatic relations in 1979. Assad and Saddam are heads of rival branches of the socialist Baath party and are bitter enemies. The feud deepened during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war in which Syria supported Iran. After the war ended, Saddam backed Christian militias in Lebanon against Syrian-supported Moslem militias. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Assad supported the idea of the summit, but reiterated Syria's initial stand. This was that the summit's location and agenda must first be discussed at an emergency meeting of the foreign ministers of the 22-member Arab League in Tunisia. He also has categorically rejected Baghdad as a host location. The foreign ministers are scheduled to meet Tuesday in Baghdad. But the source said Assad's reply also stated that ``it must be clarified that independently from the issue of the summit, Syria will stand with all its might next to Iraq or any other Arab country exposed to Israeli aggression.'' In a related development Lebanese Premier Salim Hoss, a close Syrian ally, informed the Arab League that his country will not attend the Baghdad summit, a source in Beirut said. Also Monday, Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat's political and security adviser, Hani al-Hassan, said he met with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa Sunday night in an attempt to convince Syria to attend the summit. ``Palestine is very keen on Syria's participation in the forthcoming summit and President Arafat is trying his utmost to ensure an atmosphere of pan-Arab understanding,'' Hassan told The Associated Press. ``The Syrian-Iraqi reconciliation is for us the cornerstone for building our confrontation with the Israeli fascist right-wing,'' he added. The PLO called for the summit to discuss the immigration of hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel, which the PLO views as a threat. Saddam said threats to Iraqi security will also be on the agenda, an issue Syrian officials said they could not support. Saddam is seeking to rally support after Britain and the United States accused Iraq of trying to smuggle nuclear bomb triggers to Baghdad. Iraq has denied it is developing nuclear weapons but threatened to use chemical weapons against Israel if attacked. The Iraqis are also seeking to rally support after Iraq-bound shipments said to contain parts for a ``super gun'' capable of hitting Israel were seized in Britain, Greece, Turkey and Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Says They Reserve Right to Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebel leaders said Monday they reserve the right to launch another offensive if current peace talks with President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government fail to produce a cease-fire and agreement to end the decade-old war. The warning was contained in a statement distributed here by the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the guerrilla organization also known as FMLN, shortly after representatives from both sides signed an agenda for peace negotiations in Caracas, the Venezuelan capital. The agenda, signed after five days of talks, commits the two sides to agree on a cease-fire by mid-September, or earlier if political accords necessary for its implementation are reached before then. The negotiators, who met under the supervision of a United Nations official, also agreed to meet again to pursue the talks in mid-June. But it did not immediately specify the place or exact date. The FMLN's statement accused government troops of leading a nationwide offensive against guerrilla positions last week. The director of the armed forces press office was unavailable for comment on the allegation. Fighting continued while the talks were going on in Venezuela, but daily reports during the past week did not seem to indicate a sharp increase in the conflict. ``The FMLN reiterates that, as long is there is no cease-fire concerted by means of political accords, and as long as there is no end to military impunity and no concrete commitments to the demilitarization of the country, we reserve the legitimate right to defend ourselves,'' the statement said. It said this included ``launching of offensives of any size whenever they might be necessary anywhere in the country.'' The FMLN launched a large offensive against the capital and three other cities in November, the biggest since the civil war began in October 1979. An estimated 2,000 people were killed in the month-long fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Three More Palestinians Killed in Protests Over Laborers' Deaths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 2 grafs after 10th graf `Arab leaders' to UPDATE with Arafat remarks. Picks up 11th pvs, `The killings...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Jordan-Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers shot and killed three Palestinians and wounded up to 112 on Monday in violence set off by the massacre of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli civilian the day before. The suspect in Sunday's killings was identified as Ami Popper, a 21-year-old Israeli discharged from the army as unfit and characterized by authorities as ``deranged'' and upset by an unhappy love affair. Police held him in custody, and a judge ordered psychiatric tests. In Amman, Jordan, a 28-year-old Palestinian with a pistol and a dagger wounded nine French tourists and a Jordanian photographer on a tour bus. Police there said he was out to avenge Sunday's killings, but did not elaborate. Thousands of Palestinian demonstrators marched in protest toward the U.S. Embassy in Amman and fought police who got in their way. At least 20,000 Palestinian residents of Baqaa Refugee Camp demonstrated, and police used tear gas when the protesters tried to march to Amman, 17 miles away. In Washington, about 75 demonstrators gathered near the State Deparment and burned an effigy of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Some waved Palestinian flags and chanted, ``Palestinian statehood now!'' Smoke from burning tires rose above towns and refugee camps in the Gaza Strip, home to the seven men gunned down Sunday while waiting for day laborers' jobs in a Tel Aviv suburb. Youths on rooftops hurled stones at army patrols. Women in traditional Palestinian dress screamed and chanted as wounded victims were brought to the U.N. clinic in this refugee camp. Arab reports listed 103 Palestinians wounded in the Gaza Strip and nine shot and wounded in scattered clashes in the occupied West Bank. The army confirmed the three deaths and reported 40 Palestinians were wounded in Gaza. It said it was checking the other reports. Arab leaders said the Sunday massacre was the result of an anti-Arab atmosphere encouraged by Shamir's hard-line policies. At a news conference in Baghdad, Iraq, Yasser Arafat asked President Bush on Monday to pressure Israel to stop what Arafat called ``atrocities'' against the Palestinian people. Arafat, chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization, rejected Israeli claims that the lone gunman was mentally unbalanced and accused Shamir of planning ``a criminal scheme against the Palestinians and the intefadeh'' _ the Palestinian uprising in the occupied lands. The killings touched off riots in which seven more Palestinians were killed by Israeli soldiers. On the floor of Parliament on Monday, Arab Parliament member Abdel Wahab Daroushe called fellow lawmakers ``murderers.'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher criticized the Israeli army for its handling of the riots Sunday. ``We are disturbed by the number of casualties inflicted by the Israeli Army,'' Boucher said in Washington. ``We have repeatedly called upon the government of Israel to exercise restraint.'' At least eight soldiers or police and two Israeli civilians were reported injured by stones Monday in Gaza and Israel, where protests by Arab citizens erupted in a half-dozen towns. In the mixed Arab-Jewish city of Haifa, swastikas were painted on walls. In the northern town of Nazareth, a group of American tourists was stranded briefly inside a hotel as youths threw firebombs and burned tires. Maj. Gen. Matan Vilnai, commander of troops in Gaza, told reporters he was worried about an upsurge of revenge attacks on Israelis because of the killings. In Jerusalem's Ein Karem neighborhood, 40-year-old Jewish restaurant owner Yaacov Shalom was slain Sunday night, reportedly by Arabs. Police said it was unclear if the motive was political, but the fundamentalist Islamic Jihad group claimed responsibility in an anonymous phone call in Nicosia, Cyprus, and said it was revenge for the Sunday slayings. Monday's deaths raised to 705 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Forty-three Israelis have been slain in the revolt, and 216 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators. Dan Naveh, the spokesman for Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, said Palestinian and other Arab leaders were trying to exploit Sunday's killings by ``a crazed gunman.'' ``We call on them to be restrained and not cynically use the tragic incident to fan the flames of violence,'' he said in a statement. Survivors told reporters the gunman ordered a group of 50 workers to sit in a line and then opened fire with an assault rifle. The rioting that broke out later was the worst bloodshed in the uprising since April 15, 1988. On that day, 17 Palestinians died in riots after PLO military leader Khalil Wazir was slain in Tunis, reportedly by Israeli commandos. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said the government had no responsibility for the attack Sunday on the Palestinian laborers. ``In the United States, very often similar incidents occur when a crazy person takes to the street and shoots people,'' he said. ``There is no connection with the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Wyoming Governor Injured in Ranch Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Cliff Hansen, a former Wyoming governor and U.S. senator, was in good condition Monday with burns suffered when a fuel tank exploded at his ranch. Hansen, 77, had second-degree burns to his face, ears and legs, said officials at St. John's Hospital. Hansen was injured Friday at his Teton County ranch when fumes from a diesel tank ignited as he worked on the tank, said Matt Winters, a spokesman for Hansen's daughter, Mary Mead. Ms. Mead is running for governor. Hansen represented Wyoming in the U.S. Senate from 1967 to 1979 and was governor from 1963 to 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Asks Who Ordered Doctor's Kidnapping in Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said Monday he wants to know ``the highest level of authority'' that approved the alleged kidnapping of a Mexican doctor charged in the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered government prosecutors to disclose the information at a hearing scheduled for Friday on the manner in which Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was brought to the United States for trial. The alleged kidnapping of the Guadalajara gynecologist April 2 has strained relations between the United States and Mexico. Mexican officials, including President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, have called the operation a violation of their national sovereignty. Rafeedie has demanded to know how Alvarez was brought here from Mexico. Alvarez's trial has been indefinitely delayed pending the outcome of the hearing. Camarena, 31, an agent for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street in February 1985. Testimony at the trial of three other men in 1988 showed that he was taken to a house and tortured and interrogated by drug lords, then slain along with his pilot. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles outside Guadalajara. Prosecutors maintain that Alvarez gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torture before his slaying. Three Mexican men and a Honduran currently are on trial for their alleged roles in the murder of Camarena, the pilot and two tourists who prosecutors say were mistaken for drug agents and slain. At a status conference to discuss Friday's hearing, Rafeedie, referring to the alleged abduction, told prosecutors: ``I'd like to know the highest level of authority who authorized this.'' Outside court, Alvarez's lawyer, Robert Steinberg, said he would call four or five witnesses at the hearing. Among them, he said, would be Antonio Garate Bustamante, a former Mexican police officer who has said he arranged the doctor's abduction from his Guadalajara office at the behest of the DEA. Steinberg alleged that Garate is wanted in Mexico for a 1986 murder and said, ``The DEA brought a killer here to hunt killers.'' DEA officials have vowed to capture and prosecute every person involved in the Camarena murder. Steinberg said he would argue that Rafeedie has no jurisdiction over the Alvarez matter and should send it to the World Court at The Hague in the Netherlands for resolution. Barring that, he said, the judge should order Alvarez returned to Mexico. ``My basic motion is to send him home,'' the attorney said. ``Give it to the Mexican authorities and let them prosecute it, if they wish.''

DOC.HEAD: New Defense Minister Named in Guatemala
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Gen. Hector Gramajo Morales retired Monday and was replaced by another career military officer, Gen. Juan Leonel Bolanos Chavez. Gramajo was the only survivor of the original cabinet President Vinicio Cerezo named when he took office Jan. 14, 1986, for a 5-year term. He had been in the army for 36 years and the retirement appeared to be part of military routine rather than politically based. Gen. Juan Jose Marroquin Siliezar replaced Bolanos as military chief of staff and Gen. Roberto Enrique Mata Galvez moved up to assistant chief of staff, the job Marroquin had filled.

DOC.HEAD: Youngsters Find Parents Shot To Death In Barricaded Bedroom
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old boy worried about his parents hammered through a barricaded bedroom door to find them shot to death in an apparent murder-suicide, authorities said Monday. Found dead of shotgun blasts were Marie Morgan, 35, and her husband Anthony Morgan, 34, said Bexar County sheriff's Deputy Chief Jim DeLesdernier. ``It's obvious he shot her and then killed himself,'' DeLesdernier said. ``We looked for a (suicide) note but didn't find one.'' The boy and two siblings, ages 3 and 4, discovered the deaths Sunday afternoon. ``They had gotten up yesterday morning and had eaten some cereal, and tried to wake Mommy and Daddy up, and he had the door barricaded and they couldn't get into it,'' DeLesdernier said. ``Long about yesterday afternoon they got concerned that they couldn't wake up Mommy and Daddy and got the hammer.''
