The eldest child was able to beat a small hole in the door and saw his mother on the bed. The children then went to a relative's house nearby for help. Morgan, an electrician, may have been depressed about being unemployed, but Mrs. Morgan was working and those close to the family did not think there were serious financial problems.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Burglar Picks Wrong Hotel Room, Wakes Up Police Chief
DOC.TEXT: Police say a man arrested for trying to break into a hotel picked the wrong room _ one occupied by a visiting police chief. ``I told him the next time you try to burglarize a place, do it where there's not a police convention,'' Wrangell Police Chief Brent Moody said Monday. Moody was in Juneau for the convention of the Alaska Police Officers Association. He and his wife were sleeping in thir second-floor room at the Westmark Juneau Hotel when a man tried to break a window about 6 a.m. Sunday. The man apparently hit the triple-pane window with a board, but the glass did not break, Moody said. The noise woke the couple up, and Moody grabbed his gun. He called the front desk to summon police, then waited almost a minute as the suspect tried to pry open the window with the board. ``He had his hand inside the window and was trying to unlatch the lock,'' Moody said. The chief then tried to grab the man's arm, but as ``I pointed my gun at him he took off.'' Juneau police soon grabbed the suspect a few blocks away. Ricky S. Sumdum, 31, was arraigned in state District Court on one count of attempted criminal trespass. If convicted, he faces up to one year in prison and a $5,000 fine. He was being held Monday at the Lemon Creek Correctional Center in lieu of $250 bail. Juneau Police Capt. Mel Personett said the would-be burglar apparently climbed atop a first-story roof extension behind the hotel to reach the second-floor window.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Destroys Three More Homes
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano has destroyed three more homes on Hawaii Island, officials said Monday. Civil Defense personnel discovered shortly after daybreak Monday that three homes in Kalapana Gardens subdivision burned during the night, said spokesman Bruce Butts. Four other homes were in the path of the flow, Butts said. A total of 70 homes have been destroyed since April 4 and the 146 since the eruption began on Jan. 3, 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Snapshots Help Detectives Find Gunmen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to recast lead and CORRECT to Mac-9 sted Mach-9.
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen who killed three people in a Harlem bar left snapshots of themselves posing with weapons, detectives said Monday. After the gunmen fled from the shooting at the International Playhouse Bar and Lounge, detectives found two Polaroid snapshots they believe show the suspects. In the pictures, the three men posed gangland-style and displayed a Mac-9 machine gun, a .30-caliber rifle and a 9mm automatic pistol. ``I'm confident we'll be picking them up soon. It's not too hard when you get a photograph,'' said Capt. Daniel J. McKenna of Manhattan detectives. ``We have street names of the three but nothing more definite than that,'' the captain added. Detectives spent hours Monday at police headquarters going through records in an attempt to trace the suspects' identities, McKenna said. Investigators still have not determined a motive for the shootings, which occurred Sunday at about 2:50 a.m. EDT.

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees to Pay Noriega's Attorneys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs, `The attorneys...,' to UPDATE with Noriega's attorneys tentatively agreeing to drop subpoena for records of payments to general from CIA, other agencies. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Federal prosecutors...'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government Monday agreed to pay Manuel Noriega's attorneys, saying the ousted Panamanian ruler should be assured a fair trial on drug charges. The defense attorneys agreed to the deal offered by U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, saying Noriega would sign promises to pay the government back if $20 million in assets are released. Noriega's lawyers had threatened to withdraw from the case, saying they could no longer function without money to pay for the complex and lengthy legal proceedings. They wanted the government to release money from 27 Noriega accounts frozen around the world, assets prosecutors value at about $20 million. The attorneys had subpoenaed pay records from the CIA, Drug Enforcement Administration and other intelligence agencies to show Noriega had income other than alleged drug bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. But at Monday's hearing they asked that both the defense motion to withdraw from the case and the subpoenas be suspended until a formal fee arrangement was worked out. The motion to withdraw and the subpoenas would then be dropped, the defense team said. Federal prosecutors acknowledged Monday that Noriega received secret payoffs from U.S. intelligence agencies but disputed defense figures that put the amount at $11 million. The issue was expected to be the centerpiece of Monday's hearing until the arrangement for the attorney fees was disclosed. The prosecution ``wanted to avoid litigation that would get into matters having to do, certainly, with classified information, with payments by our government and other governments to Noriega,'' defense attorney Jon May said. ``It was in their interests to do so.'' Lehtinen told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler during a hearing that the federal Criminal Justice Act included provisions for the fee arrangement. ``Some cases are exceedingly complex, some are extremely long,'' said Lehtinen. ``It would be reasonable for counsel to be appointed by the court, and those fees paid by the government.'' The judge set at hearing for Thursday to discuss details of the fees. Defense attorney Frank Rubino said he was satisfied with the proposal. ``We do concur with them. We think this particular section (of the law) may solve the problem in extreme cases of this nature,'' he said. Rubino said Noriega, who was in court but did not testify, agreed to sign affidavits declaring he was indigent and that if his assets were freed he would repay the federal government. Rubino has said Noriega received $11 million from the United States for information about drug smuggling, along with $6 million or $7 million from as yet unidentified foreign countries. Prosecutors acknowledge that the United States paid Noriega, but dispute the details. ``The government believes that the amount is substantially less than that offered by the defense counsel,'' Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said Monday. ``I cannot be more specific because that information is not public.'' One account alone, in the United Kingdom, has about $10 million in it, said defense attorney Steven Kollin. Under classified information rules governing the trial, the attorneys could not say whose name was on the account, but exchanges in court indicate it may be the name of Noriega's wife. ``There is money in that account, and that's what we're fighting for,'' Kollin said. Hoeveler had urged prosecutors to expedite action on the asset issue, saying he views the question of attorneys' fees as extremely important. The judge has expressed skepticism of government claims that the money is all drug-related, saying as a military officer and leader of a country, Noriega must have had legitimate income. Noriega was indicted in February 1988 on charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from the Medellin cartel in exchange for turning Panama into a safe haven and transit point to support cocaine smuggling into the United States. He turned himself in to U.S. authorities on Jan. 4, two weeks after the invasion of Panama, and was flown to Florida, where he is being held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney's Man in Quebec Quits Government in Surprise
DOC.TEXT: Environment Minister Lucien Bouchard, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's chief lieutenant in Quebec, resigned Monday, dealing what may be a fatal blow to the Meech Lake accord on keeping Quebec in the federation. The 1987 accord, a proposed constitutional amendment, would give provinces special powers and recognize Quebec as a ``distinct society'' within Canada. All 10 provinces by law have a June 23 deadline to ratify the accord. The constitutional dispute over the accord has revived independence talk in Quebec, a largely French-speaking province. Bouchard and Mulroney agreed that Bouchard would quit after an hourlong meeting at the prime minister's residence Monday, sources told the Canadian Press news agency. Bouchard, 52, was considered the leader of the nationalists in the 61-member Quebec Conservative caucus in parliament. Other Quebec nationalists are likely to view his resignation as rejection of a special House of Commons committee report recommending ratification of the Meech Lake accord and of added measures contained in a companion resolution. Bouchard got in trouble after sending a telegram of encouragement to the Parti Quebecois, which in 1980 fought for an independent Quebec. Mulroney counts Bouchard among his oldest and closest political friends. In a telegram sent to a Parti Quebecois meeting in Alma, Quebec, Bouchard praised those who fought for an independent Quebec during the 1980 referendum. He refused to apologize for the telegram Sunday after arriving from Paris at Mirabel airport outside Montreal. He said he was proud of having worked for sovereignty-association and praised former party leader Rene Levesque. The telegram outraged opposition lawmakers in Ottawa, but was greeted with a standing ovation by party workers in Alma after it was read aloud Saturday by party leader Jacques Parizeau.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Judge's Age Discrimination Suit
DOC.TEXT: Vermont Supreme Court Justice Louis Peck can remain on the bench even though he is past the state's mandatory retirement age for judges, a federal appeals court ruled Monday. The ruling by the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals comes almost a year after Peck was scheduled to be retired by the state because he had turned 70. The state Constitution calls on all judges to retire at age 70, but Peck had fought the provision, saying it conflicted with a federal age discrimination law. ``I feel like a condemned man who has had a reprieve,'' said Peck Monday night after learning of the decision. ``Personally it is very satisfying.'' Peck, now 71, said he will now give some thought to stepping down. ``I may retire anyway,'' he said. The ruling by the New York-based federal appeals court settles the Peck case, but it does not settle the issue. Two other federal appeals courts, the 8th Circuit and 1st Circuit, have ruled the other way on the question, which means judges in those jurisdictions must adhere to their states' mandatory retirement provisions. ``Obviously Congress has not made its intention clear if the court disagree,'' said William Gray, the lawyer who represented the state of Vermont in the suit against Peck. Gray said it would be several weeks before the state decided whether it would appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``Taking away from states the power to decide when they retire their judges is a major shift of power from the states,'' said Gray. Thomas Lehner, the state court administrator, said he had not seen the decision and would not comment until he had. At issue was whether a federal law _ the federal Age Discrimination and Employment Act _ applied to appointed state judges. The law prohibits age discrimination against most employees. The state of Vermont argued first that judges fit one of the exceptions _ ``appointees on the policymaking level'' _ and second that Congress should not tell states how to set up their courts. On the first argument, the appeals court said appointed state judges do not fall under the exception. ``Congress meant to deny ADEA protection only to such appointees as would normally work closely with and be accountable to the official who appointed them,'' the judges said. On the second argument, the judges said Vermont had failed to show the federal law improperly trampled on the rights of the states. ``There is no suggestion that Congress surreptitiously enacted any legislation without notice to the state of Vermont,'' the court said. The decision by the New York-based 2nd Circuit counters rulings by the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and the St. Louis-based 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Those federal appeals courts upheld state mandatory retirement provisions. Peck was appointed to the Vermont Supreme Court in 1981. His current term expires in 1993. He turned 70 on Dec. 24, 1988, prompting Lehner to place him on retirement status, effective June 30, 1989, and prompting Peck to file an age discrimination complaint with the EEOC, which filed suit on his behalf. Last July, U.S. District Judge Lee Gagliardi sided with Peck, prompting the appeal by the state to the 2nd Circuit. The Vermont Supreme Court has five members. It is the only appeals court in the state.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Declines Comment on Probe Report
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard officials said Monday they knew nothing about a reported federal probe of drug corruption involving at least 11 guardsmen. An NBC report Monday night said the corruption case was expected to go to a federal grand jury soon. The report cited unnamed sources as saying the case focused on a member of President Bush's Coast Guard protection detail in Maine and an officer stationed in Islamorada in the Florida Keys. ``We are trying to find out if there is such a thing,'' said Jim Simpson, the press secretary for Admiral Paul Yost, the Coast Guard commandant. ``All we have right now are NBC's allegations.'' Federal authorities said the two unnamed guardsmen, along with at least nine other present and former members of the Coast Guard, are under investigation for selling classified information to smugglers, NBC reported. Four members of the Coast Guard's Islamorada station were convicted in 1988 on drug charges involving four kilos of cocaine they allegedly seized in waters off Florida and sold to an undercover agent in North Carolina, the Coast Guard said. Art Sola, Jeffrey Mey, Steven Vanheuson and James Weiss have been in prison since then, and Coast Guard officials said the case was closed, Simpson said. ``We knew about the guys who've been convicted, but as far as any pending cases, Admiral Yost was not aware of them,'' Simpson said. ``If they have evidence, they should bring an indictment and put guys in jail instead of leaking it through the press.'' Sources cited by NBC say the new indictments would be handed up as part of phase two of ``Operation Tempest.''

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of May 14-21:
DOC.HEAD: McClatchy Newspapers Sees Falling Ad Sales
DOC.TEXT: Responding to a 51 percent decline in earnings during the first quarter, McClatchy Newspapers Inc. says it is braced for more potential bad news this year and is cutting costs. Officials at the company's annual meeting May 16 blamed the decline on falling ad sales for newspapers across the country. Retail ad linage ``softened dramatically in March at most of our papers as it did throughout most of the country and resulted in a very disappointing first quarter,'' said Erwin Potts, president and chief executive officer of the company, which publishes The Sacramento Bee and 18 other newspapers in four states. Treasurer James P. Smith said net first-quarter income fell from $4.8 million in 1989 to $2.4 million in 1990. Smith also attributed the lower profits in part to interest expense from McClatchy's recent purchase of several South Carolina papers and on start-up costs for a newsprint mill in Washington state. ``We may yet take some tough hits before 1990 is over,'' said Potts, if ad linage remains low. ``We expect that things will rebound, if not later this year, then certainly next year.'' On the positive side, Potts said circulation has continued to grow in the past five years at all McClatchy's major papers but one, which is in an area of Washington state hurt financially by the shutdown of a nuclear power plant. The Sacramento Bee led the circulation growth last year, with daily circulation up 5.3 percent and Sunday up 5.2 percent. For McClatchy Newspapers, revenues totaled $381 million in 1989, up 7 percent from the previous year, Smith said. Advertising revenues totaled $303 million and circulation revenues $63 million, he said. Net income totaled $34 million, up from $29 million in 1988 and representing a 31 percent increase over the past four years, Smith said. The company on Wednesday declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of 4 cents per share, payable July 3, 1990.
DOC.HEAD: J. Stewart Bryan III Elected Media General Board Chairman
DOC.TEXT: J. Stewart Bryan III, whose family started in the newspaper business in Richmond 140 years ago, was chosen May 18 to succeed his father as board chairman of Media General Inc. The board of directors also elected him president and chief executive officer, replacing James S. Evans, who was elected vice chairman. Bryan is also a member of the board of directors of The Associated Press. His father, D. Tennant Bryan, 83, will become chairman of the Media General board's executive committee. Media General is the parent company of Richmond Newspapers Inc., which publishes the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader. Media General also owns the Winston-Salem Journal in North Carolina and the Tampa Tribune in Florida; three television stations, two cable television companies and a 40 percent stake in the New Jersey-based Garden State Newspapers. Under Evans' direction, the company has trimmed its holdings under a restructuring plan to focus on its core East Coast media interests. One of the biggest changes was the sale last year of two groups of community weekly newspapers in Los Angeles and Orange counties in California. Stewart Bryan said the industry has been in the doldrums but that earnings would be ``robust'' this year. He would not give an estimate. Bryan also said the company expects near-term growth will be internal and that no major acquisitions are envisioned.
DOC.HEAD: New Kansas City Newspaper Hits the Streets
DOC.TEXT: The sole investor in Kansas City's new afternoon newspaper says he hopes to buck a national trend and attract enough readers for a profit. Analysts say that's going to be tough. The first edition of The Kansas City Evening News rolled off the press May 14. Steve Rose, president of a family-owned chain of 18 suburban weekly papers and owner of the new 50-cent tabloid, said the paper sold about 22,800 copies its first day. Media analysts contend the newspaper will face tough times because of a general decline in advertising revenues. Rose said he can make a profit through low costs, small circulation and street sales. The newspaper will not be delivered to homes. He said he's not trying to compete directly with The Kansas City Star, a morning paper with daily circulation of 297,000. Rose said he got the idea for a newspaper in March, when the Kansas City Star Co. stopped publishing an afternoon edition and merged it with the morning newspaper after years of declining afternoon circulation. ``I don't want and I don't need 50,000 to 100,000 readers,'' Rose said. ``If we start down that path, suddenly all the economies change. That's exactly where Ralph Ingersoll ended up.'' Ingersoll started the tabloid St. Louis Sun to compete with The St. Louis Post-Dispatch for morning readers, but the Sun shut down last month after only seven months. Ingersoll cited home-delivery costs and inadequate street sales. Rose's newspaper, unlike the much larger St. Louis Sun, has an editorial staff of four. It will consist mostly of news from wire services. The Monday-through-Friday paper shares a press, building and other equipment with Rose's weeklies. Startup costs have been under $1 million, he said. Ken Berents, an analyst for Alex Brown & Sons Inc. in New York, said starting a new newspaper in a town with a monopoly newspaper like Kansas City is like ``running uphill'' with ankle weights on.
DOC.HEAD: Court Strikes Down Judge's Order Restricting Reporters
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court ruled May 17 that a circuit judge acted illegally when he restricted reporters covering a trial stemming from an alleged rape at the South Dakota governor's mansion. The high court said in a unanimous decision that Circuit Judge Marshall Young of Rapid City must rescind his order. Young had threatened reporters with arrest if they published the names of people involved in the March trial of two juveniles. Gov. George Mickelson has acknowledged that his son, David, was one of the two. Young's order was illegal because he failed to hold a hearing before issuing it, made it too broad and required law enforcement officers to enforce possible violations of the order, the Supreme Court said. However, the justices declined to rule on the constitutionality of the state law on which the circuit judge's order was based. The Sioux Falls Argus Leader and The Associated Press had argued that the law, which prohibits the publication of names of people involved in juvenile court proceedings, was an unconstitutional prior restraint on the news media's right to publish lawfully obtained information. Young presided over a closed-door trial of two 17-year-old boys charged with sex offenses in connection with a Nov. 28 incident at the governor's mansion. After the two-day trial, the judge acquitted one boy of non-forcible rape and acquitted the other of aiding and abetting rape. The two boys and a third 17-year-old admitted to charges of underage drinking and were given probation and ordered to do community work. Young also ordered that the two boys who had been charged with sex offenses must each pay one-half the medical expenses of the alleged rape victim, a 16-year-old girl.

DOC.HEAD: Gannett Foundation Reports Interest in Stock
DOC.TEXT: The Gannett Foundation said May 14 it has had ``numerous expressions of interest'' from potential buyers since announcing it was exploring the sale of its 10 percent stake in media giant Gannett Co. Inc. The foundation has hired the investment banking firm Salomon Brothers Inc. to negotiate the possible sale of its 15.94 million shares of Gannett stock. The foundation's chairman, retired Gannett Co. Chairman Allen H. Neuharth, and its chief executive, Charles L. Overby, have said they prefer to sell the stock to the company or to an employee stock-option plan. ``But we have had numerous expressions of interest from other potential buyers and Salomon will explore all of those,'' they said in a statement. The foundation is Gannett's largest shareholder. Both are located in Arlington, Va. The proposed sale of the stake has raised questions about whether the newspaper, outdoor advertising and broadcasting company has been put into play as a possible takeover target. The foundation said it was considering selling its stake because it had to seek higher income than paid by common stock dividends to meet the obligation imposed on foundations to pay out 5 percent of their assets annually. It had assets of nearly $650 million at the end of last year and spent $30 million on grants for journalism education, adult literacy, community projects and other philanthropic programs. Gannett Co. earned $397.5 million, or $2.47 share, on revenue of $3.52 billion in 1989. It owns USA Today and 82 other daily newspapers, 52 non-daily publications, 10 television stations, 16 radio stations, Gannett News Services and the largest outdoor advertising company in North America.
DOC.HEAD: Maxwell's Mirror Group Agrees To Buy Supermarket Tabs
DOC.TEXT: British media baron Robert Maxwell said May 16 his Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd. has agreed to buy the gossipy tabloids Globe, National Examiner and Sun. Terms were not disclosed. Maxwell said he hoped to complete the purchase from Globe International Publishing Inc. by mid-June. Globe International, a privately held publishing concern based in Montreal, said the combined circulation of the three weekly magazines exceeds 2.5 million.
DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Overturns $785,000 Libel Award
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supreme Court overturned a $785,000 damages award to a county attorney, saying a newspaper did not libel him by publishing statements that were true but implied wrongdoing. The May 11 decision reversed a 1989 state Court of Appeals ruling against the Duluth News-Tribune. At issue were three articles published by the newspaper in 1981 about Carlton County Attorney Carlton Diesen's performance in prosecuting domestic abuse cases. Diesen said the articles ruined his reputation, caused him extreme embarrassment and cost him re-election. He sued the newspaper, its executive editor at the time and the reporter who wrote the articles. A St. Louis County District Court jury awarded Diesen $285,000 in compensatory damages and $500,000 in punitive damages. In dismissing the action, the Supreme Court said that Diesen had not proved actual malice on the part of the newspaper.
DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders Injunction Against Reuters
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ordered an injunction May 17 preventing Reuters from backing out of a photo-exchange agreement with United Press International. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in reversing a lower court's decision, said UPI had shown that it would suffer irreparable harm if the arrangement were discontinued. The request for the injunction stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI to a Reuters lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange. In March, U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure denied the order and UPI appealed. Three judges of the appeals court reversed Leisure and directed him to issue the injunction, which would remain in effect until the lawsuits are resolved. The picture-exchange contract was made in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters with photographs from the United States and for Reuters to provide UPI with pictures from other countries. The agreement was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. Reuters claimed the agreement is not living up to its expectations. UPI said it would lose clients and possibly go out of business without foreign photos from Reuters.
DOC.HEAD: Bill Requiring Editorialists To Disclose Finances Appears Dead
DOC.TEXT: A bill that would require Florida editorial writers to disclose their finances appears to be dead, although the sponsor may make a last-ditch effort to salvage it. Some lawmakers thought the measure, sponsored in the House by Orlando Republican Bruce McEwan, was nothing more than a shot at the press. ``As much as I might want to get in there and make a little jab at editorial boards, I think the greater freedom of expression is more important,'' said Rep. John Cosgrove, D-Miami. The bill would include newspaper editorial board members in a current law requiring many state employees to file statements disclosing their financial interests or face a $5,000 fine. It would also require all editorials to be signed by the authors. The bill drew widespread interest from newspaper executives across the country who saw it as one of the most blatant attempts at press-bashing in recent memory, said Dick Shelton, executive director of the Florida Press Association. ``We felt they (legislators) were peeved at the press and wanted to get the press' attention,'' Shelton said. ``I think the attention they got was dismay that our legislators would consider something so obviously unconstitutional.'' The measure narrowly won approval in early May in a House subcommittee. But McEwan was unable to convince the Judiciary Committee to forward it onto the floor.

DOC.HEAD: Public Works Director, 2 Others Lose Libel Suit Against Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The city public works director and two other men lost a $1.5 million libel suit against the Laredo Morning Times on May 11. A state District Court jury concluded that the reputation of public works director Joe Guerra was damaged in the first of four Times articles about a candidate's claim that city equipment was used improperly. But the jury awarded no damages, holding that the offending article did not constitute ``actual malice.'' Nor did the newspaper act ``with reckless disregard for the truth,'' the jury said. Guerra, Felix de Leon and Guadalupe F. Gonzalez sued the Times and one of its editors in connection with articles published Oct. 17-20, 1985. The jury found that all four articles were substantially true and the subject was of public concern. The Times contended that the first article merely reported what occurred at a news conference the previous day, when mayoral candidate Victor Solis alleged that a road grader was used to grade the parking lot of a night club as a political favor to the incumbent mayor and two others. De Leon was identified in the first article as the owner of the property where the improvements were made. Gonzalez actually owned the property. The jury found that three followup articles, in which Guerra and other city officials denied the allegations, did not libel Guerra and that none of the articles identified Gonzalez.
DOC.HEAD: Discrimination Claim Settled for $65,000
DOC.TEXT: The Capital Times newspaper agreed May 11 to pay a former free-lance correspondent $65,000 to settle a discrimination case shortly before the matter was to be heard by an administrative law judge. Mary Patricia ``Patsy'' McGuire agreed to withdraw her complaints that The Capital Times refused to hire her for reporting positions four times because she was a woman and had an arthritic handicap. McGuire filed her complaints in 1986 with the Equal Rights Division of the state Department of Industry, Labor, and Human Relations. Both sides were scheduled for hearings beginning on May 15 before an administrative law judge, who was to consider three of the four claims. ``We negotiated back and forth and arrived at a settlement of $65,000 for personal damages,'' said Michael Fox, McGuire's attorney. ``It is a straight monetary settlement. There is no admission of right and wrong on either side.'' Capital Times Editor Dave Zweifel said the newspaper had hired those it believed to be most qualified. ``I'm very disappointed the case was ever brought. Sometimes in a case like this, it's just better to settle,'' he said. McGuire had written freelance articles for the newspaper for four years. She suffered from a crippling form of arthritis but had surgery that gave her mobility, Fox said.
DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Editor Charged With Murder in Reservation Violence
DOC.TEXT: SALABERRY-DE-VALLEYFIELD, Quebec (AP) _ A Mohawk newspaper editor was charged May 14 with murdering a fellow Indian in a gun battle over casino gambling on the St. Regis Indian Reservation. Doug George, an outspoken, 35-year-old opponent of gambling, was charged in Quebec Provincial Court in the May 1 slaying of Harold Edwards, 31. The slaying of Edwards and another Mohawk the same day prompted hundreds of New York and Canadian police to break with their hands-off policy toward Indian matters and enter the 28,000-acre reservation to keep the peace. George was being held without bail on a charge of second-degree murder, which carries a life sentence with parole eligibility in 10 years. George, managing editor of two newspapers on the St. Regis Indian Reservation, the Indian Times and Akwesasne Notes, regularly used the papers to tout his anti-gambling views.
DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Releases American Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam released an American publisher May 14 after detaining him for three weeks for unknown reasons, a spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok said. Mike Morrow arrived in Bangkok from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City, said Jim Williams, the embassy spokesman. He had no other details, and Morrow could not be reached immediately. Friends said Morrow was in Vietnam looking into investment possibilities. They said he was arrested April 23 in the central city of Da Nang, then taken to Ho Chi Minh City. A companion who was also arrested, French businessman Terry Rodzynk, was released earlier. The Vietnamese government has not revealed the reasons for the arrests. An American who said she was recently detained for five days in Vietnam said Morrow may have been held because of contacts with dissidents in the country. The American, who said the reason for her detention was never made clear, spoke on condition of anonymity. Morrow started a private news service in Vietnam during the Vietnam War. He was held briefly by Communist forces during the war. A longtime resident of Hong Kong, Morrow is the publisher of Petroleum News, an industry journal. He also heads Asia 2000 Ltd., a publishing house, and a trading company in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Pair Convicted of Insider Trading by Getting Preview of Magazine Column
DOC.TEXT: A judge froze the assets of a former print shop worker and a stockbroker after they were convicted May 16 on insider trading charges for scooping tips from Business Week before the magazine hit the newsstands. U.S. District Judge Stephen V. Wilson ordered the assets frozen after a jury convicted William N. Jackson, 34, of Long Beach and Brian Callahan, 30, of Anaheim on the charges. Jackson, a former quality control analyst at a printing firm, could be fined up to $80,000 for his part in the insider trading scheme, prosecutors said. Callahan, a former Prudential-Bache broker, faces a maximum fine of $110,000. The two men traded in 53 stocks between 1987 and 1988 using information gleaned from Business Week. Jackson made more than $19,000 for himself and two brothers, and Callahan made the same amount for himself and his clients plus $8,000 in commissions, the government alleged. Jackson reviewed a freshly printed copy of Business Week each Wednesday night, then phoned Callahan the next morning to buy stocks recommended in the ``Inside Wall Street'' column, prosecutors said. The magazine, though printed on Wednesday nights, does not reach newsstands until Thursday evening. The Securities and Exchange Commission said it would seek all profits, plus interest, and triple that amount in penalties. The men's attorney, Joseph Connolly, argued the SEC was ``stretching the securities laws almost beyond recognition'' and called the violations marginal. ``These are a couple of guys who lost their jobs,' he said. ``They're not wealthy, either of them.'' Jackson acknowledged he bought stock, but testified he didn't realize he was breaking the law or confidentiality requirements of his company, R.R. Donnelley and Sons of Torrance. Callahan testified he believed Jackson got his tips from a computer program.
DOC.HEAD: Toyota Denies Keeping Pickens' Ads Out of Japanese Media
DOC.TEXT: Several of Tokyo's largest newspapers said May 17 they held up ads by Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, who is battling for control of a Japanese company. The ads claim that collusive business practices force higher prices on Japanese consumers. The papers said they were considering printing a version that does not name the Japanese companies Pickens believes to be at fault. ``There's no freedom of speech in Japan,'' said Pickens' lawyer, Kanji Ishizumi. ``Toyota published an ad in a U.S. paper saying `shut up' to Pickens. They were able to enjoy freedom of speech in the United States, but Pickens can't do that here.'' Pickens issued a statement May 16 in Texas claiming Toyota and its powerful advertising agency, Dentsu, were trying to block him from publishing the ads. Since last year, Boone Co., a U.S. investment firm, has held the largest equity stake in Koito Manufacturing Co., a major automobile parts maker closely linked to Toyota, Japan's largest automaker. Pickens says his unsuccessful battle to gain a seat on Koito's board of directors and to exercise leadership in the company illustrates how investment opportunities are closed to foreigners in Japan.
DOC.HEAD: Drug Conference Scheduled for Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The Foundation for American Communications, FACS, and the Gannett Foundation have scheduled a conference for journalists on the illegal drug trade. The conference, June 8-10 at the Ramada Renaissance TechWorld in Washington, will include a presentation on ``Life, Death and Journalism Among the Cocaine Kings,'' by Juan Manuel Santos of El Tiempo newspaper in Bogota. Economists, Drug Enforcement Administration and State Department officials will discuss how the drug trade works, money laundering and the medical effects of drugs. Those interested in registering can contact Telford Work, Julie Healey or Douglas Ramsey at 213-851-7372.

DOC.HEAD: Florida's High Court: Reporters Don't Have Privilege in Eyewitness Cases
DOC.TEXT: The First Amendment doesn't exempt reporters from the obligation of testifying about crimes they witness, Florida's Supreme Court said in rejecting an appeal by The Miami Herald. ``While we are mindful of the importance of a vigorous and aggressive press, we fail to see how compelling a reporter to testify concerning his eyewitness observations of a relevant event in a criminal proceeding in any way `chills' or impinges on the newsgathering process,'' Justice Parker Lee McDonald wrote for the majority. The Herald, Florida's largest newspaper, hasn't decided if it will appeal the May 17 decision, said attorney Samuel Terilli Jr. He said the ruling would have a limited impact because it was written to cover only a narrow, specific set of circumstances. ``It applies only to reporters who have eyewitnessed crimes, searches and similar events in criminal cases, and that just doesn't happen too often,'' Terilli said. Reporter Joel Achenbach was subpoenaed by an attorney for a New York man arrested on drug smuggling charges at the Miami International Airport. Achenbach was accompanying three Metro-Dade police officers at the time as part of his research for an article. Details of the search and arrest in Achenbach's story differed from police reports. A state trial court and Florida's 3rd District Court of Appeal rejected the Herald's argument that the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution extended to Achenbach a qualified privilege to refuse to divulge information obtained first-hand as a witness to an event in a criminal case.
DOC.HEAD: School Disciplines Students on Alternative Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: About 200 people staged a protest rally at Wheaton College May 15 after nine students were disciplined for alleged obscenity and sexual references in an underground newspaper. But J. Richard Chase, president of the evangelical Christian college, said the school would be guided by biblical principles. ``There are limits to what we will have on our campus,'' Chase said. ``We believe there are biblical standards. We believe in a civil society.'' The Icecream Socialist was formed to provide an alternative to the school's official paper, students said. But when the paper published a poem alleged to include sexual innuendo and a stream-of-consciousness piece that included obscenities, college officials intervened. One student involved in the paper quit rather than be expelled, two students who worked on the paper were suspended for a semester, five others have been placed on probation and one student, a graduating senior, received a warning. Some of the nine questioned why they were disciplined, since they had issued a public apology. Chase said if action hadn't been taken, others would have gotten the message, ``Do whatever you want, (then) send an apology.''
DOC.HEAD: Ombudsmen Not Always Popular With Colleagues
DOC.TEXT: Reporters and editors at The Orange County Register in Santa Ana, Calif., tend to avoid Pat Riley. As the paper's ombudsman, Riley's Sunday column often outlines his colleagues' mistakes. ``Writing a column means you have a less pleasant relationship with the staff because you have to put someone's name in the column,'' Riley said May 14 as the Organization of News Ombudsmen's conference opened. Henry McNulty of The Hartford (Conn.) Courant said the group's intials, ONO, reflect the attitude of colleagues when they see an ombudsman coming: ``Oh, no. What have I done now?'' said McNulty. ``The readers are quite sophisticated about the media and they are quick to point out errors or biases,'' said Charles Bond of The Palm Beach Post in West Palm Beach, Fla. Kerry Sipe of The Virginian-Pilot said newspapers are following the trend of responsiveness to the consumer. ``Just as an oil company is held responsible by the consumer for its oil spills, so a newspaper is asked to take responsibility for what it does and clean up after itself when it errs,'' he said. Riley said most of the Register's staff treat the matter professionally. ``We criticize everybody else in the world, and I think the staff _ though they're not always pleased _ realizes we have to be subject to the same criticism,'' he said. The ombudsmen agreed there are some issues, such as abortion, on which they have no easy answers. McNulty said he gets about the same number of complaints from pro-life advocates as from pro-choice advocates claiming a story was biased against them. ``We listen. But at the same time, we don't let those criticisms dampen or curtail our coverage. We still consider ourselves news people. We will still cover the stories,'' Riley said. ``There are no solutions to some complaints about stories. But what is important is that there is a two-way communication between the reader and the newspaper. With that comes the hope that the paper is hearing what the reader is saying,'' McNulty said.
DOC.HEAD: University Drama Center Plans National Journal
DOC.TEXT: The University of Cincinnati's new Helen Weinberger Center for the Study of Drama and Playwriting hopes this winter to begin publishing a national journal covering all aspects of American drama. The journal will be titled ``American Drama.'' It is to be published by the American Drama Institute and edited by Norma Jenckes, director of the Weinberger center. Ms. Jenckes is an associate professor of English and comparative literature at the university. The first issue of the twice-yearly journal is to be issued in January 1991. It will be circulated to scholars, teachers and libraries nationwide, university spokesman Jim Feuer said.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Newspaper Bans Rev. Al Sharpton Quotes
DOC.TEXT: The North Jersey Herald & News announced May 15 it would no longer publish comments by the Rev. Al Sharpton, calling him ``a reverend of racism and a minister of hate.'' The newspaper's five-member editorial board unanimously agreed not to print Sharpton comments unless they are newsworthy, said Thomas Benner, editorial page editor. Benner said the editorial board acted partly because of a recent appeal by New York Mayor David N. Dinkins for racial healing. The newspaper also banned using Sharpton statements a couple of years ago during the newspaper's coverage of Tawana Brawley, a 15-year-old black girl who alleged she was raped by white men in Wappingers Falls, N.Y. Sharpton became her adviser and a family spokesman in the case. A grand jury eventually said Brawley's story was false. Sharpton is serving as adviser to the family of Yusuf Hawkins, a black youth allegedly shot to death by white teen-agers in Brooklyn, N.Y. A jury on May 17 found Joseph Fama of Brooklyn guilty of second-degree murder and 12 other counts in the killing.
DOC.HEAD: Banned Journalist Free To Return to South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Journalist Donald Woods, whose book on a South African black activist was made into the movie ``Cry Freedom,'' is free to return to South Africa after being banned for years, his former newspaper said May 20. The East London Daily Dispatch, where Woods was the editor in the 1970s, said it had received a letter from President F.W. de Klerk saying there were no restrictions or pending charges against Woods. ``There really does seem to be a new spirit in South Africa, and I'm greatly looking forward forward to coming back to experience it for myself,'' Woods told his former newspaper in an interview from London. Woods befriended Steve Biko before the black activist's death in police custody in September 1977. A month later, Woods was placed under a banning order that prevented him from working as a journalist in South Africa. It was illegal for the media to quote Woods in South Africa until February, when de Klerk announced a series of reforms lifting restrictions on banned people. Woods and his family fled South Africa in 1978 and have been living in London ever since.
DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Destroy Press Freedom in Medellin
DOC.TEXT: The drug war has hit close to home at El Espectador, a daily newspaper in Bogota and outspoken foe of the cocaine barons. Seven Espectador employees have been killed in eight months in Medellin, the home base of the Colombian drug cartel, and the paper no longer circulates here. The reprisals made many people afraid to be seen seen with copies of the newspaper. News vendors kept it out of sight and slipped copies to customers surreptitiously. Newsboys quit selling it in the streets. El Espectador, which means The Spectator, is Colombia's second-largest newspaper, after El Tiempo of Bogota. Medellin's two newspapers, El Mundo and El Colombiano, have printed less about the drug war since the terrorism campaign began. A reporter, who feared to let his name be used, said El Espectador's fate in Medellin probably would be repeated in other cities, and ``the traffickers will not quit until they destroy El Espectador.'' ``This is the most dramatic and successful attack on press freedom I have ever heard of,'' he said. ``In other countries, you might get killed for what you write, but here they murder you just for working.'' Police posted a half-dozen officers at the Medellin offices after the assassinations Oct. 10 of El Espectador's manager in the city, Martha Luz Lopez, and its chief of distribution, Miguel Soler. They told employees to lock themselves in. Telephone callers gave the staff three days to quit their jobs. In November, the employees finally did quit, but El Espectador continued circulating in Medellin until April, when traffickers murdered Gustavo Tabera, one of the men in charge of distribution. El Espectador announced after the murder that the paper no longer would circulate in Antioquia state and its capital, Medellin. Antioquia state provided 30 percent of El Espectador's classified advertising, but the economic loss was minor compared to the loss of prestige. Although the paper's main office now is in Bogota, it was founded in Medellin in 1887 by Fidel Cano. His descendents still run it. The Medellin cartel has said it will kill members of the family as part of a campaign of violence against the government of President Virgilio Barco.
DOC.HEAD: Outdoor Writers Rescue Two Cubans at Sea
DOC.TEXT: Four outdoor writers interrupted their fishing off the Florida Keys on May 14 to rescue two Cuban refugees on a makeshift raft. ``Their hands and feets were like prunes, they were trembling, but they were really happy to see us,'' said Don Mann, one of 160 writers attending a meeting of the Florida Outdoor Writers Association this week. The Cubans, ages 21 and 22, had been at sea five days, Mann said. They still had five cans of Russian-labeled food but had run out of water May 12. ``They kept shouting `Estados Unidos, Estados Unidos.' And when we told them they were near the United States, they were ecstatic,'' said Mann, a contributing editor for Florida Sportsman magazine. The refugees were picked up 18 miles south of Islamorada. Their raft comprised three truck innertubes and a couple of wooden planks, Mann said. While the writers waited for instructions from the Coast Guard, Mann caught a 25-pound dolphin fish. The Cubans were turned over to the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service.

DOC.HEAD: The Oregonian Drops Breslin
DOC.TEXT: The Oregonian has dropped columnist Jimmy Breslin because of racial insults he made about a co-worker, the newspaper told its readers May 17. Breslin recently lambasted a fellow reporter with Newsday in New York who criticized one of his columns for demeaning women and for being sexist. The reporter, an Asian-American woman, was not present during Breslin's tirade. William A. Hilliard, editor of The Oregonian, announced the paper had canceled the column, saying there was no excuse for what Breslin did. ``Breslin revealed attitudes that have no place in the newsroom or in a nation of people from all walks of life, of all colors, religions and ethnic and national backgrounds,'' Hilliard wrote. ``And Breslin has no place in The Oregonian.''
DOC.HEAD: Wick Communications Buys Territorial Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Wick Communications Co. of Scottsdale has bought Territorial Newspapers, owner of three Tucson-area papers. E.D. Jewett, editor-publisher of The Daily Territorial, Weekly Territorial and the weekly Oro Valley Territorial, said he will be ``publisher emeritus.'' Jewett founded the company in 1966. Jewett said his son, Steven E. Jewett, will become publisher of the three newspapers after the sale. The purchase price was not disclosed.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Photographer Beaten, Pittsville Man Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A man whose mobile home was damaged by high winds was arrested after allegedly attacking a newspaper photographer. Todd Dudek of The Daily Times of Salisbury was treated for cracked ribs and a dislocated shoulder from the May 10 attack. Richard W. Esham of Pittsville was arrested on charges of assault and battery and malicious destruction of property. Dudek was sent to take pictures of the home and Esham struck him, threw him into a ditch and broke his camera, police said.
DOC.HEAD: City Agrees To Halt Newsletter Ad Solicitation
DOC.TEXT: Local officials agreed to stop soliciting ads for their town-published newsletter after the newspaper in nearby Sun City complained. Surprise Today will continue to be published, but will cover only town business and will contain no advertising, said town attorney Robert McCoy. News-Sun Inc., which publishes the the Daily News-Sun, asked town officials to suspend publication of the newsletter. David Bodney, lawyer for the newspaper company, said the decision not to use advertising in the newsletter and to limit its scope to public business ended the matter.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper To Go Mornings, Sundays
DOC.TEXT: The Evening-Weekend Journal is switching to morning publication and will change its name when the switch is made Aug. 4, Publisher Robert M. Derr Jr. said. The newspaper, now published Monday-Friday afternoons and Saturday mornings, will be renamed The Morning-Sunday Journal. Derr said the newspaper will have expanded sports and financial sections.
DOC.HEAD: Columnist Proposes in Paper
DOC.TEXT: Sports columnist John Rohde of The Daily Oklahoman told readers May 17 if they wanted to read about sports ``you won't find it here today.'' ``I promise to return to our usual subject tomorrow, but today I'm going to try to change someone's life. My own.'' He wrote that ``It's with trembling fingers and a racing heart that I type the following: `Debbie Burchart, will you marry me?'' Burchart said ``yes'' after seeing the column. Rohde said it was the first anniversary of the day they met. ``I'm not sure how people will perceive this column, Deb. But as you've come to know by now, that's pretty much the case every time I occupy this space. Proposing to you in this forum is either somewhat courageous or incredibly stupid. Either way, my sincerity is genuine.'' He proposed Aug. 1 as the wedding day, then said, ``Please, don't respond with a letter to the editor.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds `MacNeil-Lehrer' More Conservative Than `Nightline'
DOC.TEXT: Public television's ``The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' features more whites and males and is more government-oriented and conservative than ABC's ``Nightline,'' says a group that studied both shows. The assertion was made by a liberal media watchdog group, Fairness & Accuracy in Reporting, in a study released May 20. FAIR president Jeff Cohen said the PBS show has a ``narrow, pro-establishment guest list'' that ``mocks the original mandate of public television'' to provide diversity. ``NewsHour'' executive producer Les Crystal said the news program agrees that diversity is important ``and we clearly feel we can and should do better in that regard.'' But he disputed what he called FAIR's contention that the show doesn't criticize the government much and asks one-sided questions. The FAIR study of ``NewsHour'' broadcasts from Feb. 6 to Aug. 4, 1989, was conducted by Boston College sociologists William Hoynes and David Croteau, who made a study critical of ``Nightline'' last year. The ``Nightline''' report, examining 40 months of the ABC program from 1985 to 1988, found that 89 percent of its guests were men, 92 percent were white, and that conservative leaders were the show's most frequent guests. FAIR's new study, entitled ``All the Usual Suspects: MacNeil-Lehrer and Nightline,'' also compared ABC's program with ``NewsHour'' during the same six-month period the latter was studied. The two professors making the study found that ABC's show has slightly broadened its guest list since the original study, but that ``our hopes for significant change were not met.'' Their ``NewsHour'' study found that of U.S. citizens appearing as guests, 90 percent of them were white and 87 percent were male. The figures rose on programs about international politics, it said, with 94 percent of U.S. citizens appearing to discuss world politics being both white and male. The study offered no racial or gender percentages for guests who were not U.S. citizens. It characterized as ``more representative'' the guests invited when the show's topic was domestic politics. It said that 26 percent of them were women, but gave no figures on the race of female guests. FAIR's study said the show's guest list was dominated by two conservative Washington think tanks, with a total of 14 guests provided by the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the American Enterprise Institute.
DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Ask That Cameras Be Allowed in Trial Courts
DOC.TEXT: News organizations asked the Illinois Supreme Court on May 18 to allow cameras and microphones in the state's trial courts. ``The best way for the public to have confidence in its judicial system is to see what's going on,'' said Richard Thies, an attorney for Illinois News Broadcasters Association, one of the petitioners. Before 1984, cameras and microphones weren't allowed in any state courts, but that year the Supreme Court opened the doors of appellate courts. The justices decided to keep cameras and microphones out of the trial courts because of fears ``that miscarriages of justice will result from the subtle, insidious effect that televising trials will have upon the behavior of the participants in court proceedings,'' former Justice Robert Underwood wrote at the time. When that decision was made, 30 states allowed cameras and microphones in trial courts. Now, 37 states allow cameras and microphones in trial courts, and Thies said the experience of those states has shown camera coverage doesn't affect the outcome of trials. ``Electronic coverage of trials would help guarantee due process by encouraging public scrutiny of trials, thus acting as a direct check on abuse of the judicial process,'' he wrote in the brief submitted to the high court. Thies said news organizations are hoping the Supreme Court will adopt a rule similar to New York's test program. The New York rule allows microphones and cameras in trial courts but prohibits taping of rape victims, jurors and undercover officers. It also prohibits audio coverage of conferences among attorneys, clients and the judge. Thies said he didn't expect the court to rule on his request before next year. Other petitioners are WLS Television Inc., WMAQ-TV, the Illinois Broadcasters Association, the Illinois Press Photographers Association and the Illinois Freedom of Information Council.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Reshuffles Slumping `Today' Show, Brings Joe Garagiola Back as Co-Host
DOC.TEXT: In a surprise move aimed at reviving its slumping ``Today'' show, NBC said May 15 that Joe Garagiola, a familiar face from the show's past, would join Bryant Gumbel and Deborah Norville as a co-host. NBC also hired Faith Daniels, co-anchor of the ``CBS Morning News'' and news segments of ``CBS This Morning,'' to anchor ``NBC News at Sunrise'' and the news segments of ``Today.'' Garagiola was a host of the show from 1969 to 1973. He will return to the show in June. The network also announced that Dick Ebersol, who played a leading part in changes that preceded the ``Today'' drop into second place, is giving up his job as senior vice president in charge of ``Today.'' He will stay as president of NBC Sports, the network said.
DOC.HEAD: Suit Over `Non-Competing Station' Clause Settled
DOC.TEXT: A former television anchorman has settled a lawsuit that he filed against the station for barring him from joining any competing Milwaukee TV station. Mike Miller, formerly employed by WITI-TV, asked in the Circuit Court suit that the contract provision prohibiting work for a competing station be ruled void. Judge Gary A. Gerlach indicated at an earlier hearing that he likely would rule the provision was too broad. ``I'm just heaving a sigh of relief,'' Miller, 38, said May 15. ``It's unusual for them to want to settle. I guess they could see the writing on the wall in our case. Now I can get on with things.'' Miller left the station in mid-March after being asked to accept a new contract cutting his pay from $75,000 a year to $68,000. WITI attorney Franklyn M. Gimbel confirmed the settlement, which contained no admission of liability by WITI. William M. Cannon, Miller's attorney, said part of the settlement was confidential. He would not disclose whether Miller will receive any money. Miller said he planned to notify other Milwaukee stations he was available. Still pending is a suit filed against WITI over the same issue by former reporter Scott Feldmeyer. That case is before the state Court of Appeals, which has ruled Feldmeyer is free to work at a competing station until a decision is issued.

DOC.HEAD: Blair Named New Mexican Associate Editor, Associate Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Billie Blair, publisher of the weekly Taos News, has been named associate editor and associate publisher of The New Mexican in Santa Fe. The appointment was announced May 21 by New Mexican owner and Publisher Robert M. McKinney. He also announced the promotion of Stephen E. Watkins from vice president to president of The New Mexican, Inc. Blair said she will remain publisher in Taos but will spend most of her time working in Santa Fe.
DOC.HEAD: Crowder Named Associate Editor at El Paso Times
DOC.TEXT: David Crowder has been named associate editor at the El Paso Times, replacing Barbara Funkhouser, who is retiring after 30 years at the newspaper. Crowder started with the Times in 1980 and has covered government and handled special projects. He worked previously at The Brownsville Herald and The Highlander, a weekly newspaper in Central Texas. Ms. Funkhouser has previously been editor, editorial page editor, religion editor, education editor and health reporter. The changes take effect June 1 and were reported in the Times May 13.
DOC.HEAD: Mackle Appointed Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Robert E. Mackle, an editor with the Dallas Times Herald, has been appointed managing editor of the Casa Grande Dispatch. During 10 years with the Times Herald, Mackle held the posts of regional editor, zone editor, assistant copy chief, assistant news editor, wire editor and wire desk editor. Dispatch editor and publisher Donovan M. Kramer Sr. said May 17 that Mackle had been selected after a nationwide search.
DOC.HEAD: Slagle Named Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Kerry Slagle, former managing editor of the Sarasota (Fla.) Herald-Tribune, has been named managing editor of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer. Thomas Read, 59, managing editor since 1986, will move to a new position as associate editor in charge of resource management, Publisher Virgil Fassio and Executive Editor J.D. Alexander said in a statement May 10. Slagle, 41, was previously managing editor of the Dallas Times-Herald for about seven years. He was one of the founding editors of Newsweek's Inside Sports magazine and is a former executive sports editor of the Chicago Sun-Times and Chicago Daily News. He has also had editing positions at The Miami Herald, The Palm Beach Post of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the Trenton (N.J.) Times.
DOC.HEAD: Ingle Elected President of Calif. Media Coalition
DOC.TEXT: Bob Ingle, executive editor of the San Jose Mercury News, was elected president of a statewide media coalition formed to assert public information rights and journalists' legal protections. Ingle was elected May 16 to a three-year term heading the board of directors of the California First Amendment Coalition. He succeeds Mel Opotowsky, senior managing editor of the Press-Enterprise in Riverside, who was the organization's founder and first president. The coalition operates a telephone legal support action line and plans research, seminars and publications to combat official secrecy and to protect news professionals from government censorship and other interference.
DOC.HEAD: James G. Edward
DOC.TEXT: James G. Edward, managing editor of The Newport Daily News for nearly 40 years before retiring in 1975, died May 13 at Newport Hospital. Edward started at the former Newport Herald after graduating from high school. He went on to work for Time, Life, Sports Illustrated and Fortune magazines before joining the Daily News as a copy reader in 1932. He later worked as a sportswriter and editor for the paper, until being named managing editor in 1936. He was a member of the New England Associated Press News Executives Association and served as its president in 1969. He also was a member of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association. Family members declined to give his age. Survivors include his wife, Lillian, two sons, three daughters, 14 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Albert Grobe
DOC.TEXT: Albert Grobe, who retired as the chief announcer at WQXR-FM in 1973, died May 19 after a long illness. He was 81. Grobe was production manager, head of the news department and news announcer at the station until his retirement in 1973. After retiring from broadcasting, Grobe started a second career as a photojournalist. His work appeared in Life magazine and other publications. He joined WQXR in 1940 after working for WINS-AM, the New York State Network and Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia's political campaigns. Grobe is survived by his wife, Sylvia, a daughter and two sons.
DOC.HEAD: Howard Ross Hale
DOC.TEXT: Howard Ross Hale, who as a Western Union telegrapher relayed reporter H.L. Mencken's stories of the 1925 Scopes Monkey Trial, died May 12. He was 85. Hale was among eight telegraphers who transmitted stories on the trial, in which schoolteacher John T. Scopes was charged with illegally teaching Darwin's theory of evolution. Mencken was covering the case for The Evening Sun of Baltimore. ``I think I transmitted every dispatch he wrote for the Sun,'' Hale said in a 1985 interview. ``But I didn't pay much attention to what was in the stories.'' Hale is survived by his wife, Elsie Parker Hale, four sisters and a brother.
DOC.HEAD: Yehuda Lisky
DOC.TEXT: Yehuda Lisky, editor of the last Yiddish newspaper in Britain, is dead at 90, The Daily Telegraph reported May 21. Lisky was born in Oszene, Poland, and as a young man traveled to Vienna to live with his brother Abraham Fuchs, an established Yiddish writer. He came to London in 1930 and worked on a Yiddish daily, Die Zeit. When it folded in 1950, Lisky started his own paper, Dos Yiddishe Folk (The Jewish People), in collaboration with poet Avron Stencl. It was published first weekly, then biweekly, then monthly and finally whenever he had the money and energy to produce it. Yiddish was the common language of East European Jewry. It largely disappeared following the Nazi persecution of World War II and the dying out of the older generation of survivors. The Daily Telegraph said Lisky's wife, Sonia, died in 1984. They are survived by two sons. It did not give the date or cause of death.
DOC.HEAD: James Earl Mays
DOC.TEXT: James Earl Mays, a former newspaper photographer, columnist and executive, died May 14 in a Virginia Beach hospital. He was 65. Mays started as a photographer for The Virginian-Pilot in Norfolk in 1947 and became chief photographer in 1955. Three years later he switched to the writing staff, later became outdoor writer and then a columnist. Mays became news director of WTAR television and radio in 1967, and joined Landmark Communications after Landmark sold the station in 1981. Mays retired in 1985. Survivors include his wife, Katherine Wood Mays, a son and two daughters.

Veteran Associated Press foreign correspondent Spencer Moosa, the last journalist to leave the Chinese mainland when the Communists conquered it, has died, his family reported May 21. He was 85. Moosa, born in Shanghai, worked for the British news agency Reuters before joining the AP and traveling with Nationalist Chinese forces to Canton, Nanking, Chengdu and Chungking. He worked in China and Taiwan for 29 years and was AP's chief correspondent in Taiwan when he retired in 1968 and joined that country's tourism bureau. Doctors attributed Moosa's death to heart and lung disease. He is survived by two daughters and a son.

Casper J. Schoener, reporter for The Associated Press at City Hall in New York for much of a 44-year career, died May 17. He was 74. In 39 years with AP, nd five years before that in the old City News Association, Schoener covered police, labor and political news. He also for a time worked the ship-reporter beat, which in the era before television and jet air travel produced social and show business tidbits. He was known to fellow reporters and the mayors he wrote about as ``Joe Schroder'' or ``Schroeder,'' the name by which he called himself, although he used the byline C.J. Schoener. Schoener took over full-time responsibility for covering City Hall in 1966 during Mayor John V. Lindsay's administration. He retired in 1981. He is survived by his wife, Peggy, two sons and two daughters.

David Wood, who reported on life at the top of British politics for more than 20 years as political editor of The Times of London, died May 18. He was 75. Wood's best-remembered exclusive was his disclosure in 1959 that Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd had been told by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan he would be transferred to another Cabinet post in several months. The report created an international sensation because Lloyd was then in Geneva attending a conference of the British, French, Soviet and U.S. foreign ministers and his position was undermined. Wood joined The Times in 1948 and retired in 1979. Survivors include a son and a daughter. The cause of death was not disclosed.

Madeline Ball Wright, who broke ground as the first woman reporter for the Springfield Republican when she was hired in 1918, died May 10 at age 101. She covered rattlesnake hunts and was the only woman among a group of reporters to sail with the Coast Guard on its blockade of rum runners during Prohibition. She retired in 1944 after more than 26 years in a variety of editorial jobs at the newspaper. Her husband, William Wright, a former features editor of the Republican, died in 1982.
DOC.HEAD: 12 Journalists Named Fellows at University of Michigan
DOC.TEXT: The University of Michigan has selected 12 journalism fellows for the next school year, including Pulitzer Prize winner Richard Cooper of The Philadelphia Inquirer. They will pursue individually designed studies and join seminars on professional and world affairs by specialists from the University of Michigan faculty and leading journalists. The program offers both general and specialized studies in medical, business, public service and investigative reporting. Others in the program are David Green of the Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader; Jorgen de Mylius, Danish Television; Janet Kolodzy, Cable News Network; Mike Lewis, WDIV-TV, Detroit; Harris Meyer, American Medical News, Chicago; William Mitchell, Rochester, N.Y., Democrat and Chronicle, and Times-Union; Lisanne Renner, The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel; Jai-Kyu Sun, Yonhap News Agency, Seoul, South Korea; Nicolas B. Tatro, The Associated Press, Jerusalem; Wilda Wahpepah, The Oregonian in Portland; and Wendy White, Investor's Daily, Los Angeles.
DOC.HEAD: AP Reporter Wins Two Peter Lisagor Awards for Exemplary Journalism
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Cohen, Midwest regional reporter for The Associated Press, has won two 1989 Peter Lisagor Awards for Exemplary Journalism. Her four-day series ``The Changing Heartland'' was recognized in the reporting category for news bureaus or wire services. The stories examined why Japanese auto plants are moving to small towns in the Midwest, the turnaround in the steel industry and its impact on Gary, Ind., the growth of a supercomputer corridor in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and the rebounding of the Iowa economy. The second award, in the business journalism category for news bureaus or wire services, was for a three-part package, ``Danger at Work.'' The series looked at the impact of increased productivity on workplace injuries, five families who turned activist after their sons were killed in on-the-job accidents, and efforts by states to pursue criminal charges against corporate officials in work accidents. The annual awards, presented May 10 this year, are presented by the Chicago Headline Club, a chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists. They are named after the late Chicago Daily News correspondent Peter Lisagor. Ms. Cohen also won Lisagor awards in 1988 and 1989.
DOC.HEAD: Mehta Named Yale Writer in Residence
DOC.TEXT: Ved Mehta, an author and staff writer for The New Yorker since 1961, has been named a writer in residence at Yale University. Mehta will be a fellow for three years at Berkeley College, one of Yale's 12 colleges for undergraduates, the university announced May 14. He will teach a course on creative writing in the fall and on non-fiction next spring. The Indian-born author is the first Rosenkranz writer in residence, named for the new $1 million endowment created by 1962 Yale graduate Robert Rosenkranz and his wife, Margaret. Mehta, a naturalized American who holds degrees from Harvard and Oxford, has written books on history, theology and linguistics. His most recent book, ``The Stolen Light,'' published in 1989, is his sixth in an autobiographical series.

Robert Maxwell, chairman and executive officer of London-based Maxwell Communications Corp., says he plans to print his newspaper The European in the United States sometime after Labor Day. Maxwell gave the commencement address at Hastings College in Nebraska and said afterward that his new weekly needs a circulation of 300,0000 to break even in three years. ... Competition for U.S. advertising dollars is coming from an unlikely source: Pravda. The Soviet Communist Party daily sent letters to about 150 American business executives inviting them to place ads. ``Times have changed,'' a Pravda representative told The Washington Post.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: The first photo series from the Hubble Space Telescope was supposed to be just an engineering test, but it surprised scientists by revealing an unsuspected double star. Hubble's inaugural photo sequence, taken from its orbit 381 miles above the Earth, showed bright, crisp stars against a black background, with much clearer images than seen in a picture taken by a ground-based telescope of the same part of the heavens. ``Fantastic,'' James Westphal, the principal scientist for the camera used in the first photo exercise, said Sunday. ``We are just as pleased as punch at this point. Our image is significantly better than we were concerned that it might be.'' Westphal said the Hubble pictures clearly show that an image which appeared in ground-based photos to be only a single star was, in fact, a rare binary star. The space telescope pictures showed two overlapping points of light, instead of a single blob as seen in a picture taken by a Chilean observatory.

Other people's smoke is a proven cause of heart disease in non-smokers, raising their risk of dying from the disease by up to 30 percent, a study says. In a presentation in Boston at the World Conference on Lung Health, Stanton Glantz of the University of California, San Francisco, said research is beginning to show exactly how cigarette smoke alters the heart, blood and arteries. He presented a study in which he reviewed others' research on the subject. In 1986, the Surgeon General concluded in his annual report on smoking and health that so-called passive smoking causes lung cancer in non-smokers. At that time, the evidence was insufficient to link passive smoking with heart disease, the report said. Newer studies have changed that, Glantz said Friday in a telephone interview.

Los Angeles lagged behind other big cities in federal narcotics charges when Robert Bonner, now President Bush's choice to head the Drug Enforcement Administration, was U.S. attorney there, court records show. Although the city regularly was near the top in the nation in federal drug arrests, it ranked far lower in the percentage of federal defendants charged with drug offenses during Bonner's tenure. Throughout the period, the most common federal criminal charges in the nation were drug-related, but in Los Angeles the most common were fraud and embezzlement, according to a recent analysis of court records by a Syracuse University research group. The study shows that Bonner's office brought a smaller percentage of drug charges than the national average for U.S. attorneys. Furthermore, he lagged behind a number of colleagues in big cities that had fewer drug arrests to begin with.

People are laughing _ yes, laughing _ at the sight of a plump, 63-year-old grandmother being mocked night after night as ``this gross wat'ry pumpkin ... this whale ... a bag of flax, a puff'd man, old, cold, wither'd and of intolerable entrails.'' Don't feel sorry for Pat Carroll. She has only herself to blame for her humiliation, and she loves every minute of it. Miss Carroll, a veteran stage, screen and TV actress and comedian, is believed to be the first female performer ever to play Sir John Falstaff, the leering, sack-swilling old windbag in ``The Merry Wives of Windsor.'' Eight times a week at the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger, Miss Carroll spends 45 grueling minutes acquiring jowls, side whiskers, mustache, beetle brows and wispy gray thatch. Then she struggles into the baggiest britches this side of Barnum & Bailey.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, May 27, the 147th day of 1990. There are 218 days left in the year.

Today's Highlight in History: On May 27, 1937, the newly completed Golden Gate Bridge connecting San Francisco with Marin County, Calif., was opened. On this date: In 1647, the first recorded American execution of a ``witch'' took place in Massachusetts. (The method involved was not burning at the stake, but hanging.) In 1818, American reformer Amelia Jenks Bloomer, who popularized the garment that bears her name _ ``bloomers'' _ was born in Homer, N.Y. In 1837, American gunfighter and frontiersman Wild Bill Hickok was born in Troy Grove, Ill. In 1935, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the National Industrial Recovery Act. In 1936, the Cunard liner ``Queen Mary'' left England on its maiden voyage. In 1941, amid rising world tensions, President Roosevelt proclaimed an ``unlimited national emergency.'' In 1941, the German battleship ``Bismarck'' sank off France, with a loss of 2,300 lives. In 1964, independent India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, died. In 1977, the City of New York fined ``human fly'' George H. Willig $1.10 _ one penny for each of the 110 stories of the World Trade Center he'd scaled the day before. In 1988, the Senate voted 93-to-5 to ratify the treaty eliminating land-based medium-range nuclear missiles. Ten years ago: South Korean troops regained full control of the provincial capital of Kwangju, suppressing a rebellion that had begun May 18. Five years ago: In a brief ceremony in Beijing, representatives of Britain and China exchanged instruments of ratification on the pact returning Hong Kong to the Chinese in 1997. One year ago: Leaders of the Chinese student protest movement proposed that demonstrators hold one more rally, then end their occupation of Tiananmen Square, an idea that was later abandoned. Today's Birthdays: Actor Vincent Price is 79. Novelist Herman Wouk is 75. Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is 72. Actor Christopher Lee is 68. Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger is 67. Actress Lee Meriwether is 55. Actor Louis Gossett Jr. is 54. Actor Bruce Weitz is 47. Senator Christopher Dodd (D-Conn.) is 46. Actor Todd Bridges is 25. Thought for Today: ``Christ died for all men _ not just the ones you know and like.'' -- Anonymous.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, May 28, the 148th day of 1990. There are 217 days left in the year. This is Memorial Day.

Today's Highlight in History: Fifty years ago, on May 28, 1940, during World War II, the Belgian army surrendered to invading German forces. On this date: In 1533, England's Archbishop of Canterbury declared the marriage of King Henry VIII to Anne Boleyn valid. In 1863, the first black regiment from the North left Boston to fight in the Civil War. In 1929, the first all-color talking picture, ``On with the Show,'' opened in New York. In 1934, the Dionne Quintuplets _ Annette, Cecile, Emilie, Marie and Yvonne _ were born to Elzire Dionne in Callender, Ontario, Canada. In 1937, President Roosevelt pushed a button in Washington signaling that vehicular traffic could cross the just-opened Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco. In 1957, the National League gave its approval for the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Giants baseball teams to move to Los Angeles and San Francisco. In 1977, 165 people were killed when fire raced through the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Ky. In 1982, Pope John Paul II began the first-ever papal visit to Britain with an appeal to Britain and Argentina to end their fighting over the disputed Falkland Islands. In 1987, Mathias Rust, a 19-year-old West German pilot, stunned the world as he landed a private plane in Moscow's Red Square, having evaded Soviet air defenses. Ten years ago: Iran's new parliament convened in Tehran to hear an address by President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and a message from the militants holding the American hostages. Five years ago: David Jacobsen, director of the American University Hospital in Beirut, was abducted (he was freed 17 months later). President Ronald Reagan announced his administration's tax revision plan in a nationally broadcast address. One year ago: Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil won the Indianapolis 500 auto race. Today's Birthdays: Los Angeles Lakers General Manager Jerry West is 52. Singer Gladys Knight is 46. Actress Sondra Locke is 43. Thought for Today: ``Kill reverence and you've killed the hero in man.'' -- Ayn Rand, Russian-born American author (1905-1982).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
