DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Nowhere do celebrity stars shine brighter than along the heavenly California beach named Malibu. But Tuesday they will pause in their orbits to vote about such earthly matters as secession _ and sewage.

Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia yearn for independence from the Soviet Union. Staten Island wants to secede from New York City. Not all that long ago New York City wanted to secede from New York State. So far nothing. In politics, there is no such thing as no-fault divorce. But Tuesday the 20,000 residents of this spangled coastal community _ everyone from Andrews (Julie) to Zimbalist (Efrem) _ put their local political future on the line. About half of them, those who are eligible to go to the polls, can declare their desire to secede from Los Angeles County and become a city in charge of its own future. Similar independence movements have become a wavelet along the golden strand from LA to San Diego. It's been a 26-year, off-and-on battle, cityhood supporters thwarted over and over again from gaining self-determination. For over two years the County Board of Supervisors has repeatedly blocked the way to the polls. This year Superior Court Judge Dzintra Janavs ordered them to stand aside. The county wanted to delay the vote a year, pleading bureacratic adjustments. When that was taken to the same Superior Court Judge, the county removed her and installed a new judge. But alas that judge ruled the year delay unnecessary. In Malibu they were wearing T-shirts that asked: ``What's the difference between Malibu and the United States? In the United States you can vote.'' Cityhood seems to have a real chance at last. It inspired President George Bush in a Beverly Hills speech to say: ``People from Panama to Prague are striving for democracy. Self-determination is contagious; they even want it in Malibu, I understand _ leaping over volleyball nets to freedom.'' Which brings in a third player in the freedom game. Pepperdine University, high on a splendiferous hill overlooking the Pacific and known on national television for fielding extravagantly talented volleyball teams, has already gone to other state authorities for permission to be captain of its fate, master of its sewage. Sewage, believe it or not, is the key word. Like the Grand Canyon, Malibu must be seen to be appreciated. It stretches 26 miles along the charmed California coast north of Santa Monica and the Pacific Palisades, both evidence of what unencumbered development can do, where houses were built on eroding sand bluffs in an effort to catch the ocean view. Burning red sunsets over the Pacific, the high light catching the mountains, become so commonplace to residents they barely take notice. They do notice that on a clear day they can see Santa Catalina Island, 23 miles out. In their book ``Backroom Politics,'' authors Bill and Nancy Boyarsky wrote of the long sewer battle: ``One of the few communities that has learned to understand this obscure political game is Malibu in Southern California, where the Santa Monica Mountains reach the sea. There, the canyons widen into coastal plain and then become part of the beaches. ``Malibu is almost 30 miles from downtown Los Angeles, and, even today, it still has a bit of a rural look. But only a little. Just a few feet separate houses on the beach, and during rush hour and on weekends, the Pacific Coast Highway, which runs through Malibu, is a noisy, smelly tangle of recreational vans, sports cars, camper trucks and sedans... ``...the desire to develop Malibu has not diminished. There is still vacant land, and the only thing stopping a building boom along the beach and back into the mountains is the lack of sewers.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
MALIBU, Calif.: of sewers.''
DOC.TEXT: That was written 16 years ago and nothing has changed, save a few more businesses, including a new hotel, on the ocean side of the highway. The beach has been developed but empty spaces stretch inland. On the other side of the mountains is the San Fernando Valley where sewers preceded unprecedented home building, a constant reminder of what can happen. Pepperdine, in the middle of what would become the city of Malibu, got itself declared exempt from the proposed municipality. The university does not want anyone else determining its future plans. Nor does the would-be city want Pepperdine governing its future. ``This is a town with a university,'' says Joan House, one candidate for city council, ``not a university town.'' Early cityhood failures in 1964 and 1976 could be blamed on the fear of higher taxes. But at the same time the same voters voted down bond issues that would have built extensive sewers which meant more homes, more people. The vote for cityhood was meant to be a vote to answer the question once and for all. But no. Knowledgeable Malibuans point out that the ballot also has five slots for the first city council. There are so many candidates against development and so few on the other side that a unified anti-city, pro-development minority could easily win the council over a splintered majority. A mayor would be elected from a new city council. Currently actor Martin Sheen is honorary mayor. Perhaps because of its celebrity community, perhaps for its laid-back nature, Malibu, like other suburbs of the movie industry, gets no respect. After his comments on freedom for Malibu, President Bush in another speech commented on community support groups springing up around the country. In Malibu, he said, a new crisis support group was called ``Mothers for Perrier.'' But a large proportion of Malibu's population are retired teachers and engineers and the like who were lucky or farsighted enough to buy into the beach 20 or more years ago when it was relatively cheap. Homes that once sold for $20,000 now sell for $750,000 and homes that sold for $150,000 now sell for over $2 million. Homes for most Malibuans are their whole wealth, and they have defended them against storms that have washed their neighbors out and fires that have raged down from the hills and landslides that have left them isolated as surely as if they were living on an island. There are certain constants. Weekend traffic chokes the Pacific Coast Highway so badly residents don't even venture out to the movies. The rule is a loaf of bread, a jug of wine and leave the BMW in the driveway. Local politics, however, are never skin-deep. Malibu on the sands seems to have feet of clay. Cozy, almost like an extended family, Malibu is learning some harsh lessons about ego and monied interests. Cityhood supporters say developers have already sunk millions into vacant Malibu land, counting on sewers and more building. But some residents are alarmed at what they consider the crass behavior of some cityhood supporters who would pillory old and respected residents who don't believe in their cause. It will all be settled June 5. Or will it? ``There's blood in the streets,'' says one resident. ``Come June 6, nobody's going to be talking to anybody else.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: ``Cadillac Man'' and ``Fire Birds''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Cadillac Man'' opened May 18; ``Fire Birds'' opens May 25
DOC.TEXT:
``Cadillac Man'' (Orion. Rated R)
Robin Williams may well be in agreement with the Los Angeles Lakers on the proposition that you can't win them all. Coming off Academy Award nominations for ``Good Morning, Vietnam'' and ``Dead Poets Society,'' it appeared the hyper comic could do no wrong. Alas, he throws a piston with ``Cadillac Man.'' Williams is far too inventive a performer to fail completely. But his protean talents are straitjacketed as Joey O'Brien, a charmless, sex-crazy car salesman whose redemption comes too late. ``Cadillac Man'' begins promisingly. Under the titles, a helicopter shot focuses on the New York skyline, then across an endless landscape of gravestones. On the edge of the cemetery, a funeral procession is stalled by a disabled hearse. Enter Joey, who sells cars with the zeal of Michael Milken peddling junk bonds. He befriends the mortician and presents a card. When he tries the same with the widow (Elaine Stritch in a funny bit), she calls him a sleaze. That's what he is, all right. Joey will say anything to sell a car. Meanwhile, he tries to service two mistresses _ one a married woman (Fran Drescher), the other a ditsy would-be designer (Annabella Sciorra) _ placate his ex-wife (Pamela Reed) and stay out of the clutches of a debt-collecting mafia boss (Bill Nelson). Joey also faces an impossible sales quota or he's fired. The tedium of Joey's travails ends with a crash: Tim Robbins smashes the showroom door with his cycle. He brandishes an automatic weapon, madly seeking the lover of his wife, who works at the agency. Are hostage situations a likely source of comedy? After watching the nightly news you might not think so. Williams and Robbins strive mightily to make it work, and almost succeed. The rangy, wild-eyed Robbins, impressive as the feckless minor leaguer in ``Bull Durham,'' somehow ingratiates as the reluctant terrorist. The two stars and the large supporting cast get little help from Ken Friedman's lusterless script or from Roger Donaldson's haphazard direction. The filmmakers seem to believe that loud is funny. It ain't. The Orion Pictures release was produced by Donaldson and Charles Roven. The rating is R for vulgar dialogue and simulated oral sex. Running time: 97 minutes. _ By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer.

``Fire Birds'' (Touchstone Pictures. Rated PG-13)
A sure sign that a movie is doomed from the start is when it opens with a printed quote from President Bush's September 1989 so-called ``war'' on Colombian drug lords, and the screening audience giggles. ``Fire Birds'' tumbles to the very depths of lousy filmmaking on that note. With a stilted screenplay by Nick Thiel and Paul F. Edwards (story by Step Tyner, John K. Swenson and Dale Dye) that never quite figures out if it's a silly love story or a contrived adventure, ``Fire Birds'' just might be a poor attempt at Hollywood patriotism. Jake Preston (Nicolas Cage) and Billie Lee Guthrie (Sean Young) are part of an elite Army helicopter corps being trained for a secret invasion in South America. Their expert mentor is Brad Little (Tommy Lee Jones). Training is partly through computerized simulators, which make video games look wimpy, and actual flight maneuvers. The shots, whether computerized or real, are breathtaking, and provide the only real excitement in the movie. Jake, in Muhammad Ali bravura, reminds anyone who'll listen that he's ``the greatest.'' And next to Little, he is. Guthrie will remind anyone who'll listen that she's no longer romantically interested in Jake, who stalks her like a greedy ivory poacher. Love in this movie unfortunately does not take a back seat to the mission, which is to be a strike against a mercenary named Stoller (Bert Rhine) who is an ace with fighter helicopters. We know Stoller is the evil bad guy because the honchos sitting around the Pentagon conference table tell us so. And in a slide presentation of Stoller helping drug dealers load their stuff for transport, the Pentagon biggies show us a close-up of Stoller's eyes. Bert Rhine must have spent hours staring in a mirror to get just the right menace to his brow. But there is no clear-cut enemy in ``Fire Birds.'' It's hard to cheer on the boys when we haven't seen the bad guys do anything bad. That part of the story isn't developed; the filmmakers merely slap a tag on a few people and we're to accept it. It just doesn't wash, and makes the mission more of a cartoon than anything else. What also works against the movie is the romance subplot. It slows the pacing and provides nothing in terms of moving the plot or providing a needed dynamic. Cage, with his basset hound droopiness and crass manners, and the anorexic-looking Young are possibly two of the most unappealing actors in the business. Both are difficult to watch, whether alone or together. There is no electricity between the two, and their heated moments give off a chill. Definitely bad casting by Mike Fenton and Judy Taylor. Jones, however, is a blessed relief with his rapid-fire presentation and middle-age vulnerabilities. He's Mr. Military all the way. He even tells his long-suffering wife at one point that he could have made her a millionaire if he had peddled his talents in the private sector. But serving his country was more important, he says. David Green has spent most of his years as a filmmaker directing and producing television dramas and documentaries, including ``Boy in the Bubble.'' That small-screen experience shows in ``Fire Birds'' because there is a limited vision and sweep. Richard T. Stevens as second-unit director does much better with the action shots, and Stan McClain's aerial photography is stellar. The production notes say producers Keith Barish and Arnold Kopelson wanted to do for the Army what ``Top Gun'' did for the Navy. They should be court-martialed. The Touchstone Pictures presentation of the Nova International Films release is rated PG-13 for some intense action, adult situations and some violence. _ By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor.

PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Sea of Love'' (MCA Home Entertainment, VHS-Beta. No suggested retail price. Rated R)
``Sea of Love'' might better be called ``Ocean of Despair'' or ``Tide of Terror,'' with its dual themes of lonely hearts and vicious murders. Director Harold Becker has crafted a taut suspense based on a series of murders that have one thing in common _ all the victims had placed ads in a singles' column of a New York magazine. In grisly fashion, the killer has the men lay naked face down on a bed and pretend to make love before shooting them in the back of the head. Two homicide detectives, Al Pacino and John Goodman, set out to find the killer by placing an ad of their own, believing the murderer, a woman, will respond and fal into their trap. Enter Ellen Barkin _ mysterious, leggy and too alluring for Pacino's own good. As one of the ad's respondents, she becomes a suspect as easily as she becomes Pacino's lover. Barkin perfectly plays the role _ it's impossible to tell if she's a cunning killer or guarded sad heart hurt once too often in the dating danger zone. And that quirky smile of her's _ one side sloping downward _ adds a hint of melancholy to even the lightest moments. Pacino, who makes his return to film after a four-year, self-imposed absence, is perfect as a paunchy, divorced alcoholic. His puffy, glassy eyes seem to have seen too many dead bodies and too many bars at closing time. The movie gets its gritty realism from the dialogue written by Richard Price, who befriended New York cops to get little nuggets such as calling a victim ``a face-down taxpayer,'' and calling the suspect a ``doer'' and a ``shooter.'' If there is a flaw in this film, it's the pat ending that seems to put on a forced happy face. Perhaps Hollywood executives demand audiences be given a warm, fuzzy finish. But viewers will find this one ingratiating and disappointing.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``King Blank To'' (Beggars Banquet) _ The Ian Lowery Group
Restless singer Ian Lowery's career has taken him from The Wall to Ski Patrol, Folk Devils and a solo career as King Blank. That's four bands, no hits. Now King Blank has been renamed The Ian Lowery Group for its second album, ``King Blank To.'' The uninitiated will need to hear it just once to understand how fame has eluded Lowery. Commercial he's not; Lowery's music can be described as neo-punk. Dueling guitars recall Television, jarring chord progressions are reminiscent of Richard Hell and nihilistic singing suggests Johnny Rotten. ``I need nobody or anything. Can you imagine?'' Lowery snarls in ``Need.'' The mixture results in a sound that's original and hard to dismiss. There's a kind of recklessness to rockers such as ``Never Trust Me'' and ``You're Gonna Pay'' that is bracing. The energy flags only on the album's slowest songs, ``Wild Times'' and ``The Party.'' Best of all are Lowery's lyrics. He comes across like Lou Reed after an especially bad day at the office. Dark descriptions of life on the fringe shed new light on such subjects as betrayal, revenge, sex, drugs and murder. The standout cut is ``Jack Dust,'' a banjo-driven folk song with a violent storyline, a sense of humor and several neat plot twists. There ought to be a market for work this good. _ By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer.

Peter and the Wolf, Op. 67, by Sergei Prokofiev; The Carnival of the Animals (EMI) _ Philharmonia Orchestra, Efrem Kurtz, conductor; Jonathan Winters, narrator
Welcome to the Jonathan Winters show. The comedian's name looms larger than the titles of the works on the booklet, and his breathless bio comes first. He also dominates this disc in just about every other way, usually not to its advantage. First, his voice and the orchestra sound like they are in differemt rooms, with the orchestra in the back of the house and Winters close up. In fact, they sound separately recorded. The orchestra, meanwhile, has a dull, lifeless quality, and the playing, particularly in Peter and the Wolf, is indifferent. Winters, when reading the text, lets a bored note creep into his voice. He also frequently adds his own comments and imitations of the characters, which generally don't equal what the music can do. He follows with little asides identifying what he's imitating. Younger children might be disturbed to hear Winters comment that the cat sounds like she'd been run over by a car. Saint-Saens' musical bestiary comes off better. Winters sticks to the text, and shows his brilliance as a mimic by using different accents for the charming and witty Ogden Nash verse that introduces each section. Ray Clark's cello solo in ``The Swan'' is long-necked and eloquent. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.TEXT: The Whitney Musuem of American Art will present a retrospective of the entire career of Maurice Prendergast, one of the leading figures in the development of American modernism in the early 20th century. Prendergast, who was born in Newfoundland in 1858, did not receive formal art training until 1891 when he spent a brief time at the Academie Julian in Paris. He studied Cezanne, Whistler and the Nabis painters, and was the first American to return from Europe who assimilated post-Impressionist styles in his work. The Whitney exhibit is grouped: ``La Belle Epoque: Observations of Modern Life, 1891-1906,'' ``Early Modernism: Studies in Color and Form, 1907-1913,'' ``Personal Vision: Myth, Fantasy and the Idyll, 1914-1924.'' The retrospective opens June 1 and runs through Sept. 2. Here is a list of exhibits and shows at other galleries and museums in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Restored Film Epic Returns to the Screen
DOC.TEXT: Charlton Heston doesn't think he got the part of Moses all by himself in Cecil B. DeMille's epic ``The Ten Commandments.'' ``I think Michaelangelo got me the part,'' he says. The 1956 classic is back in the news. As part of its film preservation program, Paramount Pictures has restored prints in 70mm with six-track stereo sound. ``The Ten Commandments'' was shown at two Los Angeles theaters on May 16-24, with engagements to follow across the country. At his Coldwater Canyon home, Heston recalled his dealings with DeMille, the ultimate autocrat of the movie set. ``DeMille's casting method was very curious,'' said the actor, who had starred for the director in ``The Greatest Show on Earth.'' ``You never got to read the script; nobody did. He would tell you the story of the film from the point of view of your character. He would tell you the various scenes, and he already had designs for the props and sets and costumes. He would show you all these things, but he never would say, `I am considering you for this part.' ``So you couldn't say, `I'd really like to play that part, and it would be marvelous to have it.' All you could say was, `It certainly sounds like it's going to be a marvelous picture, Mr. DeMille.' ``Then two or three months later he would call you in and it would be essentially the same thing, though he had more things to show you. Finally, he made a choice. But you were never engaged in a dialogue on that score,'' Heston said. ``I think the thing he could never get out of his mind was that early in the casting process, someone pointed out that Michaelangelo's statue of Moses looked very much like me. It really does. The broken nose is the same, the cheekbones, the long jaw, the forehead, the deep-set eyes and all that.'' Paramount's restoration and re-release of its classics (the first was ``Funny Face'') drew applause from Heston. Long involved with the American Film Institute, he has been vitally interested in preservation _ ``the most important thing the AFI does.'' ``If (restoration) doesn't take place, then the film is gone,'' he said. ``That would be tragic, because film has been described not only as the art form of the 20th century, but the American art form. ``Paramount is taking a significant lead in the archival process. Behind what used to be the Paramount tank with the big sky cyclorama (a curved screen used as background for stage settings) in back, where many of the scenes for `The Ten Commandments' were shot, the studio is building an archival facility. It will be used to store films under controlled conditions of climate and humidity.'' Illinois-born Charlton Heston was a 27-year-old actor from Broadway and television when he arrived in Hollywood for a five-picture contract with Hal Wallis. His first movie was ``Dark City.'' His second film was ``The Greatest Show on Earth,'' which he says brought his best notice ever. DeMille showed him a letter from a moviegoer who complimented James Stewart, Betty Hutton, Gloria Grahame, Cornel Wilde and the rest of the cast, adding, ``I thought the circus manager did very well in there with the real actors.'' Heston appeared in a few more films until DeMille summoned him once more. Moses was an immense role for an actor barely in his 30s. ``I think in all there were nine different makeups,'' said Heston. ``Not counting the baby, which my son, Fraser, played at the age of 3 months. I went from the young prince Moses to the aged patriarch, the white-haired, long-bearded Moses who watches his people cross over Jordan and he goes up the mountain not to immortality, because he wasn't divine. But he disappears from the ken of man.'' What was it like working for DeMille? ``He was very demanding, and mind you I only worked for him in his last two pictures. If he was a martinet in his early days, that had mellowed a bit. He was relentlessly demanding, so was Willy Wyler, so was George Stevens. ``He was extraordinarily courteous with the actors; he had quite a formal manner. He still came to work in a suit and a tie; on location, the same suit with britches and puttees for rough country. ``He didn't shoot a lot of closeups. In those days they didn't. Look at `Casablanca' and there are three closeups in the entire film, two of Bergman and one of Bogart. The proliferation of closeups has increased as the film definition and color gradation has improved.'' Heston added that DeMille often used assistant directors and prop men as ``whipping boys'' but was always courteous to extras, addressing them as ``ladies and gentlemen.'' Chuck Heston at 67 has weathered the years well. He's never dodged a controversy _ such as his battles with the liberal Ed Asner over Screen Actors Guild politics, ads for the National Rifle Association and his support of President Bush and other Republicans _ and he's kept his hand in the profession. He recently starred in ``Treasure Island,'' written and directed by Fraser and released on the TNT network. Heston reported proudly that the movie was picked up by Warner Bros. for theatrical distribution. Another new film is ``Solar Crisis,'' a science-fiction tale for release this summer. He has produced his second book, reporting on his experience in directing ``The Caine Mutiny Court Martial'' in China. Most recently, he was promoted to God, playing the diety in Paul Hogan's new film ``Almost an Angel.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Calm, Cool, Collected
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In his vintage zoot suit, two-tone wing-tipped shoes and fashionably tipped straw hat, August Darnell is the very picture of cool. The frontman for Kid Creole and the Coconuts will tell you that himself, smiling playfully, making words sound as neatly pleated as a well-pressed pair of slacks. ``We don't want drugs and AIDS. No to the people of the Well of the Egg.'' Ramon de la Mata, urban policy consultant to the government of the autonomous region of Madrid, which commissioned the project, recently talked about the 71-year-old Saenz's de Oiza's perspective in an interview. ``Confronted with an aggressive environment _ the adjacent traffic-clogged M-30 beltway and surrounding faceless apartment blocks _ Oiza builds a wall around his houses, saying, `I don't like this city; let's turn this building in on itself.''' Pozo del Huevo is one of numerous shantytowns built in the 1950s on the outskirts of Madrid by rural immigrants drawn to the city by an industrial boom. Land speculation and inadequate provisions for public dwellings condemned them and their children to sub-standard housing in areas that have become breeding grounds for delinquency and drug trafficking. Oiza's rejection of the urban environment through his walled city is felt as a snub to the residents of the prosperous adjacent La Estrella neighborhood and the surrounding area of Moratalaz, where prices for three-bedroom apartments have almost doubled since 1987. Their damaged pride surfaced as raw fury when they learned it would be the inhabitants of the Pozo del Huevo shantytown _ in their eyes, all Gypsies, drug addicts and carriers of switchblade knives _ who would be moving into the project. ``A lot of people talk about preventive medicine these days,'' said local resident and hospital employee Juan Domingo. ``Well, what we want to do is prevent a crime wave around here.'' As Madrid's sensationalist press fueled the fires with such headlines as ``The Human Cage,'' and ``Prison for the Poor,'' residents of La Estrella and Moratalaz cut traffic on the M-30 every Thursday afternoon, demanding that the Pozo del Huevo people be housed elsewhere and the Saenz de Oiza apartments be sold to people such as themselves. Some 65 percent of the adult males in the Pozo del Huevo are seasonal construction workers and, as in most urban areas of Spain, youth umemployment is more than double the 16 percent overall national rate. But heroin addiction and trafficking, endemic in most of Madrid's other marginal areas, and the accompanying high crime levels are negligible. ``We drove the dealers out at gunpoint,'' says Tomas Blazquez, president of the Pozo del Huevo neighborhood association. Maria Luisa, who lives with her husband, two children and parents-in-law in one of the damp, ramshackle shanties in Pozo del Huevo, says there is concealed homelessness in Madrid. ``Nobody dares to build shanty houses anymore. Twenty years ago, you got married young, and if you didn't have a house, you built a shanty. Now young people carry on living with their parents in their shanties.'' But urban affairs officials say shanty-building on the fringes of Madrid, however illegal, is still very active. Housing Relocation head Rosa Molina says gypsies who live in the La Veguilla shantytown north of the city are now building shanties for Moroccans, the most recent of the immigrant arrivals, and renting them for the equivalent of $100 a month. Another housing official, Miguel Angel Pascual, say this ``shanty speculation'' is being fueled by the massive influx into the Madrid area by families attracted by news of government plans to build extensive low-cost housing. When the government council member for urban policy urged that the $18.6 million Saenz de Oiza project apartments be sold to middle-class families to finance other housing for Pozo del Huevo people somewhere else, they marched on government headquarters, demanding respect for the 1985 agreement. They also expressed resentment that the architect and builders failed to solicit their opinion about their new residence. A day later, the Madrid regional government renewed its commitment to move the people of the Egg Well from their crumbling shanties into the walled city.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The 5th Annual Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, one of the largest annual poetry prizes in the United States, will be awarded at the Newberry Library in Chicago on June 1. Established by Indianapolis philanthropist Ruth Lilly, niece of Eli Lilly, who founded the pharmaceutical giant, the $25,000 award is presented annually to an outstanding American poet. The award is organized and administered by the American Council for the Arts in New York City and by the Modern Poetry Association in Chicago, publishers of ``Poetry'' magazine. Lilly also created the Ruth Lilly National Collegiate Poetry Fellowship. The fellowship provides $15,000 for a year's study and practice of poetry in an academic environment for a young, American poet.

Betty Carter, the Dutchess of Jazz, will record her new album for Polygram Jazz's Verve label at the Bottom Line. Trumpeter Freddie Hubbard will be featured on the LP, to be mixture of standards and originals. Saxophonist Craig Handy also will be featured. In other jazz news, Capitol-Blue Note has released four records that have not be available in a decade: Lee Morgan's ``Tom Cat,'' Dexter Gordon's ``Clubhouse,'' Jimmy Smith's ``Cool Blues'' and Wayne Shorter's ``The Soothsayer.'' Two first-time releases also will be out this month: Bobby Hutcherson's ``Oblique'' and Grant Green's ``Matador.'' Joining vibist Hutcherson on ``Oblique'' are drummer Joe Chambers and pianist Herbie Hancock. McCoy Tyner and Elvin Jones join Green on ``Matador,'' a recording that was only briefly available in Japan. It features John Coltrane's version of ``My Favorite Things.''

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., coping with recent management upheaval and big losses, is expected to reorganize by uncoupling investment- banking and brokerage operations and possibly changing its name. Company sources said Friday the plan, likely to be announced by month's end, could help rehabilitate the image of the troubled American Express Co. unit, which lost nearly $1 billion last quarter.

Pan Am Corp. put a ``For Sale'' sign on the Pan Am Shuttle, signaling that the venerable but financially troubled airline company is under increased pressure to raise cash. The decision, revealed Friday, means both of the principal air shuttle services carrying passengers along the heavily traveled Northeast Corridor between Boston, New York and Washington, D.C., may be sold. Developer Donald Trump said recently he was considering selling his Trump Shuttle.

The two Germanys signed a historic treaty that will bind them into a single economic entity in less than seven weeks and all but formally end their four-decade separation. The treaty, signed Friday, also will plunge fragile East Germany into the rigors of capitalism starting July 2. Many East Germans fear unemployment and price increases could be the immediate result.

Federal Reserve policy-makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy. Their intentions were disclosed Friday with the release of minutes of the meeting. Fed policymakers met again in secret last Tuesday amid signals that they had decided to continue the tight-money policy.

A majority of large banks surveyed in May reported they had tightened lending standards to small and medium-sized businesses in the first four months of this year. The Federal Reserve survey released Friday offered what some lawmakers called the first hard evidence substantiating complaints of a credit crunch for small business owners.

Advertisements masquerading as objective programming came under attack at House hearings into so-called ``infomercials.'' Government officials and researchers at the House Small Business subcommittees hearings Friday said consumers would be better served if program-length television commercials were clearly identified and more closely monitored for substantiation of claims.

Federal prosecutors began the painstaking task of trying to recreate allegedly illegal commodities trades to convince a jury that three traders on trial for fraud are guilty. Jurors donned headsets Friday to hear the FBI tapes that the government says implicate the trio, the first of 47 traders in the world's largest futures trading markets to face fraud charges stemming from an undercover sting operation last year.

Almost $1 billion worth of art was sold during a 13-day series of art auctions marked by a van Gogh portrait and a Renoir cafe scene that fetched a record $150 million. But auction houses said in releasing sales figures Friday that the stunning prices for ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' and ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' seemed to be the exception, and that the broader market for art was much softer.

Chrysler Corp.'s new muscle car, the Dodge Viper, will debut during the 1992 model year at a sticker price of less than $50,000, chairman Lee Iacocca said. His announcement Friday marked the first official confirmation that the Viper, designed partly to improve Chrysler's image, would go into production. Iacocca spoke after a six-city tour promoting the quality of Chrysler vehicles.

The stock market settled for a mixed showing Friday, running into resistance after Thursday's rise to a record high. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 11.80 to 2,819.91, reducing its weekly gain to 18.33. Bond prices also fell on fear that the Federal Resere won't ease interest rates. The dollar rose against most key currencies. DOC.HEAD: With PM-UAW Convention
UAW At A Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about the United Auto Workers union.

MEMBERSHIP: About 1 million active and 400,000 retirees in the United States now, down from about 1.5 million active and 300,000 retirees in 1979. MEMBERSHIP BREAKDOWN: 68 percent in automobile and auto-parts industries, 7 percent in the aerospace industry, 6 percent in agricultural implements and about 20 percent in a variety of other jobs, including some brewery workers, state employees in Michigan and jai alai players in New England. LOCALS: About 1,200, all in the United States except Local 251 in Wallaceburg, Ontario. BARGAINING UNITS: About 3,200. Some locals have more than one bargaining unit. CONTRACTS: Current labor agreements with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. were negotiated and signed in 1987. The UAW-Chrysler Corp. contract was signed a year later. All expire at midnight, Sept. 14. HEADQUARTERS: Solidarity House in Detroit. LEADERSHIP: Owen Bieber, first elected at 1983 constitutional convention. Vice Presidents Stephen Yokich, Ernie Lofton, Stan Marshall and Odessa Kommer. ORGANIZATION: The union is governed by a 23-member International Executive Board made up of seven officers and 16 regional directors. HISTORY: Chartered by the American Federation of Labor in August 1935, the union grew quickly after a series of sit-down strikes, starting at GM plants in Flint. In early 1937, UAW members returned to work after a one-page contract was signed. Workers at Chrysler and later Ford voted to be represented by the union. Since its founding, the UAW has remained free of widespread scandal and corruption that have plagued other large labor organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Official Stands by Criticism of U.S. Attitudes, Policies
DOC.TEXT: The co-author of a book criticizing U.S. attitudes and trade policies toward Japan said his nation is fighting an uphill economic battle against a ``crazy giant.'' The United States could rebound as an industrial power _ not by Japan-bashing or retaliatory trade policies against his country, but by reviving the spirit that settled the West, Shintaro Ishihara said. ``You should help yourselves,'' he said. Ishihara and Sony Corp. Chairman Akio Morita co-wrote the 1989 book, ``The Japan That Can Say No.'' The book was published only in Japan but translated copies and excerpts have circulated widely in this country. In the book, Ishihara argues that Japan needs to be more assertive in standing up to America. He brags about Japan's technological superiority and suggests that Japan could change the military balance of power by selling microchips used to target nuclear missiles to the Soviet Union instead of America. Ishihara also says American criticism of Japan is based on racism. He and Morita blame short-sighted management for America's declining competitiveness. Ishihara, a conservative member of the Japanese Diet or parliament, spoke to about 300 people Sunday at a public meeting organized by U.S. Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., at Lawrence Technological University in this Detroit suburb. ``All the Japanese believe in what I say,'' Ishihara said through an interpreter at a news conference after the meeting Sunday. ``Detroit is one of the focuses of the U.S.-Japan friction. I have learned much from this town ... (but) nothing surprised me. ``I don't think I have to change my way of thinking.'' Washington and Tokyo recently negotiated the removal of Japanese import barriers on trade in satellites, supercomputers and wood products. As a result, the Bush administration has decided not to put Japan on this year's ``hit list'' of countries with unfair trading practices under the ``Super 301'' provision of the 1988 Trade Act. Despite the agreement, Ishihara said the trade act is ``a wrong law'' that will only increase trade tensions. U.S. exercise of the Super 301 clause ``is something like a powerful giant wielding a sword _ a crazy giant, hurting themselves,'' he said. Ishihara also was harshly critical of bootleg translations of ``The Japan That Can Say No'' by, among others, the Pentagon and Levin himself _ who published portions of it in the Congressional Record. ``I used to believe that freedom of speech was guaranteed in the United States,'' Ishihara said, ``but what has been done to my book was a lynch.'' In Washington early this month, he said he was working on publishing an English version. Levin said Americans are rightly concerned about what he said were the relatively closed markets that have contributed to this country's $50 billion trade deficit with Japan. But he conceded that some of Ishihara's criticism of U.S. shortcomings in education, management and cooperation between government and the private sector was justified. ``Americans feel it just isn't right that what we produce with the sweat of our hands and the energies of our minds don't have access to Japan,'' Levin said. ``Americans are impatient; we don't like it. ``But you also heard the applause (during the public meeting) when you heard someone say, `We've got to shape up, too,''' he said. ``When there was no $50-billion trade deficit, nobody was talking about racism.'' Levin said he planned to visit Japan later this year to meet with Ishihara and his constituents. More face-to-face meetings could improve U.S.-Japan relations now defined mainly by government negotiators and the media, he said. ``We really don't know each other very well,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains Against Yen For Fourth Day
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen for the fourth consecutive trading day today, and the yen's weakening sharply pushed down prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 153.25 yen, up 0.35 yen from last Friday's close of 152.90 yen. After opening at 153.38 yen, it moved in a range of 153.20 yen to 153.60 yen. The dollar now has gained 1.95 yen in the last four trading days. Currency dealers said the dollar gained from a widespread anticipation that the decline of U.S. interest rates would stop. ``There was no major market-affecting news other than slowdown of the lowering of U.S. interest rates,'' said a dealer with Daiichi Kangyo Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But I don't expect the dollar's upswing to continue much further.'' Another dealer, at the Bank of Tokyo, said the dollar was boosted slightly by speculative trading. ``Traders sought to buy the dollar up to the upper 153 level, but could not break the barrier at 153.60 yen today,'' he said. In the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which fell 47.88 points last Friday, shed another 248.67 points, or 0.78 percent, closing at 31,765.05. Securities dealers attributed the decline to the yen's weakening against the dollar and falling bond prices. ``The market sentiment is bearish because of the declining Japanese yen,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe of Nikko Securities. ``After the Nikkei index reached the 32,000 mark last Thursday, investors began profit-taking, causing lower prices.'' Dealers said construction and food shares were sold while pharmaceutical and electronic shares rose moderately. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was at 87.09 points at 5 p.m. (4 a.m.EDT), down from last Friday's close of 87.58. Their yield rose to 7.155 percent from 7.000 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus and Novell Merger Plans Called Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, Noorda, reached ..., with one graf to UPDATE with today's comments from Novell.
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp. has dropped its planned $1.5 billion merger with Novell Inc., saying a last-minute demand by Novell's chairman for equal board representation nixed the deal. ``We obviously have to question their motives, there's no way we can deal with that,'' said Jim Manzi, president and chief executive officer of Lotus. Cambridge-based Lotus and Novell announced plans to merge in early April in an effort to forge a stronger computer software competitor against rival Microsoft Corp. Under the stock-swap plan, Novell was to become a subsidiary of Lotus. ``We are disappointed that we have had to break off negotiations; however, in the due diligence process we discovered that the implementation issues associated with the merger were too great,'' Manzi said in a statement Saturday. In a telephone interview from Florida later, Manzi said Lotus decided to end negotiations after Provo, Utah-based Novell made its last-minute request. Manzi said he and Lotus board members met with Novell's board and Ray Noorda, the company's chairman, president and chief executive officer, on Tuesday and Wednesday. ``We agreed to change the name of the (subsidiary) to Lotus@Novell Corp. and agreed to make Ray chairman,'' Manzi said. Lotus originally said Noorda would have been vice chairman of Lotus@Novell. ``And we agreed on things that his board wanted. They were offers I made to make sure that we were on good footing when the transaction was completed.'' Manzi said he had expected to finalize the deal on Friday. ``Then I get a call on Friday saying they had put in a demand for an equal board,'' he said. Richard Eckel, a spokesman for Lotus, said Novell wanted an equal number of people on the board. ``Under no circumstances would we set up an equal board, and we said no way because it would deadlock the board,'' he said. In a statement today, Novell said its board felt equal representation was crucial to the combined company's success. Novell said it hoped negotiations would be reopened in the future. Novell produces software to link computers in networks for business-related tasks. It approached Lotus with the idea of a merger in an effort to gain access to Lotus' worldwide market. Under the proposed agreement, Lotus was to swap 1.91931 shares of its common stock for each share of Novell common. Lotus would have issued about 41.6 million new shares, which valued Novell at about $1.5 billion based Lotus' share price of $36.25 when the deal was announced. The company's stock weakened after the announcement, though. It was unchanged Friday at $34.25 in national over-the-counter trading. Novel rose 12{ cents Friday to $40.12{. Its stock stood at $42.87{ before the merger plan was announced last month. The merger, which was due to be completed in July, was subject to approval by the boards of directors and stockholders of both companies. Lotus is a leading producer of business software based primarily on its popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet program. It recently expanded that program, designed for use with International Business Machine Corp.'s personal computers, to work on computers made by other manufacturers. Lotus was ranked No. 3 among software companies last year with $556 million in revenue. It trailed No. 2 Microsoft, regarded as the leader in business software, and Computer Associates International Inc., according to Software Magazine. Novell had $422 million in revenue. ``We're doing just fine in our competition with Microsoft,'' Manzi said. ``We expect our business to be unaffected by this action,'' he said, adding that Lotus had no plans to seek a merger with any other companies. ``Right now we're back to doing our thing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gerber Sells Day-Care Centers
DOC.TEXT: Gerber Products Co. announced Monday it is selling its 115 day-care centers, another divestiture aimed at getting the company back to the basics of baby food. Fred Schomer, Gerber's executive vice president and chief financial officer of Gerber, said an affiliate of KD Equities, a New York-based private investment partnership, would buy Gerber Children's Centers Inc. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The subsidiary provides day care and educational programs for more than 13,000 preschoolers in New York, Illinois, California, Florida, Oklahoma, Ohio, Michigan, Maryland, Virginia, Georgia, Texas and Arizona. Marion H. Antonini, chairman of KD Operating Cos., said the company planned to keep the current staff and continue programs now in place at the centers. In the last two years, Gerber has sold several unprofitable subsidiaries, including a trucking company and companies that made children's furniture, infant car seats, plush toys and sleepwear. Gerber, as it refocuses on baby food, recently announced it will begin testing a new line of foods for children ages 18 months to 36 months. Analysts have applauded Gerber's decisions to divest itself of its fringe businesses. Gerber reported net income of $94.1 million on sales of $1.14 billion for the year ended March 31.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 449.43 up 1.12 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Markets Open Lower On Drier Weather Outlook
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were moderately lower in early trading this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, pressured in part by forecasts for drier weather in the Midwest and Southeast. Heavy rain during the past two weeks has slowed corn planting and lowered yield prospects for winter wheat but the gradual clearing expected this week could allow farmers to get back into their fields, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Further selling stemmed from an Agriculture Department report released late Friday that showed lighter-than-expected participation by farmers in the 1990 acreage set-aside program, which means farmers may plant more corn than the market had anticipated. Analysts linked additional selling to speculation the Soviet Union may reduce its grain imports because the cost of importing grain has become a drain on the Soviet economy, Lespinasse said. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1} cents to 3} cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.82 a bushel; corn futures were 1} cents to 3\ cents lower with May at $2.82 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents lower with May at $1.48 a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 6{ cents lower with May at $6.07 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .55 cent higher with June at 74.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .30 cent higher with May at 85.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent to .37 cent higher with June at 66.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .63 cent to 1.63 cents higher with May at 69.85 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled higher on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Jumps by 31
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and natural gas rigs rose for the third straight week, increasing by 31 to total 972, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. In the past two weeks, the rig count had posted increases of three and then 11. Previously, the count had declined for several weeks. This week's count also is well ahead of the 737 total posted a year ago, Baker Hughes said. The Houston-based company's rig count is the widely watched industry index of drilling activity. It reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, California posted the largest increase with 16, followed by Oklahoma and Louisiana, which each gained nine rigs. Wyoming's count increased by six, Kansas' was up by four and Pennsylvania and Ohio gained one each. Texas lost three rigs, Colorado was down by two and Michigan lost one.

DOC.HEAD: K mart Profits Up
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. said Monday its first-quarter profits rose 6.4 percent as sales increased 16.1 percent. K mart, the nation's second-largest retailer, reported net income of $100.1 million, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter ended April 26, up from $94.1 million, or 47 cents a share, for the first quarter of fiscal 1989. Sales were $7.04 billion, up from $6.07 billion in the year-earlier period. Joseph E. Antonini, chairman and chief executive officer, said increased sales and careful monitoring of expenses boosted profits. K mart has more than 4,000 retail outlets in the United States, Puerto Rico and Canada, including 2,321 K mart discount stores. It also operates PayLess Drug, Builder's Square, Waldenbooks, PACE membership warehouse and The Sports Authority stores.

DOC.TEXT: Prices advanced on London's Stock Exchange Monday, pushed higher by strength in the stock index futures market. Trading was light. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index rose 13 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at its session high of 2,282.1. The day's low was 2,261.3.
