DOC.HEAD: French Food Group To Sell U.S. Biscuit Companies
DOC.TEXT: French food manufacturer BSN SA put its U.S. biscuit subsidiaries on the block Monday as part of its plan to focus on high-growth markets in Eastern Europe and Asia. The company said its Mother's and Salerno subsidiaries, with combined annual revenue of about $200 million, hold only 5.7 percent of the U.S. biscuit market. Further expansion would have been too costly, BSN said. BSN, the second-largest biscuit producer in the world following the acquisition of the European and Asian units of RJR Nabisco Inc. in the past year, said new opportunities are opening in Eastern Europe and Asia. The French food group retains U.S. units in other products, including yogurt-maker Dannon Co. and Lea & Perrins, a producer of condiments. BSN, which posted net profit of 2.698 billion francs, or $458 million, and consolidated revenue of 48.699 billion francs, or $8.28 billion, in 1989, teamed up with an Indian investor earlier this year to purchase Nabisco's operations in New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong for $180 million. It was the French company's first foothold on the East Asian mainland. Last year, BSN purchased Nabisco's five European subsidiaries for $2.5 billion, then sold off two of the units based in Britain to recoup about half of what it had spent on the original purchase.

DOC.HEAD: Ads of Vodka-Touting Gorbachev to Change for Soviet President's Visit
LaserPhoto MP3
DOC.TEXT: Billboards showing Mikhail S. Gorbachev touting a Minnesota-made vodka will be changed during the Soviet president's visit to the Twin Cities next month, a liquor wholesaler said Monday. ``Civically, we feel it's our part to welcome him respectfully,'' said Mitchell Johnson, president of Johnson Brothers Wholesale Liquor Co. of St. Paul. Johnson Brothers earlier had approved the billboard campaign for Minnesota-made Karkov vodka. The billboards show a likeness of Gorbachev holding a bottle of Karkov under the caption ``The Party's Over,'' a reference to the Communist Party's problems. The 38 billboards dot the Minneapolis-St. Paul area and were scheduled to be up until mid-June. Gorbachev is scheduled to visit the Twin Cities for six hours on June 3 after attending summit talks with President Bush in Washington. ``We planned this campaign many, many months ago. We did not know Gorbachev was going to come to the Twin Cities,'' Johnson said. The billboard was created by Schmitt & Sloan, a Minneapolis ad agency. U.S. Distilled Products Co. makes the vodka in Princeton and markets it in several states.
Stock prices rose today, extending the rally that has carried the market to record highs of late. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 21.76 at 2,841.67.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola To Begin Testing All U.S. Employees For Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. said Monday it it will begin universal drug testing of its 60,000 U.S. employees this year, apparently becoming the second major corporation to test all workers for substance abuse. The giant electronics company, based in suburban Schaumburg, has been testing job applicants since 1987, said spokeswoman Margot Brown. Motorola also has had a policy of testing of workers involved in accidents or exhibiting dangerous behavior. Under the expanded policy, all employees will be tested within the next three years, Ms. Brown said. ``Motorola has experienced problems with drug use, as have most other major corporations,'' she said. Texas Instruments Inc., another electronics manufacturer, began universal drug testing in November 1989, said spokeswoman Sandy Christopher. Dallas-based Texas Instruments employs about 52,000 people in the United States. Upper management was tested in the fourth quarter of 1989, and testing of all employees began Jan. 2. ``There's been a very small percentage of employees who've complained about invasion of their privacy. But surprisingly enough, the employees are very supportive of the policy,'' Ms. Christopher said. ``It gets into safety. Who wants to be working next to someone that's on drugs? And to produce quality products, it's very important to have a drug-free workplace,'' she said. After seeking employee opinions, Ms. Brown of Motorola said: ``What we came up with was that a lot of our employees were concerned about a drug problem and felt that if we were going to do testing of our employees, the only fair way to do it was to test all of them. ``We feel our approach is balanced. Motorolans who don't abuse drugs will have a safe workplace, and those who do abuse drugs will be offered help,'' she added. Employees will be tested by urinalysis. If that test is positive, a second, a more complex test will be used to check the results. Employees testing positive once will be offered confidential counseling, and those testing positive twice will be dismissed. Neither company's workers are represented by unions. The Institute for a Drug-Free Workplace in Washington praised Motorola's action. ``I think it's an excellent program, and it's one we have found that employees are increasingly supportive of,'' said Mark A. de Bernardo, the institute's executive director. A Gallup poll in December showed 60 percent of American workers favor drug testing by their employers. The percentage fell to 51 percent when the 1,007 workers were asked whether companies should be able to test any employee randomly. The poll also showed 29 percent of the workers surveyed thought drug testing invaded privacy and should be done only under limited circumstances. The poll, with a 3.1 percent margin of error, was commissioned by the institute, a coalition of 14 large corporations concerned about employer rights in battling drug abuse. Both Motorola and Texas Instruments are institute members. The American Civil Liberties Union opposes such testing. ``Because the test will eventually test all employees makes it no less an invasion of privacy than a totally random system,'' said Harvey Grossman, legal director of the Illinois ACLU chapter. ``And the willingness of a majority of people to abandon their privacy rights doesn't in any way invalidate the feelings and the integrity of those who believe they're entitled to their most basic and fundamental privacy interests despite someone paying them for an honest day's work,'' Grossman said. ``We're not opposed to companies taking proper measures to ensure that employees' performance is not impaired on the job, particularly in safety-related issues,'' said Gene Guerrero, legislative representative for the ACLU's Washington office. ``But if you as an employer are concerned about safety and productivity, use an impairment test. Don't run around telling people what they can do on their time off,'' Guerrero said.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil Names Vice Presidents
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp. on Monday named Jack E. Crawford, a vice president of Mobil Chemical Co. and general manager of the petrochemicals division, as vice president in charge of environmental affairs. The appointment was part of several executive changes announced by the oil giant. Crawford, whose appointment is expected to become effective Sept. 1, succeeds Joseph V. D'Ambrisi, who plans to retire Nov. 1 as vice president of research, engineering and environmental affairs. D'Ambrisi will be on special assignment starting Sept. 1. Jerry G. Griffith, a vice president of engineering for Mobil Research and Development Corp., was named Crawford's replacement. Named to replace Griffith was Edward F. Kondis, vice president of the natural gas, exploration and producing division.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Ends Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained ground Monday in worldwide foreign exchange as traders speculated that U.S. interest rates would be holding steady for the time being. Gold prices fell after rising in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $373.30 a troy ounce, off $1.40 from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $372.35 an ounce, down 90 cents. Currency dealers said the market believes the Federal Reserve won't ease its credit policies anytime soon, and that should keep interest rates at their current levels. Higher rates tend to support a currency. Also boosting the dollar, particularly against the West German mark, were reports of political discord in West Germany over reunificaiton plans with East Germany, dealers said. But Gabriele Schmitt, a corporate dealer for the Bank of New York, downplayed Monday's dollar advance, saying trading was so light prior to the Memorial Day holiday that any movement in the dollar might have been exaggerated. ``There really is not any liquidity in the market to have a reasonable trading pattern,'' she said. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar gained 0.35 yen to 153.25 yen, extending its gain to 1.95 yen in four days. The dollar traded at 153.45 yen in London, and at 153.73 yen in New York, up from 153.00 Friday. The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling rose in London to $1.6917 from $1.6910, and fell in New York to $1.6875 from $1.6900. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.66245 West German marks, up from 1.6483; 1.4217 Swiss francs, up from 1.4050; 5.6020 French francs, up from 5.5595; 1,222.50 Italian lire, up from 1,212.75; and 1.17715 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17975. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday, included: 1.6630 West German marks, up from 1.6478; 1.4225 Swiss francs, up from 1.4045; 5.6060 French francs, up from 5.5555; 1.8692 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8550; 1222.75 Italian lire, up from 1212.00; and 1.1793 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1782. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $373.25 an ounce from $369.75 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $373.50 an ounce from $370.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 22 cents to close at $374.08 an ounce. Silver prices firmed. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.131 a troy ounce, up from $5.122 late Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.14 an ounce from $5.06.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspapers Find Tough Going in Effort to Attract U.S. Advertisers
DOC.TEXT: Soviet newspapers Izvestia and Pravda are chasing American advertising pegged to the the upcoming summit between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. But their ad salesmen are finding it's a tough sell. U.S. companies, even those already doing business in the Soviet Union, are taking a go-slow approach to print advertising for a Russian audience. The government-run newspaper Izvestia disclosed plans in April to publish a pair of special supplements on the United States during the summit, which starts next week. The Russian-language supplements would be tucked inside about 2 million copies of the newspaper, which has a total circulation of 11 million. While several U.S. companies and ad agencies have expressed interest, none has bought space yet, an official said Monday. ``American businessmen are perhaps not as aggressive in terms of looking at the market possibilities in Russia in this way,'' said Anthony R. Wight, head of Publicitas Inc., in charge of ad sales for Izvestia. Wight said Izvestia has been peddling space to Western advertisers since January. Nearly all of the buyers so far have been European. Pravda, the official newspaper of the Soviet Communist Party, sent out notices to dozens of American companies last week encouraging them to buy full-page ads during the summit. It claims circulation of more than 8 million. ``Only a couple of years ago the very notion of rebirth of the stock exchange in Russia or direct participation in the Soviet enterprise amounted to heresy, but that is not the case anymore,'' Pravda's I.N. Filipov wrote to American business leaders in asking for their advertising support. The message arrived via facsimile machine at some companies, and some companies said there were skeptical about the authenticity of the offer. Victor Linnik, a Pravda correspondent in New York who is overseeing the newspaper's ad sales here, said the offer was genuine and that the first Western advertiser in Pravda was the German airline Lufthansa in early May. ``The country is moving to a new stage in its economic development. The world has changed, and Pravda simply cannot remain indifferent to the commercial side of its own business,'' he said. But Linnik said late last week no American companies had signed up although there had been ``some interest expressed.'' Izvestia is selling a full-page ad in the supplements for $42,500 for a black-and-white ad; Pravda quoted a price of $50,000 for a full-page ad. For comparison, The Wall Street Journal charges $99,385 for a full-page ad in its national edition; USA Today charges $57,232 during the week for a similar full-page ad in its paper. Ad agency executives said the lack of an independent auditing system for Soviet circulation claims makes some companies wary of the newspapers. They add that Western companies have only limited access to Soviet markets, many have no presence there at all and some feel they can spend their money better on other trade-related activities. ``It only makes sense for two reasons _ you either anticipate going into the market or you are already there,'' said Allen Banks, media director for Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Inc. in New York. Pepsi-Cola International has bought time on Soviet television and advertises on Soviet billboards and at its soft drink kiosks in Russia, but has made no decision on newspaper advertising. ``We are certainly looking at it at this point, but we really haven't come to a decision,'' said Anna Nerbovig, a spokeswoman for Pepsi-Cola International. Philip Morris Cos. Inc. sells Marlboro cigarettes in Russia. ``It's something we would consider, but we don't know yet,'' said company spokeswoman Posie DiSesa. William E. Cornelius, director of trade policy for Dow Chemical Co. in Midland, Mich., said Dow has been in business in the Soviet Union for 20 years, has a sales office in Moscow and recently completed a study of the feasibility of setting up a chemical manufacturing complex in Russia. But he said his company is ``basically a supplier of industrial products, not consumer products, and therefore advertising in those consumer newspapers would serve no practical purpose for us.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Slide Further As Supply Outlook Grows
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, continuing a recent trend linked to weather conditions and greater availability of South American supplies. Grain futures also retreated in Chicago. On other commodity markets, energy futures tumbled; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 10 cents 11} cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $6.10{ a bushel. Wheat futures ended 2{ cents to 3 cents lower with July at $3.37 a bushel; May corn was 4{ cents to 5\ cents lower with July at $2.77 a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 3\ cents lower with July at $1.51\ a bushel. All contracts for May deliveries of grains and soybeans expired at noon Monday. The May soybean contract went off the board at $6.04{ a bushel, May wheat expired at $3.83{, May corn at $2.80 and May oats at $1.44{. July soybeans have dropped by 50 cents a bushel since May 10, when the Agriculture Department issued a report projecting a bountiful 1990 harvest of 1.9 billion bushels and an increase in the U.S. soybean stockpile. Analysts said rising South American soybean exports have bolstered perceptions that Brazil and Argentina can handle current global demand and at prices that are generally lower than in the U.S. Weather conditions also have undermined soybean prices. The same rainy weather that has hampered corn planting in the Midwest has driven speculation that farmers will switch some of their planned corn acres to soybeans, since soybeans can be planted later with no loss of yield. Monday's forecasts called for relatively little rain this week in the Midwest. ``We should see some acceleration of planting of corn and soybeans both,'' said Walter Spilka, a grain-market analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. In a weekly report issued after markets closed, the USDA said corn planting was 76 percent finished as of Sunday compared with the norm of 88 percent for that date; soybean planting was 17 percent done compared with the norm of 43 percent. Analysts linked additional selling across the board to speculation the Soviet Union may reduce its grain imports because the cost of importing grain has become a drain on the Soviet economy. Selling pressure in the wheat market was offset by news that China was seeking to buy 400,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. After the close, the USDA announced it had targeted Algeria for sales of 2 million metric tons of wheat and Zaire for 100,000 metric tons. Energy futures tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid perceptions of rising U.S. gasoline supplies, said Tom Bentz, director of trading for United Energy Inc. He said traders will be watching Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute report for an expected increase of about 2 percent in refinery runs, which would verify the market's view that gasoline supplies are increasing. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 21 cents to 47 cents lower with June at $18.26 a barrel; heating oil was .04 cent to .58 cent lower with June at 51.44 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .60 cent to 1.08 cents lower with June at 63.35 cents a gallon. Gold futures fell modestly while silver futures advanced on New York's Commodity Exchange. Platinum futures fell sharply on the New York Merc amid profit-taking after two days of strong gains. Gold finished $1.50 lower across the board with June at $374.10 a troy ounce; silver was 0.9 cent to 1.4 cents higher with May at $5.131 a troy ounce; platinum was $5.90 to $7.30 lower with July at $501.10 a troy ounce. Cattle futures settled mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash markets; pork futures finished mostly lower on profit-taking after a three-day rally. Live cattle futures finished .15 cent lower to .50 cent higher with June at 74.82 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .25 cent higher with May at 85.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent lower to .18 cent higher with June at 67 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .95 cent lower to .03 cent higher with May at 68.25 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Fall on Profit-Taking
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices declined Monday as traders took profits in the absence of any news developments. Gasoline futures, which have led the market in recent sessions, continued that trend. The June contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline fell sharply, dropping 1.08 cents to 63.35 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The July contract and August contracts also posted big declines. Richard Redoglia, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said traders holding near-term contracts decided to liquidate them and take their profits. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, fell 47 cents to settle at $18.26 a 42-gallon barrel, and subsequent months also declined. Meanwhile, the June contract for delivery of home heating oil slipped 0.48 cent to 51.44 cents a gallon, with subsequent months also dropping. Traders said there were no developments to affect the market Monday, but concerns about oversupply of gasoline and oil persisted. In natural gas trading, the June contract rose to $1.557 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.554 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Lone Wolf Defense Lawyer Joins a Pack
DOC.TEXT: Stanley S. Arkin, one of the nation's best-known trial attorneys and a leading defense lawyer in Wall Street fraud cases, has decided to hang his shingle on someone else's door. The 52-year-old courtroom veteran, who began his career defending accused murderers and drug dealers and later expanded to more complex cases ranging from celebrity divorces to stock manipulation, said Monday he's joining Chadbourne & Park, a 250-lawyer firm based in New York, on July 1. Arkin's decision to vacate his lone-wolf practice after 20 years surprised some colleagues in Manhattan's elite fraternity of high-paid lawyers. But others called it a reflection of the growing power of big multi-service firms that make it increasingly difficult for smaller practices to compete. ``Going back a number of years ago, none of the large firms had that capability. Most of that work was referred out,'' said Andrew Lawler, a fellow defense attorney who has maintained his own practice. ``As more have taken on these matters themselves, there's fewer referrals.'' Arkin said the increasingly complicated nature of his work required expertise in many fields from tax law to bankruptcy, and his association with Chadbourne ``will enable me to expand the scope of my practice by offering clients the varied legal resources of a major law firm.'' Asked in a telephone interview whether he feared dulling the allure of his rogue identity by joining a larger practice, he said: ``I'll be Stanley Arkin at Chadbourne Park and be even more sellable.'' Arkin is one of the country's leading securities fraud and trial attorneys, whose client list reads like a who's who of celebrities both on and off Wall Street. He's also is an aggressive businessman who reportedly earns more than $1 million in fees a year and has been known to accept non-cash compensation ranging from African dolls to Georgia O'Keeffe paintings. ``Stanley is undoubtedly one of the top _ if not the top _ business getter in the private practice defense bar. More than that, he's a remarkable lawyer,'' said attorney John Siffert, an Arkin friend. Asked why Arkin would abandon his lone-wolf image, Siffert said, ``a lone wolf sometimes wants to be part of the pack.'' Arkin's best-known claim to fame in recent years has been representing Wall Street professionals implicated in fraud. He is outspoken in his criticism of what he calls the overzealous prosecution of insider trading cases, once likening it to ``shooting a black-marketeer in Russia.'' His clients have included Richard B. Wigton, a Kidder Peabody & Co. trader who faced insider trading charges later dropped by federal prosecutors; Salim B. Lewis, a well-known stock speculator convicted on charges of stock manipulation; and Ronald Yagoda, head trader at Marcus Schloss & Co., acquitted of insider trading in what became known as the ``Yuppie Five'' fraud ring. One of Arkin's most important clients was a comparative nobody: Vincent Chiarella, a printer accused of illegally trading stocks based on secret information he obtained by reading tender-offer documents he printed. Arkin successfully argued an appeal before the Supreme Court in 1980 and the conviction was overturned in what became a landmark decision about what defined an inside trader. He also represents Father Bruce Ritter, former head of Covenant House, a well-known charitable organization based in New York tainted by allegations of financial irregularities and sexual misconduct. His matrimonial clients include Richard Snyder, chief executive officer of Simon & Schuster, and ``Tonight Show'' host Johnny Carson. Chadbourne & Parke is a wide ranging law firm with offices in New York, Washington, Los Angeles, the United Arab Emirates and beginning this summer, Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Newman's Dressing Goes To Burger Chain
DOC.TEXT: Actor Paul Newman will play a starring role in Burger King's salad line, the fast-food chain announced Monday. Newman, who sells his own all-natural salad dressing nationally, has developed five new varieties for Burger King, which will offer them along with his original ``Newman's Own Oil & Vinegar'' for salads at its 6,000 restaurants. ``This all-natural product will help `shake up' awareness of our salad line,'' said Gary Langstaff, executive vice president of marketing for Burger King. ``We were looking for a way to distinguish our salad offerings to customers.'' The salad dressings are Light Italian, Bleu Cheese, French, Thousand Island and Ranch and can be used with Burger King's prepackaged salads: chunky chicken, chef, garden and side salads. Burger King will promote the new salad dressings with a ``shake it up'' pogo stick competition in Huntington, Calif., May 25-26 and a national television campaign beginning Tuesday. The TV ads feature vignettes of Newman undressing in films including ``The Sting,'' ``The Prize'' and ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' The TV ads advise viewers: ``For years, you've seen Paul Newman undressing. Now you can see Paul Newman dressing.'' Newman says he donates profits from his food company to charity.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Credit Program for Iraq to Get More Review
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Monday it would undertake a more searching look at Iraqi credit purchases of U.S. farm products, including payments above the market price that may have provided cash rebates. Officials said an administrative review so far ``uncovered no evidence to suggest that there has been diversion of commodities sold to Iraq'' for illegal purposes. Undersecretary Richard Crowder, in releasing a report of the review, said the U.S. government ``has not incurred any losses'' as a result of Iraq's use of the program. The department's review involved credit guarantees for up to three years. The department, through its Commodity Credit Corp., does not lend the money but stands behind commercial banks who do. Iraq has used the guarantees to buy more than $4.5 billion worth of U.S. commodities since 1983. Kelly Shipp, spokeswoman for Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, said about $30 million is left in the first $500 million worth of guarantees for Iraq this fiscal year. A decision on the second $500 million will be held up while the additional review is made. Among the potential irregularities checked by the department was a ``stamp tax'' of an unspecified amount that Iraq had requested of some exporters. Iraq has agreed to exempt the credit shipments in the future, officials. The report said the administrative review, which included a visit to Baghdad last month, suggested additional inquiry into two key areas. One question involves the extent and reasons for high prices in certain transactions, including corn, rice and sugar, during 1985 to 1987. Prices paid by Iraq appeared to be at least $10 per metric ton higher than typical world prices for rice and corn, and $15 to $40 higher for sugar. ``It appears that these price levels may have resulted in part from supplier perceptions that Iraq was a very high-risk market due to wartime conditions (with Iran),'' the report said. Other possible reasons may have been ``the limited number of U.S. suppliers'' who were willing to deal in this high-risk market, when Iraq was at war with Iran, and Iraq's policy of seeking freight financing, which only a few suppliers were able or willing to provide. Another uncertainty was the extent of services that may have been provided in connection with the credit sales and whether the values of those sales were properly reported. The report said these services requested of exporters by Iraq appear to have been in the form of either additional agricultural products, non-agricultural products such as truck parts or tires, cash rebates or discounts or use of designated Iraqi shipping companies. Officials said the review began last fall after the department learned of allegations that approximately $720 million of guaranteed loans were part of a loan portfolio under federal investigation in Atlanta. ``Allegedly, the CCC-guaranteed loans were part of a clandestine loan operation in which officials of the Atlanta branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro had booked more than $2 billion in unauthorized and unreported loans to Iraq,'' the report said. Federal grand jury proceedings in the Atlanta case have yet to produce indictments and no details are available, the report said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Another positive ...' to CORRECT latest surplus figure to billion sted million.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market reached a new high for the fourth time in the past six sessions Monday, getting still more mileage out of its spring rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 24.77 points to 2,844.68, surpassing the previous closing peak of 2,831.71 it established last Thursday. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 997 up, 538 down and 486 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 166.28 million shares, against 162.52 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 201.14 million shares. Interest rates were mixed to slightly lower in the credit markets Monday. Yields on long-term government bonds hovered in the 8.68 percent-8.72 percent range. But analysts said hopes persisted that rates could soon resume a more emphatic decline. The upsurge in stock prices since the end of April has been attributed largely to falling interest rates, and accompanying assurances that the Federal Reserve seems less and less likely to tighten credit. Fresh support for that view is expected on Thursday, when the Commerce Department reports on the gross national product for the first quarter of the year. Analysts project that the data will show growth at an annual rate of 1.5 percent to 1.7 percent, down from an earlier estimate of 2.1 percent. Another positive influence was Monday's word that the government had a larger-than-expected budget surplus of $42.52 billion in April, against $40.57 billion in April 1989. The widened surplus, in a month when Treasury accounts are typically swollen by peak tax receipts, was seen as a hopeful development in efforts to narrow the annual government deficit. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines rose 1| to 117; Coca-Cola 1 to 43{; Philip Morris } to 44{; General Electric \ to 68], and Merck 2\ to 81{. Louisiana General Services jumped 3[ to 20\. The company agreed to be acquired by Citizens Utilities Co. through an exchange of each Louisiana General share for about 0.67 of a Citizens class B share. Harnischfeger fell 1} to 19~. The company reported earnings for the fiscal quarter ended April 30 of 55 cents a share, against 53 cents in the comparable period last year. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $31.57 billion, or 0.93 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added 1.73 to 195.28. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 4.48 to 417.23, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 3.36 at 358.00. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 4.58 to 452.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.36, up 3.04.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Firm Sells Rubber Business To Bayer
DOC.TEXT: Nova Corp., a Canadian energy and chemical firm, said Monday it was selling its Polysar rubber division to the West German firm Bayer AG for $1.06 billion. Nova will use the proceeds from the sale to reduce its debt, the company said in a statement from its Calgary, Alberta, headquarters. The rubber business is part of Polysar Ltd., a firm acquired by Nova in 1988. Bayer said the acquisition would supplement its rubber business, giving it plants that produce synthetic rubber primarily for tire and industrial uses. The transaction, which must be approved by government officials in the United States, Canada and Europe, also provides for Bayer to assume Polysar's outstanding debt. Polysar has plants in Texas, Ontario, Belgium and France, and employes 3,500 people. Bayer's interests include chemicals and health care.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Gives Fenton Plant an Extra Seven Weeks
With AM-UAW Convention, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has decided to postpone for seven weeks the planned September shutdown of one of its two plants in the St. Louis suburb of Fenton, officials said Monday. The company said that higher-than-expected fleet orders for convertibles from the Sun Belt will keep Plant No. 1 running the extra time. The plant, which makes the Dodge Daytona and the Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible, had been scheduled to close permanently Sept. 21, but will now remain in operation until Nov. 9. The decision to move its production to plants in Michigan and Delaware will put about 2,300 hourly and salaried employees out of work. Chrysler announced plans to close the plant in February, blaming falling sales for the models made there. But on Monday, Chrysler spokesman Doug Nicoll said orders for 1991 models from fleets, such as rental companies, particularly in the Sun Belt, forced the automaker to change plans. Chrysler also plans to temporarily close the Newark, Del., plant, which will take over production of the LeBaron models, and the Sterling Heights, Mich., plant, which will build the Daytona, to set up assembly lines. Monday's decision will delay that retooling until Dec. 21, Nicoll said.

Eds: Coming within 15 minutes:
DALLAS _ Greyhound Lines Inc., strapped for cash because of a bus drivers' strike and seeking to avert bankruptcy, offered Monday to buy back $225 million of its junk bond debt at deep discounts.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Expecting Second Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines expects to make a small profit in the second quarter after posting a first-quarter operating loss of almost $90 million, a spokesman for the carrier said. ``We are projecting a modest profit for the second quarter,'' Bob Gibbons said Monday. The three-month period ends June 30 and results will be available Aug. 10. In the first quarter, Northwest booked its first operating loss since the airline was taken over last August by former Marriott Corp. executive Alfred Checchi and other investors. John Dasburg, the airline's finance and administration executive vice president, attributed the loss to rising fuel costs and unfavorable currency exchange rates. Gibbons said Northwest continues to make progress in reducing the $3.1 billion debt incurred in the buyout. The debt now stands at about $2.1 billion and Dasburg has said it will shrink to $1.75 billion by the end of the year, Gibbons said. Meanwhile, Gibbons said the airline still is searching for funds to replace part of an equity investment by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines that was part of the buyout. KLM was forced by the U.S. Transportation Department to shave its $400 million equity stake to $175 million.

DOC.HEAD: Cable Industry Show: Something for Everyone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to UPDATE with content of Cowboy Channel. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Cable TV seemed to have something for everyone at an industry convention: a Cowboy Channel, In Court Television for law junkies, even a senior citizen network ``for viewers who weren't born yesterday.'' The big question at the National Cable Television Association convention Monday seemed to be how to sell so many choices to viewers. Dozens of displays by huge variety of cable outlets greeted visitors. Alongside the established networks _ such as Turner Broadcasting System Inc.'s family of channels and familiar faces HBO, MTV and ESPN _ were a host of new choices. Among the many starting or planning to broadcast were the law channel, Country star Willie Nelson's Cowboy Channel, to carry Western movies and country music videos, and Golden American Network for senior citizens. The narrow focus of many of these new channels reflects the industry's growing strategy of targeting ``niche'' channels, cable officials said. Cable executives participating in a panel discussion Monday said that technology expected to arrive in this decade will greatly expand the capacity of local cable systems to carry more channels. That means programming may be sold the way magazines are, targeted at specific-interest audiences. The key will be whether the special interest channels can succeed with an audience of less than 1 million subscribers, said Charles Dolan, chairman of Cablevision Systems Corp. of Woodbury, N.Y. By contrast, the seven largest cable channels all currently are available to more than 50 million subscribers. ``The challenge is to find large enough niches,'' said John Malone, president of Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver. Some executives suggested a package of special-interest stations could be sold to the viewer. That would be in contrast to today's broad basic service, which might include programming without interest for any particular customer. Such a limited service might be viable with ``niche sponsorship,'' if advertisers were willing to pay a higher rate for commercial time knowing that the audience was a prime target for their product, Malone said. But Robert Miron, president of Newhouse Broadcasting of North Syracuse, N.Y., cautioned that ``it would be dangerous to destroy'' broad-based basic cable service. Such concerns are being debated in the conference rooms during the three-day meeting, but on the exhibit floor it's all showbiz. Nelson, who is the chairman of the board of the Cowboy Channel, drew a long line of conventioneers seeking his autograph. The only longer line was the one to meet Renee Tenison, Playboy magazine's 1990 Playmate of the Year, who was signing autographs at the Playboy at Night network's booth. The big shots of the industry appeared to be in a contest for who could construct the most impressive promotional booth. The Disney Channel's, for example, was a sprawling white and silver castle, each side equipped with a trio of TV screens showing Disney programs. Not surprisingly, one of the largest exhibits belonged to Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting. The gleaming display included lounge areas and private meeting rooms.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Higher, Share Prices Edge Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened higher against the yen Tuesday morning, helping trigger an early decline in share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar started trading at 153.36 yen, up 0.11 yen from Monday's 153.25-yen close. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 134.65 points, or 0.42 percent, to hit 31,630.40 within the first 25 minutes of trading. The index lost 248.67 points on Monday. The dollar was moving narrowly in early trading after its higher opening, which followed overnight gains in New York, said Kimio Kobori, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. The dollar closed Monday at 153.73 yen in New York, up from 153.00 yen last Friday. The dollar's gain in New York resulted from a market belief that the Federal Reserve won't ease its credit policies anytime soon, keeping interest rates at current levels. Higher rates tend to support a currency. Kobori said, ``Trading in Tokyo is hardly moving mainly because there is no major market-affecting news here now.'' Traders attributed the Nikkei's early fell to the yen's continuing weakness agaisnt the dollar, which discouraged stock investors and sent them to the sidelines. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond inched up to 87.18 from Monday's close of 87.09. That lowered the yield to 7.13 percent from 7.15 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ag Official: `Support Us. Help Us Out'
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet policymaker said his country's economic restructuring will be jeopardized without the help of U.S. farm technology to improve agricultural production. ``Support us. Help us out. Share your know-how,'' Ivan Skiba, chief of the agrarian department of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, told an audience of academics, businessmen and farm leaders Monday. A Harvard economist, however, was pessimistic about the prospects for success in the reforms being pushed by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. ``Gorbachev has inherited a very sick society. Unfortunately, he's made it worse,'' said Marshall Goldman, associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard. The exchange came at Iowa State University at a symposium on economic and political reforms in the USSR. Skiba said agriculture is a top Soviet priority. ``Without it, further movement in perestroika would be vexed,'' he said. Skiba said the problem of Soviet food supplies is becoming more acute despite increased production. He said major investments and joint ventures are needed. Major priorities are improving food storage and processing and developing an open-market economy, said Alexander Nikonov, president of the Lenin All-Union Academy of Agricultural Sciences and a top advisor to Gorbachev. Nikonov said losses from grain and commodity spoilage are valued at five times Soviet farm imports. Skiba predicted radical changes in Soviet grain purchases, expanding on a shift that began in recent years toward increased interest in soybeans and soybean products to enhance the protein content of livestock feed. Skiba said Soviet inflation is running at 7.5 percent, peasants are not accepting programs aimed at moving to private ownership of land and continued subsidizes to ensure low food prices are no longer defensible economically. In Moscow, a document obtained Monday by The Associated Press showed that the Kremlin plans to double food prices as part of desperately needed economic reforms to gradually introduce a market economy. Goldman said the Soviet economy is in more serious trouble, with inflation running as high as 20 percent and the economy actually contracting at a real rate of at least 5 percent. Food products are rationed in almost every large city, he said. The Soviet budget deficit has ballooned to 10 percent to 12 percent of gross national product, compared with a U.S. deficit equivalent to 3 percent to 4 percent of GNP, he said. ``I think prospects for reform are dim,'' Goldman said.

DOC.HEAD: American General Wins Proxy Fight in Preliminary Results
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp., which surprised shareholders recently by announcing the company was for sale, said preliminary results showed it prevailed in a proxy fight with a suitor, Torchmark Corp. American General, the nation's fourth-largest insurance company, said Monday that results from independent inspectors of the shareholder vote at the May 2 annual meeting indicated that the company's slate of six board candidates defeated Torchmark's slate by a margin of 2-to-1. Shareholders also rejected resolutions proposed by Birmingham, Ala.-based Torchmark calling for American General to hire an investment bank and appoint a committee of independent directors to evaluate acquisition proposals, American General said. American General said it does not expect a change in the results but said they remain subject to review and challenge. American General announced at the annual meeting that the company was vulnerable to possible acquisitions and therefore decided to offer itself for sale to realize the maximum value for stockholders. Torchmark made an unsolicited $6.34 billion cash and stock offer in March but withdrew the offer when American General turned it down, opting instead to wage a proxy fight to elect its own nominees to the 15-member board. Houston-based American General, with subsidiaries operating in 50 states and Canada, had been battling with the much smaller Torchmark, which is best known for its Liberty National Mutual Insurance subsidiary.

DOC.HEAD: Top Bank Regulator To Visit New England Amid `Credit Crunch'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top bank regulator told New England governors Monday he will tour the region to help spread the message that banks should continue making good loans. The promised visits by Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke come in response to continued complaints that tough federal regulations are discouraging loans to small businesses throughout the Northeast. Regulators under Clarke's control are winding up several months of extensive examinations into real estate lending at major New England banks. But, according to the governors, the repercussions of their work are still being felt by small and medium-sized businesses that have been unable to continue lines of credit due to the tightened lending climate. ``The bottom-line conclusion that I want to get across as a result of this meeting is that we are not telling banks not to lend money,'' Clarke said at a news conference in his office. ``We're telling banks to be careful in the way they lend money,'' Clarke said. ``But there are still plenty of good loans to be made.'' Clarke met with governors Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, Judd Gregg of New Hampshire and John McKernan of Maine. Howard Brown, Connecticut's banking commissioner, also attended. The governors met earlier in the day with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Clarke said the so-called credit crunch in New England may stem from an overreaction by banks to the heightened scrutiny by federal regulators. Allaying the concerns of bankers, he said, would be a major purpose of his visits. ``I have agreed to make several appearances in the Northeast over the next month and I will be getting that message out,'' said Clarke, whose office is responsible for examing national banks. ``It's almost inevitable that if you have a slowdown in certain economic sectors that you're going to have a tightening of credit standards... I don't think that's inappropriate,'' Clarke said. ``What would be inappropriate would be to just have a blanket shutting off of the faucet.'' The governors did not blame New England's slumping economy on the tight credit climate created by banking regulators. But Dukakis said innocent bystanders are being hurt. ``We're concerned about what has happened to the small and medium-sized companies in New England who are good risks (and) are the heart and soul of the New England Economy because they create most of our new jobs and whose credit is being affected because of what has happened on the real estate side,'' Dukakis said. A hotline set up in Massachusetts has heard complaints from some 250 companies haveing difficulty obtaining or continuing credit and the state is working directly with about 50 of them, Dukakis said. Brown, who represented Connecticut Gov. William O'Neill at the meeting, said federal regulators who look at loans to small businesses ``may not have a good feel for the asset quality and the persons behind those loans.'' Federal examiners have, among other things, ordered banks to reclassify as ``non-performing'' loans that have been kept current, Brown said. They have also told banks to increase their reserves for bad loans, taking out of circulation money that might go out as loans to creditworthy customers, he said. Gregg said the response by Clarke and Greenspan Monday indicated that the complaints from New England are being heard. ``We got out point across,'' Gregg said.

DOC.HEAD: International Growth P&G Goal, Chairman Tells Analysts
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co.'s new chairman told stock analysts the company plans to emphasize international sales during the next year. ``If we do it right, it will be our principal engine of growth,'' Edwin L. Artzt said to about 100 analysts, referring to overseas sales. He also said the company will attempt to cut production and distribution costs by $1 billion during the next two years. Artzt, who became the company's chairman and chief executive officer in January, was head of P&G's European division from 1975 to 1980. The two-hour meeting was his first with analysts. The company's new fiscal year begins July 31. P&G plans to expand development of such products as Tide laundry detergent and Pampers diapers, which sell worldwide but are tailored to meet local market requirements, Artzt said. Artzt showed nearly identical television commercials for P&G shampoo from the United States, Japan and Britain to illustrate the company's ability to introduce the same product in different markets. ``Our concept of globalization does not mean we plan to run our business globally. My long experience on the international business has convinced me that that would not work,'' he said. Emphasizing international sales is P&G's most realistic way to maintain earnings growth in its core businesses of soap and personal care products, said Hugh Zurkuhlen, an analyst for Salomon Brothers. ``The (domestic) markets for soap and toothpaste don't grow. ... But discretionary spending is still growing in southeast Asia and Latin America,'' he said. ``As long as there's world peace, there is good potential for growth overseas.'' Artzt said the company expects to maintain sales growth in the United States through innovations such as diapers designed especially for boys or girls. ``In 23 of our 41 U.S. categories, our company (market) share is less than 25 percent,'' he said. ``Just getting to a 25 percent share would add about $300 million after tax to our bottom line ... in those categories.'' P&G has reduced proposed uses for its experimental fat substitute Olestra so it can win faster U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval for the product, Artzt said. He said the company would propose broader uses later.

DOC.HEAD: Smith Corona Appoints President
DOC.TEXT: Smith Corona Corp. has announced the appointment of William D. Henderson as president and chief operating officer to oversee the company's worldwide marketing, sales, manufacturing and engineering divisions. Henderson will take over the position on July 1, said G. Lee Thompson, Smith Corona's chairman and chief executive officer. Thompson currently serves as president. Chief operating officer is a new position, the company said Monday. Henderson, 43, has served for the past nine years as executive officer and group vice president at Hanson Industries, the U.S. arm of Hanson PLC which controls Smith Corona. He has also been president and chief executive officer of Durkee Famous Foods and an executive at FMC Corp. Based in New Canaan, Smith Corona is the world's largest manufacturer of portable electronic typewriters and personal word processors. The company also manufactures and sells office supplies, forms and customized printed products.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Production Drops
DOC.TEXT: U.S. steel production dropped 0.3 percent in the week ending May 19, a trade group said. American steel mills produced 1.96 million tons of raw steel last week, representing 87 percent of their capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. So far this year, steel production has totaled 38 million net tons, down 4.2 percent from 1989's year-to-date total of 39.7 million net tons, the institute said Monday. By region, steel production last week was: Indiana@Chicago 511,000 net tons (501,000 the previous week); Pittsburgh@Youngstown 335,000 (332,000); Southern 282,000 (285,000); North East Coast 219,000 (234,000). Also, Midwest 206,000 net tons (195,000); Lake Erie 151,000 (155,000); Detroit 145,000 (152,000); and Western 106,000 (106,000).

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Agrees to Abide by the Law
DOC.TEXT: Sundstrand Corp. has agreed to abide by federal securities laws that regulators said it ignored while overbilling the government on defense contracts. The aerospace contractor, although neither admitting nor denying charges it violated securities laws, agreed to a permanent injunction in U.S. District Court Monday barring it from disregarding accounting and financial reporting rules in the future. Sundstrand also agreed to set up a committee of independent directors to review whether the company's fraud case led to violations not addressed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its complaint. The settlement, subject to approval by a judge, would end the SEC's investigation. Sundstrand pleaded guilty in 1988 to overbilling the government on defense contracts for airplane parts and paid nearly $200 million to settle the case, the biggest penalty ever assessed for defense fraud. The commission charged that by concealing millions of dollars in cost overruns between 1980 and 1986, Sundstrand misled investors by underestimating its debts and overstating its profits. SEC lawyer Wendy D. Fox said the injunction was necessary to ensure Sundstrand will comply with security laws in the future. ``Sundstrand has settled this matter in order to avoid protracted and costly litigation over practices long since discontinued by this company,'' said Harry C. Stonecipher, president and chief executive officer. ``Sundstrand has moved on and the injunction will have no financial impact on the company. It obliges us to do what we would do in any event, that is, to comply with the law.''
